Six ladies and a small boy started to the mountain near Juniata Gap three days ago to pick huckleberries. While thus absorbed a heavy rain and fog set in and they lost their way. Drenched to the skin and in terror of wild beasts, they huddled together all night beneath an oak tree, and when morning dawned they found they were only two minutes' walk from a hotel.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 10.--The Pennsylvania Railroad began work in earnest to-day on its fourth track from this city. All the sheds and outhouses adjoining were also demolished, and the railroad gates were taken down at West Grand-street.

A remarkable instance of telephonic communication occurred in Charleston last Sunday. A young man employed in the Western Union Telegraph office in that city conversed without any difficulty with his brother, who was in Omaha, 1,500 miles away. ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 13.--Edward Sheridan, a mason, lost a child by death on Sunday. PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 14.--Antonio Breen, an Italian, was found dead in an outhouse at his dwelling this evening. SAN DIEGO, Cal., Aug. 14.--Yesterday afternoon Superior Judge W.L. Pierce of this city was shot and seriously wounded by W.S. Clendennin. The Judge was talking with ex-Gov. Murray of Utah, when Clendennin passed down the street, stopped suddenly, and, drawing a revolver, shot Judge Pierce in the back. A judicial opinion by Pierce unfavorable to Clendennin is understood to be the cause of the shooting.

LONDON, Aug. 16.--Home Secretary Matthews, Justice Stephen, the Lord Chancellor, and medical experts to-day held a conference at the Homo Office, with a view to arriving at a decision in the Maybrick case. It lasted four hours. It is regarded as a certainty that the Home Office is in doubt, and it is believed that the result of the deliberations must necessarily be a pardon or a commutation of sentence.

OWEN SOUND, Ontario, Aug. 16.--The gale yesterday was the worst of the season. The wind averaged forty-five miles an hour from the northwest. On Thursday morning the steam barge Chamberlain and tug Sauey Pin lost a raft of 10,000 logs off Cape Rich. They had to run here for shelter.

PAUL, Minn., Aug. 17.--A decision was handed down in St. Paul yesterday, signed jointly by Judges Brill and Wilkin, in the case of the City of St. Paul against the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company. The suit was brought to recover land now used by the railroad and valued at $250,000. The decision was in favor of the railroad.

Beach, Stanley Mortimer, W.K. Thorn, Jr., Winthrop Rutherford, and S.C. Baldwin, Jr. Beach and Baldwin alternated. The final score was: Yellows. 8; Blues. 4.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18.--Everything in the yachting way has been very quiet here to-day, there being only a few yachts in the harbor and nothing of interest having happened aboard them.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18.--A Musser, at one time a well-known and respected citizen of Brunswick, Mo., to-day made a novel attempt of suicide that will doubtless prove successful. Mr. Musser was arrested yesterday afternoon at the Union Station charged with the theft of numerous sachels.

The body of the man found on Fire Island beach July 28, and which was at first thought to be that of aeronaut Hogan, has been fully identified as that of F.S. Worden of Chicago. Worden came to New-York a few months ago for the purpose of having his voice cultivated.

Mrs. Carrie Haynes, the janitress of 140 West Thirty-sixth-street, died suddenly yesterday under peculiar circumstances. About 3:30 A.M. she was awakened by cries of "Police!" and "Murder!" From the window of her front room in the basement she saw two men fighting on the sidewalk.

The encampment of the National Guard just concluded at Peekskill has proved, so far as can be judjed, quite as successful as any of its predecessors, measuring success by the practical gain of the troops in soldierly efficiency.

The Thirteenth Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y., started on a week's Western pilgrimage last evening. Five hundred men out of an enrollment of 825 marched out of the armory in Flatbush-avenue, Brooklyn, at 6 o'clock, with Col. David E. Austen at their head.

One of the great attractions of literary Rhine tourists, the Rochus-Kapelle, above Bingen, so splendidly described by Goethe in his "Rheinreise," has been struck by lightning and burned to the ground.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18.--The steamer City of Sydney, from Hong-Kong and Yokohama, which arrived this evening, was expected to bring details of the earthquake at Kumamoto, the first news of which was cabled from Yokohama July 30.
Mexico and Japan have signed a treaty which constitutes an entirely new departure in Japan's foreign relations. Its most important feature is the complete elimination of "exterritoriality."

ROME, July 29.--Of the strange fortunes that may come to men of great name after death many authors have written. Sir Thomas Browne tells us that "the Egyptian mummies, which Cambyses or time hath spared, avarice now consumeth. Mummy is become merchandise, Mizraim cures wounds, and Pharaoh is sold for balsams."

MADRID, Aug. 18.--The report that the Alhambra had been damaged by the hurricane that visited Grana la yestrday is denied. The gardens surrounding the palace were devastated by the storm, but the building itself escaped damage.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 18.--W.K. Perry, the aeronaut who sustained severe injuries by falling from a balloon 700 feet high at Mount Holly Fair, near Charlotte, ten days ago, died to-night from internal injuries. Perry leaves a wife and two children, who came here from Birmingham, Ala., several days ago.

ALBANY, Aug. 20.--The Central Cross-Town Railroad of New-York City, in its report for the quarter ended June 30, shows gross earnings of $61,484; operating expenses, (including all taxes,) $34,140; gross income from all sources, $27,644; net income from all sources, $18,761.

The annual swimming championships of the Amateur Athletic Union will be decided on the Harlem River this afternoon. The contests will be started from the Atalanta Boat Club's house. One Hundred and Fifty-second-street and Harlem River, at 5 P.M., and will be under the auspices of the Manhattan Athletic Club.

The great feature yesterday of the Plattdeutsche Volksfest, which is being held at Schuetzen Park, Union Hill, N.J., was the marriage, in the old German style, of a blushing, pretty German girl to the man of her choice in the presence of something more than 15,000 people.
DANVERS, Mass., Aug. 20.--Gilman A. Kimbail of Middleton, who was attacked with hydrophobia on Saturday, died very quietly last night, having been kept under the influence of hypodermic injections.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows of the State met at Odd Fellows Hall at 9 A.M. to-day. There were 400 delegates present, and during the day at least as many more arrived.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Messrs. Wren and Graham of Brooklyn, members of the American Canoe Association, have launched their canoes in the Beaverkill and started on a voyage to Philadelphia. They expect to reach the City of Brotherly Love about Sept. 2. They are supplied with the necessary camping paraphernalia.

TROY, Aug. 20.--The doors of the Lynd House were closed this morning and the proprietor of the hotel, Samuel E. Jones, could not be found in the city.
Frederick Finck, Jr., who committed suicide early Monday morning by jumping from the Winsor Line steamer Norman off Atlantic City, was a prosperous young business man of this city.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 20.--William Thaw, the Pennsylvania Railroad magnate, whose death was announced in Sunday's TIMES, was noted chiefly for his good works. Every year he distributed about $200,000 in miscellaneous charity, besides the many thousands he gave ...

While the South Ferry boat Pacific was on the way to this city at 7:30 o'clock last night an unknown man about thirty-five years old, with full beard and dressed in dark clothes, jumped on the rear deck and was drowned. His body was not recovered.
A.J. Cassatt of Philadelphia is at the Brevoort House. Real Admiral S.P. Carter, United States Navy, is at the Grand Hotel.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 20.--The mud drum of the boiler at Gangwisch's Brewery, on Marketstreet, Allegheny City, exploded with terrific force this afternoon, almost completely wrecking the large three-story building. Henry Snyder, an employe, was killed outright, and two others, Lizzie Blasco and William Johnson, were seriously, but not fatally hurt. The damage will reach $10,000.

Miss Jennie McCarthy of 462 Washingtonstreet, is an unfortunate young woman. In the first place, her path in life has been strewn with thorns instead of roses. She has made the pathway more difficult to walk owing to an inordinate appetite for alcoholic stimulant.

Little will be left undone to make the celebration in honor of the arrival of "The Brigands" at its first hundred-mile post a fitting one, and the Casino will be a blaze of glory and light tonight. Mr. Rudolph Aronson has prepared an interesting musical programme to be interpreted ...

Coroner Mathews of New-Rochelle was called yesterday to investigate the death of Mrs. Charles Theall, who died at Port Chester the previous night quite suddenly, aged eighty years. She was formerly a milliner in the village, and had accumulated some money.

WOLFBOROUGH, N.H., Aug. 20.--Alfred Porter, aged about nineteen years, of Dover, a student at Dartmouth College, was shot last night and instantly killed at Kenniston's Island, near this place.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 20.--Great interest is felt in military circles in the result of the brigade court-martial of Surgeon Major Wilmur Hodgson of the Third New-Jersey Regiment, whose trial for alleged conduct unbecoming an officer of the National Guard and a gentleman began at Newark last night and will be continued on Friday evening.
CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 20.--via Galveston.-- The work of locating the route of the Transatlantic Railroad, between Chiapas and Tabasco, is progressing.

Mrs. Margaret Kaerber, a widow, living at 461 West Twenty-seventh-street, died yesterday at St. Catherine's Hospital, Brooklyn, from taking a dose of laudanum with the intention of committing suicide.

The Prohibitionists of Westchester County met in convention in Temperance Hall, Sing Sing, yesterday afternoon, to elect delegates to the next General State Convention, to be held in Syracuse on the 4th and 5th of September.

There have been several complaints recently concerning the delay in repairing Thirty-thirdstreet, near Fifth-avenue. A correspondent writes that seven men began work east of Fifthavenue about ten weeks ago and repaved about 100 feet half the width of the street.

BOSTON, Aug. 20.--The leader of the new embassy, Kentara Kaneko, which was commissioned by the Emperor to prepare for the opening of the first Japanese Parliament, in November, 1890, is visiting Boston for a few days.
BOSTON, Aug. 20.--The Hon. Thomas C. Amory, of the old Boston family of that name, a classmate of Charles Sumner, Harvard, 1830, died to-night in his seventy-seventh year.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--The Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad gave notice to-day that it would meet the 15 cent. proportional rate between Chicago and St. Paul on through ...

Cornelius Simonson of Chelsea, S.I., has just discovered on his farm what may prove to be a valuable deposit of brick clay. The bed was found about three feet below the surface, and it appears to be of large size. If the deposit should turn out to be a large one and well adapted to the making of bricks a new industry will be developed on the island.

MISSOULA, Montana, Aug. 20.--Reliable information reached here last night that the Indians are again menacing the lives of the whites at Demersville. They have broken into a house, and one person has been killed.

TECUMSEH, Ontario, Aug. 20.--About 12 o'clock last night fire broke out in Rector Robinet's house, this village. Robinet was awakened by the smoke about the time an alarm was given from the outside, and groping to the kitchen he opened the door.

The Col. M.C. Murphy Association, born during the war, invited all the friends of the widely-known State Senator to come to Lion Park, Ninth-avenue and One Hundred and Eighthstreet, Monday evening, and enjoy themselves.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 20.--The annual coaching parade, first held three years ago, has come to be the great event of the Summer here, and to-day's parade was a gay affair. The prizes offered this year were eight in number, instead of four.
The Leon Sanders Association, speaking for the residents of the Fourth, Sixth, and Eighth Assembly Districts, have adopted resolutions asking the Park Department to take steps to ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20.--Drafts--Sight, 10; telegraphic, 15.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 20.--The answers to the invitations to the centennial of the Catholic hierarchy, to be held in Baltimore Nov. 10 and succeeding days, indicate a very large attendance. Fully fifty of the Bishops of the United States will be present.

BOSTON, Aug. 20.--The Bostons defeated the New-Yorks to-day with the greatest ease. In fact, the contest was so one-sided as to be robbed of all interest except that taken in the slugging of the Bostons.

Oscar Tway, who was arrested in Brooklyn a week ago for impersonating a Federal officer and swindling grocers out of small sums of money, who sent to the penitentiary for three years yesterday by Justice Petterson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--Unofficial reports received at the Navy Department from Baltimore are to the effect that the gunboat Petrel, on trial yesterday, has probably just succeeded in meeting the contract requirements.

Rumors of trouble in the old oil-exporting house of Pagenstecher Co. obtained a limited circulation in the Produce Exchange and other downtown circles yesterday. It was said that the firm had stopped loading vessels that were at the piers preparing to take large cargoes of oil ...

Arthur T. Halliday, a son of the Rev. S.B. Halliday, who for many years was assistant pastor at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, was sent to the Amity ville Insane Asylum on Monday suffering from what is supposed to be paresis.

The United Foresters of Kings County closed their picnic at Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. The attendance was very large, and financially the festival was a decided success. Yesterday's sports were not strictly athletic, but contributed largely to the amusement of the spectators.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 20.--Particulars of the attempted assassination of Albert Youngblood at his home in Chickasaw Nation have been received here. Youngblood is a halfbreed Indian, and has made a reputation as a preacher of the Baptist denomination.
STREATOR, Ill., Aug. 20.--"Strike" is the order officially made by the Executive Board to-day to the coal miners of this field. The majority of them have been "striking" since May ...

Acting Commissioner Rogers of the StreetCleaning Department was not in the best of humor yesterday after reading in the newspapers the accounts of his burlesque trial of Superintendent Bacon of the department ...

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20.--The British bark Onaway, Capt. Anderson, which sailed from this port June 5 for Bilboa, with a crew of fifteen men and 124,234 gallons of crude petroleum, valued at $8,956, is believed to have been lost, as nothing has been heard of her since she passed out the Delaware Capes. The Captain's wife and two childran accompanied him.

Coroner Hanly took the ante-mortem statement in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday morning of Michael A. Rogers, who was found the night before at Eighth-avenue and Twelfthstreet with a fractured skull.

BUFFALO, Aug. 20.--The American Society of Microscopists was rather tardy in getting down to business this morning. It was 10:30 o'clock before Dr. Lee Smith, Chairman of the Local Committee, called upon the Right ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 20.--Robert Marvel, after fasting sixty-seven days, died this morning at 7 o'clock. His case is so extraordinary that it has attracted the attention not only of the curious public, but of the medical fraternity far and near. He was eighty-five years old.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--A light engine ran into the rear of a stock train on the New-York Central and Hudson River Road at Tribe's Hill this afternoon. The caboose and two cars loaded with hogs were derailed. Several of the hogs were killed. The passenger tracks were blocked for an hour.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J. Aug. 20.--Mrs. Andrews and Mrs. Smith, daughters of Judge John F. Mitchell, were returning from his house to their own last night about 11 o'clock when a man sprang out at them, thrust a revolver in Mrs. Andrews's face, and seized her. Both ladies screamed, and the fortunate appearance of a pedestrian frightened off their assailant. The assault was made in George-street, one of the most public of the city's thoroughfares.

United States Commissioner Osborn yesterday held for examination on Saturday Paul Haimont, who came to this country from France a few weeks ago in company with Henri Noll and his wife and a large amount of stolen money.

Chancellor McGill of New-Jersey has just set aside a decree of divorce in a remarkable case. Two years and a half ago Oscar L. Britton applied for a divorce from his wife. The petition stated that the residence of the wife was unknown.

A board of officers, to consist of Major James Gilliss, Quartermaster; Capt. John F. Rodgers, Military Storekeeper, and First Lieut. William W. Witherspoon, Twelfth Infantry, has been ordered to assemble at the Quartermaster General's office, Washington, Wednesday, Aug. 28, for the examination of candidates for appointment as superintendents of National Cemeteries.

LONDON, Aug. 20.--Miss Grace Hawthorne's suit against Manager A.M. Palmer, for breach of contract in failing to produce "Theodora" in London, will be tried late in the Autumn. Sir Charles Russell and Sir Henry James have received retainers in the case. Dr. Mallory, father of Miss Hawthorne's partner, has been subpoenaed, and will come to London to testify.

LOCKPORT, Aug. 20.--The last blow at the Niagara Falls Racing and Fair Grounds Association was struck to-day, when suit was begun in behalf of three Niagara Falls banks to recover three notes valued at $16,000.

Racing at long range was inaugurated at the magnificent new track of the New-York Jockey Club at West Chester yesterday afternoon. A great crowd was there to enjoy the sport; to see the most beautiful race track in the world; to enjoy liberal management and its advantages; ...
John Van der Cook, an insurance agent of Delhi, N.Y., was overcome by the heat yesterday, and a little after 8 o'clock P.M. he lost consciousness and fell at Barclay-street and Broadway.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 20.--M. Vyshnegradsky, Minister of Finance, intends to tax the Protestant churches in the Baltic provinces. These churches have hitherto been exempt from taxation. This is one of a serious of reforms by which the Government intends to thoroughly Russianize the old Baltic German institutions and to diminish the influence of the German Protestant clergy.
Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court yesterday signed an order refusing to grant an injunction in a suit brought by Robert Wallace against Hyman and Henry Sonn and Thomas J. McGuire.

SELMA, Ala., Aug. 20.--Selma is still stirred up on account of race troubles. Warrants of arrest were issued to-day for Bryant, Clark, and Jones of the Independent for inciting race animosities, but they could not be found in the city. Four colored persons were arrested this evening for obstructing the service of process by the Sheriff, and their trial will come off in the morning. The military is kept in readiness for an emergency.
Andrew McDonald, who is now the head gardener at the Friends' Asylum for the Insane in Philadelphia, has instituted a search for his father, Owen, and his brother and sister, Patrick and Sarah.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 20.--Manager Chapman has prepared the official programme for the encampment. Next Monday evening the Sons of Veterans will hold a camp fire at the West Side Turner Hall. Commander in Chief Warner of the Grand Army will preside.

Capt. Samuel Davis of North Chatham, Mass., was a passenger from this city by the steamer Puritan, for Fall River, on Monday. When the boat was off Execution Light, near City Island, he jumped overboard.

Upon a judgment and execution for $5,517 20 in favor of his brother, all of Eben S. Allen's interest in the iron foundry and machine shop of Allen Co., at 140 and 142 East Forty-firststreet, was sold yesterday at auction to Assemblyman Thomas Smith, Jr., of the Third Assembly District, for $350.
ALBANY, Aug. 21.--The Republicans here are in a delighted state of mind over the manner in which Gov. Hill has exposed his hand.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 21.--John T. Natcher, one of the largest painting contractors in the city, was fatally shot this afternoon by Benjamin Lee, a journeyman painter.

Charles Boun, who is twenty-one years old, and Theresa Berke, who is 16, eloped from NewBrunswick, N.J., yesterday morning. They repented their act while on the journey, but were afraid or ashamed to go home. They roamed about Jersey City until Capt. Farrar, who had watched them for some time, arrested them. The New-Brunswick police were notified, and Detective Douglas of that city responded and took them home.

ALBANY, Aug. 21.--William F. Howe appeared before Gov. Hill this morning and argued the application for Executive clemency for Charles Giblin, James Nolan, and John Lewis, three of the five murderers now confined in the Tombs, New-York City, awaiting execution on Friday.
The Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad report for the quarter ending June 30 shows the operating cost to have been 67.2 per cent. of the earnings.
BUFFALO, Aug. 21.--At the second day's session of the Society of Microscopists several new names were added to the roll of membership.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 21.--News was received this evening of a fight at Marysville between three officers and two outlaws. For a long time it has been known that parties named Hall and Mason had been selling liquor to the Indians.

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--The Selectmen of Revere will not issue a permit to John L. Sullivan to give a sparring exhibition at Oak Island, Revere Beach, so that part of the slugger's plans will have to be changed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--First Assistant Postmaster General Clarkson's very candid statement that he had appointed about 15,000 fourth-classs Postmasters in the five months since Mr. Harrison's Administration began recalls what was done in the time of President Jackson.
CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 21.--An important transfer of mining property was effected here yesterday in the sale of the famous ore body known as the Santa Fe Copper Mine, situated in the State of Chiapas.

George W. Wadleigh, who was formerly Edward E. Rice's secretary, some time ago came to the conclusion that the $20 per week alimony which he had been ordered in the Supreme Court to pay to his former wife, Leanna, was too much.

ROME, Ga., Aug. 21.--During a session of the Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows here this morning Col. Adolph Brandt, while opposing a resolution, fell dead in the hall from an attack of apoplexy. He was a prominent lawyer of Atlanta and widely known throughout the State.

The second race of the Greewich Yacht Club's catboat series will be sailed on Saturday. The winners of the first race were Charles Barrett's J.C. and L. Jacobs's Giggle. Twelve boats are entered for the series. Additional entries will be received up to 10 o'clock on the day of the race by Arthur E. Rendle, Chairman of the Regatta Committee.

The appropriation of a liberal sum by the municipal authorities for fitting up the rifle range in Van Cortlandt Park insures an early and complete preparation of this new training ground of the city troops.

Sergt. Schmittberger of the Nineteenth Precinct Police Station was in high glee yesterday over the discovery of a witness who was ready to swear that he had seen a man set fire to the premises at 305 Seventh-avenue, in which ten people were burned to death early Monday morning.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 21.--The last stroke of the 3 o'clock bell had hardly died away this morning when a sudden and brilliant glare spread over the lower section of the cities of Allegheny and Pittsburg.

HARTFORD, Aug. 21.--The fist half century of the Connecticut Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows will be celebrated at New-Haven Sept. 3 by a public demonstration in which not less than 3,000 members of the order will take part.

The Amateur Athletic Union's swimming championships at 100 yards and 1 mile were decided yesterday on the Harlem River. They were given under the management of the Manhattan Athletic Club, and were started at 5 o'clock. The tide was favorable to the swimmers.

Jank Hoe, the "illusionist," whose engagement at the Union-Square Theatre has not been profitable, did not give a performance last night. The report was that his "backer" had concluded that there was no money in the enterprise and has withdrawn and the probability is that the engagement has reached an abrupt close.

FARGO, Dakota, Aug. 21.--The first party State Convention ever held in North Dakota met here to-day. The politicians have been gathering for several days, and the city is crowded with delegates, candidates, and spectators.

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--Mr. Henry H. Faxon and his colleagues of the committee of the temperance Republicans, met behind closed doors today and decided to call the conference of the temperance men of the party from all over the State on Sept. 3, in Boston.
STRASBURG, Aug. 21.--After military tattoo last evening crowds assembled at the palace and cheered lustily in honor of the Emperor and Empress of Germany.

On Sunday afternoon George Decker of Mariners' Harbor, S.I., visited this city and hired a horse and buggy at Isaac H. Dahlman's stables, 205 East Twenty-fourth-street. He did not return to the stable and Dahlman visited Staten Island for tidings of the rig, which is valued at about $400.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 21.--The flourishing city of Colfax, on the Illinois Central, twenty miles northeast of this place, is in flames, and it is believed that it will be entirely destroyed. Bloomington has been telegraphed, asking for aid from the Fire Department. No particulars are likely to be obtained for some time.

The ill feeling between the Garde Lafayette and the Orpheon Francais, that culminated in a fight on Tuesday night, has existed for a long time. Both organizations have headquarters at 21 South Fifth-avenue, and each has about sixty members.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 21.--Amid the booming of cannon and cheers from the multitude gathered at the Central Station the President arrived here at 10:15 o'clock, over two hours and a half late, owing to an accident to the engine of a train in front of the Western express between Baltimore and Washington yesterday.

Five of the seven men of finance who, as the Executive Committee of the Finance Committee of the World's Fair of 1892, are to raise the funds upon which the success of the vast enterprise depends, met yesterday at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, in Nassau-street. Samuel D. Babcock, August Belmont, John H. Inman, J. Edward Simmons, and Charles Stewart Smith were present.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 21.--Secretary of War Proctor, Gen. Schofield, and other officers of the United States Army, who spent the night in the city as the guests of Col. Le Grand B. Cannon, went to Plattsburg this morning, accompanied ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 21.--The election of Congressman in the Third District takes place Sept. 3, and a brisk campaign was begun by the rival candidates at the close of last week. Mr. Price, the Democratic candidate, opened at Thibodeaux, moving westward, and Mr. Miner, the Republican, raised his banner at Lake Charles and moves eastward.
Controller Myers yesterday received the resignation of William C. Towen, the Deputy Collector in the Marker Bureau of the Finance Department.
FRANKLIN, Penn., Aug. 21.--The match pacing race between the stallions Arctic and Crawford Wilkes for a purse of $1,000 was won by the latter.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 21.--George Thompson, a negro chicken thief who has just been released from State prison, was arrested by Trenton detectives to-day and taken to Mercer County jail. Thompson was sentenced a year and a half ago for repeated chicken thefts here.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 21.--A careful estimate of the hop yield of the Northwest puts it at hardly two-thirds that of last year by reason of long-continued drought. Picking is to begin next week, and no trouble is anticipated from lack of pickers. No Chinamen are to be employed, either, as an outgrowth of the trouble of last year.

Twenty members of the Washington Heights Taxpayers' Association came down to the Mayor's office yesterday to tell the Board of Estimate and Apportionment what they thought about the proposed viaduct at Macomb's Dam and how much they needed it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--There are knowing ones in the local Republican camps who say that when the sun rises on the day following the next County Republican Covention George R. Davis, ex-boss of the machine in this county, will be at the helm of the new machine.
HASTINGS, Minn., Aug. 21.--The large barn of David Wentworth was struck by lightning yesterday morning and burned to the ground. The loss is about $3,000; insured for about $2,000.

The funeral of Leonard J. Carpenter was held at the family residence, 113 East Twentyninth-street, yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock. A delegation from the Veteran Corps of the Seventh Regiment, of which Mr. Carpenter was a member, was present during the services, which were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Spenser of Tarrytown. The burial was at that place.

The editor of the Toledo Blade, (a Republican paper,) who is reputed to be on very intimate terms with Mr. FORAKER, has recently published a coldly-savage article on Mr. JOHN SHERMAN which shows that the Foraker Republicans in Ohio are in a bad temper.

That there is a large number of amateur photographers still in the city was shown last night by the attendance at an informal meeting of the Society of Amateur Photographers at its rooms, 122 West Thirty-sixth-street.

Three of the fastest steamships afloat left their piers in the North River yesterday afternoon and started for Liverpool--the Teutonic of the White Star Line, the City of New-York of the Inman Line, and the City of Rome of the Anchor Line.

LONDON, Aug. 21.--The strike of the dock laborers is spreading. One thousand men employed on the Commercial Docks joined the strikers to-day. The Socialists are trying to lead the movement, and the red flag is being displayed.
NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 21.--The Prohibitionists in Connecticut are doing very little work for the proposed amendment to the Constitution, on account of a lack of funds.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 21.--The farmers in this section of New-Jersey are having rather hard luck this season. While their grain and grass crops have not fallen below the average, their fruit crops will in many instances be almost total losses. Melon vines have been destroyed either by wet weather or worms, and ...

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 21.--The Wauregan Cotton Goods Mills, E.P. Taft, Treasurer, decided to suspend payment to-day and allow their notes to go to protest. The failure is connected with the disaster that overcame Lewis Brothers, ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 21.--Two steam yachts, the Wideawake of Brewerton and the Jessie Lang of Phoenix, came into collision this afternoon at the junction of the Oswego and Seneca Rivers. The Jessie Lang sank, and all on board, about twenty-five persons, went into the water. All were rescued by the Wideawake except Miss Clara Van Wormer of Phoenix. She was drowned.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 21.--The Farmers' Alliance Exchange of Florida to-day took the first step toward making Jacksonville the home market for Florida-raised cotton. For many years Florida's product has been sent to Savannah, Brunswick, and other points, but Jacksonville will now handle the crop.

Mrs. James Hooker Hamersley gave birth to a girl baby on Tuesday afternoon. According to the provisions of Louis C. SARATOGA, Aug. 29.--With the perversity of most mundane mortals, Saratogians are now hoping for a rainy day. LUCERNE, Aug. 30.--Mr. Washburn, the United States Minister to Switzerland, has made a formal protest to the Bundesrath against the wrongful arrest of four American tourists at Berne on the charge of being pickpockets.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 30.--President Arnoux of the New-York State Bar Association announced to-day the names of the members of the Committee of Arrangements for the celebration by the association of the centenary of the Federal Judiciary.

LONDON, Aug. 30.--The indications this morning are not very favorable to the immediate settlement of the strike. A meeting of a committee of strikers, presided over by John Burns, was held last night, at which important action was taken looking to making the strike general.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 30.--The records at the fishing pier were broken this afternoon by an extraordinary run of large striped bass. Clarence Baer, a fourteen-year-old Philadelphia boy, caught a nine-pound bass with a drop line, and Charles Budine caught a thirteen-anda-half-pound bass with a rod and reel, both breaking the records in their class. Gold medals have been offered to the champions is each class by James A. Bradley, the proprietor of the pier.

The Hudson County (N.J.) Undertakers' Association held a secret meeting on Thursday night for the trial of charges preferred against Undertaker John F. O'Hara of Hoboken by Undertaker A.J. Volk of the same city. O'Hara is a Coroner and has a contract for the burial of the Hoboken poor. Volk charged him with unprofessional conduct in burying a body which the complaining undertaker had abandoned.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 30.--Arnold E. Farquahr, a clerk in General Passenger Agent Hempstead's office at the Consolidated Railroad station, has embezzled about $950 of the company's money and departed.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30.--The poloists played to-day for cups offered by W.C. Sanford. The sides were as follows: Blues--Foxhall Keene, Stanley Mortimer, Carl Havemeyer, and August Belmont, Jr. Yellows--Thomas Hitchcock, Jr., W.K. Thorn, Jr., J.L. Stevens, and E.L. Winthrop, Jr. The sides were very even and play had to be continued until dark to decide the match. The final score was: Yellows, 5; Blues, 4.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 30.--Glenview Belle won the three-year-old race at the trots here today, making a record of 2:20 . She seemed able to go even faster, her driver easing her up to let one of her competitors inside the distance flag. She is a daughter of Nutwood and is Kentucky bred.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 30.--Two men were killed and seven terribly burned at the Homestead Steel Works of Carnegie, Phipps Co. at Homestead, Penn., this afternoon, by the boiling over of a ladle containing ten tons of molten steel. Three of the injured will die.
LONDON, Aug. 31.--The steamship Robilant sld. from Singapore for New-York Aug. 29. The steamship Colorado, (Br.,) Capt. Jenkins, sld. from Hull for New-York yesterday.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Aug. 30.--Word reached here at noon to-day that forty miners at work in the Alleghany mine, near Frostburg, had been shut in and probably drowned. Water had broken in from the abandoned AEtna mine and had driven the miners further away from the main headway.

LONDON, Aug. 30.--Advices from Yokohama state that disastrous storms have recently occurred in Wakayama. Ten thousand persons perished in the floods following the storms, and 20,000 were rendered homeless. The loss of property was enormous.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 30.--Gen. W.T. Sherman intended returning to Chicago for a stay of a day or so with his brother, Major Hoyt Sherman of Des Moines, Iowa, but, reaching here at 2 o'clock this afternoon, he suddenly changed his mind and took a New-York train without even going to a hotel.

BOSTON, Aug. 30.--Mrs. Catherine Sullivan, mother of John L. Sullivan, the pugilist, died at her residence, on Parnell-street, Roxbury, this evening, from water on the heart. She was a native of Ireland, fifty-two years old, and has been an invalid several years, having been bed,ridden for two years past.

Wall-street was informed yesterday by Zimmerman Forshay that a large number of counterfeit fifty-kroner notes on the Lundsalls Enskilda Bank of Lundsalls, Sweden, were being offered for exchange in this city. Zimmerman Forshay thing there are about ten thousand of these notes, and it is said that some people have received them in exchange. They came from San Francisco and are dated 1875. They are fair counterfeits, but the printing is somewhat clouded.

REPUBLIC, Mich., Aug. 31.--Reimund Holzhay, the "Lone Highwayman," who has terrorized Northern Wisconsin for five months past, robbing trains, waylaying stages, and "holding up" pedestrians, is in custody. He was captured here this morning by City Marshal Glode and Justice of the Peace E.F. Weiser, and will be taken to Bessemer to answer for the killing of Fleischbein, at Gogebic, on Monday of this week. Holzhay confesses to all the stage and train robberies.

The Brooklyn Common Council yesterday found the $2,500 in unexpended balances for which they have been searching, and left on their junket to Gettysburg. Aldermen McCarty, Coffee, and Murphy were the only ones who did not go along. With the Aldermen went forty local Democratic politicians and minor officeholders. They reached Jersey City about 2:30 o'clock and left on a special vestibule train half an hour later.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Aug. 31.--Warren, Sussex, and Morris Counties are being flooded with counterfeit silver dollars, the work of a gang of Italians belonging to the colony of Allen Brothers, at Stanhope. Many merchants have been victimized, and one arrest has been made. The man arrested said he got the counterfeits from the paymaster of the Hibernia Mines, where he had been at work. The authorities will make a full investigation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31.--The steamer Zealandia arrived from Australia, New-Zealand, and Honolulu this afternoon. It was considered probable here that Admiral Kimberly would arrive from Samoa, but the steamer brought no Samoan passengers.

The third and last of the big series of games between the New-York and Boston aspirants for championship honors was brought to a close last evening on account of darkness, with the scores even, each club having made 9 runs. It was a game that will long be remembered.

The Democratic General Committee holds its first meeting to-night, and will fix the dates for the primaries for the election of delegates to the State Convention. Next week the Republicans hold their first meeting, at which thus will do similar work.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Sept. 1.--The faith cure people west of this city, near the village of Bluffton, have gotten themselves into serious trouble over the death of a young man they were assuming to cure of a wound in the leg, caused by running against a stake while playing.

Central Labor Federation yesterday received a communication from the Socialistic Labor Party stating that the party had called for a convention of all labor organizations to urge them to go into independent political action. The Federation delegates did not seem to be favorably inclined toward the scheme, so the matter was laid over.
KINGSTON, Sept. 1.--James Cummings, who gained some notoriety by standing guard over his lot with a double-barreled shotgun one day last week, has sued this city for damages.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 1.--Between 2 and 3 o'clock this morning an excursion train, composed entirely of colored people, arrived at the Gouldsborough station from Baton Rouge. A large number of colored men and women were near the station waiting for the train, which was due at 11 o'clock.
The Park Theatre was lighted up last night for a private inspection of the improvements that have been made since Ed Harrigan quitted it.

Meredith, John Ritchie, and George Shields, known as 'old hosses' and 'old timers,' sat around in the Press Club one afternoon recently and talked about the times of the war and told of the funny capers that cannon balls and musket balls cut. Capt. Meredith said he once found a dead Confederate behind a tree.
BUFFALO, Sept. 1.--On Aug. 20 J.S. Bruce of New-York registered at the Cataract House, Niagara Falls. Five days later it was discovered that he had disappeared.

The Todmorden handbell ringers arrived from Liverpool last evening on the steamship Arizona.
The Louisville and Nashville Railroad will today open for business its extension from Pineville, Ky., to Middleborough, the new town at Cumberland Gap.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--A Washington special to the Chicago Times says: "The Venezuelan claims, which have been pending for many years, were considered by the forty-seventh Congress and a new convention was ordered.

TRENTON, Sept. 1.--The holding of primaries by the new Democratic County Committee in Hudson for the choice of delegates to the State Convention has made the attitude of that county to the progressing campaign the chief topic of speculation in political circles the last week.
LONDON, Sept. 1.--The steamship Crystal, (Br.,) Capt. Stannard, from New-York Aug. 13, arr. at Leith yesterday.

The man who stood on the Brooklyn Bridge Saturday trying to count the kites that were flying from over housetops in the city was nearly thrown into a state of nervous imbecility and rushed madly to the entrance without deigning to reply to a questioner as to the result of his observations.

ROUSE'S POINT, Aug. 31.--The modern tourist thinks nothing of "doing" the 100 miles of Lake Champlain and the thirty-five additional miles of Lake George in one day. He passes rapidly along the former by rail, or a whit more slowly by the large steamer; rushes into a car at Ticonderoga, and is wheeled over to Baldwin, where he takes another steamer to Caldwell.

President Harrison has rather a peculiar shake. He reaches out for the hand, grasps it rather tightly, gives it one quick downward jerk, and then a pull as if to pass the person along, letting go as suddenly as he grasped it.

The telegram reporting that all Americans are to be expelled from China does not embody a fact of the greatest intrinsic importance, since there are only 1,022 Americans in China, including all ages, sexes, and occupations. But the moral embodied should, and doubtless will, be preached from many pulpits.

Something seems to be the matter with the Harlem River. The great crowd of boating enthusiasts that up to two or three weeks ago used to flock to the river on Sundays and transform the rather unpicturesque stream into a scene of life and festivity has practically deserted it.

The name of Chae Chan Ping is now familiar to American ears. He is a Chinese gentleman who has given the United States courts a great deal of trouble in his endeavors to force his unwelcome presence upon the citizens of this fair and free country. He was landed on a writ of habeas corpus some months ago, ever since which time he has been endeavoring to defeat the conditions of the Scott Exclusion act.

DEER PARK, Md., Sept. 1.--The President remained indoors about all day, and did not attend church as usual. It is probable that the President will leave Deer Park the middle of this week, perhaps on Wednesday, and go to Washington.

Secretary Lawrence of the Coney Island Jockey Club to-day announces the weights for three important handicaps to be run at the Sheepshead Bay track this week. The Twin city will be run to-morrow, the New-York on Thursday, and the Omnium on Saturday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 1.--Advices from Fernandina to-night indicate that the longsheremen's threatened strike did not materialize. The Captains of the lumber vessels acceded to the demands of the stevedores and will pay advanced prices on all vessels. This advance rate is to apply to that portion of cargoes already in holds and to the balance to be put aboard.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler and Mrs. Cuyler of Brooklyn were among the 502 saloon passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Servia from Liverpool. The revenue cutter Manhattan, Captain D.F. Tozier, was to have taken a party of Dr. Cuyler's parishioners down the bay to welcome him home, if the Servia had turned up on a week day.

PARIS, Aug. 12.--The Grand Plaza near the Bois, in the Rue Pergolese, opened its doors yesterday. It is, even in its unfinished state, a magnificent building. Large in surface, it is even greater in height, constructed principally of iron and brick, and costing over three millions to a company of Spanish gentlemen who went into this enterprise ...

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1.--The steamer Gem City of the St. Paul Packet Line, which left this city at 4 o'clock Saturday afternoon, while proceeding on her way began sinking at a point a few miles above Alton, at about 8 o'clock Saturday night. She was headed for the shore and sank almost immediately upon reaching the bank, lying in eight feet of water.

Gen. Sherman, who arrived home from the West at midnight Saturday, was seen at his residence, 75 West Seventy-first-street, yesterday afternoon and asked to supply the particulars of the alleged affront offered him at Milwaukee Friday by members of the Phil Sheridan Grand Army Post of Chicago, in whose car he and his party had accidentally taken seats, which they were obliged to surrender.

For a long time in Communipaw there has been great rivalry between the owners of two catboats, the H.H. Holmes and the Three Brothers. The former is owned by A.L. Kreymeyer and the latter by Charles Stuhrer, both members of the Pavonia Yacht Club.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 1.--Enormous shoals of menhaden have been driven into this harbor by the easterly winds, which have been blowing quite heavily of late. There are millions upon millions of the fish, and they are large and fat. A swarm of steam and sail menhaden fishing vessels are following them.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Sept. 1.--The public memorial exercises which were held to-day by the Knights of Pythias in memory of the twelve members of that organization who went down in the flood were largely attended. Col. John P. Linton pronounced the culogy, and the references to the dead members and the manner in which they met their doom was very interesting.

Quite a large number of personal and professional friends gathered yesterday afternoon at the "Little Church Around the Corner," in Twenty-ninth street, to give their last testimony of respect for the late George Faweett Rowe.

Charles Mara, an expressman of 48 Springstreet, was arrested yesterday morning at Twenty-second-street and Broadway because he had no permit for removing theatrical scenery, , which he was taking from the Grand Central Station to Williamsburg for the N.S. Wood Combination.

H.M. Baker, formerly of the firm of Campbell Baker, stationers of Broad-street, Newark. N. J., has taken a sudden departure for the West. It is said that he took $1,500 of the funds of the firm to which he had no right, and that Mr. Campbell forced him to assign his interest in the business.

ALBANY, Sept. 1.--While an eleven-year-old daughter of Byron Welch of 20 Mulberry-street was carrying in her arms her sister, eleven months old, to-day, the little one cried for a drink of water. The girl picked up a bowl containing embalming fluid, which stood beside the corpse of another child of the family, and allowed the babe to drink of the poisonous mixture. A physician was summoned, but the child died soon afterward.

The cornerstone of the new parochial school of St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church in Jersey City was laid to-day. The Rev. Father De Concilio officiatad, assisted dy priests from Newark, Paterson, Hobokon, Weehawken, Irvington, and Jersey City.

Lewis W. Hopps, who has several laundries, and lives with his widowed mother in her boarding house at 245 West Fourteenth-street, was visited ten days ago by William Metzler, who had just come of age, but who, when Mr. Hopps last saw him, was a lad of promise employed as a telegraph operator. Metzler had so changed as hardly to be recognized. He was in rags, ill from chills and fever, and utterly destitute.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1.--Australian papers say that about June 26 the Save, a small trading vessel, was boarded by natives at Malayta, and one of them shot Mate Ladden dead, while another beheaded a trader named Cooper with an axe. Keating, the owner of the vessel, and several others on board were badly injured, but drove off the natives, killing twelve of them. It is since reported that Keating has died.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 1.--Russell B. Harrison arrived here last night and put up at the United States. This morning he went up to Hotel Balmoral, Mount McGregor, where he is the guest of W.J. Arkell.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 1.--Compilations of cemmercial statistics for the past business year show a substantial increase over former years, and the presence in all branches of trade of a confidence and firm feeling that have not exisied since the year before the war.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 1.--At all the masses at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church to-day the building was crowded, and those who went there with the expectation of hearing the officiating priest make references to the recent attempt to deprive the congregation of the right to conduct a sectarian school on the church premises at the expense of the taxpayers of School District No. 3 were not disappointed.

Special matinees in honor of Labor Day will be given this afternoon, of "Mankind" at the Fourteenth Street Theatre, "The Still Alarm" at the Grand Opera House, and by Herrmann's Transatlantic Vandeville Company at the Bijou.

Mrs. Stetson and daughter of Union township were berrying in the vicinity of Harbor Bridge when they had a lively encounter with a snake. Mrs. Stetson was making her way through a thicket of small trees and bushes, her daughter following at a distance of fifteen or twenty yards.

Two games were played on the Polo Grounds yesterday between the New-York and Pittsburg Clubs, and the Giants managed to win both. Boston, however, succeeded in winning the same number from Indianapolis, and in consequence the standing of the leaders is the same to-day as it was last week. Over 12,000 persons witnessed the contests.

SARATOGA, Sept. 2.--"If to-day had broken cold and rainy," said a hotel proprietor this morning, "the outgoing trains couldn't have held the folks who would have wanted to get away; as it is, a good many in my place who were undecided last night have elected to remain and enjoy at least one more day of this beautiful weather."

BOSTON, Sept. 2.--Fifteen thousand people witnessed the races under the auspices of the New-England Amateur Rowing Association on Charles River this afternoon. The conditions were admirable, with smooth water and just wind enough to temper the heat of the sun.

Business was very generally suspended in Brooklyn yesterday. Thousands of people patronized the ball games, the outdoor sports, and the tennis grounds at Prospect Park. The local theatre managers took advantage of the opportune holiday to open their houses for the season, and most of them gave both afternoon and evening performances.

JOLIET, Ill., Sept. 2.--The conference of the coal miners and coal operators held here this afternoon resulted in a settlement of the wage troubles throughout the Northern Illinois coal fields and an early resumption of work except in the mines of W.L. Scott.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 2.--Extensive excavations are being made at the suburban town of Coyoacan, at a place lying on the outskirts of the wilderness, known as the pedregal or stony ground, which in former years was noted as a haunt of brigands, and is even now considere as a resort for dangerous characters when pursued by officers of justice.

PHOENICIA, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The woodcock scason up here in the woods is reported as being failure by sportsmen. As the breeding places of woodcock fire on the ground it is believed that the frequent rains have interfered with the production of young birds. The partridge season opened to-day, but it is said that game is scarce for similar reasons. Squirrels and rabbits a reported numerous in Illster, Greene, and adjoining counties.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Sept. 2.--This was Brooklyn Day on the battlefield, and the Fourth NewYork Cavalry and the Tenth New-York Infantry dedicated memorials. General exercises were held in the Court House, at which Alderman William McKee presided.

The Park Theatre, lately occupied by Mr. Harrigan, has fallen into other hands. The house has been papered, painted, and carpeted anew, and is now much brighter and more cheerful in appearance than it was last Winter. CHICAGO, Sept. 2.--The examination of talesmen with a view to determining their fitness or unfitness to serve as jurors in the Cronin case was resumed in the criminal court this morning. Nothing of interest has thus far been developed.

When a new holiday was added to the list, which is not too long, and it was provided that it should be known as Labor Day, people in general expected that in its observance some special significance and purpose would be brought to light. Thus far nothing of the kind has happened.

Lowrey arrived by special train from Greenwood this morning at 3 o'clock, having succeeded before, he left in getting the armed whites who had assembled at Greenwood to return to their homes, instead of going to the scene of the threatened race war. MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 2.--J. Frank Collom, the young attorney of this city who was arrested about three weeks ago charged with a series of forgeries aggregating about $227,000, late this evening made an assignment to the Minnesota Title and Trust Company.

The Kings County Democrats began their Fall campaign last night with a fight, and for a time it was a very bitter one. The ring was formed in the Brooklyn Athenaeum, and the spectators and participants were the members of the Democratic General Committee.

With the approval of Secretary Proctor, Major Gen. Schofield has issued the following order: "The garrisons of Fort Laramie, Wyoming territory; Fort Hays, Kansas, and Fort Lyon, Colorado, will be withdrawn and the several posts named will be abandoned, and the troops thus withdrawn will be assigned to other stations by the division commander. SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2.--It is stated that Archbishop Riordan of this city is in failing health, and it is reported that he has called a conference of Bishops in the archdiocese, to convene in this city at an early date, to select three names to be recommended to the Pope from which to select a coadjutor.

Old volunteer firemen's daughters and young firemen's sweethearts were as thick as hops in Brommer's Union Park at One Hundred and Thirty-third-street and Union-avenue yesterday. They were enjoying the fifth annual picnic and barbecue of the Volunteer Firemen's...

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 2.--The convention to frame the Constitution for the proposed State of Wyoming met in the Capitol to-day. Temporary organization was effected by the election of H.S. Elliott of Johnson County Presdent and John K. Jeffrey of Laramie County Secretary.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 2.--The thirty-fourth annual convention of the German Roman Catholic Society began here to-day. There are in attendance 700 delegates, representing 26 States and 439 organizations, with 38,996 members.

Several hundred ladies and gentlemen gathered yesterday at the pretty clubhouse of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club at Port Morris to witness the start and finish of the annual Fall regatta of the club. A very high southeast wind was blowing up the Sound, but it was so light as to raise hardly a ripple on the surface of the water.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 2.--The will of William Thaw, the dead millionaire railroad king, has just been probated. It occupies thirty-six pages of typewritten foolscap, and was made July 5 of the present year. His estate, except his coal lands, is divided into sixteen equal parts.

During the Administration of Mr. CLEVELAND and under the direction of Commissioner SPARKS careful inquiry concerning a large number of desert-land entries was made by the special agents of the General Land Office. Many of these entries were declared to be fraudulent, and in some cases the land covered by them was restored to the public domain.

MOUNT TABOR, N.J., Sept. 2.--The twentieth annual camp meeting of the Newark Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church has come to an end. As for tangible results, the meetings have not been entirely successful. Few prominent clergymen have preached here, and the crowds that have attended have some more with the idea of a picnic in mind than with any care for their spiritual welfare.

The friends and members of the Brooklyn Yacht Club enjoyed a fine sail yesterday on the bay at the Fall regatta of the club. The steamboat Governor Safford took down a large party of ladies, who seemed to thoroughly enjoy watching the fliers as they skimmed over the water with a piping breeze from the southwest. The Regatta Committee were William Dodman and John J. Welsh.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 2.--A novel case, in which the clammers of Staten Island and NewJersey are interested, has just been decided, and the decision will set at rest many disputes which have at times arisen between these opposing factions.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 2.--Since the establishment of the annual meet of wheelmen at Hartford nearly five years ago, none has been so successful as the third annual meet of the Hartford Wheel Club, which was begun today. In the morning a parade was given, in which 388 wheelmen participated, all large Eastern cities being represented.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2.--The last will and testament of Henry Shaw, of Botanical-Garden fame, is made public. It bears date of Jan. 26, 1885. The bulk of the property does to the city, on conditions to be accepted and to be carried out by trustees.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 2.--The attendance at to-day's sessions of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was light, owing to the absence of a large delegation on an excursion to Muskoka. At the general meeting of the association 185 new members were elected. The number of papers sent in was 221.

Menhaden fishing in the waters of Long Island Sound and in the lower bay has never been more prosperous than during the past few months. Nearly all the vessels engaged in catching menhaden report thus far alucrative season's work.

In Newark, N.J., yesterday Labor Day was celebrated by the workingmen from that city and all the neighboring towns. The two labor associations of Newark held picnics at which prominent labor men and politicians spoke.

Another demonstration of the oft-demonstrated fact that electricity, in sufficient quantity, will kill was made yesterday afternoon in the dynamo room of the East River Electric Lighting Company at 421 East Twenty-fourthstreet, when an experienced electrician accidentally came in contact with the current and was struck dead in an instant.

Before the Grand Jury that convenes to-day District Attorney Fellows will, it is said, have resentments to make against two departments --or, rather, against subordinate officials in two departments of the City Government.

The second annual Suabian Harvest Home Festival held by the Snabian Sick Benefit Society of Hudson County, N.J., opened in Greenville yesterday and will be concluded to-day. RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 2.--The annual ladies' regatta of the North Shrewsbury River Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon in a light easterly breeze. Only three yachts started: Commodore Edward Russell's Lizzie R., Thomas Chadwick's Gem, and Charles Burd's Annie B.

The German barkentine Johanna of Topenburg arrived in this port Sunday, ninety-three days out from the island of Mauritius. The Johanna is under the command of Capt. Meniders, and her cargo of sugar is consigned to a New-York firm. Capt. Meniders reports considerable smallpox as prevailing on the island of Mauritius just before the departure of the Johanna.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The delegates to the seventh annual convention of the State Wine, Beer, and Liquor Dealers' Association began arriving here Sunday night, and about all of them were in their places when President B. T. Kearns called the convention to order at Maennerchor Hall to-night.

The late James Albery, the English dramatist began life as an apprentice in a rope walk, an was in the business of manufacturing rope and twine in London when his first and best play, "Two Roses," was produced at the Vaudeville Theatre June 4, 1870. He wrote many plays thereafter--some characterized by rare delicacy of feeling and beautiful facility of expression-- but none of them held the public favor long.

PAWLING, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The fair held here last week has revealed one thing which may call for vigorous police interference, and that is that a gang of thieves and swindlers, who have headquarters in New-York, will attend every fair within a hundred miles of the metropolis.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 2.--The law officers of the Crown, Sir Richard Webster and Sir Edward Clarke, have reported that the Governor General was right not to interfere with the operation of the Jesuits' Estates act; that the act was clearly within the powers of the Provincial Legislature, and that there is no case to send to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 2.--Frank Palmer, age 15, a student of Little Falls Academy and a son of Charles Palmer, a prominent lawyer of that place, was shot in the head and killed by Barbor Gregory, a hunting companion, to-day, while the latter was trying to remove a cap from his gun. The top of Palmer's head was blown off. Gregory is almost crazed by the accident.

A committee of the House of Lords has been for some time inquiring into the emoluments of its officials, and the report has just been presented. If the recommendations are carried out there will be an aggregate saving of 6,874 per annum.

FORT WILLIAM HENRY, Lake George, Sept. 2.-- The Sherman House, situated on French Point, near the narrows, burned to the ground early this morning. The main building was two and a half stories high and could accommodate about one hundred and fifty guests. There were fifteen in the house when the fire broke out, all of whom got out in safety. Very little was saved except the cottages.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 2.--There was a collision on the Danville and New River Railroad this afternoon west of Martinsville between a mixed train and a supply train. Both trains were badly wrecked. Adam Price, colored, was killed and three other train hands badly injured, but no passengers were seriously hurt.

LOUIS, Sept. 2.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day Judge Thayer rendered a decision to the affect that the counterfeiting of the Union label used on cigars cannot be prevented or punished. Labor Day was honored with general observance as a holiday in this city yesterday. Business ceased and the people took an outing. There was not so much in it to distinguish it from the ordinary holiday as had been anticipated. The parade of labor organizations had little merit as a spectacle and fell short of being otherwise specially imposing.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 2.--Judge Boland of the Police Court, and ex-office Justice of the Peace, to-day handed down a decision of the test case made by the saloon men of the validity of the penalty clause of the Sunday law.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2.--The Senatorial committee, with Senator George G. Vest of Missouri in the chair, began an investigation into the value of Chicago's meat products and their transportation this morning at the Grand Pacific Hotel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2,--The Supreme Council of the American Legion of Honor to-day devoted itself to a consideration of the report of the Law Committee. The result was a continuance of the guarantee or reserve fund in the present form and the continuance of the sick relief benefit system with some minor changes. The next meeting will be held at Long Branch on the fourth Tuesday in August, 1891.

The recent rapid trips of ocean steamers from Europe have attracted the attention of those who closely watch ocean tide and current effects. The City of Paris and the Lahn made remarkable runs, and before the week closed the Anchoria made port, to the utter surprise of owners, officers, and passengers, one day sooner than usual.

Dr. Waddington, the last Dean of Durham, was a great epicure, and one of the best judges of wine in Europe. After his death, in 1869, his cellar realized a very large sum. BISMARCK, Dakota, Sept. 2.--John Grass, the famous Sioux chief, who was prostrated by the heat a few days ago, is still alive and resting well, and there is a prospect of his ultimate recovery, though the old chief has given up hope.

SOMERSET, Ky., Sept. 2.--News reaches here to-night that a negro assaulted the twelve-yearold daughter of William Oates, living near Monticello. He was pursued by a posse and caught in the woods. No rope was handy, so he was tied to a stake and burned to death.

The day was very generally observed throughout the country by the cessation of all business, parades by the local labor organizations, and numberless picnics. Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburg, Chicago, Detroit, Baltimore, Cincinnati, Kansas City, and most of the smaller cities carried out this general programme with little or no variation.

Owing to the remoteness of the scene of the recently-ended British manoeuvres, it has been impossible to obtain reports except at irregular intervals. It is now known, however, that the operations of the first week were carried on without any very decisive result until Saturday of that week, when after a sharp running fight, two battle ships and a cruiser of Admiral Baird's fleet were captured by a part of Sir George Tryon's defending squadron.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 2.--The barkentine Nicanor, Capt. J.H. Wolf, from Montevideo for New-York, stranded on the south bar of the Great Egg Harbor Inlet at 1:30 this morning. The weather was thick and smoky. There was a strong inshore current, and the ship was considerably out of her course.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2.--The handicap court tennis tournament is closed, George R. Fearing, Jr., a player of the first class, having defeated C.A. Baldwin of the second class in the final, after giving him a handicap of 15. The score was 6--5, 6--2, 6--5. Fearing thus wins the prize given by Thomas Hitchcock, Jr.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 2.--The new volume of special acts adopted by the Legislature during the session which was concluded in June will call public attention anew to the danger them is in this State from special legislation.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2.--William H. Hoagland, a grocery clerk, was bitten by a dog about nine weeks ago, but it was note until three days ago that symptoms of hydrophobia developed. Hoagland died in great agony this morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2.--Another apprentice boy on the United States steamer New-Hampshire, the third in less than a week, died to-day of typhoid fever. The ship authorities have ordered tents and blankets to enable the boys to camp out on the sand while the ship is being disinfected.

LONDON, Sept. 2.--Mr. Gladstone has gone to Paris. Mr. Labouchere writes to the newspapers that he has learned that Italy joined the tripple alliance on receiving a promise from Lord Salisbury to aid Italy and defend the Italian littoral in the event of a European war. Mr. Labouchere challenges Sir James Fergusson, Under Foreign Secretary, to publish the dispatches in connection with this affair.

DENISON, Texas. Sept. 2.--"Jim" Dyer, one of the most notorious desperadoes in West Indian Territory, was shot and mortally wounded yesterday at the mouth of Allen Bayou by John McHenry. Dyer was riding up and down the street past McHenry's house with rifle in hand. Some words passed between the two men when McHenry shot Dyer. Dyer and his brothers were expelled from Texas some years ago for shooting an officer in Fannin County.

For the past three years this country has been in a relatively tranquil state of mind in regard to its currency, not so much from any conviction that the system regulating the currency is a safe and good one, but from the feeling common to all enterprising communities, and especially strong with us, that if to-day is fairly prosperous to-morrow may take care of itself.

Saharf, now held in custody at Montreal for forgery and uttering forged paper in the State of Connecticut. A.P Dickinson is the officer authorized by the United States Government to receive the prisoner. The amount involved by Scharf's forgeries is only $1,500.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 3.--The Board of Chosen Freeholders of Passaic County to-day decided to erect an extension to the county jail for the detention of prisoners under 16 years of age. The upper story will be fitted up as a board room, Grand Jury room, The building will cost about $15,000.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 3.--Forty carloads of sealkins in three separate trains making passenger time passed through Cheyenne to-day over the Union Pacific for the East from San Francisco. The consignment is the entire catch of the Alaska Fur Company for last year, and is bound for England. The time agreed upon for the delivery at destination is eighteen days from San Francisco.

TAMPICO, Mexico, Sept. 3, via Galveston.-- Serious floods prevail here and in the surrounding districts. The water is higher than during the floods last year.
