It was almost a complete revision of the jury laws, especially that part of them which most interests the public by increasing the difficulty of escaping service as a juror. Methods of dodging jury duty had been so numerous that everybody knew of them.

A dispatch from Albany printed in yesterday's TIMES said that, on petition of the Attorney General, Judge Van Brunt had granted an order, returnable Sept. 9, requiring the Equitable Reserve Fund Life Association of this city to show cause why it should not be restrained from doing business and a receiver be appointed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5.--Over 20,000 people took part to-day in the exercises commemorating the beginning of Presbyterian theological education in the United States. The celebration was in a great open field, in tents on the site of the Old Log College, the first Presbyterian theological school in the country, near Hartsville, Bucks County, about twenty-five miles from this city.

Before School Commissioner Gallaway started for Europe on his vacation he left instructions with the Corporation Counsel to discontinue the school-site condemnation proceedings for the Washington, Albany, and Carlisle streets property.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--The extraordinary deadlock over the Chairmanship of the Western States Passenger Association came to a climax to-day.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 5.--The final matches in the tennis tournament were played to-day. The weather was favorable. The first match was the final singles between R. Huntington and Chase. Huntington won in three straight sets, 6--3, 6--3, 6--4, and thus takes first prize in the singles.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 5.--The First Congregational Church of Stratford observed its two hundred and fiftieth anniversary to-day. The Rev. Joel S. Ives delivered the historical address.

The United States corvette Essex is to have her fireroom fitted for forced draught, to be introduced from the ash pan. It has been learned that nearly all the corvertes, as fast as they arrive at the navy yards for repairs, are to be fitted likewise.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The Prohibition State Convention reassembled in Shakespeare Hall at 9 o'clock this morning and was called to order by Prof. Hopkins, the Chairman.

The new crop of bears who smashed the Northern Pacific stocks by a sudden and reckless raid on Wednesday night worked hard to maintain a bold front yesterday, with a result that netted them neither glory nor money.

James M. Aviles and Charles F. Klugkist, composing the firm of Aviles Brothers, dealers in lumber, , at 381 South-street, made an assignment yesterday to George B. Read, Joseph M. Aviles, the senior partner, has been in business here about fifteen years, owned a plantation at Clenfuegos and was the capitalist of the firm, claiming to have about $75,000 in the business.

To gather data for his lectures this Winter to the teachers of New-York, Prof. Albert S. Bickmore of the American Museum of Natural History, started last June on a tour through Alaska, British Columbia, and Washington Territory, and he returned to this city Tuesday well and in excellent spirits after having made such a trip as few men may boast of.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Mayor Cornelius R. Parsons was down on the bills to speak at the liquor dealers' banquet at Ontario Beach this afternoon. He was to respond to the toast "Our Guests." Mayor Parsons did not appear, but sent a telegram of regret instead. Judge E.W. Werner had been assigned to enlighten the rum dealers on the judiciary.

On the present Eastern trip the diamond-field representatives of Indianapolis are making a record of which Hoosiers can justly feel proud. They won two games in Boston, and started with the Giants by making them lower their colors in the opening game played yesterday.

John Schlapfer, a well-known resident of Union Hill, N.J., shot and killed his brother, Jacob Schlapfer, Treasurer of the Weehawken Granite Works, at the residence of the latter, 43 Humboldt-street, on Wednesday night, and then took his own life.

The Executive Committee of the Committee on Site and Buildings of the Columbus Exposition in 1892 got fairly, well started in their work yesterday and managed to cut out some work for the other committees having the big show in charge.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 5.--The Noll Cottage to-day furnished another important link in the new phase of the strange and sensational Hamilton case.

A special meeting of the Board of Police Justices was called for last evening. What it was called for is yet unknown to outsiders, as it was not held. Only seven of the fifteen Justices appeared in the Jefferson Market Court room.

The natural reaction which follows a special day, such as Futurity Day should have been but wasn't, was felt among racegoers at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. The attendance was small, in spite of the fact that Firenzi and Exile were to meet in the race for the New-York Handicap at a mile and a half.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 5.--Twelve States are represented at the Waterways Convention. The permanent officers are: Chairman--Capt. C.M. Holloway of Cincinnati; Secretary--Edwin Stevens of Cincinnati; Assistants--J.W. Bryant of New-Orleans, R.J. Barbour of Kentucky, E. A. Keating of Memphis; vice Presidents--Capt.

The heavy fog that lay upon the East River yesterday morning caused a collision between two steam vessels, and it seemed a miracle that nobody was killed. The vessels were the steamer Providence of the Old Colony Line and Commodore Gerry's steam yacht, the Electra.
Commissioner Reilly looks with favor on the amended bill and hopes that its practical working will show beneficial results. In a talk with a TIMES reporter yesterday he said:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5.--When the case of Deputy Marshal Nagle was resumed to-day in the Federal Court several witnesses who had known Judge Terry for years were examined and their general statements were to the effect that Terry had been in the habit of making idle threats and was regarded as a dangerous man when his passion was aroused.

LONDON, Sept. 5.--Mr.Bradenock, D.G.C. of Orangemen of England, has issued a manifesto inviting Orangemen throughout the kingdom to unite in opposition to Mr. Balfour's scheme for the establishment of a Catholic university in Ireland.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 5.--One of the largest crowds ever seen at Hampden Park came to see the Grand Circuit races this afternoon.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Mayor John Newkirk, whose peculiar actions and extraordinary rulings in Common Council have gained for him a considerable amount of notoriety, issued a circular to-night, which will be delivered through the mails at the houses of taxpayers to-morrow morning.

The big five-story manufactory of Meyer G. Cohen, manufacturer of cloaks and jerseys at 334 Canal-street, extending through to 37 Lispenard-street, was-closed all day yesterday, and Mr. Cohen could not be seen by the many credtiors who called there to find out what was the matter.

This is an extra day at the Sheepshead Bay track, where six races are to be run, and the probabilities are that the last race, for which there are twenty-six entries, will be divided so that there will be seven.
We had expected, when the Treasury statement for the 1st of September was made showing so remarkable an increase in the net debt, that some explanation of it would be afforded.

President Ridgway of the Board of Emigration, accompanied by members of the Castle Garden Committee, went to Ward's Island yesterday to make a re-examination of the cases of the forty-six Syrians who have been detained there recently.
Gen. F.D. Legitime, the big, black fighter whom Hippolyte succeeded in "running out" of the turbulent little "Black Republic," got to New-York yesterday by the Ward Line steamer Manhattan from Cuba.

Several thousand persons were at Jones's Wood, Sixty-seventh-street and East River, yesterday to witness the thirty-third annual games of the Caledonian Club of New-York. Besides athletic contests, which were nearly all between professionals, was a picnic, dancing, and a general social time.

William Gillette arrived in New-York last night from Vermont, bringing with him the completed manuscripts upon which he has been at work during the Summer. One is intended to form the groundwork for a spectacle which Imre Kiralfy is to produce, and illustrates the adventures of some Yankee tourists in a trip around the world.

The National Wool Growers' Association, which is controlled by certain politicians in Ohio, has learned that the National Association of Wool Manufacturers has dared independently to call a meeting to be held on the l7th inst. "for the purpose of maturing and uniting upon a satisfactory schedule of duties upon wool and woolens."
This year's manoeuvres of the British naval forces in home waters have been less fruitful in sensations than those of some Augusts preceding.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--There is no question among the best-informed authorities here that Corporal Tanner has got to go. The only doubt is as to the date of his departure. Late to-night it is reported that his resignation is already in Secretary Noble's hands, having been handed to him this afternoon during a long interview which took place in the Secretary's office.

BOSTON, Sept. 5.--G.H. Fall, a Boston lawyer, has just returned from Bolivia, and brings some valuable information concerning the work done there by W.H. Christy, a Boston man. About four years ago Christy came into possession of the Londres Mine, which has since proven to be one of the richest in the world.

There will be harmony at the Republican State Convention. That is assured. Warner Miller has said it and has caused the men whom Thomas C. Platt has left on guard while he is away to jump with delight.

WALLA WALLA, Washington, Sept. 5.--The Republican Territorial Convention has been in session since 10 A.M. yesterday. On the first ballot ex-Gov. E.P. Ferry of Seattle was nominated for Governor and John L. Wilson for Congress.

Considerable comment is heard in naval circles regarding the controversy recently made public between Naval Constructors Wilson and Bowles. From the fact that Naval Constructor Bowles is a Naval Academy man and the first graduate of that institution to be appointed to the Constructors' Corps, the younger officers are disposed to side with him.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 5.--Mahone not only expects a bountiful supply of money from the Northern Republicans, but counts upon securing the services of some of the ablest speakers of his party in that section during this campaign.
In a town so frequently and at the present time so profoundly agitated as Chicago, the work, of a "Local Agitation Committee" seems superfluous.

The Central Building and Loan Association, 102 Greenwich-avenue, has elected the following officers for the ensuing year: James F. Kenny, President; John J. Cryan, Treasurer; Charles O'Neill, Secretary William J. Nicholson, Attorney; Directors--B.P. Clark, P.O. McCann, Edward Coffey, Joseph W. Nicholson, Max Geyer, C.F. Anderson, and J. Donnelly.

The man whose skull was fractured last Friday morning at Broadway and Thirty-fifthstreet by a blow with a cane in the hands of Henry D. Harrigan, on whom he attempted to commit highway robbery, died yesterday at the New-York Hospital, where he was known as James P. Reedy.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 5.--It Was Burgess against himself in the Autumn races for fortyfooters given to-day by the Eastern Yacht Club and his later design, the Verena, had no trouble in capturing the first prize. The wind was light from the southeast at the start but made several shifts during the day.
LONDON, Sept. 5.--There was a slight break in the ranks of the employers this morning. Five wharfingers agreed to the men's terms, and upon their wharves work is now going on to the full capacity.

The ship Anahuac of Boston, Capt. Whelden, arrived here yesterday after an unusually exciting and dangerous voyage of 133 days from Colombo. Capt. Whelden reports that after leaving Ceylon he had a succession of heavy head seas and winds and was handled very roughly.

About two hundred and fifty members of the Hoboken Turtle Club forseek their old allegiance yesterday and ate clams. They ate them in the style known as a "genuine Rhode Island clambake." Caterer Archie Stalker built a goodsized mound just-south of the club's pavilion at Gabe Case's.

HURON, South Dakota, Sept. 5.--At 1 o'clock this morning the Democratic Convention adopted a platform indorsing and upholding free trade; congratulating the people on Statehood; opposing constitutional prohibition; sympathizing with labor organizations and pledging assistance to them; favoring minority representation, and arraigning Dakota Republicans for extravagance and mismanagement in Territorial affairs.

HARTFORD, Sept. 5.--Gov. Bulkeley has received the resolutions adopted by the Bridgeport Board of Trade in favor of having the World's Fair in 1892 held in New-York City. He has also received a large number of communications from business men in New-Haven in favor of New-York.
If Controller Brinkerhoff of Brooklyn continues in his present frame of mind it will be a long time before the bills run up by the Aldermen on their recent Gettysburg junket are paid.

Mayor Grant, Corporation Counsel Clark, and Commissioner of Public Works Gilrey had a long and earnest conference in the Mayor's office yesterday morning over the question of the refusal of the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company to pay its share as owner of the Fourth-avenue street car line of the expense of repaying the streets along which the line runs.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 6.--The fourth day of the Grand Circuit meeting here was interfered with by rain, so that only one of the three events was finished. After a considerable delay, on account of the water which stood on the track in front of the stand, the 2:17 pacers were called.

HARTFORD, Sept 6.--The Sixteenth Connecticut Regiment, under command of Col. Frank W. Cheney, will have its annual reunion this year on the battlefield at Antietam, the members leaving this city for the front on Saturday, Sept. 14.

Believers in the coal stocks had yesterday another day of glory and profit. Delaware and Hudson sold at the highest figure it has ever touched; so did Lackawanna, so far as the prices of recent years go, and Jersey Central put itself into the same happy category. Reading went up, too.

The feature of to-day's racing will be the race for the Omnium Handicap, at a mile and an eighth, in which Firenzi has a great task set her to carry 130 pounds to victory over a fair field of horses, to each of which she is asked to give lumps of weight.

Passenger train No. 1 on the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad, due at Youngstown, Ohio, at 5 o'clock yesterday morning, was derailed at Pymatuning. A freight train was lying on a siding, and a brakeman at the switch, in a hurry to get his train out, turned the switch.
While the Vesuvius has been preparing for the final test of her pneumatic guns two other methods of using dynamite, explosive gelatine, or other similar substances, have attracted public attention.
BOSTON, Sept. 6.--The Douglas Axe Manufacturing Company--office in Boston at 274 Purchase-street, and factory at Douglas, Mass. --has placed its affairs in the hands of Lawyer Moorefield Storey.

The most interesting athletic event of to-day is the first annual individual athletic championship of the Amateur Athletic Union, to be held on the Brooklyn Athletic Association's grounds. De Kalb and Classon avenues, Brooklyn, at 3 P.M. Seven athletes are entered, and they will compete in ten events, their points counting in any event 5 for first, 3 for second, and 1 for third place. Fishermen, like Summer tourists, are apt to return to the city too early in the Fall and thus miss the pleasantest season for angling. The delightful Autumn weather, when a warm sun makes the day agreeable and cool nights temper the air so that sleeping is a joy for those visiting lakes and ponds, cannot be equaled for fishing.

Wall-street was interested somewhat yesterday in the newspaper dispatches announcing that Attorney General Hogg of Texas had brought a suit to declare fletitious the mortgage bonds issued under the reorganization of the International and Great Northern Railroad Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6.--The President to-day made the following appointments: Minister Resident and Consul General to Bolivia. --THOMAS H. ANDERSON of Ohio.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 6.--The Hon. John F. Lewis of Rockingham County, who at one time represented this State in the United States Senate, and was Lieutenant Governor under Cameron, is out to-day in a ringing letter denouncing Mahone.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept, 6.--President Harrison, accompanied by Postmaster General Wanamaker, left for Washington at 11:27 this morning. The closing of the President's visit to the Postmaster General's Chelton Hills residence was this morning marked by the planting of a tree.

Dr. David Tilton Brown, who hanged himself in his barn at Batavia, Ill., Wednesday night, was very well known to the older members of the medical profession in this State and throughout the country. For twenty years previous to 1875 he was Superintendent of the Bloomingdale Insane Asylum, and was considered an authority on the treatment of insanity.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 6.--Dr. James Hall, who was buried in Greenmount Cemetery this week, was one of the most remarkable men this State ever knew. It was he who planted Maryland's colony in Liberia, and remained a power in African affairs for more than thirty years.

LEWISTON, Idaho, Sept. 6.--The commission, consisting of Gen. Benjamin Simpson, the Hon. J.H. Shoup, and Capt. N.B. Humphrey, who went up some three weeks since to negotiate with the Coeur d'Alene. Indians for the surrender of the mineral and timber lands and navigable waters on their reservation, is making...

New-York's aggregation of baseball talent received another setback yesterday in the shape of a second defeat administered by the representatives of Indianapolis. This time, however, Boston won and to-day the Giants are over a game behind their Eastern rivals. It was a mean exhibition.

SANTA FE, New-Mexico, Sept. 6.--The State Constitutional Convention is fairly down to business and accomplished a great deal of work to-day. The Committee on Elective Franchise made a lengthy report. It provides that six months' residence in the State shall be necessary before a man can vote and no religious test is required.

BUFFALO, Sept. 6.--There has never been any question in the minds of those who knew Carlisle D. Graham well that the story of his trip over Niagara Falls last Sunday was a "fake" pure and simple. Yet, in the face of the fact that one of those who witnessed Sunday morning's performance has exposed the cheat, ...

Out of respect possibly for the crowd of morbid spectators who thronged the steps of the Tombs Police Court yesterday and tried vainly to get inside, Justice Hogan held the examination of wicked little Mrs. Swinton and her rascally son, "Josh" Mann, in the Court of Special Sessions which was large enough to give everybody who wanted one a seat.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 6.--A largely-attended meeting of the Catholic clergy of Baltimore and Washington was held in the library of the cathedral yesterday for the purpose of discussing the details of the November centennial. Cardinal Gibbons presided.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Sept. 6.--J.T. Robinson of Long Island and Capt. William Short of this town were drowned this morning while trying to launch their lifeboats. The surfboats owned by G.G. Stokes were started out on their daily fishing trips for the several hotels here.

It was an off day at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday, only a lot of over-night events being decided, and these were affairs of little or no consequence. The crowd was small, and the racing of the most commonplace character.

Two lumber-laden three-masted schooners ar rived yesterday in command of their mates, who reported that their respective Captains had been lost overboard. In one case there are suspicious circumstances surrounding the loss of the Captain.

The Seidl Society, organized by Brooklyn ladies last June to attend the orchestral concerts under the direction of Anton Seidl at Brighton Beach, Coney Island, this Summer, has incidentally taken up a good deal of philanthropic work, and will continue to do such work.
Bernard Gilday was for some time an agent of the Society for the Prevention of Crime. He gave up that career to make an easier living, and his escapades have got him into hot water.

Prof. Pierre Charles Marie Villa died two days ago at his home, 999 Sixth-avenue. His death, not altogether unlooked for, was due to a complication of diseases, the chief of which was acute bronchitis. While comparatively unknown to the general public, Prof. Villa exercised a wide influence in the circles of the French colony.

The vast majority of the 30,000 citizens of New-York who are personally and directly interested in the changes in the jury law which will go into effect Oct. 1 gained their first information respecting these important amendments from yesterday's TIMES.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 6.--At an early hour this morning Timothy Stocking, a faro dealer in the Arcade gambling hall, shot and instantly killed Billy Murphy, an ex-convict from the Joliet Penitentiary. The story leading up to the murder is something of a romance.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 6.--The Common Council chamber and the large hallway on one side and rooms on the other side were crowded with spectators to-night in the expectation of witnessing scenes similar to those enacted last Friday night.
There is at present a strong party among the Roman Catholic clergy in favor of promoting CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS to the rank of sainthood.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 6.--A party of NewYorkers is expected to arrive here to-morrow morning to examine into the advantages of this port for safe and profitable investment.

PIERCE CITY, Mo., Sept 6.--The jury returned a verdict of not guilty in the case of the State of Missouri against Father Hynes. This was the case of malicious mischief for breaking the stile at the Catholic cemetery of which Father Hynes had had control for ten years.

Visions of a life of travel and adventure have dwelt in the minds of fifteen-year-old Charles Smith and sixteen-year-old Edward Gibbs, two Brooklyn boys, for a long time. Charles lives with his father and mother at 42 Heywardstreet and Edward lives just across the street at 61.

Reports that pleuro-pneumonia had attacked some of the finest herds of imported cattle in Bay Shore, L.I, and that a good many animals had been killed to prevent the spread of the disease were printed in a Brooklyn newspaper yesterday. Nine cattle belonging to Frank C. Lawrence, Jr., the story went on, had been killed on account of tuberculosis.

There was a lively time yesterday afternoon when the Sheriff's officers sought to get possession of the big manufactory of Meyer G. Cohen, cloaks and jerseys, at No. 37 Lispenard-street, and the genial Deputy Sheriff Kaufman, who had charge of the case, was rather roughly handled.

Henry W. Genet, known as "Prince Hal" in his palmy days, one of the members of the Tweed Ring, died at his residence at 100 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street at 9:50 o'clock yesterday morning.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Provisions were inclined to drag a little to-day. Hutchinson took care of October Pork and Armour of September Short Ribs, but in the general trade there was no freedom or feature.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 6.--Asbury Park was amazed this morning when it was announced that Voorhees De Hart, a son of Gen. De Hart of New-Brunswick, had eloped with the wife of James R. Prayne of Philadelphia.

RALKIGH, N.C., Sept. 6.--No secret organization, no matter what its object, has ever attained the numbers or the influence in public affairs, or in the agricultural and commercial interests of the State, that is now possessed by the organization known as the Farmers' Alliance.

NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 6.--The United States steel cruiser Yorktown was under way at 5 o'clock this morning, and a half hour later was speeding over the harbor in the direction of the measured mile course.

The Commissioner of Public Works is doing a public service in attempting to hold the private corporations that use the public streets to their obligations toward the city.

An attachment was issued by Presiding Justice Van Brunt of the Supreme Court against the property in this State of Perres Dickinson of Knoxville, Tenn., in favor of M.L. Woods and J.C. Fay, Messrs. Woods and Fay have a claim of $24,048 against Dickinson for legal services rendered between July, 1885 and September 1888, in litigation in the United States Court of Claims.

There was an interesting meeting yesterday afternoon in the parlors of the Presbyterian Mission Rooms, at 53 Fifth-avenue, in honor of a number of missionaries and teachers who will sail on the Servia for Liverpool to-day, en route for Beyrout, Syria.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 7.--The celebration of Guilford's two hundred and fiftieth anniversary will begin to-morrow with a historical service in the Congregational church at Madison, originally a part of the town of Guilford.

BERLIN, Sept. 7.--The approach of the opening of the final session of tha Reichstag is causing all parties to ask what form of policy the Government is likely to take on which to go before the country.

A story comes from Japan of the recovery of a picture painted over a thousand years ago (in 859 A.D.) by Kanaoka, the father of Japanese pictorial art. It represents a figure about two feet high, every detail being finished with the elaborate care lavished by the old Japanese masters on their choicest works.

The Fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club was sailed yesterday over whitecaps in a piping breeze. There were sixteen starters, but excepting the Clara and the Liris all the noted fliers were absent.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 7.--This season is making a strenuous effort to hold out longer than usual hereabout, and is succeeding pretty well.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 7.--The public excitement over the flight of Dana, the trusted Treasurer of the Douglass Axe Company, was greatly increased to-day when it became known that one of his sons had disappeared with him. The son's name is William D. Dana, and although he is but twenty-four years old, he has been for some time the Assistant Superintendent of the works at East Douglass.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7.--Senators and Representatives elect to the Fifty-first Congress may now intelligently arrange their plans for the next three months, the President having at last decided that it would be inexpedient to call a special session of Congress.

LONDON, Sept. 9.--O'Connor was beaten to-day as completely and with as seeming ease as if he had been an amateur, although, in fact, his time over the course was the best ever made, barring that of his competitor.

"Shenandoah," an interesting drama dealing with the romantic side of life in the South during the civil war, was received at the Star Theatre last night with a great demonstration of approval. Mr. Bronson Howard, the author, was called before the curtain twice during the evening and cheered vociferously; but the best tributes he received were the tears and laughter evoked by his play.

The Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, at the regular monthly meeting of the board yesterday afternoon, resolved to take steps looking to the immediate improvement of the approaches and the enlargement of the traffic facilities of the bridge.

Apparently without any trouble the Giants won a game from their Cleveland opponents on the Pole Grounds yesterday afternoon. After the third inning the New-Yorks won as they pleased. They took the lead at what stage and held it throughout the contest. To add to his unsteadiness, Gruber, who pitched for Cleveland, was hit hard and often, while Keefe handled the ball in a skillful manner.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9.--The police of Newark and the Hudson County authorities are making strong efforts to unravel the mystery surrounding the murder of Frank Avedios, the bootblack whose body was found on the Pennsylvania gravel docks, at Harrison, on Sunday morning.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 9.--The September term of the County Court and Court of Sessions convened this afternoon, and the Assembly ceiling fraud was brought to the attention of the Grand Jury. County Judge John C. Nott and Justices Edgar Powell and Peter H.C. Low were upon the bench.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 9.--The dressed-beef Senatorial investigation commitee began its session here this morning in the parlors of the Midland Hotel. Senators Manderson and Farwell had not arrived at the hour of assembling, but Chairman Vest and Members Plumb and coke were promptly on hand, and after being formally called to order, the investigation began.

LONDON, Sept. 9.--The race on the Thames for 1,000 and the championship of the world, over a course four miles and three furlongs long, between William O'Connor, champion oarsman of the United States and Canada, and Henry E. Searle, the Australian, was rowed to-day, and was won by Searle by six lengths. His time was 22:42. The course was well kept.

Mr. GLADSTONE in his old age often exhibits the capacity noted by MACAULAY of Mr. GLADSTONE in his youth. He has still a great command of sonorous but somewhat vague verbiage. Nobody can say a thing more plainly and forcibly, and on the other hand nobody can use language of which the meaning is susceptible of more various interpretations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--It seems that although a great deal of matter has been published about the Cronin murder, the true story of the discovery of evidence at the Carlson cottage has never been told until now.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--The Republican National Committee is making a bid for the votes and influence of the cattle growers in Montana at the coming election by sending out thousands of copies of a pamphlet published in the interest of protective duties on importations of hides.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9.The six days' celebration of the anniversary of the defense of Baltimore in our second war with Great Britain commenced here today. The events to be celebrated were of national importance, and the fact that one of them, the bombardment of Fort McHenry, inspired that patriotic outburst in song.

Millie Hamilton, a married negress whose husband is an aqueduct laborer, came to town last evening to visit Gussie Hall, also colored and married, at 193 Prince-street, and they drank beer until they quarrelled, and Mrs. Hamilton began a light by striking Mrs. Hall with a glass so as to cut her lip and forehead.

There was a notable horse sale in the Central Park Riding Academy yesterday. It was not judiciously advertised for some unexplained reason, and did not attract the usual representative collection of buyers. The assemblage was of a motley character, the arrangements were not first-class, and the bidding was dispiriting to the auctioneer at times.

Behrens, who lives on Vanderbiltavenue, between One Hundred and Seventy fourth and One Hundred and Seventy-fifth streets, came down town yesterday to ask his lawyer what he could do to prevent the contractor who is excavating the cut for the Harlem Railroad from dumping any more of the dirt in front of the Behrens residence.

ALBANY, Sept. 9.--The grand circuit trotting began here this afternoon with a free opening day, which served to draw a big crowd to Island Park. There were only two events on the programme, but they furnished lively sport and occupied the entire afternoon.

The public schools were all reopened yesterday after the Summer vacation. The teachers and children looked bright after their long rest, and study was resumed with zest. The attendance at the public schools this year, it is estimated, will be increased by some 10,000, making an ageregate of about 300,000 scholars.

The Baptist pastors yesterday held their first regular weekly meeting since the Summer vacation in the basement of the Twenty-thirdStreet Church. The order of the day was the giving of vacation reminiscences.

The United States steel cruiser Atlanta left the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday morning shortly after 8 o'clock, and under an easy head of steam forged down the East River, past the Battery, and out into the bay.

Yesterday's stock market had nothing sensational in it. A marked buoyant tendency was kept in check by realizing sales on a fairly large scale, induced by dispatches from the West announcing new discord among the Granger railways. Bearish room traders made much of this and worked earnestly to bring about a slump.

Tickets to the annual championships of the Amateur Athletic Union, to be held Saturday on the New-York Athletic Club's grounds at Travers Island, are now for sale at the New-York Athletic Club's house, 104 West Fifty-fifth-street, and the Manhattan Athletic Club's headquarters, 524 Fifth-avenue. The price for transportation by steamer from East Thirty-second-street to Travers Island and return, and also admission to the games, are only $1.

The Social Science Congress at Saratoga has adjourned, having subserved its purpose of letting one-half the world know what the other half is thinking about. The work of the association has, perhaps, been somewhat narrowed by the secession of bodies occupied with certain special subjects, such as history and finance.

William Terriss and Miss Millward, of all the foreign stars who are to appear in this country this season, are the only ones who will present a new play adapted by an American. LENOX, Mass., Sept. 9.--The Sloanes gave a magnificent ball this evening, which was the greatest society event of the season. A small dinner party, to which twenty or thirty people were invited, preceded the ball, which took place in the new ballroom. This oocasion was really the first time the new ballroom has been used since it was completed.

The bears showed more courage in yesterday's stock market than they have dared to display in a long while. They made attacks upon the whole list, but affected but few stocks, and those that did yield went off only fractionally. Though recently talking with a good deal of philosophy about its being time for a "healthy reaction," the bull leaders fought with determination against every bear onslaught.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--The September crop report of the Department of Agriculture makes the general average of corn 91, a reduction of nearly 5 points; of Winter wheat, when harvested, $9.4, from 92 on the 1st of July; of Spring wheat 83.9, an increase from 81.2 in August.

To naval officers the non-arrival of the Atlanta at Newport is regarded as a very serious matter. The cruiser left this port on Monday morning, taking the outside passage around Montauk Point. The weather was overcast and cloud when she put to sea, and through the Narrows the waves were rolling in a most threatening manner.

The first meeting of the Union League Club since the Summer hegira, was held last night. The attendance was not very large, and as there was no business of importance to be considered, President Depew was requested to give the members present an account of his recent visit to Europe.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 12.--The United States steamer Standish, Boatswain John Sinclair commanding, was lying in the Chesapeake Bay off Thomas Point, at anchor without a rudder, in a bad way.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., Sept. 12.--All day long the wind has blown furiously from the eastward, and the prospects are that it will continue to blow hard all night.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Sept. 12.--Two hundred and fifty of Gen. E. Bird Grubb's old regiment, the Thirty-seventh New-Jersey, assembled at his residence here at 11 o'clock this morning. After a business meeting a luncheon was served in the bowling alley. The festivities and speechmaking continued nearly all day.
ANTWERP, Sept. 12.--Nothing remains of the cartridge factory in which the explosion occurred on Friday last.

The storm which broke upon this city on Tuesday morning and continued Wednesday and yesterday with increasing severity is remarkable in several particulars. It extends along the coast from Virginia to Maine. The storm centre, which was off the coast of Virginia at the beginning, has remained stationary, and the wind and rain have only changed by getting worse.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 12.--Detailed reports of the great storm along the Atlantic coast received in this city show that in the vicinity of the Delaware Breakwater it was the most disastrous in its effects ever known. Nearly thirty vessels have been wrecked and the lives of fifty seamen have been sacrificed to the fury of the gale.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12.--Mr. George Jones, who has been the nucleus of the National Greenback Party for some time, has been here several days making arrangements for the holding of a National Convention of that party here to-day.

Oliver A. Samuelson, a painter, living at 80 Skillman-street, Brooklyn, tried to kill his daughter, Ada, yesterday morning, then fired one-shot at a young man who was hastening to the rescue, and, finally, fired a bullet into his own breast and, cut his throat with a penknife.

A generation ago the duelist was a man respected and admired; to-day he is a laughingstock. Then the duel was a tragedy; now it is a farce. PANAMA, Sept. 5.--An idea of the produce business of Guatemala is given by the statement now made that during the past three months of the present year 78,552 hend of cattle; sheep, and hogs were slaughtered in the republic; that 1,842,935 pounds of four of native production and 242,000 pounds of imported brands were sold.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--Naval officers here and others who have had to do with constructing naval vessels find much to encourage their faith in the American navy and console them for what appeared to be bad failures in marine architecture in the report of the latest English naval manceuvres, which has just reached the department.

Alderman Christian Goetz of the Eighth Assembly District, who had been on trial for two days, for bribing Louis Lewis, a voter at the last election, was yesterday acquitsed of the charge. NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 14.--The delegates elected last evening at the Republican primaries called to choose representatives to the State Convention are all in favor of John Kean, Jr., for Governor. Mr. Kean is the retiring Congressman from the Third District. His name will be presented by the Middlesex delegation unless Union desires the honor.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 14.--Reports from Alaska, just received, give the salmon pack at 371,000 cases. In view of the fact that three weeks ago the pack was considered nil, this is a good showing. The salmon did not begin to run until the fall rains began. The season is about over, so that there will be very few more fish packed--not enough to materially alter the above figures.

FIRE ISLAND, Sept. 3.--Fire Island Light plays an important part in the navigation of our coast. The great European steamers lay their course for this light when they cross the ocean, and vessels coming up along the southern coast first try to sight the revolving light on the Fire Island beach, and then to keep in view the other lighthouses, which are scattered in a row all along the New-England coast.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 14.--A United States mail agent named Textore, who runs on the Southwest Pennsylavania Road between Pittsburg and Fairchance, Penn., was arrested by a United States Inspector this morning for robbing the mails. BAYSHORE, L.I., Sept. 14.--A race between pleasure boats of Great South Bay for prizes offered by the Great South Bay Yacht Club took place to-day. There were two classes--sloops and catboats. GETTYSBURG, Penn., Sept. 15.--One hundred and twenty members of the Sixteenth Connecticut Infantry arrived here to-day on a special excursion train. They will inspect the battlefield to-morrow and leave for Antietam. The party is from Hartford, New-Haven, and New-Britain.

Mr. Augustin Daly is home again after a five weeks' trip to London and Paris. He returned yesterday on the Aurania, and his personal appearance corroborates his statement that the trip was highly beneficial to his physical condition.

Peaches will be poor and plenty for a few days. On Saturday the market was overloaded with windfalls, and there were scarcely any peaches to be had that were in an undamaged condition. Miss Christine Lamoureaux, of Philadelphia, has commenced suit against William Ames to recover $25,000 for breach of promise. Mr. Ames is one of the chief men interested in the Ames Spike Works, at Washington and Steuben streets, Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15.--During the present Administration a great change will take place in the personnel of the commanding officers of the army. President Harrison will have had to appoint nine Brigadier Generals.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 15.--John K. Hallock has worked out a design for a grand exposition building which has already received wide indorsement within the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, in which he is a Fellow, and which his friends and neighbors believe will place Erie high in favor for the honor of furnishing the engineering designs for the World's Fair of 1892.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 15.--The hotel corridors are well filled to-night by hundreds of strangers who are here to "do" the great Inter-State Fair which opens in this city to-morrow morning and continues two weeks.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15.--The advance returns of the Bureau of Statistics of the United States give some information about the export trade to Canada during the year that ended June 30, 1889. In nearly all articles of commerce a substantial increase of sales appears to have taken place.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 15.--To-day Walter G. Campbell of Youngstown, N.Y., made the trip through the rapids of the Niagara gorge below the Falls. If Campbell wanted the officers to stop him he was disappointed, for he was left free to go or not, as he chose.

NORTH RIVER, Warren County, N. Y., Sept. 15.--Recent editorials in THE TIMES concerning the Adirondack wilderness have aroused the deepest interest in this county. HARTFORD, Sept. 15.--A rare and fine violin of the great master Nicolaus Amati, made in 1674, is a welcome addition to the limited stock of genuine Cremonas owned in this city. It is an old work of art, and is now owned by Mr. A. H. Pitkin.

LONDON, Sept. 15.--Discount was easy during the past week at 3 for three months, and 2 for short. The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 4. Business on the Stock Exchange during the week was dull.

Police Superintendent Campbell of Brooklyn is working very hard to run down a gang of swindlers who have been carrying on opera tions under the firm name of Horace Walters Son. They claim to be bankers and to have an office at 72 Arch-street, Brooklyn.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15.--Bamberger, Bloom Co.'s establishment, one of the three largest wholesale dry goods and notion houses in Louisville, was destroyed by fire to-night. The fire at midnight was still raging.

PARIS, Sept. 15.--The race for the Omnium Stakes (French Cesarewitch) was run to-day and was won by Amazon by a length and a half. Tirelarigot was second, two lengths ahead of Achille, third. Eighteen ran. The last betting was 20 to 1 against Amazon, 20 to 1 against Tirelarigot, and 5 to 1 against Achille.

SANTA FE, New-Mexico, Sept. 15.--In the State Constitutional Convention yesterday the discussion of the article submitted by the Committee on Judicial Department was continued.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 15.--It is announced that negotiations have not yet been entered into between England and the United States for the settlement of the Atlantic fishery question.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15.--When the curtain fell at the Chicago Opera House last evening, it marked not only the close of what is said to have been the longest run ever enjoyed by a theatrical attraction in Chicago, but with it disappeared the last vestige of the Summer season of 1889.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15.--A movement is on foot among the passenger men, both east and west of Chicago, to form a gigantic association in which shall be invested the rate-making power or the entire territory between the Atlantic seaboard and the Missouri River.

PARIS, Sept. 16.--The Tribunal of the Seine has decided that the Directors of the Comptoir d'Escompte shall refund the sums claimed by shareholders who purchased shares on the strength of the promises made by the Directors in their report of January last.

This afternoon will see the opening of the Fall meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, and from now until Monday, the 30th inst., there will be six races run daily over this popular track. If the programme for the opening day is a foretaste of what is to come, the meeting will be a surprisingly good one.

Edward Mitchell, the newly-appointed United States District Attorney for the Southern District of New-York, appeared before Judge Benedict yesterday morning and upon presenting his commission was sworn into office.

QUEBEC, Sept. 16.--Capt. Tooker and the officers and crew of the wrecked ship Kinburn have arrived from Point des Neonto on board the steamer Otter. Capt. Tooker reports that his vessel went ashore at night in a dense fog. He attributes the accident to the action of the currents and the fog.
Daniel Kiernan, who is said to earn $4 a day, has lived with his wife and three children in a squalid tenement at 595 Grove-street, Jersey City.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 16.--The weekly bulletin of the Weather Bureau here, issued today, gives complete records of the damage by the recent storms, especially to crops. The rainfall for the week was greatly in excess of the average, ranging from 2.86 inches at Morristown to 8.64 inches at Egg Harbor City.

The modified plan of the extension to be issued to creditors of the Wauregan and Nottingham Mills and of Edward P. Taft of Providence, R.I., has been prepared under the direction of the creditors' committee and is in the hands of the printers. It will be sent to the creditors individually to-morrow.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16.--Charles Osborne, five years old, fell from a third-story window this morning at 132 South Twenty-third-street, and was badly injured.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16.--The Rev. William J.R. Taylor last of night resigned the pastorate of the Clinton-Avenue Reformed Church. The trouble was that he had been asked to accept a reduced salary.

Straw hats suffered on the Produce Exchange yesterday, and very many members will appear this morning with new derbys. Straw hats and white hats are not in season on the Exchange after the 15th of September, but as the 15th came on Sunday this year the pleasantries which emphasize the retirement of Summer headgear did not take place until yesterday.

MACON, Sept. 16.--THE TIMES'S correspondent is here to-night, after a long hunt over the State to catch up with Legislators Huff and Patterson, the would-be duelists. Huff was at his home here this morning, away from the Legislature, and Patterson spent the forenoon in the Atlanta Assembly.

KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 16.--The weather here is rainy, stormy, and very threatening. The centre of the cyclone is expected to pass near here after midnight. All shipping has gone up into Hurricane Harbor for a more secure anchorage.

The M.J. Quigley Association of 52 Springstreet will not undertake the management of another chowder party for a long time. They perfected arrangements for a visit on Sunday to New-Dorp, S.I., and the Annex Ferry steamer R.P. James started with the champion Quigley chowder eaters from the foot of Broome-street at 10 A.M.

The steamship Alvo, which arrived from Savanilla yesterday, brought as a passenger E. Prophete, a brother of Gen. Anselm Prophete, recently Legitime's Minister of Finance. Affairs at Port au Prince are reported to be improving under the direction of Hippolyte.

LONDON, Sept. 16.--Most of the strikers resumed work this morning. It is expected that work on all the docks will be in full swing tomorrow. A thousand unemployed dock laborers are waiting at the gates of the docks.

William M. Ivins, ex-City Chamberlain, has retired from the firm of W.R. Grace Co., with which he has been connected as a partner for some years. The partnership expired by limitation, and Mr. Ivins will now devote his time exclusively to the practice of law and to the management of his personal affairs. He has taken offices at 40 and 42 Wall-street.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 16.--Mrs. Elizabeth R. Russell of this city is about to bring suit against James A. Bradley, the founder of Asbury Park, for $25,000 damages for false imprisonment.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 16.--The New-York Turn Verein under command of Col. Hermann Benecke gave an exhibition of a sham battle at Savin Rock to-day.

The reference case of the Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge against property owners on Park-row who are in the way of proposed improvements, and whose land the Trustees accordingly seek to have condemned, was begun yesterday before Emmet R. Olcott at his office, 35 Broadway.

OTTAWA, Sept. 16.--Lord Stanley, Governor General, Lady Stanley, and the Viceregal party leave here to-morrow on a trip over the Canadian Pacific Railway to the Pacific coast. An elaborate programme has been prepared, as it is the Governor's first tour in the West.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Ill., Sept. 16.--A race war between whites and blacks occurred here Saturday night. A few days ago a St. Louis negro named "Slick" came to town, and Saturday afternoon, in a quarrel with a white man, he attacked him with a knife.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 16.--On account of unfavorable weather to-day the attendance at the opening of the great Inter-State Fair was rather light. The prospects for a large attendance during the week are good, however, as the railroad companies have arranged for numerous excursions from all directions.

AUCKLAND, Sept. 16.--The Tonga steamer Wainui has brought to this port the Captain and crew of the British ship Garston, Capt. Davies, from Sydney, N.S.W., for San Fancisco, which foundered in mid-ocean. The shipwrecked sailors were twenty-two days in an open boat without food or water.

The twenty-fifth convention of the Cigarmakers' International Union was begun yesterday morning at Tammany Hall. There were present about one hundred and thirty delegates from various parts of the United States and also from Canada.

Representatives of the Presbyterian churches of New-York, at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the lecture room of the Fourteenth-Street Presbyterian Church, thought it best to change the date of the annual Presbytery meeting. The pilot boat Ambrose Snow came up the bay in safety yesterday morning and anchored off Stapleton at 6 o'clock. She has the last of the pilot fleet to arrive since the great gale and considerable anxiety had been felt about her. The event proved that the Snow is a very stanch craft and can weather about any storm that blows.

George W. Lyon, the new Surveyor of the Port, will probably enter on has duties in a day or two. WASHINGTON, Sept. 16.--Secretary Tracy sent a dispatch to ex-Secretary Whitney to-day, saying that he could not refrain from congratulating him on the success of the Baltimore. "Permit me to congratulate you," he said, "on the magnificent performance of the Baltimore."

CHICAGO, Sept. 16.--The Rev. Charles H. Fowler, D.D., of San Francisco, a Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, who has just completed a trip around the globe, this morning expressed the belief that ten years hence America would pay for its anti-Chinese laws with the blood of her citizens.

The meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Club at the Hoffman House last night was not largely attended, but it was livelier than such meetings usually are. Col. A.H. Rogers was present, and made a strong effort to enlist the club in his contemplated crusade against the Street-Cleaning Department. The club would not enlist, although it joined him in deploring the employment of pauper labor in any city de partment.

Two of the transatlantic cables of the Western Union Telegraph Company parted during the storm last week and have not yet been repaired. It was said at the offices of the company yesterday that the accident could not interfere with the business of the company as it still had five cables in perfect working order. The broken cables are to be mended as soon as possible. The break occurred off the Flemish Capes.

There will be no cobwebs in the secret recesses of the Standard Theatre this morning, for that playhouse was struck last night by a melodramatic cyclone which made the rafters shake and set the shingles dancing.

The will of Frank Vincent, ST., of Tarrytown, who died Sept. 6, was filed and proved yesterday in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court. The instrument, which was dated March 23, 1888, gives all the property of the testator, estimated to be worth $60,000, to his family.
As the outcome of the matches shot at Creedmoor during the annual Fall prize meeting of the National Rifle Association, a novel competition has been proposed by Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn.

The Supreme Council of Scottish Rite Masons will begin their annual convocation this morning at 10 o'clock. The members of the council have been coming into the city for the past two days, and the deliberations of this important body of Masonry promise to be of unusual interest.

Upon investigation of the case of John Wood, the fireman whose death on the steamship Cairngorm was reported in yesterday's TIMES. Health Officer Smith concluded that yellow fever symptoms of a decided character were present.
Herman Wolker, a young German living at 207 Frost-street, Brooklyn, made three attempts at suicide on Sunday night but failed to take his life.

TIOGA JUNCTION, Penn., Sept. 16.--About 7:05 P.M. the train from Elmira south on the Tioga Railroad carrying seven coaches ran into a Fall Brook engine at this station, causing a fearful wreck, killing two persons and injuring thirteen.

The body of Edward F. Miller, who was found dead at the foot of a stairway in the Manhattan Hotel, Twenty-eighth-street and Sixth-avenue, lay yesterday in a plain casket at Roth's undertaking establishment, 524 Sixth-avenue.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 16.--The One Hundred and Fiftieth New-York Regiment left town today for Gettysburg, numerous friends accompanying the command.
"Paul Kauvar" drew a large audience lass evening at the Grand Opera House in spite of the heat, and frequent applause followed the falling of the curtain at the end of the different acts.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 16.--Sir William Ritchie, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Canada, and Chief Justice Armour of the Court of Queen's Bench have pronounced themselves in favor of the movement for the establishment of a Dominion divorce court.

Supervisor George Green of the Twenty-second Ward, Brooklyn, was sent to the Kings County Insane Asylum yesterday pending an examination into his mental condition.
The defenses of the Rivers Thames and Medway against naval attack are to be strengthened by the construction of a new earthwork fort at Scarp's Gate, near Sheerness.

The sale of the Spendthrift yearlings was held by Mr. Easton at the American Horse Exchange yesterday. A bay colt, half-brother to Masterpiece, was the pick of the lot, and after some spirited bidding he went to Mr. Charles Reed for $3,025, who sold him again before the sale was over to Charles Taylor, a colored man.

SOMERSET, Penn., Sept. 16.--This community was thrown into the most intense excitement to-day at noon by the escape from the rickety jail of the Nicely brothers, who shot and killed Farmer Umberger, after robbing him of $16,000. Sheriff Rush McMillen had left town early in the morning, taking an insane woman to Dixmont.

About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a middleaged man, apparently a laborer, climbed up the stairs of a Sixth-avenue elevated station. His gait was unsteady and it was evident that he had been drinking more than was consistent with a clear head.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 16.--It is rumored here to-night, and partially confirmed by members of the Grand Jury, that that body has found wholesale indictments against officers of the Raritan River Railroad, charging them with complicity in a murder.

A singular insurance case was brought to the notice of the Vice Chancellor at Jersey City yesterday. M.C.W.C. Britton was a young telegraph operator employed by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

At the Charities Conference yesterday at San Francisco the Rev. C.S. Hoyt of Albany, N.Y., presided. A paper by Dr. W.W. Gooding of Washington, D.C., on "The State in the Care of its Insane," was read and discussed.

After a forced suspension for two months the gambling houses in the Nineteenth Precinct reopened on Monday, and the "tiger" resumed business at the old stands. He was fairly well patronized, although the word had not had time to be extensively circulated.

The annual convocation of the Supreme Council of the Accepted Scottish Rite began yesterday morning at 10 o'clook. It was, consequently, a great day for Masons around Scottish Rite Hall, at Madison-avenue and Twentyninth-street. Masonic chiefs from every quarter have registered their names until there is positively little room left on the big record of arrivals.

In the matter of the dissolving of the injunction restraining the New-England Railroad from erecting sheds,on Pier 46 and adjoining piers on the East River, New-York, the Attorney General has decided to refer the matter back to the courts, and the papers in the case have been sent to Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court.
RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 17.--The storm did not injure the North Shrewsbury River oysters. They were made a little fresh, of course, but this freshness will entirely disappear in two or three days.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17.--A brutal prize fight occurred at the saloon of the Daly Brothers, local bruisers of considerable note, last night, which has resulted in the death of one of the participants Thomas E. Jackson, aged eighteen years, is the victim.

The feature of the trial of Henry S. Ives yesderday was the seathing cross-examination of Edward W. Woodruff, the State's principal witness. The aim of Mr. Ives's counsel, Mr. Brooke, obviously was to show that the witness, whose memory of things favorable to the prosecution's line of evidence had been excellent, was not as ready a source of information on other matters.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 17.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railroad was held in this city this afternoon.

After the defeat of Raceland in the fourth race yesterday Mr. Belmont, the owner of the Suburban winner, Raceland, appeared to be in an unhappy frame of mind. The riding of Garrison, his jockey, did not suit him, and he went to the paddock to see the young man.

William Terries, the English actor, arrived on the Ems yesterday. There are more gray hairs on his head than there were when he was here with Henry Irving six years ago, and he has arrived at that period of life when he tells younger men that something or other happened "before your time, I fancy."

Collector Joel B. Erhardt rendered his decision yesterday in the reappraisement cases of worsted importations from Bradford, England, and as was more than half suspected, sustained the decision or the General Appraiser.

Wind and rain have done a great deal of damage to country produce. The new hay crop especially has suffered greatly. Much hay that was not thoroughly dried has been soaked, and has not only lost its bright color, but in many instances is becoming musty and moldy.

A handsome new steamship, the Port Caroline, of the Anglo-Australasian Line, arrived at this port yesterday for the first time. She left Yokohama on the 4th of July and came through the Red Sea, Suez Canal, and Mediterrenean,...

MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 17.--The Connecticut State Fair opened here to-day and will continue until Friday. These affairs have come to be events of importance in this State. The receipts taken on one day last year amounted to $3,500.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 17.--The New-Jersey State Liquor League held its annual meeting in this city to-day. About three hundred delegates were present from all sections of the State.

The beginning of the end in regard to the selection of a site for the World's Fair was ushered in yesterday when the Committee on Site started out to visit the places that have been most ardently championed.

The Secretary of the Interior has reversed the action of the Commissioner of the General Land Office, who ruled against the Iowa Railroad Land Company, which succeeded to the land grant to the Cedar Rapids and Missouri River Railroad Company. The Secretary decides that the company is entitled to select lauds lying within the indemnity limits of the old unconstructed line east of Cedar Rapids.

What promised to be a day of delightful sport at the Gentlemen's Driving Club yesterday was spoiled by a downpour of rain that drove the crowd to cover and converted the track into a temporary river of mud.
MAY'S LANDING, N.J., Sept 17.--Mrs. Hamilton was too ill to appear in court to-day to plead to the indictment against her for atrocious assault.
The Republican convention which was held at Trenton, N.J., yesterday declared that the canvass of this year is "one of local and State policy only."

In Germany, under the shelter of the socalled protective tariff, competition with respect to prices has been almost entirely suppressed in many important industries by means of combination agreements, commonly called "conventions," the combined producers striving to take full advantage of the tariff duties in their protected home market.
Surrogate Ransom yesterday handed down a decision admitting to probate the will of Edward D. Phyfe, who died in 1888, after spending the last years of his life in hoarding money.
BOSTON, Sept. 17.--Mr. John Stetson's yacht Sapphire came near going to the bottom of Boston Harbor this afternoon, as the result of a collision with a coal barge.

A man who didn't give his name appeared in the office of one of Wall-street's trust companies yesterday and asked to have transferred a bond for $1,000, ostensibly issued by the Wheeling and Cincinnati Mineral Railroad in 1882.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 17--When the Republicans awoke this morning it was to find that Gen. Edward Burd Grubb apparently had not slept at all, but had sat up all night with his very vigorous boom, and had nursed it into a condition of increased vigor.

When the old rag-disinfecting ring was undergoing investigation it was found to be no easy task to discover the actual members of the concern. They had a habit of burrowing, as if they wanted to get out of sight.

HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The Register is authorized to say that Diedrich Willers will not allow his name to be used at the Democratic State Convention as a candidate for the office of Secretary of State or for any other office. His chief reason for this declaration is declining health.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 17.--The Chamber of Deputies was crowded to overflowing last evening by an assemblage interested in witnessing the opening of the third period of sessions of the Eleventh Congress.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 17.--The will of the late Prof. Ellas Loomis, which was made public today, bequeaths the bulk of his estate, which is valued at from $250,000 to $300,000, to Yale University to be known as the "Loomis Fund."

HARTFORD, Sept. 17.--The violation of the public statutes in this State relating to birth, marriage, and death returns has become so serious that the State Board of Health has taken the matter in hand and will enforce the penalties hereafter.
Preliminary work was done in Clarendon Hall yesterday afternoon to form the American Protective Union of Piano and Organ Manufacturers. Bill Bill of the Music Trade Review issued the call.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 17.--To-day's single session of the Constitutional Convention was the stormiest yet held. Campbell of Laramie and Coffeen of Spridan, Democratic leaders, locked horns on the woman suffrage plank.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17.--A very heavy rain fell for a few minutes this evening, about 6 o'clock. The water came down in torrents. Within ten minutes the streets were running streams.
Charles McElvaine, Thomas Quinian, and "Murty" Dennin or Deneen, the man indicted for the murder of Grocer Luca, were arraigned in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept. 17.--George W. Chandler, aged forty-five years, a well-known citizen, left home with his horse as usual yesterday morning. Last evening his horse was found, wandering about Methuen, and this morning Chandler's body was found under a culvert near a brook, with his head partly submerged in two feet of water, he having committed suicide. No cause is known for the suicide.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The Chicago Times will print to-morrow morning a story which puts in explicit form the vague charges current for some time concerning misapplication of Clanna-Gael funds by the Secretary of that organization. Thomas H. Ronayne of New-York.
The Committee of Twenty-four of Tammany Hall held a pow-wow in the wigwam yesterday to have a "heap talk" over the Syracuse Convention.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 17.--Considerble interest is felt in this city in the fate of Charles Giblin, who is now awaiting the execution of his death sentence in New-York.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 17.--At the meeting of the State League of Republican Clubs in this city next week a resolution asking Congress to repeal the civil Service act will be offered for passage. This proposition comes from the eastern end of the State.

The Austrian military authorities have determined that the Fall manoeuvres of the First Army Corps should not be witnessed by the military attaches of any country except those identified with the Triple Alliance.

LYNN, Mass., Sept. 17.--The steamer Centipede, Capt. Hanson, from Philadelphia for Lynn, with coal, arrived here this morning. From the 8th to the 14th she lay inside the Delaware Breakwater, held by the violence of the gale. On Monday, the 9th inst., she dragged her anchors violently, and her engine was started to prevent her going ashore.

Two Austro-Hungarians, a glazier and his wife, who arrived yesterday at Castle Garden, evinced a most remarkable and complete trust in the Deity. They had no money whatever and but trifling bits of personal property.

BOSTON, Sept. 17.--The Executive Committee of the National Association of Wool Manufact urers, with some invited members, have been in secret conference here to-day. There were about forty present, President William Whitman in the chair.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The American Cable Railway Company doing business in New-York filed suits against both the North and South Side Cable Railways of this city this morning in the United States Circuit Court.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 17.--When the Democratic State Committee met recently at Des Moines, a Sioux City man came in smiling with the proxies of the two absentees. As a result of that incident, this town got six out of eleven votes as the place for holding the convention, and that is why this town is overflowing with Democrats to-night.

George W. Lyon, the new Surveyor of the Port, called at the Custom House yesterday and got acquainted. First he saw the Collector, whom he has known for some time. Then he was introduced to Surveyor Beattle, whom he had never met.

LOWVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The Lewis County Republican Convention in this village to-day was a harmonious gathering. Every town in the county was fully represented except Osceola. Delegates were elected to the State Convention as follows: H.A. Phillips, J.D. Paris, W.D. Lewis, C.E.B. Williams, and C.S. Mereness. No preferences were expressed.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 17.--The defeat of exCongressman John Kean, Jr., for the Gubernatorial nomination was a severe disappointment to his friends in this city, who had confidently boasted that he was certain of being nominated.

HARTFORD, Sept. 17.--The Standard Oil Company has obtained permission from the Court of Common Council of this city to erect one of its warehouses here for the storage of oil.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 17.--Capt. P.W. McKinney, the Democratic nominee for Governor, is in the city this evening, on his way to Hanover Court House, where he speaks to-morrow. He is in excellent health and fine voice.

It is now a pretty well authenticated fact that Health Officer Smith was not any too careful in detaining the sick man who arrived on Monday as a passenger on the steamship Hondo, from Greytown, Nicaragua.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The miserably poor grading of current arrivals here of wheat is attracting widespread attention, and there do not appear to be many persons, in the trade who can offer a satisfactory explanation of the existing state of affairs.

Virginia L. Wagner, a teacher in the primary department of Public School No. 45, Brooklyn, mysteriously disappeared on the morning of July 3. She was about twenty-three years old, quite tall, of dark complexion, passionately devoted to music, a bright conversationalist, graceful in her movements, and winning in her manner.

ALBANY, Sept. 17.--The Republican primaries were held to-day in the First, Second, and Third Assembly Districts. A larger vote than usual was polled, and everything passed off harmoniously.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 17.--Great excitement prevailed among the city officials here this morning when it was discovered that the Pennsylvania Railroad Company had begun to tear up a portion of Railroad-avenue.

Chicago is still sending woebegone dispatches to Wall-street. Not very much result, however, attends this latest effort of the Western stock jobbers to put down prices. The Granger stocks, against which, of course, this new campaign is directed, have so far declined to go down.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17.--The fact that the Pension Office is a bureau of the Interior Department and the Commissioner of Pensions subject to the control of the Secretary of that department does not suit the men who want to ran the pension business according to their own notions.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 17.--Members of Assembly were nominated by the Republicans of St. Lawrence County to-day as follows: First District, Gen. N.M. Curtis of Ogdensburg, renominated; Second District, William H. Kimball of Canton, renominated; Third District, William Bradford of Louisville.

Capt. Bayard Thayer's thirty-six-foot Burgess boat Papoose went off the ways at New-London Monday, and has gone to Newport to race the forties on Friday. Her competitors will probably be the Liris, Gorilla, Mariquita, and Nymph.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Sept. 17.--Four NewYork State monuments were dedicated in the rain to-day. In the morning the One Hundred and Fiftieth Infantry assembled on the southeastern side of Culp's. Hill, where their memorial is erected. Gen. Ketcham presided.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept 16.--The case of Mary Glynn of Pittston was called in the criminal court to-day. She is accused of poisoning her mother, Mrs. Mary Creaghan of Seranton, and also of being implicated in poisoning her father-in-law anted her mother-in-law some months ago.
BOSTON, Sept. 17.--For five innings-to-day the Philadelphia players held the Bostons down to no runs, while through an error by Quinn they had scored 1 run in the second inning.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 17.--A large number of curiosities from the frozen north were brought home on the whaling schooner Era, Capt. Spices, which arrived here yesterday with oil from Cumberland Inlet.

BOSTON, Sept. 17.--The ship South American of Boston, Capt. Connolly, from Iloilo for NewYork with sugar, was totally wrecked at Struys Bay, Cape Agulhas, South Africa, on the 15th inst. The crew are reported to have been saved. The ship was owned by Henry Hastings Co. She was 1,762 tons register, and considered the finest wooden ship afloat.

The candidates for positions on the Columbia College football team who have been in training at Erastina, S.I., since Sept. 11 have been greatly hampered by the recent rains and have not made as rapid progress with the ball as they have wished.

DETROIT, Sept. 17.--The Detroit International Fair and Exposition was formally opened this morning by Gov. Luce. The grounds, which cover about seventy acres of land, are handsomely laid out in terraces and walks.

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The Kemmler case came up before Judge Day to-day, who heard arguments on the evidence taken by Referee Becker. Bourke Cockran of New-York and Charles Hatch of Buffalo appeared for Kemmler, and Attorney General Tabor and Assistant Kennepick of Buffalo for the people. Referee Becker and Dr. Southwick of Buffalo were also present.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--The case of Huiskamp against J.J. West, ex-editor of the Chicago Times, and his Secretary, Graham, came up before Justice Brayton this morning.

HARTFORD, Sept. 18.--The total number of deaths in Connecticut during the month of August was 1,190, being 243 less than for the corresponding month in 1888 and 139 less than in July.
The loyal Republicans of the Eighth Assembly District met last night at 280 Broome-street and signalized their advent into the political world by electing J. Scheurmer President.

CAPE HAYTIEN, Hayti, Sept. 11.--Since the abdication and flight of Legetime affairs in Hayti have been comparatively quiet, and until the history of this republic takes its natural course and repeats itself there is every reason to believe that they will continue so.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 18.--Louis and Elizabeth Messman are wanted in Rockland County, N.Y., to claim a large fortune left them by the death of their father.

Expenses-- 1888, $1,148,414; 1889, $1,236,525; increase, $88,111. Net--1888, $807,036; 1889, $869,792; increase, $62,756.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 18.--The fact that there is to be a lawsuit over the will of the late John Guy Vassar is established. William Maxwell, who is wanted in Baltimore for obtaining money under false pretenses, was arrested in Brooklyn a few days ago and yester day he was arraigned before Justice Cullen in the Supreme Court.

LONDON, Sept. 18.--Speaking at a political meeting at Huddersfield last evening, Mr. Joseph Chamberlain predicted that "the alliance between the Liberal-Unionists and Conservatives would continue until the agitation in favor of the separation of England and Ireland was killed."

Yesterday was a typical Brooklyn Jockey Club day--stormy, muggy, wet, and disagreeable in every way for both horses and racegoers. The track was sloppy on top and heavy and holding underneath, the most, trying possible kind of a track for a horse to run on.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 18.--Gen. T.J. Morgan called the meeting of the Army of the Cumberland to order to-day, Gen. Rosecrans being indisposed. The meeting was opened by prayer by the Rev. G.W. Dumbell.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18.--The cruiser Chicago finished her speed trials to-day, and made the lowest speed of any of her trials.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The Third District Democratic Convention of Oneida County, held at Clayville to-day, named J.C. Greenman, S. J. Barrows, and D.A. Dishier as delegates to the State Convention.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The John Crouse Memorial College for Women was to-day presented to the Trustees or Syracuse University by D.E Crouse, son of the donor of the building, who is dead.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 18.--At 3 o'clock this afternoon Dr. Patton delivered his second annual address of welcome to the college students assembled in Marquand Chapel. His address was not long, but just what every son of Princeton wanted to hear.

Among the many prominent men named as the probable Republican candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn one frequently mentioned is exMayor Frederick A. Schroeder. A petition askking him to accept has been in circulation for several week, and hundreds of names have been signed to it.

The United States frigate Kearsarge, Commander Shepard, arrived yesterday from Cape Haytien. She carries a complement of 200 men, including officers, and mounts 8 guns. She reports fine weather on the voyage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--The Giants took two games from the Senators to-day. They worked hard for the first one, but the second was easy. In the first game the two Keefes were pitted against each other, and up to the tenth inning both were equally effective.

Louis Straus, banker at 15 William-street, made an individual assignment yesterday, without preference, to Charles B. Storrs, lawyer, of 120 Broadway. Mr. Straus was the senior partner of the firm of Louis Straus Co. of New York, Boston, and Philadelphia. He started in business on his own account in January, 1883, with a small capital, having previously been a clerk.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., Sept 18.--The trial of Mrs. Robert Ray Hamilton, indicted for assault on her child's nurse, Mary Ann Donnelly, began here to-day. The court room was crowded as it never was crowded before.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--As the official recount of votes in West Virginia has conclusively shown that ex-Representative Goff was not elected Governor of the State, he is out of a job, and the political gossips are looking for a place in which the Administration may stow him for the next three years.

J., Sept. 18.--The Board of Education has been requested by the Junior Order of American Mechanics to order that hereafter the national flag be displayed during school hours on the public school buildings. Ever since 1875 the American citizens of Italian birth have been in the habit of annually celebrating the 20th of September, on which date the army of Victor Emanuel entered Rome and the house of Savoy formally took possession of the Imperial City as the capital of a united Italy.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 18.--Gov. Hill was to have delivered an address to-day at the Dela ware County Fair at Delhi. Owing to the inclement weather, however, the fair was postponed until Oct. 3, when the Governor will again endeavor to deliver his address. The Governor and his staff returned to Elmira this morning.

Wall-street is still deluged with abounding tales of distress from the West. There is a tradition in Wall-street that there was once a man who did believe Chicago. He's dead.

In a match race between W. E. Connor's Nahli and John H. Cornwall's Tattler, both jib and mainsail rig, sailed off Sands Point Tuesday in a fresh southwest breeze, the Nahli won in 3:40. The Tattler was so badly beaten she did not finish. The time is remarkable for a twenty-four-footer, the distance sailed being nineteen and a half knots, with two turns.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 18.--Miss Jennie N. Paine, who has charge of the old Paine homestead at 14 Delaine-street, has been informed by cable of the death in Paris of her brother, Chevalier Ira Abner Paine, the crack pistol shot of the world.
