ROME, Sept. 18.--The English and Italian Governments have signed a more stringent anti-slavery convention than has hitherto existed. It declares the slave traffic to be an act of piracy and enables cruisers to deal more promptly with captured slavers. The Mediterranean is excluded from the operations of the treaty.

Just after the accommodation train on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, scheduled to leave the Grand Central Station at 8:01, pulled out last evening, the engine jumped the track at the first switch. Fortunately for those aboard--and the coaches had few vacant seats--the engineer had little difficulty in bringing the train to a stop before all the wheels of the locomotive were off the rails. The train was delayed twenty-five minutes.

The next trial in order after that of the Vesuvius will be the speed tests of the Concord and Bennington. These two vessels, though still in the ways, are rapidly nearing completion. Their engines are being put up. The Concord and Bennington are building at the Roach yards in Chester, Penn. They are similar to the Yorktown, but are required to develop a higher horse power than the Crampbuilt craft.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 18.--It is understood here that Cecil Gabbett, General Manager of the West Point Railroad, has been offered the gen eral managership of the Central system, and that the matter will be made public at the next meeting of the Directors.

LONDON, Sept. 18.--Work on the docks is assuming its normal aspect. Fewer non-union men are employed, and many of the men engaged to fill the places of strikers are joining the union.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 18.--H.J. Lane of Sackett's Harbor was to-day renominated by the Republicans for member for Assembly from the First Jefferson District by acclamation.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19.--By a vigorous use of the bat the Giants succeeded in winning a ball from the League team of this city to-day. The local men started off with the lead in the opening inning, but the gait was too fast for them and they had to give way in the third.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 19.--About as queer a legal tangle over an estate as has happened is developed in the matter of the estate of the late Joseph B. Humphreys, ex-County Auditor, and that of Martha L., his wife.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--To-day's bond offers were as follows: Coupon 4s, $18,500 at 128; registered 4s, $100,000 at 128; registered 4 s, $11,000 at 105 ; 4 per cents. registered $100,000 at 128; 4 per cent. coupon, $60,000 at 105 . All the offers were accepted.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 19.--The manoeuvring tests of the United States cruiser Yorktown have been completed. The cruiser has exhibited all the remarkable turning qualities which were promised by her official trial performances. She may now safely be termed the handiest vessel in the navy up to date.

Ex-Congressman E.R. Meade was arrested last night on Broadway by one of Capt. Reilly's policemen and was taken to the station house. He acted as if he were intoxicated, but later it was found that he was suffering from mental depression. The police sent for an ambulance and had him removed to the New-York Hospital.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 19.--The game laws of this State will be off on the 1st of October, and from that time until the 1st of January the sportsmen's season will be dominant.

Mayor Grant went out of town on a mysterious mission last night--to be gone several days. He declined to divulge his objective point and turned off persistent inquiries touching his movements good-naturedly. Two explanations were offered for his departure.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 19.--The postponed sale of the Cininnati, Washington and Baltimore Railroad was held here to-day. The road was sold to E.R. Bacon for $5,000,000. He represents English and American security holders.

The opening of the Academy, with the revival of "The Old Homestead," which was announced for next Monday, has again been postponed, this time until next Thursday evening. Denman Thompson says he is mad, but he can't help himself.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 19.--The developments in the State bond swindle are coming so rapidly that business on the New-Orleans Stock Exchange has been paralyzed, and transactions in State and city Government securities are at a standstill.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 19.--The college term Yale opened this morning with prayers at Battell Chapel. Every seat in the body of the church was occupied, and the galleries were thronged by fair friends of the upper classmen and the relatives of the boys of '93. The beginning of the term has been very quiet, and good order has prevailed at all times.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--It is understood that a commission for Major Merrill of Massachusetts as Commissioner of Pensions was made out to-day and forwarded to the President at Deer Park to-night.

Woodbridge Clifford, the Postmaster at North Edgecomb, Me., was appointed under Postmaster General Amos Kendall Oct. 4, 1839, and has held the office ever since that date. It is very doubtful if there is another Postmaster in the country who can boast of a record exceeding this period of half a century.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The Inter-State Fair attracted a large crowd of people to the city to-day. Gov. Hill is in the city, and he and Lieut. Gov. Davis of Penneylvania will attend the fair to-morrow. Gov. Hill will deliver a short address. To-day he is visiting old personal friends in the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--Secretary Tracy's determination to have the two 3,000-ton cruisers built in the New-York and Norfolk Navy Yards will give the naval Constructors and steam engineers an opportunity to show how the Government workshops compare with those of private shipbuilders for celerity and quality of workmanship.

A dispatch from Pittsburg in respect of a letter written by Lieut. Robert C. Patterson, Quartermaster of the Fourteenth Regiment Pennsylvania National Guard, in which it is stated that the decision in the recent international military match at Creedmoor by the executive officer of the National Rifle Association was "a clear case of robbery" on the part of Gen. Robbins, claims attention.

There is a chance for the belligerent Republicans in the Eighth District to do some more gouging in true "Silver-Dollar" Smith style tonight, when the O'Brien gang and the antiO'Brienites hold their primaries to elect delegates to the Republican State Convention.

After four days of solid attention to the business of its important convocation the Supreme Council of the Accepted Scottish Rite for the Northern jurisdiction of the United States adjourned yesterday.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19.--The preliminary meeting of the Chickamauga Association was held this afternoon in a mammoth tent erected for the occasion.

The Pennsylvania Railroad's New-York and Chicago Limited runs through the ill-starred valley of the Conemaugh in the soft light of the afternoon, affording a wild and weird panorama of the flood's track. It passes over the fated bridge at Johnstown, above which so many people perished by flood or fire.--Exchange.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 19.--The first of the series of special yacht races off here to-day for the Morgan and Rogers Cups developed good contests. There was more wind than has favored any race off here this season. In fact, there was so much wind that nearly half the yachts entered did not start.
LONDON, Sept. 19.--Major Field, formerly Secretary of the British-American Mortgage Company, was sentenced to-day to twelve months' imprisonment at hard labor for forging coupons of the company.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 19.--Winterset is considerably stirred up by the unexplained departure and absence of J.B.W. Westfall, Secretary of the Mutual Loan and Trust Company.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 19.--The opening to-day of the first Simpson timber dry dock constructed for the Government in the navy yard was a grand success. The Bay Line steamer Virginia was chartered by the builders of the dock and brought down a large number of guests.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19.--The wheat market for both cash and futures was higher to-day. One of the principal features of the trade was an improved demand for round lots as well as car lots.

At 9:10 last night a fire broke out at the St. George Hotel, 825 Broadway. A still alarm was given to Truck Company No. 3, in East Thirteenth-street, and the fire was put out before any damage was done. It was caused by some rubbish in the Kitchen furnace.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The Democratic Convention of the Third Assembly District of Rensselaer County to-day elected the following delegates to the State Convention at Syracuse: J.J. Cassin, F.P. Harder, and James E. Ryan. The delegates are not committed.

The danger to which pedestrians are subjucted by the careless stringing and handling of overhead electric light wires in the public streets was aptly illustrated by an accident which occurred yesterday morning in front of the Hotel Hungaria, 2 Union-square.
ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 19.--Grand Duke Constantine, uncle of the Czar, who suffered a stroke of paralysis two months ago, is dying. He is conscious, though unable to speak.

The Board of Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company held a meeting in Wallstreet yesterday that had a good deal more life than harmony in it. Mr. Henry Villard, who lately has become the recognized head and front of the big railroad company, had to submit to a vote adverse to his plans and desires.

When the Acting Commissioner of the General Land Office, Mr. STONE, sat down to prepare the annual report, a summary of which was given to the public yesterday, he steadily kept in mind a purpose to discredit the work of his immediate predecessors, Mr. SPARKS and Mr. STOCKSLAGER.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 19.--At to-day's session of the Homeopathic State Medical Society it was decided to make an effort to have the State appropriate sufficient money to establish a State Homeopathic Asylum for the Insane.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 19.--The Halifax graving dock, the largest on this side of the Atlantic, will be formally opened to-morrow by the entrance of the warship Canada. The dock cost $1,000,000 and has been three years building.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The first snow of the season began falling here at 2:50 o'clock this afternoon, but soon turned into a cold, drizzling rain.
LONDON, Sept. 19.--The Cunard Line steamship Gailia, Capt. Murphy, from New-York Sept. 11 for Liverpool, was signaled off Brow Head at 7:35 P. M. to-day.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The Republicans of the Twentieth Senatorial District, composed of the counties of St. Lawrence, Franklin, and Lewis, met in convention at Canton to-day and unanimously renominated Senator George Z. Erwin of Potsdam. Senator Erwin was called upon and addressed the convention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--A cable dispatch has been received at the Department of State from Consul Allen at Kingston, Jamaica, saying that a riot occurred at Navassa, an island in the Caribbean Sea, in which a number of Americans were killed.

An Omaha dispatch says that the labor unions comprising the Employes' Union of the Pacific system have formed themselves into an organization which is to be known as the Brotherhood of Railway Employes.

BOSTON, Sept. 19.--Owing to the continuous rainy weather and the consequent heaviness of the track at Beacon Park the Balch ten-thou sand-dollar stallion race was again postponed to-day, this time until Monday next, by which time a good track is expected.

A controversy has arisen between Health Commissioner Griffin of Brooklyn and the local Civil Service Commission over the action of the former in appointing twenty physicians to serve as sanitary inspectors during the Summer months.

The Committee on Site for the World's Fair will meet to-day to vote formally on the muchconsidered question of where the fair shall be held. It will probably begin by voting on proposed sites which are not in most favor and rejecting them, but will finally reach a decision on the site that is considered most desirable.

A casual glance at the vestibule attachments in use on the Pennsylvania Railroad trains might leave the impression that their only function was to provide a safe and easy passage between the cars. Not so. The Pullman perfected safety vestibules are the most powerful safeguards yet devised against accident by collision or telescoping. The strength of the steel frames effectually estops one car from running into another.--Exchange.

The weather yesterday afternoon was not too alluring, but the warm sunshine of the morning had encouraged the thousands who had been anxious to visit the New-Jersey State Fair Grounds at Waverly to venture out. It was said by the men at the gate that over thirty thousand people had passed in.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The WellsFargo Express Company bought out the Erie Express Company about a year ago, and now has exclusive express privileges over the Erie Railroad system under a long contract.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19.--It is now believed that the steam launch Leo, which left Lorain, twentyeight miles west of here, for this port last Sunday afternoon, was blown up about 3 o'clock Monday morning.

Mayor Grant yesterday appointed Mr. William J. Kenny Supervisor of the City Record in place of Mr. William G. McLaughlin, resigned. Mr. Kenny is a trained newspaper man, and brings to his new office the experience of eighteen years among the New-York dailies.
Arthur T. Halliday, the son of the Rev. S.B. Halliday, who escaped from the Amityville Insane Asylum on Monday, was taken to the Second Precinct Station House in Brooklyn yesterday.

The schooner Wildfire, Capt. Grafton, bound from Rondout for Lynn with a cargo of cement, was run into off Black Rock, Long Island Sound, by the Fall River steamer Puritan, at 10 o'clock Wednesday night.
The cool wave felt in this city yesterday morning came down from the Northwest, and was felt in various places more than here.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The Fall term of Union College opened yesterday with prospects very bright.
BUFFALO, Sept. 19.--The second trial of Gen. Lester B. Faulkner, charged with wrecking the Dansville National Bank, was begun in the United States District Court before Judge Coxe this morning.
CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 19.--A chapter on suffrage was to-day made a part of the Constitution for the State of Wyoming. It is, in effect, that women may vote.

WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 19.--The east-bound St. Louis and San Francisco passenger train was derailed near Leon, Butler County, yesterday, by the spreading of the rails. Three passenger coaches left the track while the train was going thirty miles an hour, and rolled down a fifteenfoot embankment.

Primary elections were held in every Republican ward and town association in Kings County last night, and from the number of the contests reported the party is going into the Fall campaign in anything but a harmonious condition.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19.--At the meeting of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland to-day Gen. Mussey presented a memorial as to the death of Judge Stanley Matthews.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 20.--A chapter on executive has been adopted by the Constitutional Convention. There is to be a Governor, Auditor, Secretary, Examiner of Public Accounts, and Treasurer. His Excellency's salary will be $2,500; the others $2,000 each.

It was a little after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon when the marine guard on duty at the lower gate of the Brooklyn Navy Yard fell into line, and presented arms to a small funeral cortege wending its way beyond the walls. Following the hearse was a body of bluejackets, while behind them marched a full marine shipguard.

New-York and Jersey City business men are wondering what is the matter with Postmaster General Wanamaker that he should take upon himself the responsibility for a new mail route between the two cities.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 20.--The movement in favor of a deep harbor on the coast of Texas is gaining ground rapidly in the West. Next month there will be a convention in this city in which nearly 1,000 delegates from every Western State will take part.

The nine men arrested in Brooklyn on Thursday night for attempting to vote illegally at the Twentieth Ward Republican primary were arreigned before Justice Kenna yesterday. They pleaded guilty, with the exception of Christopher Callahan, who alleged that he was ignorant of any wrong in what he did.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., Sept. 20.--Mrs. Robert Ray Hamilton will probably be conveyed to the Trenton Prison to-morrow. She takes her sentence with good grace, Sheriff Johnson says, and her appetite is as good as ever.
Agnes Hartigan of Orangeburg, N.J., attempted to cross Broadway at Fourteenthstreet yesterday afternoon, when car No. 67, bound down town, came along, and she stood between the tracks to let it pass.

LEWES, Del., Sept. 20.--The following information relative to the condition of the vessels which encountered the late storm is furnished: The bark Il Salvatore and the schooners Henry M. Clark and Major W.H. Tantum have been surveyed and condemned.

The cigarmakers' convention, in session at Tammany Hall, was called to order yesterday promptly at 9 o'clock and once continued the tinkering of their constitution that has been going on since Tuesday last under the recommendations of the Committee on Constitution.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 20.--At the instance of Collector Bailey, United States Dis trict Attorney A.J. Evans to-day instituted proceedings in twelve cases under the foreign labor law. The cases are those of Mexicans living on the south side of the Rio Grande and doing day labor on this ride, going home at night under the implied contract to return the next day to complete their services.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 20.--The west bend of the Van Wies Aqueduct, three miles west of Fultonville on the Erie Canal, has given out. Superintendent Shanahan is at the scene. It may be necessary to suspend navigation for twenty-four hours.
How quick the mighty fall when out of office! The Second New-Jersey Brigade Society issued circulars of the date of Aug. 23 announcing the second reunion of the society in Elizabeth Sept. 26.
The cornerstone of the new building of the Hamilton Club, soon to be erected on Fortyfirst street, near Locust, will contain a remarkable pack of playing cards.

Boston has no vessel in tlhe oyster trade that receives its cargo from the South. The oysters that are opened here come by steamer from Norfolk or Baltimore, or from nearer home, along the rivers running into Narragansett Bay.
"Grandsire Caswell" was one of the early settlers of Harrison, Me., ancestor of four or five generations of hardy families, some still residing on the original homestead.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 20.--The regular September shoot of the Riverside Gun and Rifle Club occurred this afternoon on their grounds adjoining Freeholder Cooper's, in Middletown Township.

There are a few restaurants in the city which are, in a measure, under the control of the City Government, or, at least, pay a portion of their earnings to the city. It is not a great source of revenue, but every little counts with Tammany.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20.--Two games were played here to-day between the champions and the Quakers. They were both interesting, attracting a large crowd. The visitors won the first in fine style, but the second resulted in a draw, both sides having scored 4 runs when darkness compelled the umpire to call the game.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 20, via Galveston.--The Grace bondholders' contract is progressing favorably on its passage through Congress. The seventh clause passed the Senate yesterday--25 votes to 18.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept 20.--During the progress of a rough drunken revel in the house of John Staples, at Mayville, near Carbondale, Penn., Thursday evening, Mrs. James Farrell was killed.

The Algeria Stakes, for two-year-olds, and the Oceanview, for three-year-olds, are the two stake events to be contested for at the Gravesend track to-day. In the first event El Rio Rey is entered as a doubtful starter.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20.--Capt. Benson of the bark Dom Pedro, from Navassa, which arrived this morning, says that when he left Navassa Sept. 1 there was no indication of an outbreak.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Coupon 4s, $1,000, $2,000, $10,000, at 128; registered 4s, $5,000, $20,000, $600,000, $5,000 at 128; registered 4 s, $4,000, $5,000, $400,000, $2,000, $100,000, at 105 ; coupon 4 s, $5,000, $4,000, at 105 .

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 20.--A brave act was performed last night by Policeman Gerstung of this city, who dragged a woman off the railroad track just as a train was about to strike her. The officer at the risk of his life sprang to her aid and, seizing her by the arm, dragged her out of danger. She fainted away at the sight of the engine thundering by. The policeman was grazed by the train.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20.--Henry A. Alioth, a member of the New-York jewelry firm of Uhry Alioth, 194 Broadway, was sued for $10,000 damages to-day by Mrs. Annie L. Helfenstein, the wife of Charles Helfenstein, one of Uhry Alioth's traveling men.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20.--All was got in readiness aboard the cruiser Yorktown at an early hour this morning, preparatory to the speed runs over the measured mile.

MIFFLINTOWN, Penn., Sept. 20.--Six big barns, with the season's crops in them, have been burned in close succession within the past three weeks in Walker Township, Juniata County, of which this town is the county seat. All were fired, it is believed, by incendiaries working in secret unison and for purposes not yet understood by the community.

Considering the very commonplace card arranged for the day at the track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday the attendance was surprisingly good. The sport was wholly without sensations, except in the Gregory race, referred to later on.

Peter Reynolds, owner of the tenement houses 341 and 347 East Thirty-fifth-street, was stabbed to death late last night by Florence J. Donohue, a tenant in 341. ST. JOHNS, N.F., Sept. 20.--The British war ship Lily struck a rock off Point Armor, off the Labrador coast, in the Straits of Belle Isle, and sank. Seven of her crew were lost.

The champion Manhattan Athletic Club will give its twelfth annual Fall games this afternoon at its grounds, Eighty-sixth-street and Eighth-avenue. The contests will begin at 2 o'clock, it is announced, and among the events to be decided will be the two-mile steeplechase and ten-mile flat championships of the Amateur Athletic Union.

ROCKLAND, Me., Sept. 20.--Yesterday morning during a gale the schooner Aroostook of Gloucester, Capt. Bradford, passed the St. John schooner G.L. Cotter, Capt. Durant, with lumber, seventy miles southeast of Matinicus, in a bad condition. When first discovered the Cotter had no signal set, but after proceeding two miles the Aroostook was signaled and wore around for the wreck.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Sept. 20.--The lead-mining interest in this region has been in a comatose condition for some years, but a discovery made yesterday at Sinsinnawa Mound has created new excitement in the business.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Sept. 20.--It is a long pull from Cheyenne, on the eastern edge of Wyoming, to the city of the Latter-Day Saints. Cheyenne is about midway between Omaha and Salt Lake, and it is more than 500 miles from Wyoming's capital city to either place.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20.--The police annals of this and other cities record many cases of mistaken identity, but all the histories of instances of circumstantial evidence and mistaken indentity weave no stronger case against an unfortunate innocent man than did the testimony against Timothy O'Grady, convicted of the murder of Police Officer Michael O'Brien on the night of April 3, 1887.

The anniversary of Victor Emanuel's entrance into Rome on Sept. 20, 1870, which marked the unification of Italy, is celebrated by Italians all the world over as a fete day. ZANZIBAR, Sept. 21.--With the object of assisting Great Britain and Germany in suppressing the slave trade the Sultan has issued an edict empowering the commanders of English and German war ships to search all Zanzibarese dowhs and other boats. The decree also provides that every person who enters the Sultan's dominions after November shall be free.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21.--The turning and manoeuvring trials of the big cruiser Chicago were completed today, and were in every respect most satisfactory, demonstrating conclusively that the Chicago has every claim to the title of a "quick manoeuvring, ship."

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 21.--The largest forest fires ever seen on Prince Edward Island raged west of Summerside on Thursday and Friday. The loss cannot be estimated. Three sawmills and a large number of dwellings and outbuildings were destroyed.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept 21.--Robert Naef, a resident of this city and Treasurer of the Schuetzen Benevolent Society, has been missing for several days, and the organization, together with his family, is becoming greatly alarmed over his disappearance. OTTAWA, Sept. 21.--The articles of incorporation of the Joggins Raft Company, which is to handle Canadian and American timber on the Pacific, have been filed. WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--Since the beginning of the present Administration Secretary Tracy has kept the navy yard at his own city of Brooklyn constantly crowded with work by carrying on there the construction of the Maine and the alterations in the Puritan, and sending there all ships in need of repairs.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 22.--Dr George H. Cook, the State Geologist and Vice President of Rutgers College, died here suddenly this afternoon of heart failure. Dr. Cock was taken ill yesterday noon, but his illness was not considered at all serious, and his death was totally unexpected. He was one of the most eminent of New-Jersey citizens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--The Fail meeting of the National Jockey Club will begin at the Ivy City race course Monday, Oct. 7, and continue five days. There will be no racing on Tuesday, that being the day of the Knights Templar parade.

A cold wind swept over the Harlem River yesterday which made it necessary for oarsmen to keep moving or else wear heavy sweaters. A bright sun made the water look so attractive and inviting that the former course was generally adopted.

When the Republicans in their National Convention issued a general invitation to every ono who wanted anything from the Treasury to apply for it, they doubtless counted on a majority in Congress that world enable them to loosen the purse strings at discretion.
CHOES, N.Y., Sept. 22.--A unique and interesting phase of the Democratic faction fight in Albany County will be investigated in the Recorder's Court in this city to-morrow morning.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 22.--Arrangements have been completed for the entertainment of the delegates to the convention of the American Bankers' Association, which is to be held in this city on Wednesday and Thursday.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The Board of Trade has given the Woman Suffrage Party the use of its office as headquarters during that party's State Convention here, Oct. 3 and 4. The Citizens' Association is aiding the preparations for the convention.

The recent arrivals of sealing schooners at Victoria show that the Behring Sea season is practically over. One vessel after another of the fleet that went out from that port in the Spring has returned in safety, until at the latest accounts only four were still absent.

GUAYAQUIL, Sept. 22, via Galveston.--ExPresident Caamano, Governor of Guayaquil, left here yesterday for the United States, as Minister Plenipotentiary and Ecuadorian delegate to the Washington international Congress. He has been granted ninety days' leave of absence. The Government prohibits Chinese immigration.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 22.--For a long time there has been a bitter fight between the shareholders and the bondholders of the Bessemer Iron Company of Upper Michigan. The amount involved runs into the millions, many men of national reputation being interested.

Mrs. Langtry has a new one-act play called "After the Rehearsal," written by Charles Osborue, in which Jean-Jacques Roussean and the Marquise de Pompadour figure. Mrs. Langtry played the Marquise at Wolverhampton, England, Sept. 9.

Minnie Palmer is to receive a percentage of the receipts of "Cinderella," in which she is to appear at Her Majesty's Theatre, in London, and the entertainment is to be billed, "Miss Minnie Palmer in 'Cinderella.'"

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 22.--Tourists are plentiful in Salt Lake City at all times of the year. They come here by way of the Union Pacific from the east or from the west and by way of the Denver and Rio Grande from the south. It is but a short side trip off the Union Pacific Line from Ogden.

Asked whether there would be any opposition on the part of the Board of Trustees of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral to the acquisition of the site of that contemplated edifice for World's Fair purposes, the Rev. Morgan Dix said he knew of none so far as the Trustees of the cathedral were concered.

The marriage of the youthful Chinese maid of Mrs. Wo Kee of 8 Mott-street to Fong Wing, senior member of Kwong Hong Long, 5 Mottstreet, was celebrated yesterday. The bride's name was Lien Fa, commonly called by her...

CINCINNATI, Sept. 23.--At the Grand Hotel this morning all the clubs of the American Association were represented at a meeting of the Directors to act on the question in dispute between the St. Louis and Brooklyn Clubs in the forfeited games of this Sept. 7 and 8.

United States Deputy Marshal Bernhard brought as a prisoner before Commissioner Hitchcock yesterday a young Austrian, who will probably be obliged to return to his own country under decidedly disagreeable circumstances.

Col. Alexander S. Bacon applied, in Justice Kenna's court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, for a warrant for the arrest of Michael Scanlon of 84 Mulberry-street, this city, on a charge of hiring the nine tramps who voted illegally at the Twentieth Ward primary in Brooklyn last Thursday. The warrant was not issued, as justice Kenna was absent, but Col. Bacon said later that he had been assured that Scanlon would be in court to-day.

Referee Emmet R. Olcott went on with the hearing in the matter of widening the Brooklyn Bridge entrances yesterday. It was the first day of the opposition, and Attorney Busche put H.E.G. Rohlfs, a truckman, on the stand.

ALBANY, Sept. 23.--The new calendar for the Court of Appeals, which reconvenes on Oct. 7, is made up of 820 new cases. All the cases on the old calendar have been transferred for consideration to the Second Division of the court.

At the Baptist conference yesterday the pastors fell into a discussion of humor in the pulpit. It was started by a paper read by the Rev. J.T. Dickinson, pastor of the North Baptist Church of Orange, on "The Humor of Shakespears as Illustrated in King Lear's Fool."

A city ordinance was passed in 1880 imposing a fee of 25 cents per day on all persons selling produce within 300 yards of any public market. The ordinance was aimed at the "squatters" and persons who keep street stands, but the market collectors have systematically...

Lightning struck the house of Mr. Spaulding at Pleasant Hill, Winona, Minn., at 8:30 Sunday night. One bolt went down the stovepipe and into the cellar. The other went off the stove and killed a girl six years old in her mother's lap. The father was knocked senseless, but not seriously hurt.

There was a meeting of the Republican State Committee in Jersey City yesterday, with a full attendance. Garrett A. Hobart was unanimously re-elected Chairman, despite his strenuous objection. Ex-Senator A.G. Cattell was chosen Vice Chairman.

LONDON, Sept 23.--Wilkie Collins, the novelist, who has been seriously ill for some time, died to-day. William Wilkie Collins, who fairly earned the reputation of being one of the best of modern English novelists, was born in London in 1824. His father was William Collins, R.A., a celebrated English landscape painter, and his mother was a sister of Mrs. Carpenter, the portrait painter.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 23.--Cornell University opens upon a new year tomorrow. The Register, Mr. A.H. Grant, said to THE TIMES'S reporter to-day that everything promised a successful year. There will be fully 400 Freshmen, and 550 new men in all.

Yesterday's stock market was fairly active, and it was strong. Something of a set-back was met in the early trading as the result of an announcement that the Louisville and Nashville was preparing to print $13,000,000 of new stock. But a speedy explanation that this increased capital was intended to extinguish a big bond debt gave the market an upward tendency again.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23.--Drafts-Sight, 10; telegraphic, 15.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23.--The President at Deer Park made the following appointment to-day: United States Marshal.--EDWARD KNOTT, for the Northern District of Iowa, in place of Will iam Desmond, who had served four years and now takes a county office.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept 23.--"Where is the Westchester County delegation?" was the common question about the United States Hotel this evening. The question was unanswered until 10 o'clock, when this dispatch was received from one of them: "Cannot arrive before Tuesday night."
Commissioner of Public Works Gilroy yesterday discharged Foreman John Fitzpatrick and the seven men who worked under him as repairing gang No. 13.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23.--It looks as if there were two storms brewing on 'Change. There has been enough of rumbling and gathering of forces in each quarter to give alarm. In one quarter there is a calm and in the other there are little gusts and spurts and squalls, which cause a scampering of those out in the wet.

The woman who was found in the cellar of the Roman Catholic church at Mount Vernon, N.Y., a few minutes prior to her death on Saturday night was not yet been identified. It appears that she inhabited the dark and musty place in which she was found for months. It is a gruesome abode.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23.--Two new plays in the repertory of Mr. William H. Crane were presented to-night at the Chicago Opera House for the first time. They were "Papa Perrichon," an English version of "Le Voyage de M. Perrichon," which has been seen in this country, and "The Balloon," a farce-comedy which has had great success in England.

Miss Elizabeth D. McCormick, who lived with her sister, Mrs. Richards, at 72 West Fortyfifth-street, died very suddenly on Sunday evening. She was a member of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, an active church worker, and Treasurer of the Sunday school.
The WestSide Boarding and Livery Stable, a frame building, owned and occupied by L. Callaghan, at 1,615 Broadway, was destroyed by fire between 11 and 12 o'clock last night.

The dock of the North German Lloyd steamers was thronged with passengers when the Fulda arrived yesterda afternoon. The number of cabin passengers, 412, is said to have exceeded that brought by any of the German lines coming into this port.

Michael Hernan, a brother of James Hernan of 221 West Twenty-seventh-street, who, it is alleged, was brutally beaten and dangerously injured by ex-Alderman James Barker during a row on Thursday night last in Clark's saloon, at Eighth-avenue and Twenty-fifth-street, obtained a warrant yesterday from Justice Ford at the Jefferson Market Police Court for the arrest of Barker. The latter is the Tammany leader in the Thirteenth Assembly District.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 23.--The killing of Policeman J.W.R. Gordon by Tugboat Engineer Daniel Sheehan at Pensacola, Fla., yesterday was the end of a thrilling short-arm pistol duel. Some days ago Gordon, in trying to arrest Sheehan, clubbed him.

ALBANY, Sept. 23.--The Canal Board held its second meeting this afternoon to consider the matter of the city of Syracuse using the surplus water of Skaneateles Lake for a water supply for that city.

The committee appointed by the New-York State Bar Association to arrange a celebration on Feb. 2 next of the one hundredth anniversary of the fonnding of the Federal judiciary will meet in the Post Office Building next Monday noon.

Messrs. H. O'Neill Co. are now in the midst of a grand opening of Fall goods which commands attention and admiration. The millinery department is particularly noticeable for its elegance and novelty.

Mr. Henry R. Towne, one of the members of the Committee on Site and Buildings, wrote to Mayor Grant yesterday on the subject of exposition finances. "There is an unmistakable indication of impatience," he writes, "on the part of the public at the seemingly unreasonable delay of the Committee on Finance in reporting a plan for the finances of the exhibition of 1892.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 23.--The delegates elected to-day to the Republican State Convention from Cortland County are R.T. Peck, M. F. Cleary, Floyd Hitchcock, Oscar Pinckney, W.C. Bockes, and C.O. Newton. Their preferences are not known.

QUEBEC, Sept. 23.--Denis Berrigan, son of Michael Timothy Berrigan, who succumbed to wounds received in the recent landslide, died to-day. The remains of several of the victims recovered yesterday were buried to-day. The funeral of Thomas Nolan, who was a member of the Eighth Battalion, was conducted with military honors.

The taking of testimony in the reference ordered by Gov. Hill in the case of Charles Giblin, under sentence of death for the murder of Madeleine Goelz, was begun yesterday before Referee Douras in the Court of Common Pleas.
BOSTON, Sept. 23.--Probably the largest crowd ever on a New-England race course blackened Beacon Park this afternoon to see Nelson win the national stallion race for a tenthousand dollar purse.

The row over the sale of the franchise to operate a surface railroad through Montaguestreet, Brooklyn, to the Wall-Street Ferry was reopened yesterday, when Controller Brinkerhoff was ready to continue the auction sale adjourned several weeks ago.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23.--The Rev. H.H. Barbour, pastor of the Belden-Avenue Baptist Church, created a sensation in tha Baptist ministers' meeting by reading a paper at this morning's session in which he denied the existence of a personal devil and treated the passages from Scripture speaking of such a personage as figurative and not literal.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 23.--Francis McCue of Grant-avenue has entered civil proceedings against Assemblyman E.P Farrell of East Newark and William J. Kearns, who was till recently his partner.

It is just learned that a project is to be set on foot by some of the most prominent officers of the United States Navy which is intended to establish for the navy a full and complete Sig nal Corps such as is now attached to the army.

COHOES, N.Y., Sept. 23.--The examination of Prescott Hildreth, charged with offering a bribe to Police Commissioner Forbes to resign his office, did not proceed to-day, as the temperature in the court room was so cold that everybody was shivering. By consent of counsel the hearing was adjourned until Wednesday.

Deputy Sheriff Anderson yesterday took possession of the store of Belford, Clarke Co., book publishers, at 22 East Eighteenth-street, on an attachment for $25,000 granted by Judge Barrett of the Supreme Court in favor of Gerald F. Shepard, to whom the claim was assigned by the First National Bank of Chicago.
At a meeting of the County Medical Society last night the following nominations were made, to be voted on at the next meeting:

The Westchester County Agricultural and Horticultural Fair opened nominally yesterday, but it will not really begin until to-day, when an admission fee will be charged, which was not the case yesterday, and if the weather permits, there will be plenty of sport and excitement to keep one busy.

The spacious auditorium of the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, in Seventh-avenue, near Fourteenth-street, was crowded to its doors last night at the first public mass meeting held in this city under the auspices of the Loyal Women of American Liberty.

The last witness for the defense in the case of Henry S. Ives was heard yesterday, and Mr. Brooke reviewed the evidence for the defendant. This morning the prosecution will sum up, and the case will go to the jury this afternoon.

PARIS, Sept. 23.--Returns from 560 electoral divisions show that 224 Republicans have been elected and 159 members of the Opposition. Among the Republicans elected there are 16 Moderates and 57 Radicals.

Every one who has felt his flesh creep over that fat villain Count Fosco and his white mice will be sorry to learn that WILKIE COLLINS is dead. While "Blind Love" is running in the Illustrated London News its versatile author has succumbed to a second attack of the acute malady which formerly beset him.

The silver jubilees of five priests of the NewYork Archdiocese occur within a week. The priests are the Rev. James H. McGean, pastor of St. Peter's; the Rev. Gabriel A. Healy, pastor of St. Bernard's; the Rev. David A. Merrick, S. J., President of St. Francis Xavier's College; ...

BOSTON, Sept. 23.--The advance guard of delegates to the Republican State Convention on Wednesday is already in town, and the headquarters of Lieut. Gov. Brackett and ex-Congressman Crape, the rival candidates for Governor, already present an animated appearance.

A new scheule went into effect on the Ninthavenue elevated railroad yesterday morning, and, although it caused some delay at first, it was soon working smoothly and satisfactorily. Frank A. Hoelzle, a young man who says that he is a lawyer and that he lives at 260 West Thirty-sixth-street, went into Frank Coyle's restaurant and barroom, at 616 Eighth-avenue, between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning and called for a drink of brandy.

With a good day and a good track to help them, the Brooklyn Jockey Club had a very good day's sport yesterday and an unusually large crowd for a Monday present to enjoy it. Young Allen, a Western jockey, made a decided hit by winning three of the seven races, and showing an unexpected amount of vim and vigor in riding his finishes.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23.--Mayor William Warner of Kansas City arrived here this morning. He said he could not give affirmative or negative reply as to whether he would accept the office of Pension Commissioner.

HARTFORD, Sept. 23.--The Board of Trade today, at its first regular Fall meeting, voted in favor of New-York City as the place for the World's Fair in 1892. The City Government to-night passed a resolution to the same effect.
LONDON, Sept. 23.--The full reports received to-day make an even better showing for the French Republic than seemed possible last night.

Mayor Grant continues to receive a great many letters relating to the World's Fair. Among the communications received yesterday was a telegram from Congressman Roswell P. Flower, who is at present in Watertown, N.Y., saying that he had given instructions for the forwarding of a check for $25,000 as his subscription to the fair.

HARTFORD, Conn., sept. 23.--The Soldiers' Catalogue scandal, in which Major John C. Kinney, the aspirant for the Hartford Post Office, is involved, has not been met yet except by an abusive attack on THE TIMES'S correspondent who brought the facts to light.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 23.--A chapeter excluding foreign police was adopted by the Constitutional Convention to-day. Differences between employer and organized labor must be submitted to a board of arbitrators. The legislative apportionment was made. Railways may grant passes to their employes and families only, and the lines must not discriminate in levying tariff.

John McCarty, the President of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen, and Acting Mayor of that city whenever Mr. Chapin is absent, visited the Adams-street police court yesterday and wielded considerable power.
MANISTEE, Mich., Sept. 23.--A big fire is raging in the lumber district. It threatens the entire lumber plant of Buckley Douglass. The loss will be over $200,000.
The combination of the opponents of the republic in France has failed. That seems to us the net result of the elections of Sunday.

The will of Congressman Samuel Sullivan Cox was filed yesterday for probate in the Sur rogate's office. It was executed on Aug. 29, 1888, and Mrs. Cox receives all the property and is made sole executrix. The will, which is short, was drawn up by Mr. Cox.
BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 23.--Nehemiah Osborn and Joseph T. Hall of Batavia and Angus L. Tompkins of Leroy were to-day elected delegates to the State Convention of the Democrats of Genesee County.
The Washington Heights Taxpayers' Association held a meeting at Mount St. Vincent Hotel last evening to protest against the use of any portion of Central Park for the site of the 1892 World's Fair.
The County Democracy Committee of Twentyfour met last evening at Cooper Union to make arrangements for the trip of the County Democracy delegation to Syracuse.
NEWPORT, Sept. 23.--The cottage colony had another society picnic on the east shore of the island, under the guise of steeplechases, to-day, and as a fashionable outing it was very successful.
ST. PAUL, Sept. 23.--In the United States Circuit Court here this morning Judge Nelson delivered an able and exhaustive opinion, holding the Minnesota meat inspection law unconstitutional and void.
BELMAR, N.J., Sept. 23.--There is now little doubt that William Fenton committed suicide on Saturday evening. No inquest has yet been held, but the evidence seems incontrovertible.

The stockholders of the Pennsylvania, Poughkeepsie and Boston Railroad have chosen the following Directors; W.W. Gibbs, J. Newbold, Philadelphia; John I. Blair, Blairstown, N.J.; J.C. Stanton, New-York; James W. Husted, Peekskill, N.Y.; George W. Murray, George W. Greene, Goshen, N.Y. The following executive officers were chosen; James W. Husted, President; D.J. McNeese, Secretary and Treasurer; J.C. Stanton, General Manager; C.H. Stanton, General Superintendent; S.G. Primrose, Chief Engineer.

ABINGDON, Va., Sept. 23.--This was a field day in politics for the people of this (Washington) county and adjacent counties for many miles around. Gen. Mahone made the opening speech of the canvass for the Republicans, and received the plaudits of a considerable crowd.
The ladies of New-York have a rare treat in store for them at Stern Brothers' Twenty-third treet stores, where the regular Fall opening is now in progress.

FABYAN HOUSE, N.H., Sept. 23.--Snow has fallen on Mount Washington for the last five days, and this morning, is was eighteen inches deep. No train was run to the summit last night owing to the depth of snow, and the track had to be shoveled out to-day before trains could make the ascent. This is the first clear day of this month.
CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 23.--The Republicans of Cortland County to-day renominated R.T. Peck for the Assembly.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 23.--Jacob Fitzgerald of Cayuga dropped dead in Watkins to-night. He was a delegate to the Republican State Convention and went to Watkins to take a train for Saratoga.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 23.--The excellent racing, together with the beautiful weather, brought out a fairly good crowd of people to Churchill Downs to-day. Only one favorite pleased its backers, Birthday, in the fourth race, galloping home a winner. The results are as follows:

The Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company is to issue $13,000,000 of new stock. The proceeds are to be need to retire an outstanding issue of $10,000,000 of 6 per cent. collateral trust bonds and such other interestbearing indebtedness as the company's Directors may find advisable.

The hearing before ex-Surrogate Daniel G. Rollins, as referee in the suit of Frank W. Sanger against T. Henry French to recover a share in the receipts from "Little Lord Fauntleroy" during its productions outside of Boston and New-York, was resumed yesterday. Both gentlemen were present.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 24.--George Francis Train was arrested in his room at the Tremont House at noon to-day on a writ sworn out by O. M. Speller on a judgment note for $1,000.

ALBANY, Sept. 24.--The Associate Alumnae of the Normal College of the City of New-York was incorporated to-day. The object is "the preservation of the friendship and pleasant intarcourse begun during our college life, and the advancement of the best interests of our Alma Mater."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 25.--Fully 20,000 people attended the Dutchess County Fair today. There was considerable rain during the day, but it did not interfere with the racing. The four-year-old race was won by D. Gardner's Howard. D.B. Herrington's Handy Mald won one heat. Time--2:44 ; 2:42 ; 2:41 ; 2:42 .

The property of the Hatch Lithographic Company, at 49 to 53 Lafayette-place, was sold out yesterday at auction. The first sale was the foreclosure of chattel mortgages by order of James M. Sweeny, attorney for the mortgagee, and after that Deputy Sheriff Fitzgerald sold out what was left. Judge Barrett yesterday granted an attachment against the company for $6,396 in favor of George T. Throop.

The shooting grounds at Marion, N.J., was tha scene of another day's sport yesterday with the imitation targets. It was wet sport at that, but trap shooters are notoriously indifferent to weather conditions, and despite the rain most of the programme events were rapidly put through.

The steamer City of Paris of the Inman Line arrived yesterday from Liverpool after a fast run. The time made was six days and sixteen minutes, being very nearly five hours behind her great record of five days, nineteen hours, and eighteen minutes, made on the trip which ended on Aug. 28.

Thomas, alias "Crab" Connors, a convict, escaped from Randall's Island on Tuesday by swimming across the Harlem River. A general alarm was sent out and yesterday he was found in a saloon on Third-avenue. Judge Murray, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday ordered him taken back to the Island.

Mothers who are getting back to town and are preparing to re-clothe their boys and girls from top to toe will be delighted to learn that they will have one-third more space to shop in at Best Co.'s Liliputian Bazaar, 60 and 62 West Twenty-third-street, and that the stock of pretty and useful things to chose from is larger than ever before.

While waiting forsome word from the Finance Committee the members of the World's Fair Committee on Site have been very industrious in trying to decide upon some definite plan by which they may most readily acquire the lands which they have selected in the neighborhood of the northern end of Central Park.

Throughout the greater part of yesterday business was practically at a standstill on the Stock Exchange. Apprehensions of a squeeze in the money market are pronounced again, and there is, as well, a growing sense of gravity over the Western railway situation.

Catlin of the Ottawa Window Glass Company, in response to a request for information concerning the sale of the Ottawa glass factories to the United Glass Company of New-York, affirmed the report of the sale of the Illinois factories. JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 25.--The Republicans met in convention this morning in Representatives' Hall, and were called to order by John R. Lynch, Fourth Auditor of the Treasury, who is closely watching the interests of the Administration.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club is now having an unfortunate experience, such as the Coney Island Club had in the last week of its Fall meeting, and the outlook for a change in the weather is anything but promising.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company began laying the spur track from its main line, near the South Elizabeth Station, to the new race track of the Linden Blood Horse Association on Tuesday. The ties were all down and the rails were laid yesterday, and stone ballasting will be begun at once. The platform from the railroad terminus to the entrance to the track is completed.

The united Fire Departments of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown had their annual parade and review yesterday afternoon under very discouraging circumstances, as there was a drizzling rain off and on all day.

At a meeting of the miners, mine owners, and business men of Deming, New-Mexico, and vicinity yesterday, resolutions were adopted urging the free importation of lead ores into the United States from Mexico.
BINGHAMTON, Sept. 25.--The Broome County Democratic Convention to-day nominated Leonard Gaige, a farmer of Kirkwood, for the Assembly.
BERLIN, Penn., Sept. 25.--One of the saddest accidents in the history of Somerset County occured here yesterday. The boiler at the sawmill of Pritz Brothers exploded.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25.--The Republic says it is stated on good authority that there will be a gathering of anti-Powderly Knights in St. Louis next week on the occasion of the visit of Mr. Powderly to this city.

A couple of weeks ago Sam Stedeker was a hero in the eyes of the betting fraternity. With a single ten-dollar bill he managed at Sheepshead Bay to successfully bank the races until he had accumulated a capital of $13,000. Then Stedeker started in as a bookmaker.
The "Christian Science" people are all agitated over the disappearance of Mrs. Mary Plunkett, the chief priestess of the never-to-beforgotten "temple" at 13 West Forty-secondstreet.

The sixth annual meeting of the New-York State Medical Association began yesterday at the Hotel Brunswick, with many prominent physicians, members of the association, and delegates from other cities in attendance. Dr. William T. Lusk of this city is President.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Sept. 25.--The new Columbia Hotel, owned by James Mooney of Philadelphia, was completely burned out early this morning with all its contents. The house had been closed for about ten days.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 25.--The annual meeting of the Society of the army of the Tennessee, which began to-day, is a notable success, both in the attendance and the enthusiasm of the people of the city.

Dr. Manuel Quintana and Dr. Roque Saenz Pefia, delegates from the Argentine Republic to the International American Congress, and Dr. Alberto Niu, delegate from Uruguay to the same body, arrived in New-York yesterday on the steamship City of Paris.

AIDEN LAIR, Essex County, N.Y., Sept. 22.-- Ever since the Adirondacks became the objective point toward which persons who love the mountains of the earth turned their longing eyes, Essex County has been the chief rendezvous.

At the Bankers' Convention in session at Kansas City, Mo., Mr. WILLIAM P. ST. JOHN, President of the Mercantile National Bank of this city, read a paper on "The United Status Legal-tender Notes and Silver."

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 25.--By superior work in the pitcher's box the Hoosiers to-day defeated the Giants. Getzein went into the box for the home team, but after Gore had been put out in the first inning he retired, having strained has arm. McGeachy pitched out the innings, one hit being made off him.

At a meeting of the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday it was resolved to accept Section 5 of the aqueduct from the contractors, Brown, Howard Co. A long discussion was raised by Controller Myers as to whether any deduction should be made for the failure of the contractors...

LONDON, Sept. 25.--At the New market meeting to-day the race for the Great Eastern Railway Handicap at three-quarters of a mile was won by Cataract, with Harlow second, and Lord George third. There were eight starters.

POCATELLO, Idaho, Sept. 25.--When this Territory was named "The Gem of the Mountains" it could not have been for anything that was seen in Pocatello; or if it was, then it must have been named just for its hardness. As for stopping in Pocatello over night, no one would think of it twice unless he were compelled by pure necessity.

BOSTON, Sept. 25.--The outcome of the Republican State Convention has been the nomination of Lieut. Gov. John Q.A. Brackett of Arlington for Governor, of ex-Mayor William H. Halle of Springfield for Lieutenant Governor, and the renomination of the present State officers.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 25.--The Mobile and Ohio south-bound mail and passenger train was "held up" at 3:10 o'clock this morning by train robbers at Buckatunna, Miss., a station seventy miles north of Mobile. The train was due here at 6 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25.--To-day's bond offers accepted were as follows: Registered fours, $150, $18,000, and $10,000 at 128; coupon fours, $5,000 at 128; registered four and a halfs, $500, $4,900, $12,000, $8,000, and $500,000 at 105 ; coupon 4 per cents, $4,000 at 105 .

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 25.--The peculiar conditions Which for upward of thirty years made it impossible to raise peaches in Connecticut have vanished, and the culture of this fruit has again become a large and important industry in Con necticut.

The statute that makes it possible to appoint civilians to the existing and prospective vacancies in the Quartermaster's and Subsistence Departments of the army is a flagrant example of legislation by conference committee.

The Republican State Convention at Saratoga was chiefly remarkable for the effort to give an appearance of harmony to the condition of the party in the State. The convention itself was bound to be harmonious in any case, for its action was under the direction of one man.

Thomas A. Jerome, aged eighty-three years, a brother of Lawrence Jerome, visited Castle Garden yesterday. He went out on the pier, where Emigration Commissioners Stephenson and Starr and Capt. Moore of the Castle Garden Transportation Company were sitting. "I can catch more fish now than any one of you," said he.

WORCESTER, Sept. 25.--Sir Arthur Sullivan's cantata. "The Golden Legend," was given at the third concert of the Music Festival this evening and achieved an unquestionable success.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 25.--Elaborate preparations have been made by citizens and soldiers of this city to tender a rousing welcome to-morrow to the survivors of the Second New-Jersey Brigade, who hold their annual reunion here.

The Jersey City Board of Aldermen on Tuesday evening passed an ordinance giving the Jersey City and Bergen Railroad Company the privilege of using electric car motors on its railroad tracks. When it wss asked what kind of motor the company contemplated using, no answer could be given.
ITHACA, N.Y, Sept. 25.--With the completion of registration to-day hostilities between the Sophomore and Freshmen Classes commenced in earnest.
JOHN INGERSOLL GILBERT, the nominee for Secretary of State, was born in Pittsford, Rutland County, Vt., in 1837, and was graduated from the University of Vermont at Burlington in the Class of '59.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25.--The Johns Hopkins University will resume work next Tuesday, Oct. 1. The recent assault upon its financial condition has reacted, and the prompt denial that the institution was in a bad condition has reassured the confidence of friends of education and strengthened its hold upon public attention.

An always notable assemblage is the annual convention of the New-York Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church. John Cable, who lived on Evergreen-avenue, Brooklyn, dropped dead on Broadway, in that city, last night. It is supposed that his death was caused by heart disease. The body was taken into a stable and Coroner Lindsay was notified.

Fletcher Winant, who was thirty-six years old and engaged in the lighterage business at 48 South-street with his father, Cornelius Winant, Jr., shot himself in the mouth at 131 West Thirteenth-street on Monday or Tuesday, and was found dead yesterday. The deceased was born on Statan Island. His ancestors were Huguenots.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 25.--A telephone message from Iverydale via St. Bernard says Emery's big soap factory was completely gutted by fire to-night. Other buildings are in danger.

Politics in the turbulent Twenty-third Assembly District are just now in a particularly lively condition. Democrats and Republicans are having little affairs of their own, and, in a measure, both parties are considerably mixed up with each other.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 25.--The annual convention of the American Bankers' Association met here to-day. The city is gayly decorated in honor of the event. The convention is the largest ever held by the bankers, fully 1,000 delegates being present from all parts of the country.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The attendance at the Interstate Fair to-day was the largest since the opening. All trains were crowded. The weather was fine.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 25.--John J. O'Brien and his two dozen sturdy henchmen from the wicked Eighth District came up here Tuesday to fight for seats in the convention.

The Washington Memorial Arch fund has now very nearly reached the fifty-three-thousand-dollar mark through liberal subscriptions which have recently been coming in. Treasurer William R. Stewart, 54 William-street, yesterday received $250 from Hector C. Havemeyer, $100 from Edwin Booth, $2 from Duncan Buchanan, and $1 from Carl Harmann Braatz of Newport, R.I. These contributions raise the grand total to $52,639.46.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 25.--A heavy storm is prevailing along the New-Jersey shore. All day long the wind has been blowing fiercely from the east, and to-night the surf is running very high and rough.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25.--Tsui Kwo Ying, the new Chinese Minister to the United States, with his suite, arrived in this city to-night over the Pennsylvania Road. There were twentyfive in the party, including the Minister's wife and son, a boy twelve years old; the wife of Mr. Wong, one of the attaches, two maids in waiting upon the ladies, and Mr. Lee, chief interpreter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25.--The President is expected to return to Washingto this week in time to attend a meeting of the Cabinet, which will probably be called to meet Saturday.

Surveyor Lyon made his first visit to the Barge Office yesterday, where superintendent Whelan presented the employes of the office to him. Afterward the Surveyor went on board the revenue cutter Washington and made a trip to Quarantine.

QUEBEC, Sept. 25.--The bodies of two little girls of Michael Bradley, who lost his whole family in the landslide, were found last night close to each other. They were not much bruised and must have died of suffocation.

We have frequently quoted from the St. Louis Globe-Democrat that paper's clearlyexpressed opinions as to the manner in which many Trusts and similar combinations are affected by tariff duties and its demands that such combinations should be overthrown or their greed restrained by a reduction or the removal of the duties on which they rely.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 25.--The American Humane Society began its thirteenth annual convention this morning. The meeting will continue through Friday. Many notable persons are present.

Judge Ehrlich of the City Court yesterday appointed Philip Lendle of 629 West Forty-eighthstreet guardian ad litem of his daughter Annie, in order to prosecute a suit for breach or promise to marry against Henry Hoffman. Annie is a songstress, whose sweet tones have been heard in Hoboken. She is seventeen years old. She says Hoffman wooed her, although he was a married man. All she asks from him is $100,000.
HAVANA, Sept. 25.--Indications of the ap proach of a cyclone are visible in the southeastern portion of the island.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Sutra will celebrate the fifth anniversary of their wedding next Tuesday evening. A dinner will be given at Delmonico's at 6 o'clock, after which there will be dancing. All the members of the Clinton and Sutra families, it is expected, will be present on the happy occasion.

OBWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 26.--Capt. David Boyd of Mexico, this county, a prominent hotel keeper, was arrested to-night, charged with the murder of Lorenzo Hayes of Little Falls on Sept. 14. The two men had a fight. Hayes was stabbed. He died of his wounds to-day.

Live birds were shot at yesterday in the tournament of sportsmen at Marion, N.J. That with the handlers of guns such sport is preferred to matches at inanimate targets was proved by an unusual number of entries and more spectators than appeared on the preceding days, when the marksmen busied themselves with clay pigeons.

The State Railroad Commissioners have decided that the Third-Avenue Surface Railway Company may hereafter use a cable as motive power along Third-avenue, the Bowery, and Park-row. The decision was made this week. Commissioner Rogers preparing the opinion and his colleagues joining with him in final action.

The Cotton Exchange was excited yesterday afternoon. BOSTON, Sept. 26.--Designer Edward Burgess has won another victory. The fishing schooner yacht Fredonia was a winner from the start in to-day's race with the pilot boat Hesper in the "miscellaneous" weather which the yachts experienced.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 26.--Mayor Haynes this afternoon signed the contract with the East Jersey Water Company for a new water supply for the city. The Fairlawn Stock Farm was sold yesterday to A.S. McCann of Lexington, Ky., for $105,000. The farm contains 144 acres of blue-grass land lying on the outskirts of Lexington. He bought no horses from the Fairlawn estate, and they will be sold at auction at Lexington on Oct. 10.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--A congress of the Socialistic Labor Party convened in this city to-day Various labor topics will be discussed. The delegates are all Germans.

AUBURN, sept. 28.--The Democratic Convention of the Second District was held to-day at Moravia. Chairman J.G. McGarr of Owasco predicted a victory at the polls, and said that Gov. Hill was a friend of the laboring man. As soon as he sat down pandemonium broke loose.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 28.--In the Faulkner trail to-day Gen. Lester B. Faulkner, the defendant, took the stand and gave the history of his life and his connection with the Dansville wrecked bank.

HARTFORD, Sept. 28.--The oldest organization of educators in this State, which is known as the Connecticut State Teachers' Association, will hold its forty-third annual session at the high school hall in this city Oct. 18 and 19.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--New-York's club didn't win to-day, but nevertheless it is in the lead for League honors. This state of affairs was brought about by a defeat administered to the Bostons by the Hooslers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--The expenditure of $50,000,000 by two English syndicates for the control of an extraordinary aggregate of industrial enterprises in the United States was completed in this city to-day.
Bishop Thompson of Mississippi is at the New-York Hotel.

The Freshmen in tha Academic and Scientific Departments last year performed an important city missionary work in conducting and by their own efforts maintaining a boys' club on Grand-avenue in the most densely populated part of the city.

Within the last two years Germany has armed twenty-four of her thirty-six regiments of cavalry with the lance. She has stripped the cuirass from every cuirassier except in the case of a Guard regiment, and in so doing placed a lance in the hands of each man deprived of his armor.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28.--The Trustees of the Clark University, through the Secretary, F. P. Goulding, announce to-day the programme for the dedicatory and opening exercises of the university. They will occur at 3 o'clock on the atternoon of Wednesday, Oct. 2, and will be held in the large hall of the university.

A meeting of the State Board of Health was held yesterday at the Everett House, at which sewerage plans for Tarrytown were examined and approved. Beyond the drainage system the plans include an elaborate automatic arrangement for rendering the sewage innocuous.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 28.--The musicians of this city have combined for the purpose of maintaining a fixed higher scale of wages and to make regulations with regard to the engagament of musicians. Their first demand was formulated yesterday, when Manager Suslee of the Masonic Opera House was informed that he must hire a larger number of musicians in the orchestra and pay them each 50 cents more per night.

PARIS, Sept. 13.--The Invalides is getting to be a very tiresome lounging place; full of dust always, full of sun these last days, and always too thronged with people; but the portion of this exhibition quarter, which I did not know and which is far worse than its right-hand palm-tree-lined section, is the left side toward the Seine.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 28.--A recount of the stock of cotton here shows a decrease of 30,000 bales American, 23,000 Egyptian, and 16,000 of other kinds, as compared with the estimated stocks. This deficiency strengthens the corner. It is reported that the chief operator in the corner has made arrangements to send the bulk of the cotton tendered him to Havre, and thus starve the Liverpool market.

The naming of men-of-war after various cities has been the cause of some very appropriate gifts being bestowed by the places thus honored. One city has presented a set of colors, another a service of silver, a third a well-fitted library.

The Rev. Gabriel A. Healy, pastor of St. Bernard's Church, on West Fourteenth-street, celebrated the silver jubilee of his ordination yesterday.
PARIS, Sept. 29.--If the official promise had been kept the exhibition awards would have been announced on Sept. 15. But in enterprises of such magnitude there is always a considerable delay.

HURON, South Dakota, Sept. 29.--To come from North Dakota into South Dakota just at this time is to move from a country in which the people are scarcely agitated by political feeling into another in which everybody is in a wild whirl of excitement.

THE BALTIMORES DEFEATED AT RIDGEWOOD PARK. Ridgewood Park rang with cheers from over 10,000 people yesterday during the progress of the Brooklyn-Baltimore game. NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 29.--Joe Donaghue, the skater, met with a mishap a day or two ago that may prevent his taking part in the world's championship in Europe this Winter. While playing football he sprained his knee, and his physician says it will be several weeks before he will be able to leave the house. He was to have sailed for Norway in two weeks, where he was to have gone into training.
PARIS, Sept. 29.--As the result of his visit to the Comte de Paris, at Sheen House, M. Herve has retired from the election contest in his district in favor of the Boulangist candidate.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 29.--The steamer City of kingston, one of the bandsomest boats on the Hudson, has just been sold to the Oregon Steam Navigation Company of Portland, Oregon, and will at once be taken to that place via Cape Horn and the Straits of Magellan. The price paid was $135,000. The same company is looking for other boats along the Hudson. The Kingston will make her last trip to-morrow night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--Mr. F.A. Carlea, who was managing editor of the St. Paul Pioneer Press for several years and chief of its Washington bureau for a year past has severed his connection with that paper and will assume active editorial management of the Portland Oregonian.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29.--The annual meeting of the American Forestry Congress will begin in this city Oct. 15 and continue four days. The sessions are to be held in Horticultural Hall, Broad-street, and Gov. James A. Beaver will preside. A number of interesting papers upon forestry and kindred subjects have been prepared, while through the liberality of citizens and organizations courtesies have been promised to those attending the Congress which will make the meeting most enjoyable.

--Harper Brothers will issue Dr. Hill's "Boswell's Johnson" as a limited edition, with numerous portraits not contained in the Oxford publication. This edition of Boswell is a monument of scholarly research and careful editing. It has super seded all others.

The United States sloop-of-war Kearsarge will sail from this port some time to-morrow with Minister Frederick Douglass, his wife, and one of his daughters, and a private secretary aboard, bound for Hayti.

HARTFORD, Sept. 29.--The American artist Alexander W. Harrison, who has received one of the gold medals at the Paris Exposition, is a descendant of Gov. Oliver Wolcott of this State. His father, Apollos Wolcott Harrison, was a native of New-Haven, and resided in that city most of his life.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 29.--The contest over the will of Christopher Meyer was to have been resumed Saturday, but the case was adjourned for two weeks, none of the New-York counsel being present. It is said that a movement is on foot to have the case compromised. The rumor is denied by counsel here, however, one of whom volunteered the information that the delay was owing to a telegraphic request to ex-Gov. Abbett.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--Theodore Cramp of the well-known shipbuilders of Philadelphia, who has been making an extensive tour of the West and Alaska, was in the city yesterday on his way home.

Burton Many, a young man eighteen years of age, living with his parents in apartments at 2,299 Eighth-avenue, attempted to commit suicide at about 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning by swallowing a solution of iodine, but was quickly taken to Manhattan Hospital in an ambulance end saved by a timely application of the stomach pump.

A vigorous protest against the Central Labor Union's going into politics was sent to that body yesterday by the Central Association of Carpet Workers, with which John Morrison is connected.

Eugene L. Herrick, the grain broker, of 190 Lincoln-place, Brooklyn, who was arrested for insulting ladies in a local dry goods store on Saturday, was released from Raymond-Street Jail yesterday on $500 bail. He went home at once, and a TIMES reporter saw him there last night.

WESTERLY, R.I., Sept. 29.--What is considered the finest piece of workmanship in the line of modeling in clay ever produced in this place has just been completed and cast in plaster at the studio of the Smith granite quarries.

Mr. and Mrs. Kendal, the English actors, who are to make a tour of America this season under the management of Mr. Daniel Frohman, arrived in New-York last night on the steamship Servia. On leaving the ship they went at once to the Victoria Hotel, where they were seen by a reporter for THE TIMES.

YONKERS, Sept. 29.--Shortly after 4 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the three-story frame building 37 North Broadway, this city, owned by C.E. Waring, and occupied by Joseph Reneker as a bakery, George Thomas as a clothing store, and the upper floors by seven families as tenements.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 29.--Chairman Dunn of the Democratic State Central Committee opened headquarters here yesterday, and today the letter of acceptance the Hon. Horace Boies, Democratic candidate for Governor, was given to the public.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 29.--The annex to Gov. David B. Hill's Liquor Dealers' Convention will assemble at the Alhambra Hall Tuesday at noon, in response to the sour-mash call issued by Gov. Hill at Saratoga six weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--An interesting volume entitled "Working Women in Large Cities," prepared by Commissioner Carroll D. Wright of the Department of Labor during the last Administration, has just come from the presses of the Government Printing Office.

The fiftieth birthday of Miss Frances E. Willard, President of the National Women's Christian Temperance Union, was celebrated Saturday night by a large gathering in the First Methodist Church, Evanston. Messages of congratulation were read from notables throughout the country, including the poet Whittier and ex-President Rutherford B. Hayes.
The physicians interested in the Bushwick and East Brooklyn Dispensary, at Myrtleavenue and Lewis-street, Brooklyn, are fighting just now over rival claimants to the Presidency of the medical staff.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Sept. 29.--Canadian and American capitalists have applied to the Canadian Parliament for a charter for a railroad from the Canadian "Soo" to Hudson's Bay.

DANSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 29.--J.E. Crisfield, George S. Ewart, and J.J. Barrett have been elected delegates from Livingston County to the Democratic State Convention. They favor O'Brien for Judge. They are instructed to support William Hamilton of Livingston for Secretary of State.

The Evangelical Alliance for the United States will hold a national meeting in Tremont Temple, Boston, the 4th, 5th, and 6th of December next. A most attractive programme has been prepared, including the names of many eminent clergymen and laymen. The meeting is expected to equal in interest and influence the great Washington Conference of 1887. Information concerning special rates of travel and entertainment will be given to the public in due time.

LONDON, Sept. 29.--Discount was in strong demand during the past week at 4 for three months and 5 for short. Speculative activity on the Stock Exchange was diverted from the usual channels and centred in South African land and mining shares.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29.--Mr. R.P. Halliday, the defaulting Cashier of the First National Bank of Mount Gilead, Ohio, came to Columbus to-day and surrendered himself to the United States Marshal. He is a defaulter to the amount of $36,000.
On the 26th of August last the people of Tokio united in celebrating the three hundredth anniversary of the establishment of their city as a political capital.

ALBANY, Sept. 29.--The Hon. Willis S. Paine, Superintendent of the State Banking Department, has resigned his office to accept the Presidency of the State Trust Company of New-York City, incorporated yesterday with a capital of $1,000,000. His resignation takes effect Oct. 1. It is understood that Gov. Hill will not appoint a successor to Mr. Paine until next week.

WESTERLY, R.I., Sept. 29.--Genial and entertaining Capt. Winslow Nash, the oldest resident of Watch Hill, who had been known for at least half a century to the Summer guests at tha resort, died yesterday in his seventy-fourth year, of heart failure.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 29.--At a stated meeting of the Common Council, the following resolution was introduced by Alderman Sheerin, and adopted by a unanimous vote: "That the Common Council of the city of Middletown heartily favors New-York City as the place for holding the World's Fair of 1892."
Lieut. S.P. Colvocoresses has been appointed head of the Department of Mechanical Drawing at the Naval Academy, Vice Lieut. Commander B.F. Tilley, detracted.

PITTSFIELD, Mass, Sept. 29.--Alfred Ford and Firon Champine were drowned this afternoon in Pontoosuc Lake. They were out rowing with two others, and, while attempting to pass each other in the boat, it accidentally overturned and all four went into the water, the two young men being drowned. Champine is twenty-three and Ford twenty-four years old. Both were single. The bodies were recovered after having been in the water an hour.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Sept. 29.-- The floods at Celaya and Lagos continue. The first train on the Central Railroad got through to-day. National trains will not be able to go through for several days, but passengers and mails are transferred from one section to another.

The steamship Victoria of the Anchor Line, which arrived Saturday night from Gibraltar and the Mediterranean, was detained at Quarantine by Health Officer Smith yesterday. On examination two cases of varioloid were found among the steerage passengers, who are mostly made up of Italians.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 30.--The most bitterly contested political campaign ever fought in Washington ends with the setting of to-day's sun. Twenty--four hours later it will have been decided whether Washington's first Government is to be Republican or Democratic.
