PITTSBURG, Sept. 30.--New-York failed to win to-day. The game, however, resulted in a draw and the Giants are still in the lead by a small margin. This, of course, is a source of satisfaction, but the Bostons are getting too close now, and the champions will have to make a spurt in order to protect their laurels.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Sept. 30.--Mrs. Manning, Miss Tate, and William McElroy, who were injured in Friday night's accident on the New-York Central Road, are all much better this morning. The funeral of Charles Franklin, the porter who was killed in the accident, was held this morning, and was largely attended by colored people and others.

ROSS FORK, Idaho, Sept. 30.--Compared with the average Indian, the thoroughbred savage who sticks to his blanket as a royal robe and accepts his weekly rations of beef, flour, and baking powder as the portion of a Prince, the lily of the field is a symbol and illusration of progressive industry.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--The cotton corner at Liverpool has collapsed on a report that Mr. Steenstrand, the manipulator of the corner, was selling. Prices for September delivery fell from 6 45-64d. to 6 16-64d., and then rose to 6 21-64d.

The publication on Sunday of Henry R. Towne's maps and his descriptive letter in regard to possible sites for the World's Fair had the desired effect of rousing active interest anew on this subject and of enlisting very many in its discussion who have heretofore held aloof.

Although the season for football is near at hand it does not look very bright for NewYork. PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30.--The annual meeting of the Princeton College Junior Class was held to-day in the English Hall. CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 30.--The Constitutional Convention finished its labors to-night, when every member of the body signed the document with a pen made of Wyoming gold. In an address to the people sound arguments in favor of Statehood and the Constitution a made. It will be submitted Nov. 6, and every effort will be made to bring out a big vote.

Julia Marlowe began her season at Ford's Opera House, Baltimore, last night appearing as Rosalind in "As You Like It." She was greeted by a large and brilliant audience, which bestowed generous applause on her performance. Miss Marlowe's Baltimore engagement is for a week, during which she will be seen as Parthenia in "Ingomar," Julia in "The Hunch back," and Galatea in "Pygmalion and Galatea.

After much talk and many weeks of hysteria Wall-street's bear contingent yesterday played its vaunted trump card. Money was made tight. The loaning rate at one time was put as high as 30 per cent. There was no trace, however, of anything like that panic which has been so freely promised and predicted. In fact, the stock market generally was really stronger at the close than at the beginning of the day's business.

Coe of 535 Washington-avenue entered and demanded to know why the department had sent him a notice to pay at once a balance of 29 cents, taxes due on a vacant lot.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--There were novelties enough on the Chicago stage last week to tempt even jaded playgoers, and the patronage accorded the leading houses has been correspondingly good.

SITKA, Sept. 12.--The United States revenue cutter Rush, commanded by Capt. Shepard, arrived at Sitka at noon to-day after a Summer's cruise in Behring Sea, attempting to protect the sealing interests of the United States.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 30.--The Prohibition City Convention to-night nominated Elias F. Morrow, a lawyer, for Mayor. The platform urges the extermination of the liquor traffic in the interest of workingmen, and denounces the Republican and Democratic Parties for the nonenforcement of the Sunday laws.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 1.--The secret conference of the anti-Mahone Republicans, called by Gen. V. D. Groner, the Chairman of the State Committee of that faction of the Republican Party in the State, is in session here to-night to adopt a line of policy to be pursued toward Mahone in the present canvass. There are about two hundred and fifty persons in attendance.

Burke. The Grand Jurors then retired, and called before them Marshal Stoddard, A.K. McLean, William B. Stansberry, and Alfred Jardet. The jury then returned into court nine indictments for embezzlement for public money.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 1.--About two weeks ago a student in the Junior Class at Dartmouth, charged with breaking down the door of a Freshman's room in Wentworth Hall, was expelled by the Faculty. His classmates united in efforts to reinstate him and submitted evidence which, they say, was sufficient to prove his innocence. The Faculty thought differently, however, and declined to allow him to return to the college.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1.--The subscriptions for the new stock of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad Company have been taken up by the present stockholders.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 1.--The Bay State House corridors are full to-night of excited delegates to to-morrow's Democratic State Convention. Most of the excitement is occasioned by the fight among the rival Democratic tactions in Boston for recognition.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 1.--In the Faulkner bank-wrecking case to-day Gen. Lester B. Faulkner again took the stand in his own defense. White important to the jury perhaps, the testimony was of no special interest to the public.

ROTTERDAM, Oct. 1.--Representatives of the shippers and the strikers had a conference today, which lasted six hours, but which was without result. The shippers' committee will meet the masters and others for the purpose of considering the strikers' damands. Afterward the strikers will hold a meeting to consider the proposals of the shippers.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., Oct. 1.--Two persons visited Mrs. Robert Ray Hamilton in her attic prison to-day. The first of these was Mrs. Rupp, late of Noll Cottage, Atlantic City. Mrs. Rupp came down from Philadelphia on an early train.

Yesterday was a lively day down in the Custom House. Theodore B. Willis, the new Naval Officer, came around in the morning to take charge of his new job. Col. Burt was there to receive him and introduce him to those who are in his department.

The night school for girls held in Grammar School No. 71, on Seventh-street, between Avenues B and C, was discontinued last June. The School Trustees of the Eleventh Ward are anxious for its re-establishment.

The Boston Chamber of Commerce yesterday elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President--Alden Speare; Vice President--Wallace F. Robinson; Treasurer--Frederick M. Chency; Directors for three years--Edwin R. De Long, Henry M. Whitney, Edward B. Hosmer, and Dana I. McIntire; Director for one year, to fill vacancy--George A. Allison.

The Campanini-Whitney Concert Company began its tour in Erie on Monday evening, opening to a large audience. Mlle. de Vere, Mme. Poole, Bologna, and Whitney were enthusiastically received. As for Campanini, his manager declares that he is in better voice than ever.
Testimony was given before Referee Douras in the Giblin case yesterday to show that Giblin had been a counterfeiter and had passed a raised bill before he tried it at the Goelz bakery.

The attention of a steamboat squad policeman was called last night to a handsome old man, an ideal King Lear, with silken, flowing, white beard and hair and regular but anxious features, who was in the waiting room at the Cortlandt-Street Ferry.

PORT ROWAN, Ontario, Oct. 1.--The schoone Erie Wave, commanded by Capt. Stafford, capsized last night between here and Clear Creek, and eight persons were drowned. The vessel had been aground for some days, and had an extra crew aboard to assist in getting her off. A squall struck her last night and she capsized.

LONDON, Oct. 1.--The trouble between Capt. J.W. Lawler and Mr. Black over the ownership of the boat Neversink, in which Capt. Lawler crossed the Atlantic, has culminated in bloodshed.

BUTTE CITY, Montana, Oct. 1.--Smoky, homely, dusty, wonderful Butte! It is all very well for people from Colorado to compare it with Leadville, which may be like it in the sense that all the large mining camps in the Rocky Mountains and in the mineral belt have many characteristics in common, but it seems impossible that there should be just such another place as Butte.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 1.--The war ship Emerald will leave to-morrow for the scene of the wreck of her Majesty's ship Lily. she will take on board a number of casks and a quantity of timber, to be used in raising the Lily's three guns, which are now lying in shoal water at Armour Point. The Emerald will be absent three weeks.

The General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church opens with a service of morning prayer at 9 o'clock to-day in St. George's Church and Memorial House.
The annual cane rush between Sophomores and Freshmen of Stevens Institute came off yesterday afternoon at St. George's Cricket Club grounds, Hoboken, at 2:30 o'clock in the afternoon...

The outlook in the Eighth Senatorial District is as complicated as a Chinese puzzle. On the Republican side, to which the district normally belongs, the friends of the wicked exSenator Gibbs manifest a desire to nominate him without regard to consequences.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--Ben Campbell Jones, son of T. Russell Jones, ex-Collector of the Port of Chicago, and a well-known capitalist, has been committed to the Asylum for the Insane at Kankakee, Ill., at the request of his family.
Emma Elizabeth Wharton, of Emma Elizabeth Dalton, was arrested in East Newark, N.J., yesterday for bigamy. She is a pretty and stylish woman of twenty-six, but is well known...

HARTFORD, Oct. 1.--The chestnut and walnut crops in this State will be the smallest in years this season. The month of September has passed without a hard frost, and the chestnut harvest is from ten days to two weeks later than usual.

Goodwin's Official Guide, No. 10, was issued last evening with the record of all races run up to and including Monday last. The book makes now a volume of something over six hundred pages, and is as full of meat as an egg. Its table of winning jockeys shows Barnes in the lead with a record of 142 winners. Taylor being second with 98, and Hamilton a close third with 97.

Boatkeeper Jackson of the pilot boat Lillie, No. 8, reported to the Pilot Board yesterday an instance of deliberate violation of the law prohibiting vessels from dumping ashes or other substances in the channels of the harbor.
Chief Clerk D. Van Duzer of the Landing Bureau, Castle Garden, was suspended by Commissioner Stephenson yesterday on a complaint made by Mrs. Sloper, a matron, employed in the same department.
Encouraging progress was made yesterday by the committees having in charge the development of the World's Fair project.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 1.--The refusal of some of the railroad companies to answer the questions propounded to them by the Governor of Iowa is likely to occasion their appearance in court as defendants in suits for forfeits.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 1.--Two good solid singles, four very scratchy ones, a base on balls, and Ewing's muff at the plate yielded the home team 6 runs in the fifth inning to-day and won the game beyond all doubt.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 1.--Ex-President Cleveland arrived to-night at the Whitneys. ExSecretary Endicott and party arrived from Boston this afternoon in a special car. The ex-Secretary and Mrs. Endicott are guests of the Whitneys.

Further efforts were made yesterday to mark up the rate or money on the Stock Exchange, and at one time it was raised as high as 16 per cent. It didn't stay there long, however, most loans of consequence being negotiated between 5 and 7 per cent, though apprehension as to what the bear manipulators might attempt or be able to do kept the quotation at a higher figure, averaging something like 10 per cent.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 1.--The Republicans of the First District of Saratoga County to-day, at Ballston Spa, nominated Cornelius R. Shaffer as a candidate for the Assembly.

The second annual indoor games of the Prospect Harriers will be held in the Fifth-Avenue Casino, Brooklyn, on Thursday, Oct. 17, at 8 P.M. The open events are 50-yard dash and 1,000-yard run, handicaps. Entries will close Oct. 7 with W.W. Kuhlke, 331 St. Mark's-avenue, Brooklyn.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The Genesee Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church met in its eightieth session to-day in this city, Bishop J.W. Fitzgerald of Minneapolis, Minn., presiding. There are about two hundred delegates in attendance, and the session will continue one week. C.W. Winchester of Medina was chosen Secretary, H.C. Woods of Victor Assistant Secretary. G.W. Harris Statician Secretary, and S. W. Morris of Lima Treasurer.

The season began at Daly's Theatre last night with the customary demonstration. This "first night" is the most fashionable theatrical event of the year in New-York, and a finer audience than that which saw the first performance of "The Golden Widow" could not be gathered together on this side of the Atlantic Ocean.

SIOUX FALLS, South Dakota, Oct. 2.--The figures of the temporary capital fight accumulate slowly, but at this time, with about two hundred precincts in the State to be heard from, Pierre leads with nearly 10,000 votes.

Col. John Rueger is the latest candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor of Brooklyn. His name was first mentioned by the delegates who went to Washington a few days ago after Federal patronage, and his availability was, it is said, a subject of discussion with Secretary Tracy.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 2.--The annual meeting of the Louisville and Nashville stocholders took place this afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 2.--In accordance with an ordinance passed by the City Council at its session last night Mayor Shakespeare this evening issued an order to the Chief of Police to close all gambling establishments in the city.

Frank Green, Signal Corps, has been ordered to superintend the removal and reconstruction between Holbrook and Fort Apache, Arizona, of the telegraph line now operatad between Prescott and Phoenix, Arizona.

VANCOUVER, Washington, Oct. 2.--Judging from the count in the two Vancouver precincts the Republican State and legislative tickets are carried in Clark County two to one. East Vancouver has been carried for the first time by the Republicans. The vote here is exceptionally heavy. The Constitution is carried three to one.

The Trunk Line Presidents met yesterday and decided not to publish a through rate to St. Paul, or in other words refused to pro rate with the Northwestern roads to that point as suggested by Commissioner Faithorn some weeks ago.
HELENA, Montana, Oct. 2.--Returns are coming in very slowly, and the figures are so close that the majorities will not be much either way. The Democrats claim the State by 300 to 500.
One of the most brilliant meets ever held in the neighborhood of New-York came off yesterday on Staten Island, through a conjunction of the Rockaway Hunt and the Richmond County Country Club.
"Founder's Day" was celebrated at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn yesterday. The public was not invited to attend, but the assembly hall was filled with students of the institution.
A Brooklyn paper contained a notice yesterday afternoon of the marriage of Augustus S. Van De Linde and Annie Wiliams, and within half an hour after its publication the groom had committed suicide.
Jefferson Hunt, who had been for thirteen years a collector in Dodge Bliss's lumber yard in Jersey City, was arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by Justice Weed for embezzlement.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Oct. 2.--After prayer, which was made by the Rev. Mr. Corlidge, an educated Indian, the Hon. A.K. Smiley welcomed the guests to the seventh annual Mohonk conference, and nominated Gen. Clinton B. Fisk for President.

"Clover" will have its one hundred and fiftieth performance at Palmer's Theatre to-night, and but four more opportunities remain to witness this charming opera. CHICAGO, Oct. 2.--The October pork deal still leads in interest in trade circles. It was less exciting to-day in many respects than Monday or Tuesday, yet it presented features enough, new and otherwise, to keep it to the front.

Hill is likely to have his hands full between now and Nov. 5 in smoothing out the party wrinkles and whipping into line the recalcitrant factions.

LONDON, Oct. 2.--It is announced that Miss Martha Otis and Mr. George Peabody Munroe with be married in Paris Nov. 6.
The new ferryboat Pierrepont of the Union Ferry Company was given a trial trip yesterday. She is 209 feet long, 37 feet beam, and draws 10 feet of water.

Inspectors of Customs Larkin, Donohue, and Coleman of Surveyor Lyon's staff were dismissed from the service yesterday. Larkin and Donohue were accused of insubordination some time ago and of collecting night fees that did not properly belong to them, as they were not assigned to the vessel from which the fees were collected.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2.--The Democratic State Convention was a very tame affair. The State ticket nominated, with one or two minor exceptions, was that outlined in last nights's dispatches. Ex-Mayor Russell of Cambridge was nominated for Governor by acclamation, and the other names on the State ticket were reported by a committee appointed for that purpose.

ROTTERDAM, Oct. 2.--Another conference took place to-day between the shippers and the representatives of the strikers. The shippers conceded some of the demands of the strikers, whereupon the representatives of the latter modified their other demands. This ends the strike, and the men will go to work to-morrow.

Four large ocean steamships spread their sails to the freshening breeze yesterday morning and flew down the bay in grand procession on their way to European ports.

It has been claimed that the Rev. Dr. Carruthers of Portland, who recently celebrated his eighty-ninth birthday, was the oldest clergyman in Maine, but this must be a mistake. The Rev. J.T. Hawes, pastor of the Congregational Church at Litchfield Corner, recently celebrated his ninety-first birthday. The Rev. Mr. Hawes and his wife joined the Juvenile Temple last week to please their grandchildren.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 2.--There is no material change in the situation at Dartmouth. The Juniors, who voted yesterday to leave the college unless the Faculty reinstated their classmate who had bean expelled, cut all recitations to-day. The Faculty has notified them that they will be suspended if they do not resume work to-morrow.

To see the crowd push into the gates of the Westchester track of the New-York Jockey Club yesterday would give one an idea that there was no racing in this vicinity except at that beautiful track.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 2.--All is joy in the camp of the Giants to-night. The boys are in high glee and it is safe to predict that if they didn't have to play good ball for a few days longer they would indulge in a little town painting to-night.

The Board of Railroad Commissioners of the State has published its conclusions in the matter of the Third-Avenue Railroad Company's application for the board's approval of a change of motive power from horses to cable.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 2.--Willis S. Paine, the retiring Superintendent of the Banking Department, to-day transferred the department's books and securities, amounting in the aggregate to $2,358,482.83, to his deputy, C.R. Hall, who is now the Acting Superintendent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The two-masted schooner George C. Finney, with a cargo of 20,000 bushels of wheat from Toledo, encountered a waterspout while off Port Colborne yesterday, and when it left her she was barely afloat. The foremast was gone to the deck, the mainmast was broken off half way down, and the jibboom was twisted out. Of the sails, only the mainsail was saved.
FARGO, North Daxota. Oct. 2.--Returns from twenty-six out of thirty-one legislative districts give the Republicans 68 on a joint ballot, and Democrats and Independents 14.
BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 2.--Clear weather favored the Baltimore shooters to-day, and a slightly-increased attendance was the result.
The twenty-second annual Fall games of the New-York Athletic Club will be held at the club's grounds at Travers Island on Saturday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2.--Secretary Tracy has decided to appoint Commodore Joseph S. Skerrett commandant of the navy yard at Portsmouth, N.H., to succeed Capt. Robert F. Bradford, who has been selected to command the Philadelphia.

HIGH BRIDGE, N.J., Oct. 2.--At the Central Railroad of New-Jersey's stone quarries, about two miles west of this place, at 2 P.M. to-day, three men were seriously injured and one killed by an explosion. They had put in a blast, and, as it did not go off as soon as they thought it should, ventured back to ascertain the cause, and the discharge occurred when they were within a few feet of the hole.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 2.-- News reached here to-day of the death of Mrs. Augustus Phillips, nee Mosee Richards, who committed suicide on Sunday by drowning.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-seventh District met here at noon to-day. Before the opening Senator Sweet claimed Seneca County with 5 votes, George Priest had Tompkins County's 6 votes, Thomas Hunter one district of Cayuga with 5 votes, and W.L. Noyes the other with the same number, while Tioga's 6 votes were unpledged. Fourteen votes were necessary to a choice.

MT. DORMAN B. EATON read at the meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League yesterday an extended and able argument against the eligibility of a President of the United States for re-election and in favor of a constitutional prohibition thereof.

Francis Broshart, Jr., aged sixteen years, of 702 Flushing-avenue, and Samuel Jones, aged fifteen, of 758 Park-avenue, Brooklyn, have been missing from their homes since Saturday last, and, it is believed, have gone to sea. An hour before leaving they told a youthful companion that they were doing to Newport, and showed him railroad tickets for that place.

Edward L. Mann, a well-to-do telegraph operator, for twenty years in the Western Union service at Louisville, Ky., committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself through the head. He was unreasonably jealous, and a surprise party given in honor of his wife's birthday excited his passion, and this, added to an excess of drink, made him wild. He leaves three children.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 2.--At 10 o'clock tonight a call was received by the Rochester Fire Department from Fairport, a village of 4,000 inhabitants, ten miles east of here. The L.J. Deland saleratus works, the largest of the kind in the country, are burning. The local steamer gave out and the fire spread to adjoining business blocks.
The cornerstone of the new building for the New-York Academy of Medicine, at 17 to 21 West Forty-third-street, was laid at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2.--Clark University was formally opened this afternoon. The exercises took place in the upper hall of the main building, where 1,500 people were packed into space hardly sufficent for 1,200. Hundreds of people were turned away unable to get inside the hall. There were no decorations in the hall and no music.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3.--A dispatch from San Francisco says: "Judge Sawyer has rendered a decision which covers the cases of all sealers seized, in Behring Sea. In 1887 the sealing schooner San Diego, owned by L.N. Handy, was seized by the cutter Rush and ordered to Sitka. She went, and nearly six hundred skins were condemned, brought here by Marshal Atkins, and sold.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 3.--The Woman Suffrage Party of this State met in convention here to-day in the Town Hall. About twentyfive delegates, including the State Committee of the party, are on hand. Numerically speaking, it does not look as if the convention will be a flattering success.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Oct. 3.--Spreading rails as a sequence to a neglected roadbed caused five passenger coaches to leave the track and topple into the ditch ten miles east of Chey enne at 10 o'clock to-day. The conductor and six passengers were seriously injured, but all will recover. The same train was in a collision with a freight train in Nebraska last night. A negro tramp was killed in this accident.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct 3.--McFarran, Shallcross Co., one of the largest pork handling firms here, will probably retire from business, in consequence of the withdrawal, with a fortune, of J.B. McFerran, the sentor member. Mr. McFerran is owner of Glenview Stock Farm and will devote himself to that. The sharp competition in the business, inaugurated by Armour and others, has cut down profits so that the other members find small inducement to continue the business.

GETTYSBURG, Ponn., Oct. 3.--The sixteen monuments erected by the State of Maine on this battlefield were christened to-night. At 8 o'clock the County Court House was crowded with 400 veterans of the Pine Tree State and the usual quota of citizens to witness the formal exerclses of dedication.

President James J. Hill of the St. Paul, Minneapolis and Manitoba Railway issued yesterday to his company's stockholders a circular explaining reasons for the proposed new issue of stock and pointing out advantages that the increased capital will enable the road to control.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 3.--One day has gone by, thirty ballots have been taken, and the Republican Judicial Convention for the Eignth District is no nearer a solution of the problem that confronted it this morning than it was when the delegates had been finally elected.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 3.--The Latonia races were run off to-day with these results: FIRST RACK.--Three-quarters of a mile, for all ages. Alta won, Passion second, and Electricity third. Time--1:18 .

ALBERT LEA, Minn., Oct 3.--A great peat fire is burning near Geneva, in this county. It is estimated that 5,500 acres of land has been burned over and 6,000 tons of hay destroyed. Over l70 loads in stacks, owned by L.T. Bell, were burned Tuesday, and every day some farmer loses more or less.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct 3.--The Hon. George Bancroft, the historian, observed his eightyninth birthday very quietly at his cottage here to-day. He received many callers and a large number of letters and telegrams of congratulation. He is in good health and possesses all of his faculties.

The funeral of Chevalier Ira Paine, the world's crack pistol shot, took place from his late home on Delane-street, Providence. R.I. yesterday, his body having arrived on Tuesday from Paris, where he died. The Rev. Thomas H. Cocroft of the Church of the Messiah performed the Episcopal service. The body was buried at Swan Point.

FINDLEY, Ohio, Oct. 3.--The Republicans of this Congressional district opened the campaign here to-night with a speech from Major William McKinley and one from Congressman H.L. Morey. The meeting was large and enthusiastic, and the Major made one of his best and most eloquent tariff efforts.

CLEVELAND, Oct 3.--New-York began the last of the series here to-day in a manner that would send a thrill of joy to the hearts of the admirers of the champions. It was a one-sided game of the most decided character.

CHARLESTON, west Va., Oct. 3.--This morning at the little station of Nuttallsburg, on the Chesapeake and Ohio Road, a shifting engine was run on a side track and the fireman, Wil1iam Layton, got out of the cab and began shooting at a mark with a revolver, while Engineer George Steele watched him from the cab window.

BOSTON, Oct. 3.--An interesting match in lawn tennis doubles was played this afternoon on the Longwood grounds, Brookline, between F. Mansfield and Kerr, the Irish Champion, on one side, and Dr. Dwight and Tom Pettitt on the othet. Mansfield and Kerr won, 7--5, 6--1, 6--3.
RACINE, Wis., Oct. 3.--Hugo Steinau, arrested in Milwaukee and brought here on a charge of abandoning his family, claims to be a son of Count von Steinau, a wealthy German nobleman.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 3.--A most excellent portrait of Gen. U. S. Grant was presented to the Military Academy two years ago by Mr. George W. Childs and was hung in a conspicuous position in the cadets' newly-decorated mess hall.

PARIS, Oct. 3.--Mr. Walter A. Wood, the veteran inventor and maker of mowers, reapers, and binders, of Hoosac Falls, N.Y., has been awarded by the judges at the exposition a special grand prize. MERIDEN, Conn., Oct. 3.--Charles B. Pratt, confidential bookkeeper and Secretary and Cashier of the H. Wales Lines Company, was arrested last night for embezzlement, and this morning the preliminary hearing was continued for two weeks, under $4,000 bonds, which he did not secure. FRESNO, Cal., Oct. 4.--Senator Stanford's three-year-old Sunol trotted a mile here to-day in 2:13 , breaking all previous records for three-year-olds.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 4.--The present management of the Mexican National Railway is being severely criticised by the press, and the condition of portions of the line, on which derailments are frequent, justify the complaints by the public and the Government inspector.
HELENA, Montana, Oct. 4.--The situation this morning shows that Toole (Dem.) is probably elected Governor.
MONTREAL, Oct. 4.--T. Tandy, General Freight Agent of the Grand Trunk Railroad, dropped dead to-night of heart disease.
Prince BISMARCK presided over the congress of Berlin in 1878, and Secretary of State BLAINE should preside over the congress of all the Americas at Washington.

George Johnson and John Hanson of Worcester, Mass., employed by Darling Brothers at Rockville, Conn., as stage builders on the Union Church, were precipitated seventy-five feet yesterday by breaking of staging. Hanson's skull was broken, and he was almost instantly killed. Johnson's back is broken, his ribs are driven into his lungs, and he can't live.

The statement that Mr. Breed of Lynn received a vote in the Massachusetts Republican Convention recalls the anecdote told years ago of an ambitious Pennsylvanian named Green, who was a candidate for an office.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4.--It is surmised here that the relations of the Administration and Judge Walter Q. Gresham are somewhat strained.

Judge Barrett of the Supreme Court yesterday went a step further than Referee Smyth in regard to cutting down lawyers' fees in the proceedings for the dissolution of the New-York Protective Associations, District Assembly No. 49.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 4.--The widow of Charles H. Moore, State Insurance Commissioner, is still in the custody of the Sheriff and quite ill. The attorneys for the creditors of the estate have caused a new citation to be issued for service upon her to-day, but Mrs. Moore was not able to appear in court.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 4.--About fifty ministers, members of the Genesee Methodist Conference, yesterday passed a resolution deprecating the removal of Tanner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--The official report of the trial of the Baltimore, received by Secretary Tracy to-day, confirms the rumor that her horse power was not quite up to the 9,000 required.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The Senatorial Convention took ten ballots this morning without change and adjourned to meet here Wednesday next. Senator sweet's friends are certain he will re renominated.
The steel despatch cruiser Dolphin was engaged yesterday in discharging powder at Ellis Island.

It was stated at the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce on Thursday that Secretary WINDOM had recently declared in a letter that if a large majority of the importers of this city were in favor of an uptown site for the new Appraiser's Stores he is "open to conviction."

MILWAUKEE, Wis, Oct. 4.--A runaway horse last evening tumbled out John W. Cary and Frederick Layton, both millionaires of this city. Both gentlemen were hurled into a pile of gravel. The accident happened on Wisconsinstreet, close to the Milwaukee Club house, and...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 4.--The Tradesman has instituted an exhaustive inquiry into the cotton mill industry of the South and has received reports from all the leading mills of the Southern States. The actual number of mills in operation is 339, against 142 in 1880, an increase...

The controversy in Boston between American actors there and the United States Treasury Department over the importation, free of duty, of the 300 tons of scenery belonging to Wilson Barrett and his theatrical company, seems to have spread, with a slightly different aspect, to this city.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 4.--The annual report of the Secretary of the Middlesex County Sunday School Association has just been prepared and sent to the State Association.

Detectives are still looking for Mrs. Raymond or Mrs. Reynolds, who figures so prominently in the Flack case, but they have not been successful in locating her. They thought they knew just where she was a week before the indictments were found against her.

A story which appeared in a morning paper, and whose publication was somewhat out of the ordinary way because unwarranted by legal proceedings, revealed certain unfortunate occurrences within the family of the late Commodore Nathaniel L. McCready which have for some time past been discussed by friends of the interested parties.

According to the established custom of Episcopal conventions the proceedings of the third day's session in St. George's Church yesterday were begun by the reading of the morning prayer, in this instance by the Rev. Dr. Henry A. Coit of New-Hampshire.

Rear Admiral L.A. Kimberly, in a communication to the Navy Department, reports his arrival at Honolulu Sept. 20, from Samoa, per steamer Alameda. He says that he has hoisted his flag on board of the Alert.

Striped bass are about the only game fish caught near at home now. They are not appearing in overwhelming numbers, and, indeed, are not as abundant as the old habitues of their resorts think they should be. As it was the week previous, so it has been this week--a few were taken at nearly every fishing ground near the city; but none was very large, nor were any big takes reported.

EL PASO, Texas, Oct. 4.--This city is considerably exercised over reports to the effect that smallpox is raging at Socorro, New-Mexico, 200 miles from this city. These reports have been confirmed by passengers and railway conductors passing through Socorro. They say that up to midnight eighty-seven cases were reported. The Board of Health of El Paso had a meeting last night and decided to quarantine Socorro. Compulsory vaccination has been ordered in the public schools.

The withdrawal of the AEtna Fire Insurance Company of Hartford from what is called the New-Hampshire compact changes the conditions under which a very interesting experiment has been carried on in that State during the last four years. In 1885 the Legislature of New-Hampshire enacted a "valued policy" law, and on Sept. 1 of that...

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The tax suit between the State of New-York and the city of NewYork for the collection of $323,000, the balance claimed to be due on the State tax of 1887, was argued on behalf of the city of New-York to-day before the referee, Edwin Countryman. The city was represented by James W.M. Newlin and George S. Coleman, Assistant Corporation Counsel.

Superintendent Murray yesterday sent a report to the Board of Police in relation to an increase of the force in precincts where they are needed on a basis of an addition of 150 men to the patrol force.
BANGOR, Me., Oct. 4.--As the three-masted British schooner Wandrin, hailing from Parrsborough, N.S., was about to sail from this place for the home port, to load lumber for New-York,...

DELHI, N.Y., Oct. 4.--Gov. Hill talked about State taxes to the Delaware County farmers today at what was called an "adjourned county fair." The Governor is using the Associated Press to spread broadcast his speeches, thus emphasizing his ideas about economy by saving the personal expense of a literary bureau.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 4.--The court of inquiry int the loss of the Lilly on the coast of Labrador on the l6th of September last concluded its investigation yesterday. The prosecution finished on Wednesday, and yesterday morning Capt. Russell and one or two expert navigators for the defense showed that the course steered by the navigator at the time of the disaster was correct in every particular.

The anti-ring Democrats of the Sixth District of Hudson County, N.J., will hold a public meeting at Union Hill this evening, which will be addressed by ex-Senator Rudolph F. Rabe, Judge William B. Rankin, William Stuhr, and Peter Mercelles.

"J.T.D."--Homicide is justifiable in every case in which it is rendered necessary in selfdefense against the person who comes to com mit a known felony with force against one's person or habitation or against the persons of those who stand near in domestic relations.

Mayor Grant sent out yesterday afternoon invitations to the members of the Committee for the International Exposition of 1892 to meet at the Governor's Room in the City Hall next Thursday, at 3 o'clock.

RIVERHEAD, Oct. 4.--The last day of the thirty-seventh annual exhibition of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society at this place had but a slight attendance. Most of the people on the fair grounds were those having articles on exhibition.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 4.--This afternoon the NewYorks again easily defeated the local club and entered on the last lap of the great struggle for baseball supremacy.

The case for the people in the Giblin hearing before Referee Douras was completed yesterday morning. The last witness called by Assistant District Attorney Jerome was Capt. Seldon A. Day of the United States Army.

The Board of Street Opening and Improvement met yesterday in the Mayor's office. A number of property owners on Washington Heights appeared to protest against the extension of High Bridge Park below One Hundred and Seventieth-street and above One Hundred and Eighty-first-street.

The remarkable smuggling exploit of Allard Sons, 304 Fifth-avenue, which was exposed last April through the agency of the Custom House officials, has recently been brought before the Collector or the Port again.

Apparently upon authority, it was announced yesterday that finally there had been drafted a financial plan for the World's Fair in New-York. It would be issued, it was stated, at a meeting of the World's Fair Finance Committee next Tuesday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 4.--Attorney General Tabor, in an opinion given to-day, holds that the Trustees of a trust company, upon receiving the consent of the Superintendent of the Banking Department, may, by resolution, increase their number to any number even in excess of the twenty-four mentioned in Section 1 of the Trust Company act.

About five hundred members and guests of the Pioneers of Liberty, an organization recently formed among the United Hebrew Trades, who went to Clarendon Hall last night expecting to dance and listen to music and make merry generally, found the door closed.

GREENSBOROUGH, N. C., Oct. 4.--The seaboard system of railroads, as controlled by Col. John M. Robinson of Baltimore, seems determined to invade the territory of the Richmond and Danville at this place.

Not since the disruption of the Metropolitan Association of Fire Underwriters in April, 1887, following the withdrawal of the Williamsburg City Fire Insurance Company from its ranks, has anything occurred to excite so much feeling and comment in insurance circles as the announcement just made by the AEtna Company of Hartford of its withdrawal from the NewHampshire compact.

The American Church Sunday School Institute will devote next Thursday evening and Friday to a special institute to be held during the session of the General Convention at Grace Chapel, 132 East Fourteenth-street.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 4.--Gov. Larrabee's indorsement of the views of Horace Boies on the transportation question, as expressed in his letter accepting the Democratic nomination for Governor, coupled as it was with a fine compliment to Mr. Boies's integrity as a man, has thrown the Republican campaign managers into hysterics.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 4.--Count de Vermont, arrested in New-York for forgery, spent a lively week here. He arrived in the latter part of August and staid at the Russell House.

As the White Star steamship Adriatic was swinging into her dock at Pier 52, North River, about 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, she drove against the dock heavily and carried away a portion of the dock, damaging it to the amount of about $1,000. No one was injured.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 4.--At the Faculty meeting to-night Cornell University scholarships were awarded to the following persons: Classical--Miss Mary P. Fitzpatrick, Brooklyn, N.Y.; A.C. Howland, South Danby, N.Y.; C. S. Northrup, Elmstone, N.Y. Mathematical-- N. Ballantyne, Ottawa, Canada; A.H. Perkins, Grauby Centre, N.Y.; W.B. Clark, Castorland, N.Y. Thirty-one persons tried the examinations. Each scholarship is worth $200 per year and lasts four years.

The all-absorbing topic of conversation now is football--who will constitute the team and what are the chances of winning the championship. Six men of last year's team ahve graduated and three graduate members of last year's eleven will in all probability not play this year.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 5.--William A. Sutherland, a prominent lawyer of this city, was unanimously nominated for the State Senate to-day by the Republicans of the Twenty-ninth (Manroe-Orleans) District. Mr. Sutherland made a very forcible speech at the convention.

For several days a gang of tramps have been encamped near Garfield, a Bergen County suburb of Passaic. On Friday night they started to make a raid on Passaic shopkeepers, robbed several tills, and had encounters with three or four dealers.

The proceedings of the fourth day's session of the Episcopal Convention in St. George's Church were begun yesterday with morning prayer, read by the Rev. Dr. Beatty of Kansas. Benediction was pronounced by the Right Rev. Leighton Coleman, D.D., Bishop of Delaware.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 5.--The people of this city were startled this morning by hearing that another bold burglary--the most daring one yet--had been perpetrated during last night.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 5.--The strike of the window-light glassblowers, which began last June and has seriously affected manufacturers and 5,000 employes in the business, most of whom are situated in New-York, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Maryland, was settled to-day in this city.

A.B. George of the Manhattan Athletic, formerly of the Spartan Harriers of London, England, a brother of the famous runners, W.G. George, reduced the American amateur record for the three-mile run yesterday afternoon at Travers Island, the Summer home of the NewYork Athletic Club.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 5.--An old volume, yellow with age, has been sound among the remnants of a church library sent to St. Peter's Episcopal Parish, Hebron, by the English Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts in the seventeen hundreds.

ALBANY, Oct. 5.--Superintendent Maxwell of the Insurance Department has received a report from Michael Shannon and John A. Horan, who were appointed to examine the affairs of the Catholic Benevolent Legion of Brooklyn and the transactions of its Supreme Council. After making a financial statement of the condition of the Legion the report says that the funds have been honestly managed, and that beneficiaries have received honorable treatment.

The coldest region in the United States is the stretch of country on the northern border from the Minnesota lakes to the western line of Dakota. At Pembina, which lies near the fortyninth parallel, the lowest temperature recorded in the great storm of the Winter of 1873 was 56 below zero. This is believed to be the lowest temperature reached in the United States.

NEWARK, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Circulars calling on the people to rise and fight landlords, priests, and officials are being distributed here. "Blood is the watchword and the knife the Bible" proclaims the circular. Efforts are making to discover the authors with a view to their punishment.

The ab sence of any proper and adequate professional training in the past--of over three hundred and twenty-five thousand teachers in the United States, but a small proportion are graduates even of normal schools--has made itself felt not only in the schools of the United States, but in those of Europe as well.
Paul Sarazin, a decorator, who occupied apartments at 15 East Twelfth-street, has not been seen there since a week ago yesterday. His disappearance is unexplained, and no trace of him can be found.

The funeral of Augustus Stgevens Van De Linde, the young bridegroom who committed suicide because his clandestine marriage had been published, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of his uncle, A.P.Stevens, at 184 Berkeley-place, Brooklyn.
A Legislative Reform Party in the Seventeenth Assembly District was informally organized last evening in Concordia Hall, 747 Ninth-avenue. All present were members of the old United Labor Party.

A system of identifying criminals by anthropometrical measurements instead of by photographs and descriptions has been employed by the French police for five years. They claim for this method that it has enabled them to rid the country of many of the professional thieves with which it was infested, and has led to the identification of escaped convicts and deserters from the army.

Miss Adeline E. Loomis, daughter of Dr. Alfred L. Loomis, and John Dyneley Prince were married in the Church of the Holy Communion by the rector, tha Rev. Dr. Mottet, yesterday at noon. The mother of the groom has been Mrs. Loomis for the past two years, and Mr. Prince is now the doctor's son-in-law as well as his stepson.

Mr. Daly's comedians, on the stage to which they belong, will be seen under the most favorable circumstances this season. The play now current, a bit of frivolity, is scarcely likely to last long, though "The Golden Widow" has, naturally, attracted very large audiences so far. Miss Rehan's charming personality gives fictitious importance to the part of Mrs. Magillicuddy, and Mr. Lewis has in Campanilla a picturesque if not a congenial role.
STOCKTON, Cal., Oct. 5.--The Grand Jury of San Joaquin County has presented its final report concerning the case of Deputy United States Marshal Nagle.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 5.--A number of Milwaukee, Cleveland, and Marquette capitalists have combined for the purpose of dividing the iron Bessemer ores with the Schleisinger syndicate, and will erect large furnaces in Marquette to reduce their own ores.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 5.--The Grand Jury was in session until 10 o'clock last night, and again to-day and to-night, examining witnesses in the Burke State bond matter. Late to-night it adjourned to Wednesday next, when, it is understood, several more indictments will be presented.

"Look, father!" exclaimed a boy with weather-bronzed face as he pointed with outstretched arm and sun-browned hand at the wind-tossed water of Little Pine Lake; "look! It's too bad! The water is white. The gulls are flying low.

ALBANY, Oct. 5.--Gov. Hill, as boss of the Democratic Party, begins his reign under circumstances that are bound to be discouraging, if not disastrous. From several parts of the State murmurs already come against his policy in foisting upon the party a ticket that is unsatisfactory in many parts of the State and in several counties is thoroughly distasteful.

The college football season in this vicinity opened yesterday at Erastina. Columbia's prospective eleven played a game with the Crescents of the Football Union. The result was disastrous to the collegians, as they were defeated by a score of 30 to 0.
Samuel H. Morrison, a letter carrier, fell down an elevator shaft in the Telephone Building, 18 Cortlandt-street, yesterday afternoon and was badly injured.

John H. Watson recovered in the Superior Court a judgment of $12,000 for damages to the easement of his property on Fifty-thirdstreet by reason of the elevated railroad structure. Mrs. Mary E. Hughes was given a judgment of $9,000.

The extraordinary term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer will reopen to-morrow, with Judge Daniels presiding.
There are cheering signs that order will soon emerge from the confusion that was inevitable at the outset of the movement to put the preliminaries for the great World's Fair of 1892 into shape.

WATERTOWN, Oct. 5.--Sportsmen who have visited the famous Northern New-York resorts during the present month in search of fish and game have been fairly rewarded for their trouble. The only drawback has been bad weather. The great storm that visited the Atlantic coast during the first week of September reached the lower lake region early last week, and there have been only three days of good weather since.

Many members of the Cotton Exchange discussed the proposal to abolish the present system of the Exchange in the classification and certification of cotton at a special meeting held yesterday at the request of members who are in favor of the change.

The Juniors seem determined to have their classmate, who was lately expelled, reinstated, and all cut recitations on Wednesday and Thursday after asking for their dismissal papers. At no time since 1869 has a class as a whole threatened to leave college.

There was plenty of excitement around the bulletin boards yesterday. Small boys, beardless youths, middle-aged men, and men past the prime of life crowded each other in their efforts to get close enough to distinguish the figures. Around the tickers in the various hotels and saloons standing room was at a premium. Everybody appeared anxious to get the first news.

The San Diego raisin vineyards report a crop that equals one box of finished raisins to the vine. When it is remembered that such a yield is unknown and impossible anywhere else in the world, it will be seen that California asks no odds and needs none as a raisin country.

MADISON BARRACKS, FORT NIAGARA, NewYork, Oct. 5.--This is one of those delightful lake posts to which army men are always anxious to be appointed. Col. Richard J. Dodge is its commander, and here it is that the "post canteen" has been tried so successfully.

JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5.--It is quite evident that the hungry Republicans have set the date for the decapitation of the present Democratic Postmaster, regardless of all civil service laws and party promises. LONDON, Oct. 5.--Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Minister to the United States, is a passenger of the steamer Aurania which sailed from Liverpool for New-York to-day.

First Lieut. Douglas A. Howard, Ordnance Department, has been relieved from duty at Watervliet Arsenal, N.Y., and ordered to duty at Providence, R.I., in connection with the manufacture of guns for the Government by the Builders' Iron Foundry.

Before the General Term of the Superior Court, consisting of Chief Judge Sedgwick and Judges Freedman and Ingraham, an appeal was argued yesterday in the case of the proceedings instituted by the city against the Vandenburgh New-York Underground Railway Company.

Daniel M. Seaman, a prominent real estate broker, doing business at 187 Broadway, was found dying in bed early yesterday morning at his residence, 318 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street. One gas burner was turned on full head, but not lighted. There was not, however, sufficient gas in the room to have asphyxiated a person in good health.

At a college meeting on the 28th a member of the Alumni Association Gymnasium Committee addressed the students on the subject of a new gymnasium. The Alumni Committee are hard at work, and it is hoped to break ground for a new building by next Commencement.

AUCKLAND, New-Zealand, Aug. 29.--The traveler amid the island groups of Polynesia discovers many strange ways by which the native races make a living. He also learns that the living they seek is most inexpensive, and that from occupations which enrich their white employers they themselves are satisfied with a very small percentage of profit.

The following from Las Novedades of this city is illustrative of the position of political parties in Spain at the present time, and is also so characteristic of Spanish humor that the tale almost reads like a page from Cervantes. The story is related as coming from the exiled revolutionary leader Ruiz Zorrilla to a London correspondent of the Epoca of Madrid.

The regular monument rush on the first Saturday night of the term resulted in a Sophomore victory, though the members of '93 still think they won. This monument rush is one of the unique institutions of Williams. It is customary for the different classes to assemble at the soldiers' monument on "Consumption Hill" to sing college songs in the evening.

Hollyer insists that his etching of Andrew Lang is a true portrait, because it would be an unheard-of luxury of negligence in an artist to have expended time, art, and money in the making of an untruthful plate of a living personage.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 5.--Joseph Fisher of this city, who is connected with the New-Jersey Bureau of Labor Statistics, has arranged some interesting statistics of the work of savings banks and building loan associations which will be published in the forthcoming report.

CORRY, Penn., Oct. 5.--The rear end of the south-bound freight on the Western New-York and Pennsylvania Railroad broke loose as the train was climbing the summit, four miles south of here, this morning, and, rushing down the hill, crashed with terrific force into the morning passenger train, which was following. All of the passengers were bruished, some injured seriously, but none fatally.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 5.--The Boston Safe Deposit Trust Company was the complainant in the United States Circuit Court here yesterday in a foreclosure suit against the American Rapid Telegraph Company.
LONDON, Oct. 5.--To-morrow's ballotages in France, which under other conditions might have been awaited with anxious trepidation, really attract no attention at all either here or across the Channel.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 5.--At 9:05 o'clock this morning the pan-American delegates arrived at the station in Boston, where they were welcomed by Mayor Hart and Mr. Coolidge, one of the American delegates, who will direct the city's entertainment of the delegates.

A few weeks ago Mr. Ilderton of this city left for a visit among relatives in England. Mr. Campion, the real estate man, gave him a homed toad to present with his compliments to a brother of Mr. Sellers, his partner.

ALBANY, Oct. 5.--Both branches of the Court of Appeals will resume sessions in the Capitol on Monday. The new court or second division will resume the calling of the numbers on the old calendar. The old court--that is, the court proper, tkaes up the new calendar under the new rule making Monday "motion day."

The condition of Wilson G. Hunt, who has been reported ill at the Clarendon Hotel, is no considered at all dangerous. It was said at the hotel last night that he had been confined to his room for a few days by a heavy cold, but that he was better and no serious complications were looked for.

Though best known as a novelist, Miss Edwards possesses (as all readers of "A Thousand Miles Up the Nile" can testify) no mean skill in real as well as imaginary descriptions, a skill amply shown in the present volume.

The sun rose on the 1st at a little before 6 o'olock, and will rise on the 31st about half an hour later, the days being shortened altogether about an hour and a quarter, a very perceptible change due to the sun's moving south in declination about 11 , which is about as rapidly as he moves in any portion of his career.

ROME, Ga., Oct.5.--A north-bound freight train on the Rome and Decatur Railroad was wrecked eight miles south of here this afternoon. The engine and a number of cars rolled down an embankment, instantly killing Fireman Charlie Sproule and a negro brakeman, name unknown. Engineer Bob Hill, famous for his many miraculous escapes in various other railroad wrecks, was seriously and probably fatally injured.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 5.--In the third race at Latonia to-day a serious accident occured. Clamor ran into Billy Pinkerton, knocking him against Unlucky, who in turn fell against Event, all three going down with their riders.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 5.--The Hon. Horace Boles, Democratic candidate for Governor, opened the campaign by a vigorous speech at Waterloo to-night.

There lives a woman in Harlem--for personal reasons she declines to allow a public use of her name--who tells a story, remarkable in many of its incidents, of almost complete recovery from a double curvature of the spine and relief from a nearly total helplessnes without the aid of medicine and purely from natural causes.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5.--The first game of football played this season by the Princeton College team took place on the Athletic grounds between the home team and Lehigh. The result of the game was the very small score of 16 to 0, as compared with last year's game of 80 to 0.

A rumor was in circulation at the Hoffman House last night that the magnates of the County Democracy had held a meeting during the afternoon at the New Amsterdam Club, and, besides indorsing the Syracuse nominations, unanimously decided that a union with Tammany Hall was desirable on Senatorial and Assembly nominations.
ST.LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 5.--Ex-Congressman John M. Glover of St. Louis announces himself as a candidate for the United States Senate from Missouri in opposition to Senator Vest.

An important discovery has been made in the environs of Nimes. Some workmen engaged on excavations for the construction of an aqueduct which are to be removed to the local museum. Meanwhile it has been decided that the surrounding ground shall be carefully searched, it being thought that it may contain other antiquities of a rare and interesting character.

Some kinds of the drop-a-nickel-in-the-slot machines that have held out their alluring promises of tutti-frutti and chocolate returns to investors have developed deceitful and dishonest characters. They have in innumerable instances proved the most aggravating of automatic swindlers.

LONG LAKE, HAMILTON COUNTY, N.Y., Oct. 5. --I have attempted to show in the letters which have preceded this that the Adirondack Mountains have been despoiled of fully two-thirds of the great forest lands which originally covered them, and that the remainder, part of which belongs to this State, is rapidly following them into desolation and ruin.

BERLIN, Oct. 5.--Official telegrams from Fredensborg received at Potsdam and the Foreign Office to-night say that the Czar will start for Berlin Thursday next. According to the present programme the Czar will go to Kiel, journeying thence by way of Oldersloe ana Schwarzenbeck to Berlin. This programme is subject to alteration.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5.--J.J. Boyle, the ex-priest of the Roman Catholic Church, who is now on trial for his life at Raleigh, N.C., charged with assaulting Geneva Whitaker in May, was well known in this city a year ago, and has been seen here at an even later date.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5.--The Sophomore Class occupied the whole of last night in posting on every tree, house, fence, and show window in town its annual "proclamation" addressed to "Ye Mongrel Herd of Freshmen."
Dr. Eugene J. Kaufman, a rich physician of this city, has entered suit for absolute divorce from his wife, who is known on the stage as Minnie Seligman.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 5.--The Peoria bicycle races were finished to-day. Four thousand people were present. The weather was much colder than that of yesterday, and the wind so strong that the expected record breaking did not take place. The races wore warmly contested. A. C. Barker and Campbell of the Berkeley team were unable to cope with the fast Western men.

The African traveler, Herr Fricke, who has since 1875 been in Africa, and escaped from Khartoum after Gen. Gordon's death, is now in Berlin. The London Daily News correspondent had a long talk with him two weeks ago or so about his adventures, and tried to learn some particulars of Gen. Gordon's last days.

HARTFORD, Oct. 5.--The total number of criminal cases disposed of in the Superior Courts of this State during the court year of 1889 was 1,468. Of this number New-Haven County furnished 525 cases, Fairfield Country 289, and Hartford County 176.

Many of the closing contests of the tournament of the New-York Tennis Club on the club grounds at One Hundred and Forty-seventhstreet, near St. Nicholas-avenue, were finished yesterday amid a good deal of applause and congratulations.

BANGOR, Me., Oct. 5.--The seizure and detention of the British schooner Wandrain in this port by the United States Marshal under orders from the court may bring to Uncle Sam new troubles regarding the rights of English vessels coming to the States.

Requests to be excused from jury duty by a number of gentlemen who had received notices to attend during the October term, which begins to-morrow, were received at the District Attorney's office yesterday. They were all returned, with an indorsement referring to the amendments to the Code of Civil Procedure governing the selection of jurors, adopted at the last session of the Legislature, which went into effect Oct. 1.

The cornerstone of the new house of the Union League Club of Brooklyn, at the corner of Bedford-avenue and Dean-street, was laid yesterday afternoon. ARTESIA, Miss., Oct. 5.--Gen. J.R. Chalmers and W.D. Frazer, candidates for Governor and Attorney General, respectively, on the Republican ticket, have written letters to the Chairman of the State Republican Committee at Jackson formally withdrawing from the ticket. This action is the result of the manifestations of public sentiment against Gen. Chalmers at West Point, Oklahoma, and other points.

The inaugural recital on the new organ in St. James's Roman Catholic Church, James-street and New Bowery, will occur to-night at 8 o'clock, and will be an interesting affair. The organists will be Romaine Callender and William E. Mulligan.

The North German Lloyd steamer Aller, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, had a very hard time of it while a few miles out from Bremerhaven on her way to Southampton. Burns and Tillett, the labor leaders, are trying to arrange the trouble, but it is feared the strike will spread.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 5.--The first meet of the Dutchess County Hunt occurred at Drayton Hall, on the Hyde Park road, to-day, twenty-five gentleman and two ladies participating in the chase. The ladies were the two Misses Morgan of Staatsburg.

It is announced that the restorations of the ducal palace in Venice are completed, and that the glorious building will be thrown open to sight in November at the latest, freed from the hoarding and balks of timber which have hidden one or other part of it for about twenty years.
The members of the Baltimore Society of Amateur, Astronomers have received a dispatch from Prof. Ritchie at the Harvard Observatory announcing a change in the crater Pliny of the moon.

In a review of railroad track laying during the first nine months of this year the Railway Age of Chicago does away with the current idea that such work in 1889 has been insignificant. It shows that over 3,300 miles of main-line track have been laid since the year began, and that the probabilities are that fully 5,000 miles, and perhaps more, will have been completed before the end of the year.

The mobilization of a fleet of four cruisers for duty on the European station is one of the first steps toward naval reorganization in this coun-- try. PARIS, Sept. 21.--Election day, is to-morrow, everybody is pulling his own way, and, unfortunately for France, concentration and union are forgotten words. Whichever way the political caldron may tip, it will do no permanent good to any party.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 5.--The cottagers showed Mrs. Cleveland marked attention while she was in town this week. She arrived at the beautiful cottage of ex-Secretary Whitney late Tuesday evening. G.G. Haven of New York drove to the Whitney place in his four-in-hand between 10 and 11 o'clock Wednesday morning and took Mr. and Mrs. Whitney and their guest for a drive on the top of his coach.

SCHOHARIE, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Situated on the banks of the Hudson River, thirty miles from the metropolis of the continent, Sing Sing Prison has been a spot of note of millions of travelers for more than half a century. But how few know anything about the life within its walls--of the fifteen hundred Human beings there imprisoned.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 5.--No change developed in to-day's balloting for a candidate by the Republican Judicial Convention for the Eighth District.

Policeman Ryan of Hoboken was assaulted and badly beaten by a gang of intoxicated Germen sailors belonging to the Bremen steamer Elbe on Friday night. When policemen pursued the men to their vessel it is asserted the first officer, Von Bortlander and Engineer Richard Bullman threatened to shoot any officer who should come on board. Later the two officers and eight sailors were arrested. The former were held in $1,500 and $1,000 bail respectively.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Cornell opened the football season this afternoon with Bucknell University and won, 66--0, in two halves of half an hour each. Bucknell was weak all around, while Cornell played a strong rushing and running game, the guarding being especially good. Osgood distinguished himself by making eleven touch-downs, and Upton, Ehle, and Yawger did work in the line.

LONDON, Oct. 6.--Sir William Tindal Robertson committed suicide at Brighton to-day by cutting his throat. He represented Brighton in the House of Commons. In politics he was a Conservative. He was blind, and served on the royal commission for inquiring into the condition of the blind. He took his life in a fit of insanity. He was formerly a physician and was about sixty-four years old.

WINONA, Miss, Oct. 6.--A fire broke out about 2:40 A.M. in R.E. Lott's two-story restaurant, on First-street. The Southern New-York Baptist Association will hold its nineteenth anniversary at the Baptist Tabernacle, 166 Second-avenue, beginning this afternoon at 3 o'clock and continuing to-morrow and Thursday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 7.--At a meeting of the Farmers' Parish Union at Clinton, in East Feliciana, Capt. Adams, President of the State Union, in the chair, a motion censuring the New-Orleans Cotton Exchange for its recent action on tare was unanimously passed.

The steamer Henry E. Bishop, while trying to enter her dock at Pier 21 North River yesterday afternoon, ran into the Spanish steamer Cludad Condal. Fifteen feet of the Bishop's bow was knocked off from keel to guards, and she was towed over to the Communipaw flats, where she sank in about fifteen feet or water.

Mr. Seth Low, ex-Mayor of Brooklyb, was yesterday elected President of Columbia College to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Dr. F.A.P. Bernard.

BOSTON, Oct. 7.--The Atchison Directors Saturdays were unanimous in approval of the plan of reorganization presented by the special committee. A few details only remain to be perfected.
BOSTON, Oct., 7.--There was another long discussion over the J.J. Murphy case at the adjourned meeting of the New-England Amateur Rowing Association and its Executive Committee to-night.
The suit of Father Dent against Bishop Ryan of Buffalo for alloged slander came up again before Judge Dykman in Brooklyn yesterday on a motion to make the complaint more definite.
CITY OF MEXICO, oct. 7.--An attempt was made last Saturday night to kidnap Emile Schmidt, a rich man of this city, in the Colonia de Indusria, by two men named Manuel Marquez and Victoria Normaltz.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7.--An attempt is being made, it is reported here to-night, to form a Barb-wire Trust. The latest of a series of secret meetings was held this afternoon at the Leland Hotel. It is said that the rise in pig-iron and the expiration of patents have domoralized the trade.
That Mr. Frank Van der Stucken is a man of energy as well as of ambition is amply shown by the frequency with which his name is associated with enterprises of importance in the world of music.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Oct. 7.--"Breakfast at 7:30 o'clock, leave the Vendome at 8:15 start for Lawrence via the Boston and Maine Railroad at 9 o'clock." This was the opening of the itinerary announcement for the guidance of the International delegates on the fifth day of the five-thousand-mile trip.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 7.--The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-third District, comprising the counties of Herkimer, Madison, and Otsego, convened in this city today at noon. Utica, although not in the district, was selected as the Place for holding the convention because it best accommodated all the counties.
BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 7.--Frederick W. Elder, the proprietor of the Blairstown House, at Blairstown, N.J., committed suicide last night by taking poison.
The Rev. Dr. R.E. Sample presided yesterday at the annual meeting of the New-York Presbytery at the Scotch Presbyterian Church on Fourteenth-street. About a hundred ministers and Elders were present.

Assistant District Attorney Goff moved before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, that the indictment for assault in the second degree against Dr. Norman W. Kingsley, the dentist, be dismissed.
Isaac Duryee, who died Sunday at his home, 13 East Forty-sixth-street, of heart disease after an illness of several months, was an old resident of this city.

O'Grady, the master of the Schooner, was washed overboard and drowned, but the remainder of the crew, about seven men, were saved.

Columbia College opened yesterday with all the excitements of a first day. Each Freshman on his arrival was brought face to face with other people's opinions of his consummate freshness.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Oct. 7.--It is reported here to-day that Andrew Carnegie has completed arrangements by which he will acquire possession of the American Midland Railway, which has for an eastern terminus Akron, and Fort Wayne for the end of the western division.

Mexican Central's gross earnings for August Were $498,384, a decrease from the same month last year of $347. The net earnings were $195,608, a decrease of $10,724. NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 7.--Capt. A. T. Wimberly, Collector of Internal Revenue, received a letter to-day from Gen. James R. Chalmers, who was nominated by the Mississippi Republicans for Governor.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct., 7.--Taussing Taylor, wool merchants at 112 south Front-Street, are embarrassed, but an extension is probable. The firm is well known in this city and through-- out the West.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 7.--A hearing was had before Judge Over, in the Orphans' Court to-day, in the case of the exceptions of the heirs of B.L. Fannestock of this city to the amount of commission claimed by B.S. Fahnestock executor of the will.

BURLINGTON,Iowa, Oct. 7.--This has been a enuine gala day for Burliagton. Fully 15,000 Germans, residents and visitors from neigboring towns, thronged the streets and participated in the exercises of the day.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 7.--Those in a position to know feel confident that Jay Gould has no idea of becoming the purchaser of the street railway property here in which the widow of Maurice Flynn is largely interested.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7.--Provisions attracted more general attendtion to-day than on any day since the Oc tober Pork deal became the absorbing feature. There was more doing, and for all lines of property almost, seller found a market. In October Port howover, there was a relutance to trade.
The steamer Ludgate Hill, which arrived yesterday from Havre, brought a very distinguished-looking passenger, who had obstinately refrained from imparting his name to the officers of the ship.

A meeting of fishermen was called last avening at 529 Ninth-avenue to discuss the project of fishermen securing a steamer of their own to run to the Fishing Banks. It is proposed to organize this city, Brooklyn, and Jersey City into sections of fishermen, who shall club together and take one share each at $100 in the new steamer.

The Committee on Site and Buildings of the World's Fair sent a communication to the Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday asking whether the Commissioners had power to appropriate $15,000,000 to purchase the site for the proposed exhibition provided the Legislature passed an act authorizing them to make such expenditure.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 7.--An order was filed in the United States Circuit Court to-day appointing ex-Gov. Daniel H. Chamberlain of New-York temporary receiver of the South Carolina Railway. Genuine lovers of good music are awaiting with the deepest interest the first appearance in America of the new conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Arthur Nikisch. HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 7.--The main thing settled by the town elections in this State today is that the secret-ballot law is a complete success. From all sections the report is satisfactory in regard to the advantages of the system.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 7.--At Mount Vernon to-day George T. Rice, the acronaut with Wallace's Circus made an ascension. As he descended over the river he became tangled in the ropes, was draggod through the water and drowed. This was Rice's hundredth ascension.

He brought his train to a standstill, but not till the head had been struck by the lower works of his locomotive.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 7.--A caller at the residence of Admiral Porter, in Jamestown, this evening, found him seated in an easy chair before a comfortable grate fire. BELLOWS FALLS, Vt., Oct. 7.--The most severe rainstorm of the season began yesterday morning, continuing till this morning, pouring steadily. The streams in this vicinity rose rapidly and last night a large portion of the abutment at the Vermoat end of the toll bridge here gave way, sliding into the river and severing communication between here and NewHampshire. A few small bridges on other streams have been carried away.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--The clique in October pork is still on deck. It bas opened the fight in the Apellate Court for a revival of Judge Shepard's dismissed injunction, and in trading circles retains its bold, defiant position.

BOSTON, Oct. 8.--A new telescope has just been completed by Alvan Clark Sons for the Harvard observatory. It will be used for photographing stars. The instrument is now in position at the observatory.

At a meeting of the Board of Supervisors of Richmond County held yesterday afternoon at Stapleton a letter was received from the State Controller stating that the State Board of Equalization had fixed the aggregate valuation of property in Richmond County at $12,410,056, an increase of $106,472 over last year's valuation. The State tax directed to be levied is $43,972.16, an increase of $11,737 over the year 1888.

Dr. Eastman, a colored physician of Concord, N.H., died at the Sturtevant House last evening of consumption. Barnard, President of the St. Louis Typothetae, welcomed the delegates to the city, and President McNally of Chicago responded. A memorial service in respect to the late Bishop of Kansas is to be held in the Memorial House of St. George's Church this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock. ANOKA, Minn., Oct. 8.--A distressing accident occurred in Frankfort Township, Wright County, yesterday morning. James Dean, a farmer, shot his son, aged eight years.

ALBANY, Oct. 8.--The Court of Appeals to-day decided that a Judge retired under the consti tutional age provision is not only entitled to $6,000 a year salary but to $1,200 in lieu of traveling expenses yearly as well. Ex-Justices Augustus Bockes and James C. Smith come under the provision, and others who will be affected by the decision will be retired before long.

LONDON, Oct. 8.--Capt. Lawler of the boat Neversink was brought before the magistrates at Portsmouth to-day and charged with attempt to murder. Judge McKay of South Carolina and the American Vice Consul were present.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--The lake freight season now drawing to a close has been a successful and profitable one. CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--The most startling example of rate cutting since the coal and coke trouble last Spring has just been made public. For weeks the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Road has been engaged in manipulating freight rates on almost every class of grain from Kansas City. Especially has this been true of corn.
BOSTON, Oct. 8.--The meeting of the Bostonian Society to-day was enlivened by the opening of the box found recently under the cornerstone of the old Merchants' Exchange.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 8.--The Massachusetts branch of the American Federation of Labor at its meeting to-day passed resolutions in favor of reducing the per capita tax from 2 cents to 1 cent a month.
The Tammany Committee of Twenty-four met yesterday afternoon and selected dates for all the Tammany contentions except the county.
The effect upon that part of the community specially interested in education of the election of Mr. SETH LOW to the Presidency of Columbia College has doubtless been in large part a surprise.

The ring Democracy of Hudson County, N. J., held two conventions in Jersey City yesterday, one in the afternoon and the other in the evening. Both were uuanimous and harmonious as ring conventions are apt to be.

The Liederkranz held its annual meeting at its clubhouse on Fifth-eighth-street last evening, and decided unanimously not to have its annual masquerade ball this Winter.
There was a notable service in the Church of the Holy Communion, Twentieth-street and Sixth-avenue, last evening.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--To-day four more jurors were sworn in to try the Cronin case, making eight now secured. The names of the last four are George L. Corke, W.S. North, Henry D. Walker; and Frank Allison. The defense used another of their peremptory challenges, leaving but twelve to their credit.

The creditors of Emil Van Gilder, the young diamond dealer of 10 Maiden-lane who has disappeared, leaving large liabilities and no assets, believe that they have been regularly "done" by that gay Hollander.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 8.--William N. Seitz, proprietor of the Pavilion Hotel at Lake Hopatcong, and James Tomer of Easton, saw a capsized boat in the lake at Byron's Cove yesterday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 8.--A short time ago the Railway Commissioners of Iowa notified the Governor that the roads in Iowa were very generally neglecting or refusing to answer a series of questions which had been propounded to them by the Commissioners.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct 8.--The international excursion party last night, for the first time in the experience of many of the delegates and attaches of the International American Congress, slept in the cars of the special train.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--The Knight who were astir early this morning glanced mournfully at a sullen, threatening sky, indicative of rain, and the chilliness of the air almost foreboded snow.

From some unknown cause a fire started in the two-story brick building on Ward's island which stands about four hundred yards in the rear of the City Insane Asylum for males soon after midnight Monday.
