A second opportunity to register was given to the voters in Brooklyn yesterday, and 45,482 availed themselves of it. This was a decided falling of from last year and the year before, but it was a big increase over the same day in 1885. Just as on the first day the heavy registration was in the new wards, while in the old districts it was light.

Ex-President Strong of the Atchison Road says that the reorganization plan, as it has been outlined, strikes him as a very equitable arrangement, and he expresses the sincere hope that it may be successful.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--Some of the best known clubmen in Philadelphia are anxiously looking for the return from across the sea of a prominent theatrical man with an accounting for several thousand dollars each with which they intrusted him some months ago.
McMahon Co.'s clever-light weight jockey, Day, who rode Chaos, the winner of the Coney Island Futurity in September last, was seriously inured in the fifth race at Jerome Park yesterday.
District Attorney Ridgway of Brooklyn was formally notified yesterday that the Court of Appeals had affirmed the conviction of John Green wald, the murderer of Lyman S. Weeks.
The variety show demands a large share of public attention this week and seems to be getting it. Herrmann's excellent company of performers has drawn big crowds at the UnionSquare Theatre.

BRAINERD, Minn., Oct. 8.--A feud has long existed between the boys living on the east and west banks of the Mississippi River, and westside boys declared a war of extermination against the east-siders.

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 8.--The King gave a Court hunt to-day in honor of the Czar. The Prince of wales and the Crown Prince took part in the sport. The Czar will leave Fredensborg to-morrow evening. He will sleep aboard the imperial yacht Derjava, which will sail for Kiel Thursday morning. The Derjava will return for the Czarina Saturday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8.--Allen O. Myers was to-day sentenced to pay a fine of $250 and to fifteen days' imprisonment in the county jail for contempt of court. The case was sent back by the Supreme Court for a rehearing. The former fine was the same and the sentence ninety days.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8.--A call far a meeting of the League of Heaven and Earth posted in Chinatown reveals the strength and boldness of the Chinese secret society which has been proscribed in China since the Taiping rebellion.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8.--One of the biggest mining deals yet made from St. Louis, involving $2,000,000 cash, and taking in New-York and London, has just been closed by Judge U.F. Cleary of this city. The property is situated in Mexico, and includes all of the mines situated on the Vegonia vein, and a one-hundred-thousand-acre grant, containing numerous gold, silver, and copper ledges of untold riches.

JEFFERSON, Texas, Oct. 8.--At the annual meeting of the East Line and Red River Railroad to-day the following officers were elected Directors: W.H. Abrams, John Bacon, F.H. Pendergrass, R. Gould, J.A. Baker, R.C. Foster, E.A. Boyce, D.S. Smith, and E.W. Taylor. The number of shares represented was 9,277. R.C. Foster was elected President, E.W. Taylor Assistant Secretary. The Executive Committee is R.C. Foster, W.H. Abrams, and D.S. Smith.
Some interesting facts in regard to the Catholic parochial school question have been brought to light by a condition of affairs that exists in the parish of the Church of the Sacred Heart, Brooklyn.

Mrs. McDonald, wife of "Mike" McDonald, the Chicago gambler and politician, who disappeared from her home in July and was reported as having eloped with the Rev. Father Joseph Moysant, a young priest of the Church of Notre Dame, Chicago, accompanying him to France, arrived on Saturday by the steamship Chicago.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 8.--The Paterson Board of Trade to-night after an animated discussion unanimously adopted resolutions pledging its cordial co-operation toward the World's Fair of 1892, declaring that the metropolis of America is the natural and proper place for holding a universal exposition in America, providing for a special ccmmittee of seven to arrange for a Paterson exhibit, and naming President William Strange as Chairman of such committee.

The Harlem Republican Club met in large numbers last evening at the clubhouse, 24 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, and passed resolutions expressing sympathy with the Congrees of American States and with the World's Fair. Ira M. Hedges, the nominee for State Treasurer, was present as the guest of the club and made a short address.

The Fresh Fruits and Vegetables Committee of the Mercantile Exchange did not secure a quorum at the meeting called for yesterday afternoon to take action on the proposed ordinance excepting the sale of fruits and vegetables by weight.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 8.--Speaker Fremont Cole was defeated in the Senatorial Convention held here to-day, and Assemblyman Charles T. Saxton of Wayne County became the Republican candidate for Senator in this (Twentyninth) District.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 8.--The city election passed off quietly to-day, with a very light vote polled. A Mayor, City Clerk, Board of Aldermen, and Common Council were elected.
Charles B. Bishop, the low comedian of the Sothern company, died suddenly last night during the performance of "Lord Chumley" at the Lyceum Theatre.

The New-Jersey Association of Democratic Clubs will meet in convention in the Academy of Music, Washington-street, Newark, to-morrow...

QUEENSTOWN, Oct. 8.--The steamship City of Paris, which arrived here to-day, reports that her decks were swept by heavy seas yesterday. A female steerage passenger and her child were swept overboard and drowned, and ten other passengers were severely injured. The saloon was flooded.

Mary Sweeney, the eighteen-year-old girl of 334 East Fortieth-street who attempted suicide by taking oxalic acid on Monday morning last, was brought before Justice McMahon in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday. She acknowledged her guilt, and bashfully told the court that she took the poison because mamma would not allow her to keen company, with a married man. Held in $500 bail.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 8.--Joseph E. Haynes was re-elected Mayor of Newark for the fourth time to-day by a Democratic majority of about 1,200. The Republicans retain control of the Council by about two majority. The gains were generally Democratic on the Board of Freeholders and the Board of Education.

Only one of the Giants played in the NewYork team against the Newarks on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The other eight were made up of resident players. Newark, in consequence, had a soft snap, winning a game by figures of 12 to 5.
Whatever proceedings are taken to-day at the General Time Convention in the Hotel Brunswick will not be developed until the Secretary makes it public after adjournment.

A mass-meeting of sheep butchers and wool pullers was held last evening at Wendel's Assembly Rooms, in West Forty-fourth-street, to refute the charges that had been made against them of having placed a dynamite bomb in Scanlan's abattoir where it explod-.

The Board of Street and Water Commissioners of Jersey City were hauled up yesterday by the Board of Finance and Taxation for rejecting the bid of Thomas J. McKenna, the lowest responsible bidder for water pipe, on Sept. 9.
CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 8, via Galveston.--Pullman sleeping cars on the Mexican National Road are now run only between Lareda and Acambaro, and not, as formerly, through to this city.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--The Secretary of the Navy has given the Cramps permission to try the Baltimore's engines once more for horse power.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 8.--With a dozen towns to hear from, the official returns at the Courant office give 26,884 majority against the prohibitory amendment.

Augustus W. Barney, hotel, restaurant, and liquor saloon at 208 Chambers-street, made an assignment yesterday to Stewart Young, giving him a preference for $1,802. Mr. Barney has been in the business about twenty years. In May last he gave a chattel mortgage to M. Apgar for $4,240, and on Sept. 10 judgement for $816 was entered against him in favor of W.C. Renwick.

The second concert of the Arion Society's song festival, which took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening, was quite the equal of the first in interest, and, unfortunately, also in extent.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Oct. 8.--Five dead bodies were taken out of the Stony Creek River to-day by workmen removing the filth and rubbish. There seems to be no doubt that there were a great many washed in here, and as the surface deposits are removed many more will likely be brought to light.
The Committee on Permanent Organization of the World's Fair held its first meeting yesterday in the Governor's Room in the City Hall.
Charles Edmunds, forty years old, a lineman in the employ of the Manhattan Electric Light Company, met with a terrible death last evening while working on a tall pole in Grand-street, near Centre.
"Butch" Miller, whose real name is said to be Frank Miller, the accomplice of Greenwald in the murder of Lyman S. Weeks in Brooklyn, is in the toils again.

No one appeared in the United States District Court yesterday to put in an answer in the suit instituted by Collector Erhardt to test the genuineness of the two paintings, supposed to be a "Holy Family" by Titian and "A Rabbi" by Rembrandt.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 8.--Gov. Hill to-day appointed Edward D. Cutler of Schenectady to fill the unexpired term of the Schenectady County Judge, David C. Beattle, deceased. Mr. Cutler is a Democrat and has represented Schenectady County in the Assembly. He has an excellent record.

MCKEESPORT, Penn., Oct. 8.--Teemer will not row Hanlan at Louisville, Ohio, next Saturday week, as E.L. Suter, the representative of Hanlan, who asked for the race for $500 a side, with gate receipts equally divided, has presented a now proposal to Teemer to row for gate receipts only.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--Those who are fully Advised of the condition of the Hon. Samuel J. Randall will be very much surprised if he ever resumes his seat in Congress. Neither Mr. Randall himself nor the members of his immediate family are fully aware of his condition.

The Toffey Guard of Jersey City gave a reception last night in its rooms in Newark-avenue to Gen. E. Burd Grubb, the Republican candidate for Governor. The General was escorted to the clubrooms by a committee, and he was givem a warm reception. He made a speech and shook hands with the 500 members of the guard.

All lovers of music will be delighted at the announcement that Goldmark Conried have engaged Dr. Hans von Bulow for a series of twenty concerts in this city. Boston, Chicago, Washington, and St. Louis. The great musician will present new programmes from the works of Beethoven, Liszt, Schumann, and other masters. The first concerts will be given in the latter part of March.

The Brooklyn Dramatic Club met at 201 Montague-street last night. Twenty-one gentlemen were present, including Edward M. Shepard, Frederick W. Hinrichs, and David A. Boody. Resolutions indorsing Mayor Chapin for re-election were presented by Mr. Boody and passed by a vote of 17 to 4, after speeches of opposition by William P. Ferguson and Arthur Wickstead denouncing Mr. Chapin as a tool of the McLaughlin ring.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Oct. 9.--The high price of oysters in the shell, owing to their scarcity, has made it necessary for packers to put up prices, and looking to this end there was a meeting of peninsula packers at Seaford yesterday, at which members of twenty-five firms, representing the trade in Cambridge, Oxford, St. Michaels, Crisfield, Marion, and Seaford were present.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 9.--When the Superintendents and managers of our insane asylums meet and compare views and discuss the proper treatment of the insane it is fair to presume that good results will follow and that the care and management of the asylums and insane will be greatly improved.

The report of the various committees of the General Time Convention, which held its second meeting of the present year at the Brunswick Hotel yesterday, showed that the growth of the association during the past six months has been the greatest in its history.

GONAIVES, Sept, 27.--Before many weeks will have passed the affairs on the Island of Hayti will have settled down to their normal state, and the inhabitants will go back to their homes to pursue the even tenor of their ways or to incite another rebellion.

For some weeks the United States Secret Service agents in this city have been congratulating themselves on the extermination of the noted Italian gang of counterfeiters. It was a gang hard to break up.

Bortell, wife of his half brother. The two families lived close together in Prairie-avenue and have always been on the most intimate...

Mayor Grant received a communication yesterday from property owners along the line and in the neighborhood of Central or Jerome avenue protesting against the granting to any person or corporation the right to lay rails in the avenue for the running of horse or cable cars.

A fire occurred last night at the engine house and hoisting shaft of the Bellevue coal breaker in the southern portion of Scranton, Penn. Seven men were at work down the shaft sinking it to a tower level when the flames were discovered, and they had a narrow escape up the burning shaft to a worked out vein which opened about midway in the shaft and led to a place of safety.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9.--At the request of Prof. William Sloane, the Chairman of the Committee of the Faculty on Athletics, a mass meeting of the students was called to-day to decide in regard to a change in the time of morning chapel. After a short discussion it was unanimously decided to make the time of morning prayers from 8 to 8:15 A.M. instead of from 8:15 to 8:30.

The meeting of the Board of Electrical Control held yesterday was one of the liveliest that body has held since Mayor Hewitt used to shake them up. An unattractive card, the improbability of a meeting of Firenzi and Kingston at Jerome Park, and the prospects of another bleak and uncomfortable day resulted in the poorest attendance of the meeting at Morris Park yesterday.
The annual meeting of the Western Union Telegraph Company was held yesterday, the old Board or Directors being re-elected. The company's gross revenues for the year ending...
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 9.--The Grand Jury today found an indictment against Chalkley Leconey for the murder of Annie Leconey, his niece, at his farmhouse near Merchantville.

The question whether the estate of a deceased copartner by an agreement made for the continuance of the business after his death is rendered liable for post-mortuary debts of the copartnership has just been decided in the negative by the Court of Appeals.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Oct. 9.--News reached here to-day of the killing of George Taylor by Col. Sugg, on the latter's ranch in the southwest part of the Chickasaw Nation. The killing occurred in the public road, three miles north of Red River. The circumstances which led to it are unknown.
DUNNELLEN, N.J., Oct. 9.--Another day's sport with the clay birds was enjoyed on the Middlesex Gun Club grounds to-day. The same ten traps were in operation and the boys kept them going constantly.

To-night the S.S. Cox memorial meeting, arranged by the Steckler Association, will take place in Cooper Union. The exercises will be opened by prayer by the Rev. P.F. McSweeny of St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church, and this will be followed by an address by ex-President Grover Cleveland.

How long will the Committee on Site continue to abuse the patience of the Evening Post? The Post is trying hard to be calm, always a difficult matter with it, but under its present provocations well-nigh impossible.
Col. Andrew.D. Baird notified the Kings County Republican Campaign Committee yesterday that he would not accept the party nomination for Mayor of Brooklyn under any circumstances.

The ninety-eighth meeting of the Southern New-York Baptist Association took place yesterday. The morning devotional exercises were led by the Rev. E.T. Hiscox, and then reports of the Trustees of the association were placed before the session. Treasurer Joseph Brokaw's report shows property in realty amounting to $68,700 and conditional securities of $294,999.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 9.--Capt. J.W. Liswell of the ship Minnie Swift, which was lost in collision with the French steamer Geographique off St. Pierre, Miquelon, has arrived here. He states that nothing of importance occurred until the llth, when the bark Zuletta was fallen in with, dismasted and waterlogged.

Theodore Thomas gave the first concert of his testimonial tour in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening. The house was occupied by a large audience, which greeted Mr. Thomas with great enthusiasm.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9.--The final official trial of the guns of the United States cruiser Vesuvius has proved a great success. Fifteen shots were fired in sixteen minutes, the contract requirements being outdone by almost one-half.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 9.--The Dartmouth Seniors elected class day officers and speakers last night for next June as follows: Marshal-- D.W. Jones, Dover, N.H.; Orator--G.H. Moses, Franklin, N.H.; Introductory addresss--H.M. Eaton, Littleton, N.H.; Class Poet--W.A. Bacon,...

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 9.--A case of suicide without apparent reason, and remarkable for cool premeditation, has just occurred in Norwich, the victim being Mr. William M. Hovey, a wealthy retired farmer, aged sixty-six years. Mr. Hovey got up at 5 o'clock in the morning,...

LONDON, Oct. 10.--The White Star Line steamship Britannic, Capt. Davison, from New-York Oct. 2 for Liverpool, was signaled off Brow Head at 12:40 A.M. to-day. The Hamburg-American Line steamship Hammonia, Capt. Kuhlwein, from Hamburg, sld. from Southampton yesterday for New-York.

BERLIN, Oct. 9.--Emperor William, attired in the uniform of a British Admiral, took lunch to-day at Kiel with Vice-Admiral Baird on board the Northumberland, the flagship of the British Channel squadron. The German naval officers at Kiel gave a banquet to the officers attached to the British squadron.

The St. George's Harriers will give an open moonlight cross-country road run on Dec, 10. A medal will be given to every runner that finishes the course, a gold watch will be awarded the winner, and medals will be given to second and thrid men. The Seventh Regiment Athletic Association will have indoor games in its armory Saturday, Dec. 7, at 8 P.M.

The steamers sailing from this city for European ports yesterday were the Adriatic, City of Chicago, and Gallia for Liverpool, the Rhynland for Antwerp, and the Aller for Southampton and Bremen.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 9.--County Judge Day filed his decision in the Kemmler case this morning. The case was a habeas-corpus proceeding to test the constitutionality of the electrical execution law. Judge Day decides that the law is constitutional and remands the prisoner to the custody of Warden Durston at Auburn Prison for execution.

There is fine promise of a lively time in the Fifth District over the reported action of the Republican County Committee's Reorganization Committee in placing the Frank J. Carroll faction on top in the fight that has been going on in the district for the past few months.
Columbia College met her match at football yesterday in Lafayette, a game between their respective teams played on the Berkeley Oval, at Morris Dock, resulting in a score of 10 points for each side.

Signor Salvini, the Italian actor who is to appear as Samson at Palmer's this evening, was sitting in his parlor at the Everett House after rehearsal yesterday, chatting with a friend, when a card was brought to him by one of the waiters.

The slot machine, as it is commonly called, which now ornaments railway stations all over the civilized world, is certainly an ingenious invention, and it seems capable of almost indefinite expansion.

Miss Pauline G. Onativia and John Richard Townsend, son of the late J. Lawrence Townsend, both of this city, were married yesterday at noon at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifthavenue and Forty-fifth-street.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 9.--The Milwaukee Road has been indicted by the United States Grand Jury for violations of the inter-State commerce law, and the trial of the cause will be of the greatest importance, testing, as it will, the ight of railroads to charge higher rates to the interior towns than to St. Paul and Minneapolis.
COPENHAGEN, Oct. 9.--The Czar embarked at midnight for Germany. He was accompanied on the railway from Fredensborg to this city by the Czarina and all the members of the royal family.

The Committee on Permanent Organization held another meeting in the Governor's Room at the City Hall yesterday, and Chairman Henry G. Marquand announced his selection of the following Executive Committee: J.M. Bowers, Chairman; John Sloane, E.D. Adams, Benjamin Wood, Thomas F. Ryan, and Charles A. Moore.

A number or petty burglaries have been perpetrated in Mount Vernon recently, and the villagers are talking of organizing again and hunting the men down, as they did when they broke up the "Brace and Bit" gang which was operating there a few years ago.

The Protestant Episcopal Parish of St. Luke's in Brooklyn is one of the wealthiest in the diocese of Long Island, and the members of the church have been desirous for a long time of erecting a handsome church edifice.
The Board of Aldermen of Jersey City decided at a late hour Tuesday night that the election officers shall consist of three ring Democrats and one Republican at each polling place.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 9.--The train bearing the Pan-American party from Portland reached the Union Station here at 5 o'clock this morning, two hours ahead of schedule time. The party were allowed to sleep, and nobody turned out before 7 o'clock.

Jay Gould and party arrived in their special train at Marshall. Mo., yesterday afternoon, and remained there for the night. They will leave for Kansas City early in the morning. Mr. Gould has authorized the construction of the proposed extension of the Missouri Pacific branch from Boonesville, Mo., to Jefferson City, thus making the Missouri Pacific the shortest line between St. Louis and Kansas City.

Ex-Postmaster General Don M. Dickinson is at the Victoria Hotel. Assistant Postmaster General J.S. Clarkson is at the Everett House. Congressman Samuel Fowler of New-Jersey is at the Westminster Hotel.

Fire was discovered in the cellar of the Register's Office in City Hall Park at about 5 P.M. yesterday. Twenty minutes later it was under control. None of the records were damaged. There are three furnaces in the cellar which send hot air through the building for heating purposes.

In the lives of the Right Rev. Ethelbert Talbot, Bishop of Wyoming, and the Right Rev. Abiel Leonard, Bishop of Utah, both of whom are now in attendance at the Episcopal Convention, there have been some rather curious coincidences.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--It is learned that the Navy Department will ask Congress during the coming Winter, in the event of the Chandler bill for the transfer of the Revenue Marine Service to the navy becoming a law, to add 3,000 men to the regular establishment.

At 7 o'clock yesterday morning employes of the Phoenix Construction Company opened the manhole at Cortlandt and Church streets, and telephone men drew a cable through one of the subways. There was a strong odor of illuminating gas, and a vain search was made for a leak in the mains of the Consolidated and Mutual Companies.

The Sophomores of the School of Mines, Columbia College, yesterday engaged in a cane rush with the Freshmen and were worsted. The contest began with a general serimmage in front of the School of Mines Building.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 9.--A private letter written by President Colby of the Wisconsin Central Railroad to a stockholder of the Northern Pacific system reveals a gigantic railway consolidation that will connect the two oceans and revolutionize international railway traffic.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 9.--The magnificent stone house of Mr. Clem Studebaker, which cost about $300,000, was almost entirely destroyed by fire this morning. The residence was one of the largest and costliest in the West. It was built of Indiana freestone, with tile roof and copper facings, and the interior was...

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 9.--A member of the New-York Athletic Association, who refuses to give his name, arrived at Cornwall last night while tramping from Binghamton to New-York on a wager. He said that he was to do it inside of a week, and that he had yet remaining twenty-two hours to the final journey. Cornwall is about fifty-four miles from New-York. He is walking along the Ontario and Western Railroad track.
Steamships State of Nevada, (Br.,) Stewart, Glasgow 11 ds., via Larne, wish mdse. and passengers to Austin Baldwin Co. Schoolship St. Mary, Lieut. Coltman command- ing, from Newport.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 9.--Dr. James B. Noyes of New-Berlin has been named by the Democratic County Committee of Chenango County as a candidate for member of Assembly. TROY, N.Y., Oct. 9.--Samuel Magie of Stillwater was nominated to-day for member of Assembly by the Democrats of the First District of Saratoga County.

After a delay of over two months Supervisor at Large Quintard yesterday appointed Francis Nolan and George H. Murphy to be Charities Commissioners of Kings County for four years from Jan. l, 1890. They will succeed Commissioners Ray and Hines, at salaries of $5,000 each.

Judge Barrett of the Supreme Court was asked yesterday why the new rule with regard to the trial of divorce cases, adopted on Tuesday, was so worded as seemingly to apply only to cases in which no answers are filed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--This was the anniversary of the great Chicago fire, and the 150,000 wage workers of this city celebrated it by subscribing for World's Fair stock. About 20,000 books were circulated in all the stores, factories, and workshops, and an hour was designated by the Mayor at which the workmen knocked off.

Gen. Robert Averill was the only witness before Referee Emmet R. Olcott yesterday in the proceeding to determine the necessity of taking private property to increase the terminal facilities at the New-York end of the Brooklyn Bridge. A meeting, attended by some of the largest carpet manufacturers of New-England, NewYork, and Philadelphia, was held (with closed doors) at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday to consider the idea of forming a carpet manufacturers' trust.
The sixth conference of the Protestant Episcopal Church workers among deaf mutes was began yesterday morning at St. Ann's Church, in West Eighteenth-street.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 9.--Simon Peter Walker, a negro youth of fifteen years, who was to have been hanged at Chesterfield Court House tomorrow, was surprised this morning to receive a visit from Gov. Lee. Seated in his buggy behind his pair of favorite gray ponies, the Governor drove out to the Court House this morning...
William Waldorf Astor entertained a notable company of gentlemen who are interested in the World's Fair project at a dinner in the main banquet hall at Delmonico's last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--The scene at the White House to-night was one the Knights Templar are not likely to forget. As a spectacular event the reception was one of the most brilliant ever seen at the Executive Mansion. The White House was elegantly decorated and illuminated.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 9.--Another suit has been brought against the estate of the dead millionaire, John Guy Vassar. During his lifetime Mr. Vassar was foremost in assisting President Taylor of Vassar College to raise an endowment...

ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Oct. 9.--Col. Franklin Fairbanks will give to the town of St. Johnsbury his entire collection of birds, minerals, shells, and curiosities, and erect a suitable granite building for a museum. His collection of birds is one of the finest in the country, and his other collections include rare and costly articles from all parts of the world. The museum will contain working rooms for students and a scientific library.

The business now being done by Mr. and Mrs. Kendal in "A Scrap of Paper" at the FifthAvenue Theatre is so remarkably good, and the advance sales are so large, that Manager Frohman has decided to continue the same bill until next Wednesday or Thursday.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas. Oct. 9.--The Southern Pacific passenger train from New-Orleans yesterday contained one car of curious freight. In an ordinary emigrant coach attached to the rear sleeper were thirty-nine Chinamen en route to China.

OAKLAND, Md., Oct. 9.--An alarming epidemic of typhoid fever prevails at Aurora, West Va., about fourteen or fifteen miles from Oakland. It is said that the entire neighborhood for miles around is infected. There is scarcely a family without one or more of its members prostrated with the disease, and in some localities there are scarcely enough well persons to nurse the sick.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 9.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following causes were argued: The People, , respondents, vs. Benton Turner, appellant.--Submitted. Susan Provost, respondent, vs. The Mayor, of New-York, appellants.--Argued by D.J. Dean for appellants, Nelson Cross for respondent.

The new "Southwestern Limited" just placed in service over the New-York Central, Lake Shore and "Big Four" Lines rushes the mails through to Chicago from this city in twentysix hours actual running time. We have been exposing, in a series of articles in the last two weeks, the corrupt ring of Democratic politicians that rules Jersey City and the county of Hudson, across the river, and giving accounts of the movement of the anti-ring Democrats, who are determined to overthrow this greedy combination.

HOTEL AMPERSAND, SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Oct, 9.--The first snow of the season full last night. The mountains and hills presented a beautiful appearance this morning in their covering of white.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9.--At a meeting of stockholders of the Nevada Bank to-day the resignation of ex-Senator James G. Fair, both as President and Director, was announced and accepted. Mr. Fair gave press of other business as the reason for his resignation. James L. Flood was then elected President of the bank.

Secretary Tracy this morning received a request from the local board of managers of the training ship Saratoga for the detail of Commander Francis M. Green of the Brooklyn Navy Yard to take charge of her. The request is the result of a long negotiation for securing Commander Green's services, and he will undoubtedly be detailed as requested. Coroner Levy yesterday took the ante-mortem statement of Mrs. Hannah Truckman, a Russian Jewess, the wife of a poor peddler, who is lying dangerously ill in her apartments on the top floor of a tenement at 13 Bayard-street from injuries received on the night of the 6th inst.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Oct. 9.--The defeat of Fremont Cole in the Republican Convention for the Twenty-eighth Senatorial District, at Geneva, yesterday, was complete. Ex-Assemblyman E.P. Babcock of Ontario was chairman. On the first ballot, Ontario gave 9 votes for C...

Joseph Brooks, the manager of W.H. Crane, tells a story regarding Mr. Crane's recent debut as a lone star in Chicago, which did not find its way over the wires.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9.--Three sets of doubles were played in the intercollegiate tennis tournament this morning. Hovey and Weeden of Brown defeated Kingsley and Mate of Harvard, 6--4, 6--2. Huntington brothers of Yale defeated Stevens and Post of Columbia, 11--9, 6--4. Campbell of Columbia and Wright of Trinity defeated Hovey and Weeden of Brown, 6--0, 6--1.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 9.--W.R. Bronson op Perth Amboy, N.J., has been nominated by the Prohibitionists of the First Assembly District, Middlesex County, for Assembly.

Another ocean race between the mammoth steamships Teutonic of the White Star Line, the City of New-York of the Inman Line, and the City of Rome of the Anchor Line, ended yesterday. The winner this time was the Teutonic, which was sighted off the Sandy Hook Lightship at 4:22 P.M.
George F. Boers, a nephew of Edwin Beers, President of the Broadway Railroad Company of Brooklyn, is believed to have been one of the men enticed to Mexico by the notorious "Liverpool Jack."

The Rev. Henry L. Badger of Southern Ohio, in reading morning prayer yesterday, gave out the hymn "Hark, hark, my soul," which was sung with great fervor by the General Convention despite the fact that this is one of the familiar sacred songs eliminated from the proposed new hymnal.

Wall-street enjoyed a food deal clearer atmos phere yesterday than has been its fortune for some time. There was no indication anywhere of abnormal tightness in the money market, and stocks generally were buoyant.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 9.--The State conference of colored men adjourned last evening after issuing an address to the colored people of the State and Nation, which sets forth the object of the organization of the State league just effected to be to advance educational interests, the abolishment of separate schools, and to secure the employment of competent...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--While the visiting Knights Templar were monopolizing the attention of nearly everybody in Washington to-day, Secretary of the interior Noble rode up to the White House in the new department carriage.

READING, Penn., Oct. 9.--The tramp outlaws who have been systematically robbing and burning houses in Berks and adjoining counties for a month back, and whose operations have created so much terror in this section, have this week added two new features to their criminal campaign. Besides burglary and incendiarism, which they continue to practice as before, they have taken also to highway robbery and train wrecking.

It was a day of disappointment at Jerome Park yesterday. One of the largest crowds that has been at the track since the disastrous Fall meeting began was there to see Firenzi and Kingston race for the stakes named in honor of the famous mare.
The relations existing between the Old Guard of this city and the Ancient and Honorable Artillery of Boston are of the most fraternal and affectionate nature.

What is called a "convention of holiness" was opened yesterday morning at the Florence Mission, on Bleecker-street. It will continue through the week. Any one, man or woman, may be a delegate. "We will nominate," said an enthusiastic lady, "candidates for everlasting life."

ALBANY, Oct. 9.--One of the most difficult examinations under the State Superintendent of public Instruction is that for State certificates. While distributing tracts among the sailors on board the ship Abbie S. Hary of Yarmouth, N. S., as she lay off Staten Island on June 5 last, the Rev. Carston Hansteen, the founder of the Scandinavian Sailors' Home in Brooklyn, was assaulted and brutally beaten by boardinghouse runners.

The "floaters" who were arrested for voting illegally at the recent Twentieth Ward primary in Brooklyn were arraigned before Justice Kenna for trial yesterday. BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 9.--The Western Union Telegraph Company to-day began putting its wires under ground.

The thirty-fifth annual-meeting of the NewYork Association of School Commissioners and Superintendents will be held in the Court House at Cortland Nov. 6, 7, and 8. "Barney" Biglin of the Castle Garden Baggage Express Company, yesterday turned in his answer and explanations to the many complaints of overcharges for delivering immigrants' baggage, to the committee appointed to investigate the matter, consisting of Commissioners Wylie, Starr, and Stephenson.

The Protestant Episcopal conference of church workers among deaf-mutes held another session yesterday at St. Ann's Church, in West Eighteenth-street. The paper which had been prepared by the Rev. Job Turner of Virginia on "Spiritual Indifference" was taken up for discussion.

For the second time this year Mr. Withers has had the misfortune to have one of his horses disqualified after winning a race.

The Democratic State headquarters were opened yesterday. Last night Chairman Griffin of the Executive Committee, arrived at the Hoffman House and was in consultation with Secretary Defreest for an hour. The Executive Committee will hold an informal meeting this afternoon for the purpose of reaching some understanding in regard to New-York County local matters. There were not many callers at either the Republican or Democratic headquarters last night.
A meeting of the New-England, Insurance Exchange was held in this city yesterday to take action upon the withdrawal of some of its members from the New-Hampshire compact.

At a meeting of the Union League Club held last night, presided over by the Hon. Chauncey M. Depew and attended by about three hundred members, a resolution indorsing the Republican State ticket, introduced by Mr. Cornelius N. Bliss and seconded by ex-Judge Noah Davis, was adopted. RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 10.--With a view to facilitating the negotiations now pending in New-York looking to a settlement of the legal complications in which the parties interested in the Flynn street railways here have been involved.

ANN ARBOR, Mich, Oct. 10.--At the close of to-day's registration at the State University the number reached 1,896. Already the high-water mark of last year is passed, and at least 300 more will enter before the year closes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--To-day's bond offerings were as follows: Coupon 4s, $3,000 at 127; registered 4s, $200,000, $35,000, and $1,000, at 127; registered 4 s, $30,000, $250,000, $4,500, and $2,500, at 105 ; registered 4s, $35,000, $13,000, and $3,500, at 127; registered 4 s, $50,000, at 105 . All the offers were accepted.
The cornerstone of the Pulitzer Building, as the new home of the World at the corner of Parkrow and Frankfort-street is to be known, was laid yesterday with considerable ceremony.

The County Committee of the County Democracy had its meeting in the small hall in Cooper Institute last night and there was quite a gathering of the adherents of the weaker wing of the local Democracy. John R. Voorhis presided, and most of the larger lights of the organization were there.

The special institute of the American Church Sunday School Institute was began last evening at Grace Chapel on Fourteenth-street. Bishop Potter presided until he was obliged to leave to attend to other duties connected with the general conference, when Bishop Whittaker of Pennsylvania took his place. The church was crowded with those interested in the work of the institute, which has for its object systematic Sunday school work.

LONDON, Oct. 10.--Viscount Cranbrook, Lord President of the Privy Council, is about to retire from the Cabinet owing to ill health. Gen. Boulanger has taken a villa near St. Helier, Jersey. He is preparing a work on European military science. The demands of the striking gas stokers at Bristol have been conceded and the men have resumed work.
TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Oct. 10.--While laborers were engaged in digging a sewer in one of the principal streets of the village to-day they struck a tombstone.

WARSAW, N.Y., Oct. 10.--The Democrats of Wyoming County have secured a new date for their adjourned County Convention, originally called for Oct. 8, but abruptly postponed by Chairman Michael C. Shea of the County Central Committee. It is Tuesday, Oct. 15, and the delegates already elected will serve.

Almost every one of the 282 members of the World's Fair General Committee was present at the meeting of that body yesterday afternoon in the Common Council Chamber, and every man there seemed imbued with the desire to give the scheme of holding the great celebration in New-York as immediate and cordial impetus.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn. Oct. 10.--The train containing the delegates to the Pan-American Congress arrived here at 2 P.M. to-day, after making two stops, one at Collinsville, where the method of making machetes to fill South American contracts was inspected, and murderouslooking bowie knives were distributed as souvenirs, and one at Meriden,where several factories were looked over.

LONDON, Oct. 10.--At the Newmarket meeting today the principal event was the race for the Czarowitch Stakes for three-year olds and upward, at about two miles and a quarter. It was won by Primrose Day, with Ingram second and Mercy third. There were twenty-two starters. The post betting was 11 to 1 against the winner.

About fifteen hundred men interested in boxing crowded into the Brooklyn Labor Lyceum last evening to witness the preliminary contests of an amateur boxing tournament held under the management of the National Athletic Club of Brooklyn.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 10.--The Twenty-third Senatorial District Republican Convention did not succeed in breaking the dead-lock to-day, and this evening adjourned till 11 o'clock tomorrow after taking 551 ballots.

The General Convention returned yesterday to the discussion of the proposed change in the judicial system of the Church, providing for an appellate court, after following the lead of the Rev W. D'Orville Doty, D.D., of Western NewYork in morning prayer.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 10.--The doubletrack railroad bridge of the New-York, Providence and Boston Railroad across the Thames was formally accepted to-day and opened to travel.

Mayor Grant's warfare against the badlyinsulated and death-dealing overhead electric light wires was continued yesterday at the meeting of the Board of Electrical Control, and the problem is constantly becoming more involved.

The bitter internal war which has for some time agitated the members of the Deborah Society is not by any means ended yet. Mrs. Henrietta Loeser founded the society and was for many years its President. Mrs. Lena Levy now holds that office.
DUNELLEN, N.Y., Oct. 10.--The third and as yet the most interesting day of the Middlesex tournament has just been concluded.

The belief of the young Emperor of Germany that he is doing some service to his "people" by traveling about Europe and making the acquaintance of other monarchs is evidently sincere and well established.

Under cover of the interest involved in the selection of a Mayoralty candidate, several Republican politicians in Brooklyn are just now engaged is a deal by which it is hoped to put the notorious John Y. McKane in control of at least one nomination at the coming Republican County Convention.

ORRVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 10.--Senator John Sherman has at last thawed out and made his first speech of the campaign. The yeomen of Wayne County gathered at the district fair grounds in numbers to view him in common with the other exhibits.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--The President made the following appointments to-day: Collector of Internal Revenue for the Fifth District of New-Jersey.--GEORGE H. LARGE of New-Jersey. Collector of Customs at Corpus Christi, Texas.-- CALVIN G. BREWSTER of Texas.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 10.--United States Minister Mizner has settled the canal difficulties, and work is now progressing. The chief impediment to the construction of the canal--the hostility of Costa Rica toward the enterprise-- has been removed and the trouble between that country and Nicaragua has bean settled by arbitration.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 10.--The fertilizer factory or G. Ober, Sons Co., established in 1857 at Locust Point, was burned today. It consisted or three large buildings, which cost $250,000.

At 2 o'clock this afternoon the biggest trotting race that has taken place in this vicinity for several years will be called. Old Fleetwood saw its largest crowd of late years when JayEye-See and St. Julien came together there half a dozen years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--The main point of interest to-night in Washington is Calumet-place, where Mrs. Logan, assisted by her guests and the wives of the various local Commanders of the Knights Templar, gave a reception to the vast conclave of Knights who have thronged the city during the present week.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10.--"I have decided to accept the position of Postmaster of this city," said John Field to-day at his place of business, "and I have chosen ex-State Senator Benjamin F. Hughes as Assistant Postmaster.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 10.--The secret envelope ballot, which was used for the first time in this State at the town elections Monday, has elated its friends and silenced its opponents.

Yesterday's stock market started off beautifully. Unfortunately, it didn't stay started that way. Various bull pools were ready for work and inclined to begin with a good deal of energy. But just as soon as business got well under way bear operators made a spirited onslaught upon the whole list with results that did not much help bull profits.

The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church has ordered the consecration of the Rev. Dr. William Andrew Leonard as Assistant Bishop of Ohio. It will take place at 11 o'clock to-morrow in St. Thomas's Church, Fifth-avenue and Fifty-third street. Bishop Doane of Albany will be the preacher, and the Bishops of Maryland and Southern Ohio will be the presenters.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10.--Baltimore lost to-day's game in the seventh inning, when the Brooklyns bunched their hits and secured a winning lead. But eight innings Were played, owing to darkness.

The great ocean race, which was reported in yesterday's papers as having been completed by the victory of the Teutonic over the City of New-York, seems to have ended in both instances in rather unfortunate consequences.

The meeting of carpet manufacturers at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel on Wednesday was held for the purpose of effecting some sort of organization of the manufacturers to counteract the influences under which the profits of their business have been gradually fading away. Some twenty of the carpet manufacturers of NewEngland, Philadelphia, and New-York were present.

Jessup, ex-cashier of the broken Scranton City Bank, which failed on the 25th of last May, was indicted for embezzlement and larceny by the Grand Jury this afternoon. When the bank failed it owed depositors about $300,000, and Jessup's estimated defalcation was placed at $150,000. Frederick Mason, who says he is a butcher, living at 64 Dover-street, Boston, is looked up in the Forty-seventh-street station on a charge of robbing the notorious Annie Whitmore. The latter was walking along Broadway about 9 o'clock last evening, and when near Thirtysixth-street the prisoner accosted her.

John Carey, thirty-three years old, who lived at 624 East Seventeenth-street, was shot last evening behind the right ear by John Clark during an encounter in front of Casey's liquor store, at Avenue C and Fifteenth-street, and was almost instantly killed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10.--Samuel J. Cresswell, a prominent iron manufacturer, was stricken with paralysis at noon to-day in the dental office of Dr. John D. Thomas, 912 Walnut-street, and died five hours later. Mr. Cresswell had called upon Dr. Thomas to have two teeth extracted. The gas was administered and the teeth were taken out.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 10.--The Republicans of the Second Oneida District today renominated for member of Assembly George G. McAdam of Rome.
Four thousand people who were at Morris Park yesterday were treated to a genuine sensation in the second race, in which Kingston and Cracksman ran a dead heat over the mile and a sixteenth course.

Salvini, the greatest actor of this time, is with us again. The beginning of his engagement at Palmer's Theatre last night was auspicious. The audience filled the theatre and gave the artist a rousing welcome.

Whelan, stockholders of the Sutro Tunnel Company, yesterday served notice on twenty-five Comstock mining companies and corporations, enjoining said companies from hereafter paying any royalties or dues of the Sutro Tunnel Company, Union Trust Company of New-York, or Comstock Tunnel Company of New-York.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 10.--A telegram received in St. Paul yesterday announces the completion of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company's line from Rockford to Spokane Falls, Washington. This opens another line from the East to Eastern Washington. The new line is via the Union Pacific, Oregon Short Line, and the Oregon Railway and Navigation.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 10.--Joseph Beille, a property owner of this city, is trying to dispossess the Third Ward Republican Club, to whom his agent some weeks also rented a building to be used as their headquarters. Beille leased the place to a New-York furniture dealer and gave him the key.
KIEL, Oct. 10.--The Czar arrived here this afternoon on the imperial yacht Derjava. The yacht steamed through the British fleet and anchored alongside the German guardship Baden.

The steamer State of Nevada, which arrived yesterday from Glasgow, brought one little family group among her saloon passengers which had been diminished during the voyage. Little Bertram Robinson, a mere babe of eighteen months, had died on Oct. 9 of scarlet fever.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Thursday, Oct. 10:

It throws some light on the manner in which this Administration has treated the reform of the civil service that a considerable number of the journals of the party of the Administation are discussing with much apparent gravity the question whether the Republican majority in Congress will repeal the civil cervive reform law.

The Metropolitan Line steamer Herman winter, of the outside freight line running to Boston, ran down and sank the steam lighter Manhattan off the Battery yesterday afternoon, as she was returning to her pier, No. 11, North River, from Boston.
The Republican Volunteer Association has let the public into its plans and purposes. It was organized last May, but its promoters thought best not to say much about it until yesterday.

TERRE HAUTE, Oct. 10.--A "red-letter day" was the third of the trotting meeting here. Six consecutive heats in the 2:16 class race were paced in the average time of 2:15 1-6, thus beating all previous records. Johnston paced a mile in 2:08, the last three-quarters of which were done in 1:34.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10.--The match for second place in singles in the intercollegiate tennis tournament took place this morning and was won by Hovey, (Brown,) defeating Hurd, (Yale,) in three straight sets, 6--2, 8--6, 6--1. Hovey's play in the first and last set was the most brilliant tennis seen during the tournament.

A great crowd attended the missionary meeting at the Academy of Music in the afternoon. The orchestra and all the galleries and boxes were filled. Bishop Dudley of Kentucky presided. Bishop Tuttle sat beside him and led the services which preceded the addresses.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10.--Dispatches to the Manufacturers' Record report the organization in London, England, of a large company to build iron and steel works at Middleborough, Ky., and the commencement of work at the same town on two furnaces of 150 tons daily capacity, each to cost about $400,000.

Judge Bookstover showed yesterday, by trying a suit for separation, that he has had enough of the referee. John T. Wilson brought an action for separation against his wife. Mary T. Wilson, on the ground of cruel treatment.
DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 10.--From official reports made to the Secretary of State the probable yield of wheat in Michigan this year is computed at 23,127,050 bushels, machine measure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--Five races were run over the track of the National Jockey Club today. The only exciting feature occurred in the steeplechase, when Mr. Knut was thrown from his horse, Cock o' the Walk, while trying to take a hurdle. The rider received a severe shock, but no serious injury. The races were run with these results:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 10.--The attendance of visiting horsemen on this the opening day of the Fairlawn stud sale here was quite large. The bidding was spirited, the sale of 85 head realising $66,100, an average of $787.55. The animals sold which brought the best prices were as follows:

Chief Judge McAdam of the City Court appeared successfully in the role of a Judge of the Solomon type yesterday. Miss Anna Barasz, a young lady of eighteen years, who lives at 56 Hester-street, appeared as complainant against Julius Rosenfeld of 17 Ludlow-street.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 10.--The receivers of the Charter Oak Life Insurance Company, Messrs. John W. Brooks of Torrington and E.A. Stedman of this city, will leave for Utah this evening for the purpose of disposing of the mine and real estate interests which were held by the company, constituting at one period in its history one of the largest assets reported to the Insurance Department.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 10.--The Genesee Methodist Conference which has just closed here has created more dissension among the ministerial appointments made by Bishop Fitzgerald of Minneapolis, Minn., than any other in the history of the conference.

The Committee on Studies of the Brooklyn Teachers' Association has recently issued a circular setting forth the work of the next year. Classes will be formed in English literature, French, German, physical training, the elements of the natural sciences, physical geographs, elemantary physics, algebra, geometry, logic, psychology, the history of education, ...

The stockholders' meeting of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of Kansas was concluded at Anthony, Kan., yesterday. The Board of Directors for the ensuing year was reduced to nine and elected as follows: Levi S. Gould, Benjamin Dickerman, Henry Wait, H.P. Emmersen, and George P. Knapp of Boston; F.G. Hobson of Norristown, Penn.; J.K. Wilson, S.A. Darrough, and J.M. Russell of Anthony.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 10.--Henry Hoar of Ansonia, Conn., and L.D. Van Arnam of Gloversville, N.Y., members of the Freshman Class of Syracuse University, were bound and taken to a swamp three miles east of this city by a party of Sophomores last night. Hoar's mustache and hair were out off and the two men were compelled to walk back to the city.

A party of about one hundred and fitfy gentlemen and ladies embarked on a tug at the Barge Office at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon and were taken to the schoolship St. Mary's lying in the East River north of Governor's Island.
The collapse of five of the stokers on board the Teutonic is a striking illustration of the cost at which the high speed of the transatlantic racers is maintained.
A number of letters were received yesterday at the office of the World's Fair Committee from real estate owners who have property in the vicinity of the proposed site of the fair.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 11.--Judge Oliver, who delivered an address at the unveiling of the Tabaret statue yesterday, and, on behalf of the Alumni Association, handed it over to the keeping of the Ottawa University authorities, caught cold at the banquet given by the Senate and the Faculty of the University last evening, and withdrew, dying shortly afterward.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 11.--Axtell, who has heretofore shown himself to be a phenomenal trotter, eclipsed any trotting performance against time ever before recorded.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Oct. 11.--The Ocean Grove Association finished its twentieth annual session in the Association building here today. All the old officers were re-elected, making the twenty-first election of Dr. E.H. Stokes to the position of President of the association. The Rev. J.H. Alday was elected to the Executive Committee to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Joseph H. Thornley.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 11.--Andrew Carnegie will establish in Pittsburg one of the finest public libraries in the United States.

From present appearances the benefit to be tendered to the Giants at the Broadway Theatre on Oct. 20 promises to be a grand success. Messrs. Hopper and Bell have received letters from many enthusiasts asking that seats be reserved for them.
One of the members of Mrs. John B. Alley's family, at 114 East Twenty-third-street, is a very ancient, very intelligent, and very loudvoiced parrot of South American lineage.

The campaign in Ohio continues to be interesting. We showed two or three days ago how it had been enlivened by the Topp letter and the charge that Mr. CAMPBELL, the Democratic candidate for Governor, had been pecuniarily interested in a project relating to the use of a patent ballot box at Federal elections.

While hundreds of people with minds intent upon their own affairs, were hurrying along in the vicinity of Chambers and Centre streets a little alter 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, there was enacted a tragedy of most startling and frightful character.

The prospectus of the fifth annual exhibition of the Architectural League of this city, which will be held at the Fifth-Avenue Art Galleries for three weeks, from Dec. 20 to Jan. 11, has been published.

HARTFORD, Oct. 11.--The total gross earnings of the Housatonic Road for the year ending June 30, 1889, were $1,159,347.12. The total freight earnings for the period were $669,767.78. From the passenger traffic the earnings amounted to $455,978.64.

BERLIN, Oct. 11.--The Czar arrived here this morning. He was accompanied by the Grand Duke George, his second son. Emperor William, several of the royal Princes, Prince Bismarck, Count Herbert Bismarck, and a number of Generals and Court officials received them at the Lehrter station.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 11.--The General Council of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of North America reconvened at the First Church, in this city, at 10 o'clock this morning, the Rev. Dr. Harkey of North Lima, Ohio, conducting ...

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 11.--Gov. Fitzhugh Lee has invited Gen. Lord Wolseley of England to take part in the ceremonies attending the unveiling of the monument to Gen. Robert E. Lee. That gentleman will probably accept the invitation. The Governor has also been urging exPresident Jefferson Davis of the Confederacy to be present on the same occasion. If the exPresident's health permits it the Governor is sure that he will attend.

Dealers in quinine here and abroad have recently felt the effect of the comparative suspension of production of the cinchona bark, which began in the East Indies several years ago, following a heavy overproduction, and the wholesale price of the great fever and ague medicine has been advanced.

The General Committee of the anti-ring Democracy of Hudson Connty, N.J., met in Jersey City last evening to hear the report of its committee appointed to confer with the Republicans and to consider some other matters.

The British naval anthorities are very much elated over the showing made by the first-class Yarrow torpedo boats while on trial recently. There is no question that the first-class Yarrow boats will be the prototype for all the larger boats of the service, and that the secondclass Yarrow torpedo crait will be the prototype for all the smaller boats.

When Germans undertake to provide place of entertainment for themselves they usually erect palaces, the structural solidity and richness of decoration of which make them of immense value not alone architecturally, but as places where the family pleasures of the German-American can foster emulation among the native-born citizens.

The International Marine Conference which will convene in Washington on Wednesday of next week, although it has hitherto attracted very little public attention, is likely to be of equal, if not greater, importance in its practical results than the Pan-American Congress, about which so mnoh has been said and written.

HARTFORD, Oct. 11.--The American Home Missionary Society of New-York received in contributions and legacies from the Congregational churches in this State in 1888 the sum of $67,662. The cash contributions amounted to $34,344.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 11.--The condition of the hop market in Otsego County--the largest hop-growing region in the country--has not changed materially since the crop was harvested, although the local market has been quite active the present week. Good to choice lots have sold at 9 to 11 cents, and for a few extra choice lots 12 cents has been paid.

The prospects of an old-fashioned heat race at the magnificent West Chester race track yesterday brought out a much larger crowd than even the most sanguine of the friends of the New-York Jockey Club had expected, for the Jarome Park meeting had strong counter attractions.
The second day's session of the American Church Sunday School Institute opened yesterday morning with holy communion in Grace Chapel, on East Fourteenth-street.

The reorganizers of the Fifth District had it all their own way at the primary election held at 123 West Houston-street last night. The followers of John C. Dodd and others of the disgruntled simply staid away from the polling place, and let things take their course.
LONDON, Oct. 11.--The steamship Donati, (Br.,) Capt. James, from New-York Sept. 27. arr. at Liverpool to-day.

James Bell, owner of the yacht Thistle, arrived in this city on the City of Rome yesterday accompanied by his wife. He registered at the Windsor, but could not be seen last evening. It has been rumered that he will talk over the subject of an international yacht race for the America's Cup next season while he is here, and make an effort to arrange a match with the New-York Yacht Club.

The political situation in Kings County is today similar to that in New-York--very much mixed. The controlling elements of both parties, the men who boss the primaries and dictate nominations, are seemingly bent upon making a short and sharp campaign.
The earnestness of Mayor GRANT in demanding that all overhead electric wires shall be made safe or cease to operate was justified by the slaughter of another lineman yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 11.--This was the second day of Fairlawn's closing out sale, and the crowd in attendance was larger than yesterday. The competition for the good things was very strong and prices ruled high. Eighty-six head were disposed of for $74,465, an average of $866. Following are the best sales:

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 11.--The delegates to the International Congress arrived here this morning, and were met at the station by Col. Buddington, commandant at the armory, Capt. Blount, Alderman Murphy, and a delegation of citizens.

The United States cruiser Atlanta was docked yesterday and work immediately commenced altering the screws for increase of pitch. The Atlanta is the lame duck of the squadron of evolution just at present.
MONTREAL, Oct. 11.--A very curious case is before the Montreal courts, which involves a conflict of authority between the Church and State.

The steamship Etruria will start on her journey eastward early this morning, bearing among her passengers the veteran showman, P. T. Barnum, Mrs. Barnum and their grandson, and Mr. Barnum's successor. Mr. Barnum Seeley.

Something like one hundred and fifty prominent Republican politicians met in Everett Hall, in Bridge-street, Brooklyn, last night, to consides the much-vexed question of the nomination of a candidate for Mayor.
BOSTON, Oct. 11.--A movement is on foot to have the Board of Police Commissioners, which is under State control, close all public bars in the city at an early date.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--The Trans-missouri Auxiliary Association had a stormy time at its meeting in this city yesterday.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 11.--The last Grand Jury considered the charges of crookedness in the Eleventh District of Watervilet at the election April 8 last, but failed in finding any verdict.

HELENA, Mon., Oct. 11.--The vote of Jefferson County was canvassed yesterday, the result being that the Democrats lose a State Senator. This leaves the upper house of the Legislature a tie, but the Democrats will have a majority of seven on joint ballot. The canvass of the vote in all counties will not be completed before tomorrow, if then.

Searcely fifteen hundred people witnessed the racing at Jerome Park yesterday, though there was an excellent programme of six races, including the Champagne Stakes for two-yearold, against the six over-night events to be decided at Morris Park.

A meeting of editors of labor papers was held yesterday at 143 Eighth-street, at which J.P. McDonald of the Paterson (N.J.) Labor Standard presided and Charles G. Brown of the Union Printer of New-York was Secretary.
Dr. Remsen Taylor, Health Officer of Long Island City, was yesterday indicted by the Queens County Grand Jury upon charges of blackmail, extortion, and receiving money under false pretenses.

DUNELLEN, N.J., Oct. 11.--The big Middlesex Gun Club tournament was concluded to-day. Four days have been spent at the traps, and during that time about 2,200 live birds have been shot at, and many thousands of inanimate targets have been shattered.

BIRMINGHAM, Oct. 11.--The National Conference of Miners to-day declared in favor of a working day of eight hours, the rule to go into operation on the 1st of January next. The miners throughout Great Britain have taken a ballot on the question, and it has been decided to go on strike if the demand is not granted.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--The World's Fair Committee has sent E. Jeffrey Lad, General Manager of the Illinois Central Railroad Company, to the Paris Exposition "to represent Chicago's interests at that place." While he has declined any compensation for his services he has been provided with $5,000 to pay expenses. It is believed by the World's Fair boomers that he will do a good deal toward creating favorable public sentiment in Europe for this city.
A walk along upper Broadway before noontime just now is made unpleasant by the number of icemen who prepare the big frozen cakes for the stores which they regularly supply on the sidewalks.

On Thursday evening a most enjoyable and quite a novel entertainment was given on board the French flagship Arethuse, now at anchor in the North River.
ALBANY, Oct. 11.--The Barnes General Committee called the Fourth Assembly District Republican Convention for to-day.

A trip along the water front of the city on any pleasant afternoon would impress the pedestrian who threaded his way out on the piers and along the bulkheads with the number of people who have time to idle away in fishing.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--Three new suspects were arrested by the police this afternoon for alleged complicity in the murder of Dr. Cronin.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 11.--The Republican Senatorial Convention, in which Titus Sheard and Frank Arnold are the principal figures, adjourned at noon to-day until Tuesday night, with a record of 569 ballots.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 11.--Frank A. Robbins's so-styled circus, menagerie, and wild west show has disbanded here under a heavy cloud of pecuniary troubles.

William Moore, a negro train hand on the Savannah, Florida and Western Road, was taken from the train at Jesup by a posse of citizens Thursday and lynched. While passing that place Wednesday he had some words with a citizen, and as the train pulled out he threw a stone which struck a bystander. A posse waited for his arrival Thursday, and, taking him off the train, made short work of him.

Three young men saw a young man and young woman coming from the parsonage of the Rev. Mr. Arrowsmith of Bayonne last Tuesday evening. The young woman was recognized as Lizzie Harrigan; the young man as James Stilson, a Bayonne peddler.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 11.--A case of more than ordinary interest to farmers was tried a few days ago. The suit was brought by a State milk inspecter against Joseph Wilbur, a milkman at Long Branch.

A sneak thief got into 81 John-street yesterday afternoon, a printing office, and quietly made off with a bundle which a clerk had laid on the delivery desk. An hour later the package was missed. It contained 5,000 blank check forms ordered by the Merchants' Bank of Binghamton, N.Y. The bank was notified by telegraph and a general alarm sent out from Police Headquarters.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 11.--Gen. Grubb, the Republican candidate for Governor, held a reception here to-day, and afterward made an address at the Republican County Convention, which was held in the Assembly Room at the Masonic Hall in the afternoon. The convention nominated John H. Conger for County Clerk as the opponent of ex-Sheriff Convery, who has been named by the Democrats. There was practically no opposition to Mr. Conger's nomination.

The Inman Line Steamship City of New-York is still fast on the sandbar off Sandy Hook. The prospects of getting her off now are apparently no better than they were Wednesday night, when she was stranded by the blunder of some one. Her position is one of great peril, and herculean work must be done to-day in a lighterage way to save her.
MADISON, N.J., Oct. 11.--At a meeting of the citizens of Madison Thursday the question whether the town should have a water supply and electric lights was decided in the affirmative.

Jay Gould came closer yesterday to showing his speculative hand than Wall-street has had the chance to notice in many a day. Few unprejudiced brokers have ever doubted that he has been an active backer of all the recent bear movements against the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe system; but against the denials of his friends and dependents there has been little save theories to urge in support of the popular suspicions against him.

An important conference of prominent citizens was held up town last evening for the purpose of organizing a citizans' movement in this city at the coming election, with a view of selecting men of merit and of integrity rather than politicians, or the automatons of politicians, for the numerous offices, particularly of the judiciary, to be voted for next month.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 11.--Residents of this city are jubilant this evening over the result of the long-contested suit against the New-Jersey Central Railroad Company for the recovery of a public dock which the railroad took possession of in 1846 and stubbornly held.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 11.--The intelligence department of the Imperial Army recently asked the Dominion Government for information regarding the military strength of Canada and the facilities engaged for the transportation of troops between the various provinces. The communication was referred to the Minister of Militia, who sent out inquiries to the Deputy Adjutants General of the various military districts.
INDIANPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 11.--The railroad men of this city are howling over Harrison's distribution of the spoils and affirm that he is only a kid-glove politician.

He claimed that the law was fulfilled when the names alone were given, and intimated that otherwise witness would be interfered with.

PARIS, Oct. 11.--Disastrous floods prevail in the Department of the Jura. A number of bridges have been carried away by the high water. Lons-le-Saulnier, the capital of the department, is inundated, and a number of villages are surrounded by water. The military are actively engaged in saving life and property.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--A good-looking young woman from Australia arrived in Chicago last night after a ten thousand mile journey in pursuit of a married man who had wedded her under pretense that he was single.

In all this hubbub about the dangers of overhead electric lighting wires and the demands for reform the name of the Board of Electrical Control has been passed around by word of mouth with so much familiarity as to raise it from comparative obscurity to a plane of publicity that is not at all disagreeable to the august gentlemen who compose that body.

Mr. BRECKINRIDGE of Arkansas, as reported in our Washington dispatches yesterday morning, gave a very fair, and, we doubt not, a correct statement of the intentions of the Democratic minority in the House with reference to any action the majority may propose to take.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 11.--At this morning's session of the Congregational Council the Rev. C.J. McCully of Calais, Me., presented the work of the Bangor Theological Seminary. Thirteen new students have been received this year, a total of thirty-one pupils.

Admiral Belknap, under date Kobe, Japan, Sept. 17, reports to the Navy Department as follows: The Omaha, the flagship at Kobe, will sail Sept. 19 for Nagasaki, Chemnipo, Corea; Che-Foo, and possibly to Tang-Chow, China, and Shanghal, returning to Yokohama via Nagasaki. The Marion is at Chemalpo, Corea. The Palos, at Kobe, Japan, will sail Sept. 19 for Nagasaki. The Monocacy is at Yokahama.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 11.--The cornerstone of the new stone lodgehouse of Alpha Delta Phi was laid to-night with secret ceremonies. A leadan box, containing documents of interest to the chapter was deposited in the cornerstone by the venerable Dr. Edward Hitchcock, '49. During this ceremony the society joined in a song peculiar to the fraternity.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 11.--Herman Frager, a miner living in the northern section of Scranton, had a thrilling experience in a mine yesterday and last night, having been imprisoned for fifteen hours in the narrow chamber where he had been at work at the Brisbin colliery.

QUEBEC, Oct. 11.--A dispatch from Point Esquimaux, through the Signal Service, says that all the fishing schooners have arrived there, and report the catch a complete failure. These is every indication of misery and priva tion for the inhabitants the coming Winter.
The news of Lineman Feeks's tragic death was telephoned from the Mayor's office toMayor Grant, who was sick at his home with a bad cold. He was naturally very much exercised over the matter.
