Success is an abused word. To too many of us it is measured by cold dollars. We are prone to forget that many things of great artistic worth do not draw money, and therefore to gauge a man's achievements by their potency in opening the public pocket.

BERLIN, Oct. 13.--Mr. Phelps, the United States Minister, was presented to the Empress by Count Kulenberg after the performance at the Opera House last Friday night, at the Empress's own request. To-morrow Mr. Phelps will be presented to ex-Empress Frederick.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13.--Henry C. Wicker, Traffic Manager of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad, resigned to-day, to take effect Nov. 1. He will shortly thereafter go to Europe to represent New-York bankers in an enterprise in London.
The firm of R.H. Macy Co., at Sixth-avenue and Fourteenth-street, has added to its already large establishment three more apartments for the carrying on of their business.

The fiftieth consecutive performance of "McKenna's Flirtation" by Barry and Fay, at the New Park Theatre, will be given to-morrow evening, and the event will be signalized by the first display of the new costumes for the ladies of the cast, which have been in preparation...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13.--The eighth annual meeting of the American Forestry Congress and the fourth annual meeting of the Pennsylvania Forestry Association will be held in Horticultural Hall, this city, beginning on Tuesday next...

The fruit market will be well supplied all this week with a great variety of fruit, and prices are likely to be moderate. At no time during the season has there been a more extensive variety. In fact, all the fruits of the year, with the exception of raspberries, strawberries, currants, cherries, and gooseberries, may be obtained...

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Oct. 13.--Fire broke out in Cook's lumber yard, at Serpent River, Ontario, Saturday afternoon. A heavy northwest wind blowing extended the flames to the docks and warehouses of this extensive firm, and at 6 P.M. the whole town was afire. There were forty buildings in the town, general stores...

The Rev. Dr. Amos B. Kendig of the HansonPlace Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, preached last evening the first of a series of five discourses on "Brooklyn's Big Ox." The one last night was entitled "The Ox is an Old One." The ox figuratively represented the liquor saloon.

Mrs. Mary Walton, aged forty-five, of NewUtrecht, tried to cross the tracks of the Brooklyn, Bath and West End Railroad at NewUtrecht-avenue last night, when she was knocked down and had both legs cut off. She was removed to the Seney Hospital, Brooklyn, in a dying condition.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 14.--The Elmira, Cortland and Northern Railroad Company has become involved in important litigation on a question of taxes with the towns of Homer, Truxton, and Cuyler in Cortland County, through whose bounds its line passes.
Col. William C. Heppenheimer has been renominated for member of Assembly by the Democrats of the Fourth District of Hudson County. N.J. He has served three terms.

The Rev. Henry A. Adams, assistant minister of Trinity Church, has accepted a call to St. Paul's Cathedral, Buffalo, and celebrated his last service in the former church yesterday. During his ministry in Trinity Parish the Rev. Mr. Adams has established an enduring reputation as an earnest worker and a brilliant pulpit crater. In his new parish in Buffalo he will find a wide field of usefulness.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the Prudence Association of Sheep Butchers reported that Simon Kaufman, butchers of West Forty-seventh-street, and S. Taylor, butcher of West Forty-eighth-street, had locked out their union men. The meeting then passed a resolution declaring that the charges...

Previous to the regular morning service in St. John's Chapel, Varick-street, yesterday a handsome new brass eagle lectern in memorial of the late Rev. Sullivan H. Weston, D.D., was placed in the chapel. The Rev. Mr. Weston was for many years connected with Trinity Parish...

John F. Donahoe, head clerk of the Money Order Department of the Hartford, (Conn.) Post Office, is a defaulter to the amount of several hundred dollars, aroused on Thursday, and a Government inspector was sent for to examine his accounts. Donahoe has not been at the office since Saturday morning, but is believed to be in town. The amount of his embezzlement is covered by bonds.

The Executive Committee of the--National Association of Amateur Oarsmen disqualified on Saturday the six oarsmen who rowed against J.J. Murphy, a disqualified Boston oarsman, in the senior scull race of the New-England Amateur Rowing Association's Labor Day regatta.

The famous old novelist was buried in Kensal Green Cemetery, in the wind-swept flat behind the church. Long before noon a crowd of spectators had gathered on the church steps and awaited the arrival of the hearse.

Connor leads the Giants in heavy batting. He made 11 home runs, 17 three-base hits, and 31 hits for two bases each. Richardson, Ewing, Tiernan, Gore, and O'Rourke have made improvements in long hits. The complete record for the season is as follows:
People at all familiar wish the way in which the Brooklyn Tabernacle is conducted are well acquainted with the all but inflexible rule that "Dr. Talmage receives no visitors on the Sabbath."

There will be no racing at West Chester this afternoon, so that there should be a large attendance at Jerome Park. A good card is promised, the entries and the weights the several horses will be called upon to carry being as follows:

Eikonogen, the new developer, is attracting a good deal of attention among amateur photographers this Fall, and many are experimenting with it. Their report is very favorable to the new discovery, and it will probably be pretty generally adopted before long.
There is a prospect of a lively Republican primary in the Seventh Ward of Brooklyn on Tuesday, and a big vote may be expected. The ticket adopted at the caucus on Thursday night...
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 13.--The New-York and New-England Road has within a few days begun to carry through freight to New-York, ia Wilson's Point, without breaking bulk.

PARIS, Oct. 13.--The race for the Prix Gladiateur was run to-day and was won by Tenebreuse by ten lengths. Siberie was second and Le Sancy a bad third. The last betting was 5 to 2 against both Tenebreuse and Siberie.
Postmaster Lawshe of Xenia, Ind., a recent appointee of President Harrison, is in a very unenviable frame of mind. The Postmaster divides his time between selling stamps and running a newspaper.

Capt. McLaughlin's desk at the Old-slip police station was fairly littered up yesterday with bogus checks bearing all sorts of signatures by which persons in almost every business section of the town had been victimized during the past month.

LONDON, Oct. 14.--The Edam, (Dutch,) Capt. Bakker, from Amsterdam for New-York, passed Grisnez yesterday. The steamship Tycho Brahe, (Belg.,) Capt. McMilan, from New-York Sept. 28, arr. at Liverpool yesterday.

The first of a series of essays on sociological evolution was delivered last evening by Dr. Lewis G. Janes at the Second Unitarian Church, Clinton and Congress streets, Brooklyn. These essays will be under the auspices of the Brooklyn Ethical Association, and will occupy two...
NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 14.--Burglars are operating again in this vicinity, and many people here are preparing to give them a warm reception.
The Norfolk papers announce that Baron Hirsch is negotiating with Lord Cholmondeley for the purchase of the Houghton Hall estate for 300,000.
There was a melancholy silence pervading the room of the Emigration Commission when the board assembled for a special meeting yesterday afternoon.

A subterranean river has just been discovered in the district of Miers, in the Department of Lot. Miers is in the heart of a wild, mountainous country, in the deepest recesses of which caves and grottoes are found, some of which appear to have been the abodes of our troglodyte ancestors.

BUFFALO, Oct. 14.--William E. Curtis, Mr. Blaine's special Commissioner in charge of the Pan-American excursion, who is evidently under instructions from his chief to watch the delegates closely and see that no views of the tariff and "protection" not authorized by the Harrison Administration are brought to their attention...
POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 14.--A meeting of all former students of Vassar College will be held in Poughkeepsie on Saturday next at 11 A.M.

HARDFORD, Oct. 14.--A singular collection of old books and manuscripts has been found within a few weeks in the Tulley homestead, at Old Saybrook, one of the most ancient towns along the Connecticut coast.
NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 14.--The gale along the Lower Hudson has grown gradually more severe all the afternoon. Considerable damage has already been done, and more is feared.
The steamer City of Rome will sail for London at 10 o'clock to-morrow, and besides her usual complement of passengers will take aboard 160 attaches of Barnum Bailey's Show.

Reports continue to come in of the wonderful performance of the Lebel rifle, the new arm now being supplied to the French infantry. What with the smallness of the calibre and the velocity imparted by the smokeless powder, the trajectory is so flat as to make the accuracy of the piece simply phenomenal.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--Two matters important to members of the Board of Trade were settled by vote of the members of that body to-day. The first proposition was to amend Section 9 of Rule 4 of the Board of Trade.

The formation of the First Battalion, NewYork State Naval Militia, commonly known as the naval reserve, is well under way, and as soon as the National Naval Reserve bill is passed, and it is possible to supply it with...

BOSTON, Oct. 14.--Of course everybody who could possibly get within the doors was present at the new Tremont Theatre this evening. A first performance of this sort is doubly interesting, and even "society" betrays its growing love for the drama by an eager competition for seats.
The traveling scholarship announced last Spring by the American Architect was awarded recently to its first winner.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 14.--Acting Chairman of the Democratic State Committee John S. Barbour does not think the importation to this State of outside orators is either necessary or judicious.

One sits under the spell of an actor like Joseph Jefferson with something of regret. The man is no longer in the blush of youth, and we cannot avoid the sadly-prophetic feeling that he cannot be with us many years more.

The Executive Committee, composed of members of the various committees that have been at work on the World's Fair project and of the Sinking Fund Commissioners, met at the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon to organize and to dispose of current business.
The highest-priced picture of modern times, the "Angelus," by Jean Francois Millet, arrived in this city by the steamer La Bourgogne on Sunday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--A week of capital business is a pleasant thing to look back upon, and that privilege is enjoyed by most of the Chicago theatrical managers to-day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--A bill was filed in the Superior Court to-day to close up the affairs of the Treacy Carbon Lamp company. The company is alleged to be a tremendous swindle, and James A. Treacy, the President, is said to be a second Keely.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 14.--The overwhelming rejection of the proposed prohibitory amendment at the recent State election has had an unexpected effect in bringing some of the leading Prohibitionists to advocate high license as a restrictive measure.
The trial of Charles McElvaine for the murder of Grocer Christian W. Luca was begun yesterday in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Moore.

PINEVILLE, Ky., Oct. 14.--Scarcely have the camp fires left by the State troops in Harlan County died out before there is another outbreak, and two more sudden deaths are recorded of the Howard-Jennings feud.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 14.--The Cincinnatis gave the St. Louis Club's hard fight for to-day's game up to the sixth inning, when Mullance was touched up for a double and two siagles, which gave the visitors a couple of earned runs and a winning lead.

AUCKLAND, Oct 14.--Dispatches from Samoa say that a public meeting was held there for the election of a King. All the foreign representatives attended. Malietoa made an address, in which he praised Mataafa and advised the people to elect him their King. As for himself, he was content to be Vice King. It is understood that Germany will refuse to recognize Mataafa.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14.--The list of the scholarships awarded for work last year has been officially announced as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14.--A conference between representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Knights of Labor took place at the Girard House this afternoon.

When the Hon. Allan McDermott was asked if he approved of Jersey City's new charter and the manner in which it was secured--the city's representatives in the Legislature nearly all getting offices under it--he replied that he was in favor of almost anything that would give the city better government. What Mr. McDermott meant to imply was, plainly, that under the ring charter the city's affairs were better conducted than before.

"Observations on the Law Relating to Coroners" was the title of a paper read by Mr. Charles Kitchell before the Society of Medical Jurisprudence and State Medicine at its meeting at 12 West Thirty-first street, last evening, and it proved the text for a very interesting discussion.

Tammany Hall will hold its County Convention at the Wigwam this evening, to put in nomination candidates to be voted for on Nov. 5, as the successors of Register James J. Slevin, of President of the Board of Aldermen J.H.V. Arnold, who was elected to succeed the late...
President Wilson of the Board of Health said yesterday that the Health Department had full power to remove the electric light wires after they have been declared a nuisance dangerous to life.
Lewis Gamper, a machinist, who lived with his wife and child at 616 Park-avenue, Brooklyn, rose from his bed early yesterday morning...

READING, Penn., Oct. 14.--The Reading Iron Works, which failed six months ago, this afternoon mailed all its creditors, circulars offering them 4 per cent, mortgage bonds, guaranteed by the Reading Railroad Company, at the rate of 50 per cent. of their claim.

It is reported that Mr. CURTIS, the gentleman who, under the directions of Mr. BLAINE, is "presonally conducting" the All-American excursion, is very much annoyed at Mr. WIMAN'S little talk to the delegates on the evening of the 13th.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 14.--The Woodward faction of Republicans to-day nominated William B. Paige in the Second Albany District for Assembly. W.W. Thompson, in his speech making the nomination, said that the Woodward branch were the true Republicans, not bought with Federal patronage, not given to slate making, and were unsupported by subsidized newspapers.

HELENA, Montana, Oct. 14.--The Sheriff of Choteau County will sell to-morrow, under a chattel mortgage held by the New-York Loan and Trust Company, about 8,000 head of cattel and 450 horses, the property of the North Montana Cattle Company.

The trust stocks dominated yesterday's market. Cotton Oi1 shares ran down from 43 to 39, while Sugar Trusts went slumping from 82 to 76. There was scarcely anything like a rally in these "securities" at any time throughout the day till at the very close of business the former recovered about a point, leaving the Sugar Trust quotation at about its bottom figure.

Collector Erhardt went back to his post in the New-York Custom House to-day, leaving here on the limited express this afternoon. His talks with the officers of the Treasury Department have given him a better knowledge of the practical administration of customs matters and the scope of a Collector's duties, as well as a clearer insight into the wishes of the authorities concerning the administration of the NewYork Custom House.

The arguments in regard to the continuance of the injunctions which prevent the removal of such wires of certain electric light companies as may be found improperly insulated or in a dangerous condition were yesterday postponed until this morning on condition that those companies shut off theirs currents in the meantime.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 14.--William I. Tharn, a prominent member of the Dutchess County Bar, sued Col. O.T. Beard, now residing here, for $7,000 for services rendered in discussing and preparing for a suit against the executors of William Beard of Brooklyn.

Dr. Talmage did not leave his home on South Oxford-street, Brooklyn, yesterday. He was very busy all day receiving verbal expressions of sympathy from many friends in and out of his congregation, reading letters and telegrams, which came from everywhere, and thinking over plans for the future.

The pilot boat Jesse Carll, which went ashore near Zach's Inlet, L.I., on Saturday night and then drifted off, was picked up yesterday at sea by the Sandy Hock pilot boat Mary E. Williams, No. 19. A prize crew was put aboard and the boat is expected in port to-day. It is said the Carll has received no injury from her accident.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 14.--To-morrow the voice of Rhode Island's business interests will probably name Rhode Island's choice of a site for the World's Fair, and the State's delegation will be governed accordingly when Congress gets to work to make the selection.
RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 14.--Gen. Grubb, the Republican candidate for Governor of New-Jersey, addressed a mass meeting at Asbury Park to-night.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14.--At a meeting of Admiral Foote Post, G.A.R., on Saturday night, Quartermaster Dr. William H. Stowe was ordered to transfer the finances of the post to the Auditors. He turned over the accounts, but refused to surrender the bank books.

Henry Trisdorfer and Louis King, composing the firm of H. Trisdorfer Co., manufacturers of dress steels and springs at 56 Leonard-street, made an assignment yesterday to Edward A. Acker, giving a preference of $500.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 14.--The trotting races which were to have taken place here to-day have been postponed until Wednesday, when the regular programme will begin.

A special meeting of the Republican County Committee, presided over by John W. Jacobus, was held in the Grand Opera House hall last night to fix the date of the primaries to elect delegated to the various local conventions that must soon be held.

The big houses in the dry goods district suffered no little loss, and bore up under considerable inconvenience yesterday through the failure of some of the electric light companies to supply them with proper illumination. Mr. Booth and Mme. Modjeska, hand in hand, bowed many times in recognition of the cheers of an audience that crowded the big Broadway Theatre last night.
A correspondent writes from Constantinople to assure me that, so far from being of a corpulent habit, the Sultan is "as lean as a lath--a mere bad (a yellow bar) of bones." So be it!

Senator JOHN SHERMAN tells the people of Ohio that "Trusts and combinations have no connection with the tariff laws," and almost in the same breath declares that combinations which prevent free competition should be "broken down" by "reducing the duties" that enable them to exact a high ring price.
For months Wall-street has been much agitated over the pressing financial necessities of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa F6 Railroad Company.
William Menzies, a dentist, who was born in England and was sixty years old, died of alcoholism yesterday at 610 sixth-avenue.

WINCHESTER, Ky., Oct. 14.--Richard Clark of this city was sent to the poorhouse to-day. He is the son of James Clark, for many years one of the most famous jurists of the State, and who was Governor of this State at the time of his death.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14.--Gov. David B. Hill arrived in this city this morning in company with Representative Roswell P. Flower, E.L. Ridgway, Chancellor Henry R. Pierson...
An Associated Press dispatch from Fort Erie, Ontario, last night announces the arrest of Edward R. Lloyd for forgery on a telegram from Inspector Byrnes of this city.
The storm of yesterday extended over a large extent of territory, and at midnight had developed into a regular gale.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 14.--The championhip season closed here to-day, and Brooklyn had an easy victory which resulted solely from the errors of Marr at short. Terry pitched a wonderful game, as did also Baldwin until he became disgusted in the sixth and left the box. Easton pitched the remainder of the game.

It will not be the fault of the Jersey City Board of Street and Water Commissioners if John Fox's efforts to get a footing in that city as a waterpipe contractor miscarry. He has no contract yet, but he has delivered--and the Commissioners have accepted--about $1,800 worth of pipe within the past month.

The Democratic State campaign can now run smoothly along. The Young Men's Democratic club had a largely-attended meeting at the Hoffman House last night and voted to ratify the ticket made up at the Syracuse Convention.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, Oct. 14.--The fact that contignous Territories have adopted Constitutions and made ready to assume the responsibilities attaching to Statehood has made no difference in public opinion with the people of Idaho.

Mr. Wheeler, the Board of Electrical Control's expert, assisted by Experts Reilly and Fitzpatrick, with twelve or fifteen linemen, contined their work yesterday of "spotting" sections of overhead electric wires where the insulation was worn out or otherwise imperfect.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 14.--Capt. M.L. Phillips, commanding the revenue cutter Dexter, received a telegram from Keeper Church of the life-saving station at Point Judith yesterday that a schooner, apparently abandoned, was six miles southwest of the point, drifting to sea. Capt. Phillips immediately proceeded in the Dexter in search of her, and fell in with her at 4 P.M. four miles east by north from the Block Island south lighthouse.
I hear that the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh are not likely ever again to live in England for any long period, and that they will divide their time between Coburg and St. Petersburg.
The prospects for intercollegiate football in New-York have been greatly changed since the representatives of the colleges met and agreed upon a schedule of games.

The burning question of liturgical revision came to the front in the General Convention yesterday as soon as the business session was called to order by the Rev. Dr. Dix, following the recital of morning prayer by the Rev. Dr. C.W. Leffingwell of the diocese of Quincy.

The long wait between the fourth and fifth acts of "Samson" at its first performance was due to an accident, and the performance of Salvini at Palmer's now closes before 11 o'clock. Last night "Samson" was repeated to a crowded house, and it will be seen again Saturday night, which will be the only Saturday evening performance given by Salvini during his present engagement.

The members of the Board of Electrical Control are being made to work much harder these days than they have been used to. They are a pretty robust set of men, however, and the chances are that they will be physically able to stand the unusual strain.

The construction work on the big doubleturreted monitor Miantonomoh is being rapidly pushed. Just at present the work is confined mostly to the after turret, which is also further advanced toward completion than is the forward one.

GALLITZIN, Penn., Oct. 14.--Diphtheria in its worst form is playing have with the lives of the little ones in this place. During the past two weeks the average number of deathe was three to four per day, and the doctors report at least fifty cases down with the disease in the town. Four families with six or seven little ones such one train ago gow are childless.

A one-armed vagrant known as "Jim" was run over at Eleventh-avenue and Thirty-fourthstreet by Locomotive No. 81 of the Hudson river Railroad last evening and was killed. His body was shockingly mangled. The intersection of the avenue was so dark, owing to the electric lights on Thirty-fourth-street not being lighted, that the engineer of the locomotive failed to see the man crossing the street.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 14.--Emma Kalina, an eight-year-old girl, arrived in Rockville last week from Friedrichchof, Eastern Prussia, having made the entire journey without a guardian. She sailed in the North German Lloyd steamer Aller on Sept, 25, taking with her only a small sack containing clothing and food.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 14.--Cornelius Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, H. Walker Webb, President of the Wagner sleeping Car Company, and Charles F. Cox, a well-known Director of the "Big Four," reached here...

CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--A plot engineered by Alderman "Billy" Kent and Thomas Downey, Republican Committeemen from the Fifth and sixth Wards, respectively, to control the coming primaries for the Fall election, was accidentally exposed to-day.
For some months the depredations of chicken thieves have been the cause of great loss and annoyance to the residents on both sides of the Harlem River in the neighborhood of Washington Bridge.

A gentleman prominently connected with electric light interests in this city said yesterday: "Notwithstanding the fact that there is more or less justice in the public clamor which is now being made against the electric-light companies in this city, it should not be forgotten that the companies have some rights and are entitled to some sympathy.
MONTREAL, Oct, 14.--Two years ago great interest was excited by the project of a railroad from Winnipeg to Hudson's Bay, which was to connect with a line of steamers to Europe.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Oct. 14.--A severe storm is raging here, attended by some serious disaster, as the body of a man has been washed ashore on the south side of the island.

BOSTON, Oct. 14.--The quiet little town of Concord is greatly stirred up over the discovery of a dastardly attempt on Saturday night to rob the last resting place of its noted dead, the grave of Ralph Waldo Emerson.

The police are looking for three young incorrigibles named Annie Foley, aged 19; Henrietta Wood, aged 18, and Mary A. Byrnes, aged 17, who made their escape one evening last week from the House of the Good Shepherd, at the foot of East Ninetieth-street.

The Baptist pastors held their usual Monday conference at the Twenty-third-Street Baptist Church, and listened to a plea "For a More Scientific Treatment of the Subject of Sermonic Illustration," by the Rev. W.C. Bitting, pastor of the Mount Morris Baptist Church.

The growth of athletics in this country during the past generation is an astonishing phenomenon. Except prize fighting, which then, as now, is carried on by gentlemen of Irish birth or extraction, and which has undoubtedly retrograded, every form of physical exercise that is susceptible of public exhibition has increased beyond all expectation.

The Sixth-avenue elevated railway is just now subjected to a danger which makes it seem singular that the officers of the line should permit the running of crowded five-car trains over the dangerous place.

The coal barg Robena, from Philadelphia, which caused so much delay on the Eastern Division of the Boston and Maine Railroad Saturday and Sunday by getting stuck in the mud at the Prison Point drawbridge, Boston, was extricated yesterday after being lightered of a large quantity of coal. The leak was found and stopped and the yessel was towed to the coal wharf.

Albert J. Markle, fifty-six years of age, of 63 East Eighty-sixth-street, was arraigned before Justice White, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday morning, charged with breaking into the house of the Rev. C.B. Smyth, at 61 East...

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 14.--The British steamship River Mersey, from Coosaw to Europe, which put into this port on the 10th inst. for bunker coal and sailed on Saturday for her destination, has put back.

New-Yorkers who had occasion to go out doors last night missed the brilliancy of the are lights, and those who had not heard of the determination of the Brush and United States Companies to shut off their currents wondered at the gloomy transformation.

The East River Electric Light Company yesterday received a set-back in the Superior Court by a decision handed down by Judge Ingraham. The company had wires, strung under authority of a permit from the Board of Electrical Control, on poles along Sixth-avenue, between Carmine and Eighteenth streets.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 14.--The examination by the United States local inspectors of steamboats into the cause of the Corona disaster was resumed to-day. James W. Handley testified that he was chief engineer of the Corona and took charge of the watch not more than two minutes previous to the explosion.

Judge George M. Van Hoesen of the Court of Common Pleas, whose term of office expires with the current year, is a candidate for renomination and, unless the politicians can be convinced of his unfitness for the bench, will...
At 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon Judge Andrews was to have heard the arguments for an against the continuance of the injunction he granted against the Mayor on Saturday.

The October meeting of the Congregational club of New-York and vicinity was held last night at 22 West Twenty-third-street. For the first time since his election as the club's president, succeeding Mr. Roswell Smith, Dr. L.C. Warner occupied the chair.

Alfred Heritage, the owner of a bakery in Summit-avenue, on Jersey City Heights, is in a heap of domestic trouble. His young and pretty wife had been his consistent helper till she became acquainted with Frank Doel, who lived around the corner.

B.F. Waterman, a son of Police Surgeon Waterman, appeared before Justice White in the Harlem Police Court yesterday and charged his mother-in-law, Mrs. Lorena D. Carpenter, who had resided in his family at 14 East One...
The few people who attended the races at Jerome Park yesterday were treated to seven races, instead of the six announced, because of one of the most ridiculous starts ever made on a race track.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 14.--At this morning's session of the General Council of the Lutheran Church, a committee was appointed to investigate and report on the feasibility of establishing a seminary in Chicago.

The wedding present of the Greek merchants in London to the Duke of Sparta sad Princess Sophia of Prussia consists of a superb dessert service of solid gold, inclosed in a rose wood cabinet, with brass mountings, and lined with blue velvet. It is accompanied by a similar cabinet, containing a set of gold spoons and forks to match the service.

The Hamburg American steamships Gellert and Italic, which were reported by the Scale as on their way to this port, the Italia, in tow of the Gellert, arrived early yesterday forenoon. They had performed a remarkably difficult feat in very good time.

Delmonico's big ballroom was a blaze of light last night, while the American and British flags were festooned on the mirrors which surround it. An imposing edifice, with three terraces, which extended the width of the room, was laden with all sorts of good things, and over...
After a very stormy voyage the Aurania arrived from Liverpool yesterday afternoon. She had met with severe northwesterly gales nearly all the way over.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 14.--A burglar last night made two attempts to enter the residence of Bernard and George O'Neill, on Jerseystreet. On the first attempt he was grappled with by Joseph Shafto, a clerk for the O'Neills, who seized the thief in the hallway. Both men struggled to the door and rolled down the stoop, the thief managing to break loose and escape.

George P. Maris, once of 1,023 Cathedralstreet, Baltimore, and private secretary of the President of the Merchants and Miners' Transportation Company, was found dead early yesterday morning at the Puritan House, 183 Bowery.

The bids for the paving of Madison-avenue between Thirty-second and Thirty-third streets, Thirty-sixth and Forty-first streets, Forty-second and Forty-eighth streets, and Fifty-eighthstreet between Madison and Fifth avenues were opened yesterday by Commissioner Gilroy.

BERLIN, Oct. 14.--The Czar has presented Prince Bismarck with a valuable snuff box, on the lid of which is a portrait of his Majesty. A similar present was given to Count Herbert Bismarck by the Czar.

PARIS, Oct. 14.--A council of war, at which Minister de Freycinet presided, was held here to-day to discuss the increase of the German frontier corps. It was decided to double the Sixth Army Corps in order that 100,000 men may be sent quickly to the frontier in case of an emergency. The council also resolved to increase Eastern railway facilities.
AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 14.--The Republican Senatorial Convention of the Twenty-sixth District will reassemble in this city to-morrow.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 14.--This morning's business at the Congregational Council was of a routine nature. A resolution asking Congress to increase the number of army and navy Chaplains was adopted.

MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 14.--An unusual political condition is developing in Franklin County this Fall; that is, unusual for this county of Republican steadfastness and freedom from dissension and factional strife.
The Jersey City fire engines went tearing down Montgomery-street yesterday afternoon in answer to an alarm from the Pennsylvania Railroad Station.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 14.--Axtell did not start for the three-year-old stake race at the Kentucky Breeders' meeting this afternoon, and what was expected to be a sensational race fell flat in consequence. The track was heavy and slow and Nancy Hanks won in straight heats in 2:26 , 2:25 , and 2:26 . Bonnie Wilmoor and Campbell's Electioneer alone trotted against her.

It falls to the lot of few coachmen to die worth between 9,000 and 10,000, as has happened in the case of the late Mr. Henry Charles Westover, who occupied that position in the Prince of Wales's household.
George B. McClellan, son of the late Gen. McClellan, was yesterday appointed Treasurer and Auditor of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge at an annual salary of $4,000. The place is no sinecure.

The railway companies controlled by the Missouri Pacific were chartered at Topeka, Kan., on Saturday. They are the Fort Scott Terminal, the Fort Scott and Southern, and the Fort Scott and Western. The City Council has granted the roads franchises and rights of way, and the work of construction was begun yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15.--To-day the Carmelite Sisters celebrate the feast of their patron Saint Teresa. Through her influence the old order of the Carmelites was entirely remodeled. Sixteen monasteries and fourteen convents are said to have been established by her efforts. She was canonized by Gregory XV. in 1662. At the Carmelite convent this morning a grand high mass was celebrated, at which Cardinal Gibbons and eleven priests were present.

The anti-ring Democratic County Convention for Hudson County, N.J., will meet in Crane's Hall, Hoboken, at 3 o'clock to-morrow afternoon to nominate county officers. The Republican County Convention will meet in Odd Fellows Hall, Hoboken, at the same hour.
In the House of Bishops yesterday the resignations of Bishop Bedell of Ohio and Bishop Williams of Japan were received. Action on their acceptance was deferred.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15.--The worst accident that ever occurred on the inclined-plane railways of this city happened to-day between 12 and 1 o'clock on the Mount Auburn inclined plane, which starts at the head of Main-street and rises to a height of between 250 and 300 feet in a space of perhaps 2,000 feet or less.

At a conference held late yesterday afternoon it was finally decided to nominate Col. Andrew D. Baird for Mayor of Brooklyn on the Republican ticket. No assurance was given that he would accept, but an authoritative statement was made that he would give the matter still further consideration.
By direction of Judge Andrews, sitting in Supreme Court, Chambers, judgment was entered by default yesterday against Upton L. Boyce, the Southern railroad operator, for $320,000 ...

WACO, Texas, Oct. 15.--Lessing, Solomon Rosenthal, wholesale and retail dealers in dry goods, importers, and cotton buyers, to-day transferred their entire wholesale business and all their real estate and business houses to H.B. Claflin Co. of New-York in consideration of $350,500.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 15.--The State convention of New-Jersey Republican clubs was held here to-day at the Temple Opera House. Over five hundred delegates were present. Gen. Grubb arrived early and was driven to the Sheridan House, where he was subjected to an ...

The search for a jury to try Charles McElvaine for the murder of Grocer Luca was continued yesterday in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, and resulted in exhausting the panel without filling the jury box.

With a due amount of enthusiasm and many proud declarations of an abiding belief in success, the big chiefs, the little chiefs, and the plain, ordinary warriors of Tammany nominated a ticket last night at their County Convention in Tammany Hall. Yet it was not a Tammany ticket, one speaker proudly proclaimed, but it was "a citizens' ticket."

The schooner Laura of this city finishes taking on a deck cargo of 100 tons of scrap iron at the Corlears-street dock and started out into the East River with a crew of five men at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning, bound up the Sound.

DOTHEN, Ala., Oct. 15.--In a difficulty here yesterday seven men were shot. Two are dead and another dying. The trouble arose between the Town Council and the draymen of the Farmers' Warehouse, the latter refusing to pay ...

We regard it as a good sign that Mr. CABOT LODGE should have felt disposed, and even required, to answer the criticism of the course of the Administration as to civil service reform which was made by Mr. GEORGE WILLIAM CURTIS at Philadelphia.

Thomas Carey, who kept a hotel and liquor saloon in Portland, Conn., died at Roosevelt Hospital early yesterday morning from a fracture of the skull. How he received the fatal injury has not yet been determined.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 15.--Gen. Mahone and Senator Riddleberger are both here to-night. While bitterly opposing each other in this campaign they have not ceased to speak as they "pass by."

CHICAGO, Oct. 15.--The investigation into the methods of the jury bribers is temporarily at a standstill to-day. The efforts of the State are not directed toward finding out the leader of the conspiracy.
A report was made by Supervisor W.J. Kenny of the City Record yesterday respecting the condition of the appropriation for "printing, stationery, and blankbooks" for the current year.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 15.--The train bearing Gov. Hill and party of New-York was delayed so as to be thrown into Atlanta a little before midnight. Gov. Hill had telegraphed ahead asking that the arrangements for his reception to-night should be abandoned, ...
Several building contractors are to be disciplined to-day by the Operative Plasterers' Union unless they yield to the demands of the union.

The fortune of baseball has smiled on NewYork and vicinity this season. A week ago the Giants came home winners of the League penpant, and yesterday Col. Byrne and his band of Brooklyn players returned to their native heath winners of the championship honors of the American Association.

BERLIN, Oct. 15.--The Czar, Grand Duke Vladimir, and Grand Duke George took part in the hunt on the estate of the Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin at Ludwigslust this morning. A number of red deer were shot by the imperial visitors.
At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen Alderman Divver offered a resolution, which was unanimously passed, that referred to the recent deaths caused by electric light wires, and continued:

READING, Penn., Oct. 15.--The Reading Gun Club opened its first annual tournament at Ben Fleishman's Fair Grounds to-day. The grounds are within easy distance from the city, but few shooters were on hand in the morning, as the sky was overcast and threatened rain.

HELENA, Montana, Oct. 15.--While excitement runs high over the Republican attempt to capture the Legislature by unseating members in Silver Bow County, there has been no outbreak of any sort. The Democrats are confident that the courts will sustain their view that the County Canvassing Board had no right to throw out any duly certified returns.

A large and aristocratic assemblage gathered at the Church of the Redeemer, at Morristown, N.J., last evening, the occasion being the marriage of Jennette, the only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Cutler of Morristown, to Mr. James Breckinridge Curtis or Indianapolis, Ind.

The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage received many letters of sympathy yesterday, and, what was more valuable, several big subscriptions for a new church. Warren G. Smith sent $500, T. New $250, F. Loeser Co., $250, J.J. Heins $50, and James Cassiday $25. The total is now $2,064.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 15.--An epidemic of whooping cough prevails in this community, and almost every other child is afflicted with the disease. On Saturday night the Board of Health held a special meeting to determine whether or not it would be advisable to close ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Coupon 4s, $1,000 and $500 at 127; registered 4s, $100,000, $500, $2,400, $2,050, $1,950, and $30,000 at 127; registered 4 s, $10,000, $500, $50,000, and $2,600 at 105 ; coupon 4 s, $30,000 and $500 at 105 .

Lew Dockstader will present his new burlesque, "She-and-Dora," at his theatre tonight. The burlesque is said to resemble closely the original in scenery and costumes, but there all semblance to Bronson Howard's war drama ceases. The cast of "She-and-Dora" includes George Marion, Luke Schoolcraft, Barry Maxwell, and all the comedians of Dockstader's organization.

Among the recent decrees handed down by the Court of Appeals is one in a hotly-contested divorce case, that of Delia M. Moller, daughter of a clergyman, of this city, against her husband, Frank C. Moller. The trial in the Special Term of the Supreme Court of this county resulted in a decree of divorce, rendered Dec. 6, 1886.

The liveliest primaries for the election of delegates to the local nominating conventions in which Brooklyn Republicans have participated for many years were held last night in every ward in that city.

Health Commissioners Wilson and Bryant, Health Officer Smith, Sanitary Superintendent Ewing, Col. W.P. Prentice, counsel to the board, and Dr. Cyrus Edson and Inspector Martin discussed high-power wires and the jurisdiction ...

The Trustees of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, in Hudson-street, decided last year to move up town. They selected a site for a new building at One Hundred and Forty-first-street and Convent-avenue, and began negotiations with the Trinity Church corporation for the sale of the Hudson-street property.
LONDON, Oct. 15.--Advices from Brisbane, Queensland, state that Sir William Macgregor, Administrator of New-Guinea, accompanied by a party of twenty-two men, recently landed on the island of Demara.

The Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club, the most disastrous in its history, ended yesterday with a regular Waterloo for the backers of favorites. Eric, Eolian, Charley Dreux, the Cyclone colt, Fitz James, and Prodigal, who were backed almost "off the boards," all finished second to rank outsiders.

The plain little tin box which was nailed on the telegraph pole at the corner of Chambers and Centre streets directly after the tragic death of Lineman John E.H. Feeks among the interlacing wires overhead was again an object of general interest yesterday.
It is a misdemeanor now to bet on the races in the State of New-York. The law under which betting may be done on race tracks fixes Oct. 15 as the last day in the year for that sort of speculation.

Ex-Congressman Steele of Indiana met with a serious accident Monday. He and his wife were riding in a carriage, behind spirited horses when a fore wheel came off, dropping the front part of the carriage down on the horses' heels. In the smash-up that followed, Major Steele had his left rrm broken, and Mrs. Steele had her left arm broken.

A field day was had yesterday in the Episcopal General Convention on the subject of liturgical revision. Following the reading of the morning prayer by the Rev. Robert S. Barrett of Georgia the House of Deputies passed a vote of thanks to Mr. William W. Astor for faithful services as Treasurer of the General Convention, agreed ...

The Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee held a meeting at the Hoffman House last evening, and were much encouraged by the announcement of Chairman Griffin that Mr. Cleveland had sent word that he was willing to lend his assistance to the good of the State ticket.
The legal battle over the dangers of overhead electric lighting wires was opened yesterday. The progress made indicates that it will continue all of to-day and perhaps longer.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 15.--The representatives of all the Americas were aroused this morning in Buffalo at 6 o'clock, and at 8 o'clock the Congressional excursion train was rolling along the Lake Shore Road.

PIERRE, South Dakota, Oct. 15.--A train of fifteen coaches, in two sections, containing 1,200 persons, came in last night, and every sleeping place, lunch house, and hotel was crowded to its utmost capacity. Residents' doors were thrown open to the crowd, and every effort was made to accommodate the largest assemblage of people ever brought together in Dakota. The streets are jammed with people, and politics, real estate, speculation, and building are everywhere running riot.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15.--Drafts--Sight, 15; telegraphic, 22 .
The Harlem Democratic Club will hold a regular meeting to-night at its house, 13, 15, and 17 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street. Ballot reform will be the principal topic of discussion.

Whatever have been the historic associations of the Broadway Tabernacle, that church was additionally dignified yesterday by the assembling of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions for the first time in this city since 1832.

The first annual convention of the New-York State League of Democratic Clubs will meet in the banquet hall of the Hoffman House on the 22d inst., and will be called to order by the Hon. John Boyd Thacher, President of the league.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Oct. 15.--About two hundred of the delegates to the annual State Convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union arrived to-day, and about one hundred more are expected to-morrow morning, when the business sessions of the convention will begin.

The Court of Appeals has affirmed an important principle in sustaining the validity of the law regulating the charges for elevating grain. It is, in substance, the principle declared years ago by the Supreme Court of the United States in certain Western cases arising under what is known as the "Granger legislation" in Illinois.

This is the second day for the registration of votes in this city. The places of registration will be open from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. You cannot vote unless registered. Even if you care nothing for the State contest, there is a prospect of a local one which should interest every citizen.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 15.--A deep shadow has fallen upon the friendship which prevailed between Judge Van Valen and Prosecutor Campbell, the bosses of the Democratic Party in Bergen County, N.J., on the one hand, and Sheriff Tunis C. Herring of the same county.
ALBANY, Oct. 15.--The State Railroad Commission to-day began its inquiry into the fatal collision between two sections of the night express near Yosts Sept. 27.

ROME, Oct. 15.--A banquet was given to Prime Minister Crispi at Palermo last night. Forty-nine Senators and 140 members of the Chamber of Deputies were present. Signor Crispi delivered an address, in which he declared that it was necessary to combat all persons, high or low, who were seeking to undermine the political edifice of Italy.

The meeting of the World's Fair Committee on Site and Buildings in THE TIMES Building yesterday afternoon was an informal one, so far as the record of it is concerned, but it is understood that some important steps were taken to push along the work. By general consent the meeting was held with closed doors.

If a citizens' ticket should be nominated as a means of curbing the power of Tammany Hall it can receive no support in the ballot boxes except from registered voters. To-day is the second day for registration, between the hours of 8 A.M. and 9 P.M. Delay on the part of citizens may be fatal to the most worthy candidates.

Again last night did the city seem to have gone into mourning for its lost brilliancy. Darkness and gloom were everywhere on Manhattan Island from Central Park to the end at the Battery, except in little isolated spots in some up-town thoroughfares, where groups of flaring gas jets tried in a feeble way to imitate the lustre of the electric lights that were gone.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The State Convention of French-American citizens met in this city today. Nearly one hundred delegates from all parts of the State were present.

The Hon. Allan L. McDermott has written an open letter to the Hon. John W. Griggs, late State Senator from Passaic County, N.J., in answer to Mr. Griggs's speech on railroad taxation delivered in Trenton, Oct. 9.

John H. Starin, Jr., died on Monday at his residence, 35 East Ninth-street, of lingering consumption. He had not been in active life for nearly ten years, and during almost that whole period had been confined to his room.
HASTINGS, Neb., Oct. 15.--The Republican Congressional Convention has nominated Secretary of State G.L. Laws to succeed the late Congressman Laird.
The New-Jersey Supreme Court yesterday declared the act reorganizing the Boards of Freeholders in Hudson and Essex Counties to be constitutional and effective.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The Republicans of the Second District of Rensselaer to-day nominated Assemblyman Joseph S. Saunders for a second term. There was open opposition to his nomination from the town of Hoosick, where the labor element is strong and where Saunders is weak.

Passers-by on Park-row yesterday afternoon gathered in large numbers and watched with no little interest the proceeding of a gang of linemen at work on the wires running along the sections from its junction with Broadway. Linemen were hurrying about with spurred boots, darting up poles, clipping wires, binding insulations, and running in new wires.

A prominent member of the New-York Produce Exchange, and one of the largest grain shippers in this city, who has taken an active interest in the trade's opposition to the McEvoy Elevator bill, said last evening:
LISBON, Oct. 15.--It is officially announced that the condition of the King is critical. The last sacrament has been administered. The whole of the body is paralyzed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15.--At the convention of the Democratic societies of the State held here to-day ex-Gov. Chauncey F. Black, the President, in his opening address, declared that the Democratic Party must consistently continue the struggle for tariff reform.

On the fifth floor of a six-story tenement house, at 42 Oliver-street, lived John O'Brien, a longshoreman, with his wife Lizzie, thirtytwo years old, and Katie, their thirteen months' child. Yesterday Lizzie wanted to go with the child to a funeral.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Acting Superintendent Hall of the Banking Department is busily engaged examining into the status of the Western mortgage companies having branches and doing business in this State.

ALBANY, Oct. 15.--Attorney General Tabor was served with an order to-day, granted by Justice Mayham of the Supreme Court, now sitting here, which gives Contractor John Snaith twenty days' additional time in which to file his ...

Spurred on by Mayor Grant's energetic desire to act in the matter of preventing dangerous accidents from electric wires overhead, the three other members of the Board of Electrical Control continued their unwontedly arduous labors yesterday. They met in the Mayor's office at 11 o'clock and left it a little before 2.

RONDOUT, N. Y., Oct. 15.--Boatmen say that the high wind of last night and this morning was the severest experienced this year. It was so rough on the Hudson River that navigation was practically at a standstill.

No vote will be received at the election next month unless secured by registration. This is the second day for registering, between 8 A.M. and 9 P.M. The issues ought to interest every good citizen. They promise to be exciting and important in this city. The right to vote should be secured to-day.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The Republican Senatorial Convention, held here this afternoon, for nominating a candidate in the Thirteenth District, was well attended, but notably lacking in life and enthusiasm. B.B. Odell, Jr., of Newburg, late defeated candidate for Senator, presided.

The New-York Jockey Club's Fall meeting closed yesterday afternoon, the usual six races being run, most of them with startling results in the success of the outsiders. But that was natural on "getaway day."
The will of Mrs. Mary I. Havemeyer, widow of Henry Havemeyer, was filed in the Surrogate's Court yesterday.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Three social organizations were incorporated to-day with headquarters in New-York City. The West End Club is to promote intercourse among members and provide a clubhouse.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct 15.--In the case of The People against J. Tallman Budd a decision was handed down this morning by the Court of Appeals affirming the judgment. Judge Andrews wrote the opinion, which was concurred in by Judges Ruger, Earl, Danforth, and Finch. The decision says:

ALBANY, Oct. 15.--Secretary of the State Board of Health Balch left for Westchester County to-day to spur up the local Board of Health relative to the removal of nuisances from the Croton reservoir water shed. The complaint comes from Commissioner Gilroy, and Secretary Balch will insist on the local board of Westchester County putting the matter through by expelling all nuisances.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 15.--The adjourned meeting of representatives of business interests, presided over by Gov. Ladd, to-day decided by a vote of 26 to 22 that Rhode Island would favor New-York as the place for holding the World's Fair.

This is the day to register. It may be done between 8 A.M. and 9 P.M. Only one more chance will be given after to-day. A Judge of the Court of Appeals and State officers are to be elected at the coming election, and the local contest promises to be important. No one can vote unless registered.

The question of Gen. James C. Duane's eligibility to hold the office of President of the Board of Aqueduct Commissioners was argued yesterday before the General Term of the Supreme Court, which reserved its decision.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15.--The Sophomore Class organized a hare-and-hounds club to-day, and elected J.M. Brennan of Kentucky President, W.L. Mudge of New-Jersey Secretary, and J.G. Wilson of Maryland Treasurer. The main object of this club is to develop long-distance runners who will compete in the intercollegiate games.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15.--The Right Rev. Mgr. O'Connell, President of the American College at Rome, arrived in Baltimore this afternoon, and is staying at the archiepiscopal residence in North Charles-street, the guest of Cardinal Gibbons.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 15.--W.B. Neeves, a real estate dealer of this city, was to-day notified that a package awaited him at the Post Office. There he found a parcel 5 inches square and 8 inches high, wrapped in paper and securely fastened.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 15.--Inquiries recently addressed by the Legislative Committee of the State Labor Association to Gen. E. Burd Grubb and ex-Gov. Leon Abbett, the candidates for Governor, have elicited replies which the committee now publish.

The Democrats of the Twelfth Senatorial District, comprising the counties of Westchester and Rockland, met in convention in Music Hall, Tarrytown, yesterday for the purpose of nominating a candidate for member of the next State Senate. Michael J. Dillon of New-Rochelle was chosen Chairman. There were twenty delegates, fifteen from Westchester and five from Rockland.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The Presbyterian Synod met in this city, in the Presbyterian church, this evening. It is a delegated body, and covers the New-England States and the State of New-York.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 16.--Ex-President Andrew D. White has arrived in Ithaca after his extended European tour, and yesterday delivered an introductory lecture in the course on the French Revolution.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16.--The strike of the bakers became general to-day and eight more shops turned out. A driver for Mangles Schmidt, proprietors of the largest bakery here, dumped two loads of dough into the Passaic River this morning. Five hundred men are now out on strike and a boycott has been organized against the boss bakers. Pickets are keeping New-York men from going to work and persuading them to return to their homes.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16.--About sixty delegates responded to their names this morning when the eighth annual convention of the American Forestry Congress and the fourth annual convention of the Pennsylvania Forestry Association was called together at Horticultural Hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--The hearing in the cases of the Independent Refiners' Associations of Oil City and Titusville, Penn., against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company was resumed before the Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 16.--The twenty-sixth annual convention of locomotive engineers was called to order in the Tabor Grand Opera House this afternoon by Secretary W.W. Hall of the local Committee on Arrangements.

Mr. Fred Gebhard has gotten himself in print again. It is charged against him that he has violated one of the rules of the Manhattan Club, of which he is a member, and that in doing so he was ably assisted by a gentleman who had previously been looking upon the wine when it was red.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 16.--The Women's Synodical Society of Home and Foreign Missions met in the First Presbyterian Church here to-day. At the morning session various phases of mission work were discussed, and addresses on home missions were delivered by the Rev. Dr. Bootles of Englewood and by missionary teachers from Utah. The afternoon was devoted to the discussion of foreign mission work, and an address was delivered by Mrs. Andrews, a missionary from India.

LONDON, Oct. 16.--An explosion occurred in the Bentilee Colliery at Longton, county of Stafford, at an early hour this morning. Seventy miners were in the pit at the time of the accident, only eleven of whom are alive. The pit was completely wrecked, and the task of recovering the buried miners will be one of great difficulty.

If a stranger could have been suspended over Manhattan Island last night he would have said that New-York was fifteen years behind the times, because she still used gas for street lighting instead of electricity.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 16.--Four local tours for sight-seeing had been laid out for to-day, and Cleveland hospitality had proposed that each of the all-America excursionists should select such as should most challenge his interest. Between 10 and 11 o'clock the visitors embarked in carriages, and in varying directions went to inspect Cleveland's business interests.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 16.--A terrible wreck occurred on the Burlington and Missouri Railroad at Gibson, a few miles from Omaha, at 6:45 last evening. About fifty passengers were injured.

LONDON, Oct. 16.--The steamer Malta, belonging to the Cunard Steamship Company, with eighteen passengers bound on a pleasure trip to Italy, went ashore at St. Just, near Land's End, during a fog. The vessel is a total wreck. All on board landed safely except one of the stokers, who was drowned. The Malta was a brig-rigged iron screw steamer of 2,132 tons. She was built at Glasgow in 1865.

The house which Capt. John Ericsson owned, and in which he lived, at 36 Beach-street, between Hudson and Varrick streets, was sold at auction yesterday at the Real Estate Exchange to H. McArdle for $18,900, by the executor of the Ericsson estate. As the house is of small value, the chances are that it will soon be torn down and replaced by a business structure.

Charles Putzel, as attorney for Uhle, Von Wagner co., hosiery and glove manufacturers, of Chemnitz, Saxony, has begun a suit for $20,000 in the New-York Supreme Court against Burnham, Hanna, Munger Co., of Detroit and Kansas City, alleging conspiracy between the latter firm and Arbib Co., selling agents of the Saxony house.

The centennial celebration of last May was an event really memorable in the annals of New-York. The inauguration of WASHINGTON as the first President of the United States was an occasion eminently worthy of celebration, and it was worthily celebrated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--Pension Commissioner Tanner was asked this afternoon whether he had anything to say respecting the recent decision of Assistant Secretary Bussey, overruling the Commissioner's order of April 25 last. He said:

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 16.--It is understood that the entire plant of the Brush Electric company has been sold to the Thomson-Houston Electric Company on a cash basis, the consideration being about $3,250,000.
The recommendation for the appointment of W.L. Bostwick as cashier of the Custom House at a salary of $5,000 went on to Washington yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--The Secretary of the Interior in a decision rendered to-day directs the Commissioner of the General Land Office to correct certain errors made in the adjustment of the land grant to the State of Wisconsin for the benefit of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railroad Company.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 16.--Gov. David B. Hill's presence in Atlanta to-day filled the city to an unprecedented extent. In the matter of the revision of the Prayer Book the House of Deputies yesterday agreed to disagree with the House of Bishops on eight propositions out of eleven which the upper house of the General Convention had adopted. The report of the Committee on Liturgical Revision is now the chief topic of interest before the convention, and until it is finally disposed of all other topics are of minor importance.

A fatal shooting affair, which has some elements of mystery about it, occurred last evening in the office of Herbert Muxlow, a wealthy expressman, at 1,287 Third-avenue.

Collector Erhardt has appointed an inspecting physician to examine Custom House employes who are obliged to be absent from duty on account of sickness.

Samuel Guggenheimer, a butcher, living at 293 Seventh-avenue, is a patient at the NewYork Hospital, suffering from a fracture of two of his ribs, the result of violence inflicted upon him by a policeman. Patrolman Matthew McConnell of the Nineteenth Precinct is charged with having brutally beaten him.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 16.--N.K. Masten, for merly Cashier of the Nevada Bank of San Francisco and a resident of the coast for sixty years, predicts the longest and coldest Winter the Pacific coast has ever experienced.
CITY OF MEXICO Oct. 16, via Galveston, Texas. --Experiments are to be made in coffee planting in the frontier States on the Rio Grande.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16.--John Maynard Harlan, a son of Justice Harlan of the United States Supreme Court, filed a petition in the Probate Court to-day for letters of administration on the estate of the late Stanley Matthews, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
While arrangements were being made for the world's series yesterday it leaked out that Brooklyn will lose the services of its present manager as soon as the season ends.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16.--The fifth annual meeting of the Commandery in Chief of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States was held to-day in the hall of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.

Yesterday and the day before were busy days for the managers of the regular line insurance companies. The Fall meeting of the National Board of Underwriters, embracing the chief executive officers of some seventy companies, brought together a large attendance on Tuesday.

COEYMANS, Oct. 16.--Acton Civill, whose body will be interred in this village, held the place of his birth in fond remembrance. More than ten years ago he built a large academy on a spacious plot of ground in the western part of the village.

The Committee on Erection of the Memorial Arch at Washington-square hope to have the fund complete in season to begin work on the structure in the coming Spring and to have it completed on April 30, 1891, which will be two years from the date the centennial procession passed under the temporary arch.

The failure of Lessing, Solomon Rosenthal, wholesale and retail dealers in dry goods and shoes at Waco, Texas, was a great surprise to the trade in this city. The greater portion of their dry goods stock was bought in this city, the shoe stock being purchased in Boston.

Most of the passengers on the steamer City of Rome which sailed for Liverpool yesterday were members of Barnum Bailey's Circus, who are going to London, where they are to perform in the Olympia, Kensington.

The persistence with which Messrs. Hess, Moss, and Gibbens of the Board of Electrical Control have championed their monopolistic subway company has led to inquiry as to the motive or motives prompting such conduct. One result of the inquiry has been exceedingly significant.

READING, Penn., Oct. 16.--The banded tramp outlaws who have made themselves a terror to this section of country for a month past are becoming even bolder than they have been hitherto, and last evening they invaded the southern suburbs of this city.
There is something in the relations between the Board of Electrical Control and the Consolidated Telegraph and Subway Company that ought to be brought to the light of day.
SIOUX FALLS, South Dakota, Oct. 16.--There is great danger that the famine among farmers of Central Dakota last Winter will repeat itself this year.

READING, Penn., Oct. 16.--Another day of the Reading Gun Club shoot has passed. H. McMurchy of Syracuse, N.Y., and W.F. Quimby and M.F. Lindsley of New-York City made their appearance to-day, and, as the scores will show, were up among the winners, as usual.

Westchester Democrats held their county convention yesterday in Lafayette Hall, White Plains. The convention was called to order by William J. Graney, Chairman of the County Committee, and then a motion was made to proceed with the temporary organization.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 16.--Gen. A.B. Campbell of Kansas, one of the prominent candidates for the Pension Commissionership, has been tendered the position of Consul at Melbourne, Australia. Mr. Campbell will accept.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 16.--During the blow on Sunday the schooners Quilp and Nannie of this port put into Cuttyhunk Harbor for anchorage. On Monday, during the heavy blow, the vessels drifted together and the crew of the Nannie took to the larger vessel.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-third District, after seven days' balloting for a candidate, adjourned to-night until to-morrow morning, with the situation unchanged and the dead-lock unbroken. Thus far 665 ballots have been taken.

MONTREAL, Oct. 16.--The students of Victoria Medical School are still in opposition to amalgamation with Laval. The Church has taken the matter in hand. Archbishop Fabre has sent the following letter to the Rev. Mothers Superior of the Hotel Dieu and the Catholic Maternity Hospitals:

At 1 o'clock this morning two gentlemen drove to Police Headquarters and were closeted for half an hour, in the Detective Bureau. It was learned that their daughters had left home yesterday morning to attend a music school kept by a professor on Twenty-third-street and had not been heard of since. One of the men was said to be a member of the Consolidated Exchange. Both were evidently wealthy men.

Secretary of the Navy Tracy appeared yesterday as a defendant before Chief Justice Sedgwick of the Superior Court in a suit brought against him and Collis P. Huntington by Lewis Sanders, a lawyer, for $5,000 for professional services claimed to have been rendered.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 16.--The annual reports of the railroad companies operating lines in this State have been received by the Railroad Commissioners. Two of them, representing the Consolidated and Housatonic systems, require changes to be made on account of technical errors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--The genial "Joe" Cannon of Illinois is in town to do a little work toward helping along his chances for the Speakership of the Fifty-first Congress. LONDON, Oct. 16.--An objection has been lodged against awarding the Cesarewitch Stakes, which was run on the 10th inst., to Primrose Day, who ran first, on the ground that the filly was not the property of W. Goater, in whose name she was entered for the race.

SANTA ANA, Cal., Oct. 16.--This morning Mrs. Effie I. Scholl was found in her house at Tustin with a frightful cut on her throat and near her were her two children, a boy of five years and a girl of three years, also with their throats cut. She had murdered her children and attempted to kill herself. It is believed that she will recover. A dull caseknife was used.

The Atlantic Association held a meeting in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. There were present Messrs. Burdock and Munson, representing the New-Haven Club; Sullivan of Lowell, Lang of Hartford, Trott and Shoemaker of Newark, and Burnham of Worcester.

The audience at the Lyceum Theatre on Tuesday night had a sensation of the most tragic character in the death of the comedian Charles B. Bishop. MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The people of Montrose, the county seat of Susquehanna County, Penn., have been for some years canvassing plans and making surveys for a projected railroad outlet northward or eastward to Binghamton, N.Y., or to some nearer point on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16.--Another cane rush between the Sophomores and Freshmen occurred here last night, and again the Sophomores were victorious. The rush took place in front of Witherspoon Hall.

CHICAGO, Oct 16.--The Tribune publishes a statement this morning that C.P. Huntington, the Southern Pacific Railroad magnate, has organized a gigantic combination of Western and Southwestern roads, which is about to be effected and will supersede the "gentlemen's agreement" and the proposed "Jay Gould Trust."
KEYPORT, N.J., Oct. 16.--The Democratic Convention of the Third District (Monmouth County) held here to-day nominated Charles Ivins of Red Bank for Assembly.
The Brooklyn Institute has issued a prospectus of lectures on art and science to be given before the institute during the coming year.

READING, Penn., Oct. 16.--John Sirkut, a Polander, was arrested in this city early this morning on a requisition from Lehigh County and taken back to Bethlehem by a constable to answer the charge of stealing Julius Ikhoff's wife and $500 in money.

The following decisions affecting the army have been published by the Adjutant General: By Secretary Proctor--The charge of $1 a day for the subsistence and care of an officer in an army hospital is reasonable, and the distribution of the money collected, giving one-fourth of the amount to the attendants and the remainder to the hospital fund, is a proper one.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 16.--Amherst College held its annual Fall sports yesterday at Hampshire County Park. Only one-half the programme of events was completed.
Gen. Robert Avery was the only witness examined yesterday in the hearing before Referee E.R. Olcott in the Brooklyn Bridge property condemnation proceedings.

The beautiful and exceedingly ornamental lamps that adorn the facade of the NEW-YORK TIMES Building were illuminated last night for the first time and shed their radiance over Printing House-square and the statue of Franklin.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 16.--At the Presbyterian Synod to-day the Rev. James Worden of the Synod of Pennsylvania and the Rev. E. W. Chamberlain of the Synod of Brazil were invited to seats in the Synod as corresponding members.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 16.--The annual convention of the street railway Presidents of the United States was opened to-day.
DANTZIC, Oct. 16.--The Czar and Grand Duke George went to Neufahrwasser this afternoon and walked on the quay, from which the public was excluded.

At Angers yesterday a monument was unveiled in honor of the 600 volunteers of the First Republic who chose to jump down from the Rock of Murs into the Loire rather than surrender to the Vendean royalists, though they knew the leap must be a fatal one.

The Autumn stock of Arnold, Constable Co. is now complete, and the counters and shelves are heaped high with tempting goods. There are beautiful brocades for the evening and the street, the patterns of all of which are new and more attractive than ever.

Col. F.K. Hain of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad announced yesterday that the running of Ninth-avenue trains through to One Hundred and Forty-fifth-street, which began two weeks ago last Monday, had been abandoned, because there was a glut of trains above Fiftyninth-street.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 16.--The twenty-first annual session of the National Board of Trade commenced in this city to-day. President Frederick Fraley of Philadelphia and Secretary Hamilton Hill of New-York are present, with about sixty delegates.

The United States frigate Pensacola, having on board the eclipse expedition party, sailed from the Brooklyn Navy Yard early yesterday morning, and it will be five months before she appears again in home waters.

The steamship City of Washington, which sailed yesterday afternoon for Havana, returned to port last night. She is at anchor off Tompkinsville. She has a bad list to port. It is supposed that the cargo shifted. The Captain refused all information.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16.--The city's suit against the Western Union Telegraph Company to recover license fees of $1 a pole and $2.50 on each mile of wire for the years 1885-6-7-8, ended in a verdict for the complainant to-day, in the United States Circuit Court, for $14,438.43.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 16.--W.S. Colville, who has been at Johnstown since the day following the flood in the employ of the State, was in the city to-day.

There was a good deal of activity around the Republican State Committee Headquarters in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. In the morning Senator Hiscock and Thomas C. Platt called there to have a sort of conference with Chairman Knapp and other leaders.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Oct. 16.--Hundreds of wives and mothers and a goodly proportion of energetic young ladies filled St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church to-day, in earnest consultation over the past work and the future prospects of the Women's Christian Temperance Union.

A Bismarck museum is to be opened at Berlin next April, on the Chancellor's seventy-fifth birthday. It is to contain every species of object relating to the Prince's public life, including a large collection of poems, praising, denouncing, or ridculing him, and an immense number of caricatures.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 16.--The Democratic State Convention to nominate a candidate for Supreme Court Judge and two University Regents met in this city last evening, but filibustered until after midnight before accomplishing anything.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16.--The firm of Dalger Jackson (Frank A. Dalger and Harold Jackson) had three floors of 317 West Baltimore-street stocked with $5,000 worth of advertising cards and lithograph art novelties.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Oct. 16.--The condition of Gen. John F. Hartranft, who has been ill for some time with pneumonia, is viewed tonight as critical. He is now said to be suffering with uraemia, and this, in view of his enfeebled condition, renders his recovery a matter of grave doubt. His friends fear the worst.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 16.--The annual report on the mining and mineral statistics of Canada for the year 1888 has been issued by the Geological Survey. The total value of the production of minerals of all kinds for the year was $1,650,000.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The removal of Postmaster Milton H. Northrup of this city and the appointment in his place of Carroll E. Smith has aroused great indignation among the citizens of Syracuse, irrespective of party affiliations.

The Aqueduct Commissioners had an interesting sort of meeting yesterday. Commissioners Howe, Tucker, and Scott of the Finance Committee made a report in regard to certain charges of extravagance in the expenditures of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--The diplomatic reception room of the State Department presented a scene of unusual brilliancy this morning when Secretary Blaine received the delegates to the International Marine Conference.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 16.--Judge Irvin of the Marion County Criminal Court held to-day that the Dressed-Beef act of the last Legislature is unconstitutional, and directed that an entry be made discharging Philip Klein of the Chicago Dressed-Beef Company, against whom the proceedings were brought.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16.--Mrs. Russell Errett, who was instantly killed in the inclined railroad accident, was the last one to be identified, and this gave rise to several incorrect statements of the names of the dead.

To-morrow afternoon the Giants and the Bridegrooms will begin the great diamond-field struggle to determine which is the champion club of the year. It required but a few moments to arrange matters. New-York wanted to meet Brooklyn, and the latter was equally anxious to face the great Giants.
BATH, N.Y., Oct. 16.--Dr. M.D. Ellison of Canisteo was nominated for Assembly at Addison to-day, by the Democrats of the Second district of Steuben County.

Yesterday's stock market was dull and almost featureless. A little rally and then a little reaction made up the history of the Stock Exchange day. There was something like a squeeze in money in the earlier part of the day, the rate at one time being raised to 12 per cent. Many banking institutions called loans and many of the best houses in the Street had to take dear money.

The Alumni Association of St. Stephen's College last night tendered the Right Rev. W.A. Leonard, a graduate of the college and the newly-consecrated Bishop of Ohio, a dinner at Martinelli's.

St. Luke's Day is to be celebrated, according to a resolution adopted by the House of Bishops and concurred in by the House of Deputies, by the celebration of Holy Communion in St. George's Church tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Oct. 17.--The third day of the State Convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union brought out a large and enthusiastic attendance. The morning session opened with routine work of the county Presidents, Superintendents, Secretaries, and Treasurers. This was followed by a prayer service, led by Mrs. Emma Horner of Dudley.
