SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 17.--Henry Rinenburg's large packing house near Carbondale was blown to pieces by a boiler explosion and several workmen had a narrow escape. The men, meat, timbers, and machinery were thrown in all directions and the building leveled to the ground.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 17.--The Republican managers of Iowa have been thrown into a state of fear and trepidation by the demand of the Cedar Rapids Gazette, a leading Republican paper, that Senator Hutchison, the Republican candidate for Governor, be withdrawn from the ticket.

The good people of the village of Coeymans will be disappointed to hear that Mr. Acton Civill, who died in this city on Saturday last, has made no mention in his will of the academy which he built in that town some ten years ago, but which has never been opened.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 17.--There has been a great deal of rejoining at Cornell to-day over the football team's scoring 6 points against mighty Yale. It was more than has been scored against Yale by any team for two years. The team arrived home this morning and was warmly welcomed. Yale will play a return game at Ithaca on Nov. 9.

The Piano and Organ Manufacturers' Association of the United States met last evening at Clarendon Hall and completed its organization. It will have for its chief object the promotion of social intercourse and the cultivation of better acquaintance among American piano and organ makers.

Mr. E.H. Ammidown has peremptorily resigned the Presidency of the American Protective Tariff Association, and the wool barons have lost their Moses. At the regular monthly meeting of the Executive Committee, held yesterday, Mr. Ammidown gave final notice that after Nov. 10 he would cease to be their President.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 17.--The most notable wedding ever solemnized in the Northwest took place at the Calvary Presbyterian Church in this city this evening at 8 o'clock.

Yonkers was yesterday patriotically decorated with flags and bunting in profusion in honor of the annual parade and review of the Volunteer Fire Department and their visiting company guests from other places.

PIERRE, South Dakota, Oct. 17.--The Legislature met in joint session at noon and proceeded to canvass the vote for United States Senators. They declared Moody and Pettigrew the Senators with rousing cheers. The body then adjourned to meet in January.
Antonio Dabola was a prisoner at Jefferson Market Court yesterday afternoon on the charge of violating the election law.

Miles, commanding the Department of the Pacific, some time ago requested the Pacific coast Congressional delegation to meet him and discuss the questions bearing on this subject. All the members of the delegation in the city met the General yesterday, and the subject was discussed at length.

The Lincoln Club of the Fifth Assembly District, or rather the Republican voters there who are opposed to the organization established in the district by the County Committee through its Reorganization Committee, started out on its campaign against the County Committee last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17.--At to-day's session of the American Forestry Congress Prof. H. Nicholas Jarchow of New-York read a paper entitled "Forestry Legislation in New-York," and Judge Warren Highy followed with some interesting points. On "Progress and Condition of Forestry in New-York."

Hayes, acting under orders from the Secretary of the Navy, sailed this afternoon on the revenue cutter Ewing for the month of the Chesapeake to arrest the 124 Navassa colored rioters, to arrive on the brigs Alice and Romance at the capes to-night or tomorrow.

The Republican County Convention met in Matthews's Hall at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and was called to order by ex-State Committeeman Israel F. Fischer. Clarence A. Barrow of the Twentieth Ward and G.H. Berwin of the Third were elected Secretaries, and after the roll had been perfected these officers were made permanent.

READING, Penn., Oct. 17.--The Reading Gun Club tournament continued to-day, with about the same attendance as on previous days. One more New-Yorker made his appearance to-day in the person of Charles Richards of the NewYork Suburban Shooting Grounds Association.

Brooklyn was the scene of a pretty home wedding last evening, that of Miss Helen Maude Johnston, daughter of H.M. Johnston, and Willis Gilbert Barnes of Utica, at the bride's residence, 67 Downing-street. The Rev. Dr. Canfield of the Church of Our Father officiated, and the bridal party stood under a canopy of white roses and ferns.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 17.--There is plenty of excitement about the Criminal Court Building today, more of it in fact than at any time since the jury bribery plot was first laid bare in all its miserable details.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 17.--The reports from the East about the purchase of the Brush Electric Company of this city by the ThomsonHouston Company of Boston are not exactly correct.
The Society of the Sons of the Revolution dined at the Down-Town Association last evening to commemorate the one hundred and twelfth anniversary of Gen. Burgoyne's surrender at Saratoga.

Henry Carlton, alias" Handsome Harry," who shot and killed Policeman Brennan Oct. 28, 1888, was yesterday resentenced by Judge Martine, in the Court of General Sessions, to be hanged on Dec. 5. Before the sentence was pronounced Carlton made a little speech.

The Republicans of Brooklyn have again chosen Mr. ANDREW D. BAIRD as a candidate for the Mayor's office against Mr. CHAPIN, the present Mayor. To their candidate the Republicans have given what may be called a "running mate" in the person of Mr. JOHN J. CLANCY, who is named for Controller.

Then nominations were agreed on by the separate county conventions of the Republicans and anti-ring Democrats of Hudson County, N.J., held in Hoboken yesterday afternoon. These conventions were composed of men evidently intent on a single purpose.

The story of Jacob Hess's connection withEdward Lauterbach's Anchor Brewing Company of Dobbs Ferry made by THE TIMES yesterday interested professional politicians almost as much as professional electricians. In the case of each the prevalent sentiment was the same.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17.--The annual meeting of the Pullman Palace Car Company was held to-day, over $17,800,000 of capital stock being represented.
A cab drove across the Brooklyn Bridge from New-York last night, and owing to its erratic movements a policeman looked in at the window. The vehicle contained two men, one of whom was insensible.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17.--A month ago a special dispatch to THE TIMES reviewed the outlook of the oyster season. It told of the damages to the supply in Long Island Sound and the poor condition of the yield in the Delaware Bay, and stated that there would be a heavy demand for the Chesapeake oysters.

Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday granted a injunction restraining the North and South American Construction Company "from certifying to the minutes of a stockholders' meeting held in Louisville, Ky., on Oct. 7, or from taking action under a resolution passed at said meeting toward winding up the North and south American Construction Company" The application for the injunction was made by George F. Wyman and Henry C. Comegys.

BOSTON, Oct. 17.--The full bench of the Supreme Court was to have come in for consultation to-day, but owing to the serious indisposition of Chief Justice Morton the sitting of the Judges is indefinitely postponed. Judge Morton is suffering from an attack of bronchitis, and his condition is said to be such as to give his friends considerable anxiety.

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 17.--At 4 o'clock this morning the Montreal through express coming south over the Northern Railroad, drawn by two locomotives, ran into the rear of a freight train near West Canaan, derailing and badly injuring the engines and several freight and passenger cars.

OLIVE, N.Y., Oct. 17.--This afternoon a young man named Melvin Smith of Sullivan, County went hunting with several companions in this town. He carried a single-barreled shotgun. While crossing a patch of woods Smith's gun was discharged. The charge of shot passed through his head and one hand, killing him. The cause of the accident is believed to have been due to the trigger of the weapon being caught in a bush.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 17.--The committee appointed by the Republicans of the First District of Monmouth County at their convention on Monday yesterday nominated Justice of the Peace William L. Conover of Englishtown for Assemblyman. At the convention they were unable to secure a candidate.

The Woman's Board of Missions, a very popular auxiliary of the American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions, held their annual meeting yesterday in the Fourth Presbyterian Church, in West Thirty-fourth-street.
An adjourned meeting of the Episcopal General Convention as a Board of Missions was held in St. George's Church last evening. Bishop Tuttle presided.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 17.--While being driven to the theatre to-night Mme. Janauschek was thrown from her carriage and is suffering from a severe shock. She is not greatly injured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17.--The delegates to the international Marine Conference met at 11 o'clock this morning in the Wallach House and were called to order by Admiral Franklin. On motion of Mr. Charles Hall, M.P., Secretary of the English delegation, Lient. Cottman, United States Navy, of the United States delegation, was elected principal Secretary.

The Democratic General Committee of Kings County at its meeting last night in Rivers's Hall, State and Court streets, Brooklyn, indorsed the State ticket and passed resolutions urging Democrats to register on Tuesday. The resiguation of P.J. Carlin was received and accepted without being read.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 17.--Mrs. Florine Thayer McCray of this city, whose book entitled "The Life work of the Author of 'Uncle Tom's Cabin'" will be issued within the next ten days, will not permit all the advantages to remain on one side in the spirited controversy now in progress concerning the authenticity of her work.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 17.--A meeting of the St. Paul Ice Palace and Carnival Association was held last night and, the weather permitting it was unanimously decided to build the most fantastic ice palace ever known, and have the biggest and finest carnival possible, at a time to be set later. Financial backing in abundance has already been secured and every indication points to the most successful carnival in the history of the Northwest.

The sub-committee of the General Committee of the County Democratic organization held a meeting late on Wednesday evening and concluded to adjourn the County Convention over to next week, in order that the organization might profit by the action of the Citizens', who, in turn, have adjourned their convention, pending the action of the Republicans.

Surrogate Ransom yesterday reserved his decision on a motion to set aside the probate of the will of George Law Kent, the son of an old New-York merchant. Kent, when a boy, was sent to England with his mother to be educated. After he grew older he lived in this city and in Paris.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 17.--The Dominion Government has decided to subsidize a line of steamships between Halifax or St. John and the West Indies. Sir Charles Tupper is in Madrid negotiating a commercial treaty with Spain and here colonies. The negotiations were commenced a year ago and promise to result successfully. This has led the Canadian Government to subsidize the steamship line in the expectation of reviving trade relations with the West Indies.

Annie Green, the thirteen-year-old girl who was found unconscious and soaking wet in the yard of her parents' residence in Walnutstreet, in Kearny Township, N.J., at midnight of Wednesday, after an unaccountable absence from early morning, was very ill yesterday. Her recovery is hoped for, but there is yet danger of brain fever.

In the United States District Court in Boston yesterday Samuel E. Bumpus Postmaster at East Falmouth, was sentenced to pay a fine of $10 and costs and to serve one year in the State prison on two charges, one for breaking into the Post Office Building there and the other for the larceny of a letter.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The eighth days' balloting in the Twenty-third Senatorial District Republican Convention ends without result, 734 ballots having been cast, with Sheard, Wilson, and Arnold still on an even footing. Congressman Delano came on this afternoon with the latest instructions from Platt, who, it is...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The closing session of the seventeenth annual convention of the Carriage Builders' National Association was held here to-day. It was announced that the subscriptions for the technical school in NewYork had reached a total of about $7,000.

The Electric Club formally opened its Winter season last evening at its East Twenty-secondstreet clubhouse. Nearly 200 of the most prominent electricians and investors in electric companies in and about New-York were present.
LONDON, Oct. 17.--The Guion Line steamship Wyowing. Capt. Rigby, from New-York Oct. 8, arr. at Queenstown at 7 o'clock this evening.

The amount of time devoted yesterday by the House of Deputies to the consideration of two propositions relating to liturgical revision demonstrates the General Convention to be a deliberate as well as a deliberative body. At morning prayer the Rev. Dr. David W. Dresser of Springfield and the Right Rev. Dr. Benjamin W. Morris, Bishop of Oregon, claimed attention.

John Cunningham, the lineman who proved his bravery by taking down the body of the unfortunate Feeks, will appear in the Court of Common Pleas next Monday as plaintiff in a suit against the East River Electric Light Company.

Having reached the utmost point of endurance of the impositions which they declare have been practiced upon them by the Appraiser's officers of this port, several of the importers of worsteds of this city carried their grievances to Secretary Windom, and that gentleman...

The Tabernacle never held as many people at one time in all its history as assembled there at the evening session to hear the President's address to the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 17.--The comfort and physical capabilities of the All-America excursion party are being considered at this point. The recent indications of weariness and fatigue on the part of the Southern members of leisurely habits are being consulted.

--The Irish-American Club of this city gushed over Gov. Hill to-night. It was at a banquet given in honor of Gen. Patrick Collins. There were present Gov. Hill, Gov. Gordon, the Hon. H.W. Grady, Capt. E.P. Howell, ex-Gov. Sims of Mississippi, Congressman Stevenson of Illinois, Mayor Glenn of this city, the Hon. Patrick Walsh, and about fifty citizens of no great importance.

Mr. Simon Sterne of 26 William-street wishes to correct the impression that in his letter offering to the Committee on Site of the World's Fair the use of his sixteen lots between One Hundred and Eleventh and One Hundred and Twelfth streets and Seventh and Eighth avenues "for a reasonable rental" he stated or inferred that the fair would be an injury to property.
OSWEGO,N.Y., Oct. 17.--The funeral of Congressman Newton W. Nutting took place this afternoon, and was largely attended by prominent residents of this and adjoining counties.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 17.--The journeymen bakers of Newark have declared a boycott against the bakeries of Mangels Schmidt, William Titus, G. Schuldt, Buehler, Adam Turkes, Daniel Fritsch, Ludwig, and Wooden. The strike threatens to become general throughout the city before it is ended.
The Armory Board had a meeting yesterday. Mayor Grant, Tax Commissioner Coleman, Gen. Fitzgerald, and Col. Cavanagh attended it.

W.C. Hawk, a member of the flour trade of the Produce Exchange, was caught by Thomas White of the Floor Committee yesterday after noon just as he was in the act of propelling a dough pudding through the air at a friend in the provision trade.

PARIS, Oct. 17.--The address of the National Committee taken to Gen. Boulanger by M. Noquet assures the General of the fidelity of the party to his cause and of their confidence in its ultimate success.

Superintendent Murray said yesterday that the two girls reported as runaways at Police Headquarters Wednesday evening were respectable, but that their social position had been very greatly exaggerated. They are the daughters of up-town tradesmen, and their parents cannot account for their escapade. No trace of them had been found last evening.

Soon after the opening of yesterday's session of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions Prof F.W. Fisk of Chicago presented the report of a committee to which had been submitted the report of Home Secretary Alden in behalf of the Prudential Committee.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 17.--William Calhoun of New-York, the expert who for six months has been investigating the financial condition of this city for a period embracing the last ten years, reported last night to the City Council the following condition of affairs:
ACCORD, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The Democrats of the Third Assembly District of Ulster County met in convention here this afternoon and renominated George H. Bush of Ellenvide for member of Assembly.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The Grand Jury came into court this morning, made their presentments, and were discharged. Not a word was said about the Assembly ceiling case, although three sealed indictments were handed in. As to the nature of these indictments nothing could be learned, but it is not believed they are directed against any of the ceiling conspirators.

Representatives of the regular Democratic, Republican, and Citizens' organizations of Long Island City met last night and nominated a union ticket, with Frederick W. Blackwenn for Mayor. S.J. Kavanagh, Democrat, and L.N. Manly, Republican, were renominated for Judges, and a full ticket was formed.

A dispatch from Chicago says: "The managers of the Chicago Club have followed the plan of the New-Yorkers to protect the name from the Brotherhood players. Articles of incorporation were issued Tuesday to the Chicago League Ball Club and the Chicago Baseball Club, both with the old managers as incorporators."

Surrogate Ransom in the Surrogate's Court yesterday gave W.E. Murray a genuine surprise. Mr. Murray appeared as counsel in connection with two motions made in the matter of the estate of Mary Scanlan. While the first motion was being argued he became so obstreperous that Surrogate Ransom sharply ordered him to stop talking and sit down.

All arrangements have been completed, for the world's baseball championship series between New-York and Brooklyn, and unless the weather clerk interferes the two champions of the diamond field will meet at the Polo Grounds this afternoon to begin the struggle to determine which is the better club.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 17.--Lucy Mack, who resides at Highland, Ulster County, N.Y., was on a sleeping car on the Hudson River Railroad attached to the train due here to-day at 2:15 P.M. She got on the car at Minneapolis, and on the way it was noticed she was despondent.

W.P. Clyde of the Clyde West India shipping Line received a confidential business dispatch from San Domingo yesterday, at 11 o'clock, in which mention was made of the unanimous election of Gen. Hippolyte to the Presidency of the Haytian Republic. Just 91 votes were cast, all of them for Legitime's successful rival. The news was at once made public on the floor of the Maritime Exchange.
BOSTON, Mass, Oct. 17.--The Calumet and Hecla Mining Company to-day declared a dividend of $5 per share.

The United States steamer Enterprise, Commander McCalla, commanding, now the sole representative of the American Navy on the European station, was reported to the Navy Department yesterday to be at Bristol, England.

BOSTON, Oct. 17.--The new Amateur Rowing Association, which President Barry of the NewEngland Amateur Rowing Association said would be formed within forty-eight hours of the time that the National Association disqualified the New-England and New-York oarsmen, is already on a sound basis.

The North Alabama Lumber Company, with headquarters at Bridgeport, Ala., have filed an assignment. Their liabilities are $120,000 assets, $140,000. The assignees are C.A. Lyerly and P.C. Wilson of Chattanooga and J.N. Hoffman, Jr., of Tullahoma, Tenn. The attaching creditors, to whom is due $65,000, will probably receive 75 cents on the dollar, the non-attaching creditors 60 cents.

The braves of Tammany Hall met in convention in the Ninth Congressional District last night and nominated Amos J. Cummings, who served in the fiftieth Congress from the Sixth District, to fill the seat made vacant by the death of Samuel Sullivan Cox.

The Evangelical Education Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church held its twentyseventh annual meeting yesterday afternoon in Grace Church Guild House. Bishop G. Peterkin of West Virginia presided, and the reports of the Treasurer and Secretary were read by the Rev. Dr. R.C. Mattlack, the General Secretary of the society. The financial statement for the year showed:

Some Stock Exchange rules which had apparently lapsed into dead letters are likely now to get attention. There is one which prescribes severe penalties for the punishment of brokers who circulate or aid the circulation of false reports intended to further stock-jobbing schemes.
The Republicans of Brooklyn and Kings County met in convention yesterday and nominated the following complete city and county tickets:

Yesterday's stock market was inclined to be very feverish. Quotations ran off easily, there being throughout the day a marked tendency toward lower prices. The chief factor in the investment and speculative situation continues to be apprehensive regarding the money market.

Augutin L. Scott, the eccentric tailor who keeps a little shop at 105 South-street, and has long been a conspicuous figure as a promenader along Park-row and Fulton-street in the afternoon, was arrested yesterday in a civil suit for $5,000 damages brought by George W. Smith, a bookseller.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 17.--A bitter factional fight is in progress among the Republicans of Chenango County. The post of County Judge and Surrogate--these two places being filled by one functionary, holding for a term of six years--is the most desirable and lucrative county office, and at each recurring election is...

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct 17.--The Lackawanna Iron and Coal Company's steel mill was the scene of a tragedy last night in which Solon Davis of this city was instantly killed by stepping into the great fly wheel while it was revolving at the rate of sixty revolutions a minute.

Perfect weather, good racing, lively betting, and management that was in every way satisfactory resulted in an enjoyable day's racing for the second day's meeting of the New-Jersey Jockey Club. As on the opening day, the candidates from the stable of the Dwyer Brothers...
Two youngsters with a record as tramp were committed to the Drumgoole Mission yesterday by Police Justice Gorman, in the Jefferson Market Police Court.

The unqualified success of ballot regulation based upon the Australian system, so far as it has been tried, will give a decided impetus to the reform movement. Of this there are many evidences already, and though the party conventions in this State...
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 18.--The number of deaths in this State during September, as reported by Dr. C.A. Lindsley, Secretary of the State Board of Health, was 1,040, being 150 less than in August.

David P. Winne, manufacturers' agent for twines and cordage at 338 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Mr. William Allan. He has been in business about twenty years, had a large trade, with a branch at San Francisco, but has had no rating at Bradstreet's for a year past.
A decree winding up the Wabash receivership of Gen. John McNulta was entered by consent of all creditors and other interested parties by Judge Gresham in Chicago yesterday.
Steamship Cherokee, Bearse, Jacksonville and Charleston 3 ds., with mdse. and passengers to William P. Clvde Co.

St. Luke's Hospital is in need of financial assistance. This fact was demonstrated at the annual meeting held last evening. The total amount of the trust funds is $659,089.72, all of which is invested according to the laws governing such funds, and the interest revenue amounts to $31,839.68.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18.--Following is the letter sent by the Pope to Cardinal Gibbons by Mgr. O'Connell with regard to the Catholic centennial:

FORT SCOTT, Kan., Oct. 18.--Jay Gould, accompanied by S.H.H. Clarke and party, arrived here yesterday, and last night he signed contracts with this city to build three lines of railroad--the Fort Scott and Belt Line, with...

Some facts of general interest to taxpayers were published by the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments on Thursday in their report for the year of the "operations and action" of their department to Mayor Grant.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 18.--The Iowa Supreme Court to-day passed upon the inter-State commerce phase of the State prohibition law, and if its decision is sustained by the United States Supreme Court it will have a far-reaching effect upon the importation of liquors into Iowa.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 18.--The National Board of Trade was in session again to-day and adjourned to meet a year hence at a place yet to be determined. Resolutions were passed opposing any modification of the inter-State commerce law, especially of the clause prohibiting...

READING, Penn., Oct. 18.--The Reading shoot finished with to-day's programme. But few shooters attended to-day, and live birds principally were shot at, though some Keystone events were sandwiched in. One or two friendly matches were shot, but no scores were retained. The following are the winners in the events:

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Oct. 18.--The seventeenth annual convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of New-Jersey closed here to-day. The devotions of the day were led by Mrs. M.C. Nobles of Atlantic Highlands.

The decision of the Court of Appeals of this State in the elevator cases has naturally caused a good deal of discussion and is likely to cause a good deal more, because it establishes, so far as the decision of that tribunal can, a principle of great importance, the validity of which is disputed.

Ex-Auditor William F. Creed of the Custom House was agreeably surprised on Thursday evening by the presentation to him at his residence, 115 Montague-street, Brooklyn, of a handsome solitaire diamond ring.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--The News says: "The Whisky Trust, which has been in session in this city for several days, is just now engaged in a desperate struggle for the complete control of the market, the outcome of which is to determine whether it is eventually to prove a success or a failure.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--The Secretary of the Treasury has rendered the following decision regarding the proper classification of lead and silver ores:
For some time past there has been in circulation a rumor that the Sugar Trust was making preparations for an abandonment of the Trust plan.

The broad palm of Mr. Thomas C. Platt was held over the delegates to the Third District Republican Senatorial Convention in Brooklyn last night, and the consequence was the absence of a contest. Harmony had not reigned in that district before for nearly ten years, and, from the bitterness of the preliminary struggle over Senator O'Connor's successor, no one expected it this year.
WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 18.--Jay Gould and party passed through here yesterday. Mr. Gould has been sick since leaving Denver. He looked very weary and worn, and did not get off his car.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 18.--Dr. W. Seward Webb, Commodore of the Lake Champlain Yacht Club, gave a brilliant reception at the clubhouse this evening to members and a large number of invited guests.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--Much quiet and effective work was done in the Cronin case to-day, and the result has been the drawing very much closer of the chain of evidence about the suspects, in prison and out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--Secretary Windom heard to-day what the importers of New-York think about his selection of Bowling Green as the site of the proposed new Appraiser's Stores. The information was given to him by a number of prominent business men, who came here to talk to the Secretary on behalf of the importers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 18.--Republican Assembly candidates were nominated in Erie County to-day as follows: First District, Daniel J. Kenetick, declined; Second, Henry W. Brendel; Third, Leroy Andrus; Fourth, Christopher Smith; Fifth, William B. Currier.
Public sentiment is telling. Investors are asserting themselves. Laws are becoming of Wall-street consequence. Trusts are upon the wane. This is not an idle phrase.

Entries to the athletic games of the National Cross-Country Association, to be held next Saturday on the Staten Island Athletic Club's grounds, at Livingston, S.I., close to-day with Secretary W. Frank, 972 Washington-avenue, this city.

Judge Robertson, the Bow-legged Bismarck of Katonah, (so called, playfully,) is in a hole. He was elected to the Senate two years ago through dissensions among the Democrats of Westchester and Rockland Counties.

The Central Labor Union of Indianapolis has undertaken to secure the re-employment of more than a hundred conductors of street cars who had been discharged as supernumerary upon the introduction by the company of "bobtail" cars.

G.R. Le Hunte, the brother of Mary Le Hunte, the young woman who has already been reported as having eloped from County Wexford, Ireland, with her father's gardener, arrived here yesterday on the Germanic.
New-York has a fair prospect to pay $4 for every quart and $2 for every pint of champagne that it drinks in any of the fashionable hotels and restaurants after the 1st of next month.

Warner Miller was in town yesterday and was very much sought after at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel by his friends, but although he passed Mr. Thomas C. Platt several times not a word was exchanged between them. Mr. Platt whisked about the corridors during evening, but was too short sighted to see Mr. Miller.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18.--The immigration year may be said virtually to have closed, for although immigrants will continue to arrive the remainder of the year, their numbers will be inconsiderable, and such few as do come will remain for the most part in the cities.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 18.--No trace has been secured yet of the whereabouts of Charles H. King, the manager of the United States Express Company's office in Newark, who disappeared suddenly from his boarding house on Monday. Fears are entertained that he committed suicide. He had been with the company for twenty-five years.

Basebal enthusiasts, like every other class of people, have their ups and downs in this world. For the past two weeks joy has reigned supreme among the ballmen of the diamond-field sport of this city, caused by the grand victory achieved by the Giants in the race for the League pennant.

Expert physicians testified in the McElvaine case in the Court of Sessions, Brooklyn, yesterday, where the murderer of Grocer Luca is standing trial. Dr. Eugene Field of 115 East Fortiethstreet, New-York, Examiner in Lunacy to the Department of Charities, said he had examined 14,000 cases of alleged insanity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--The annual report for the fiscal year 1888-9 of the Commissioner of Pensions has been submitted to the Secretary of the Interior. The following summary of the report will show the more important details of the work of the bureau during the fiscal year:
LISBON, Oct. 18.--The conditon of the King has become worse. The paralysis of his body has increased.

Eight Samoan warriors in full feather, or rather in full undress costume, appeared on the stage of Koster Bial's Concert Hall last night, and showed a big audience how they behave themselves in their native islands.

A plan has been under informal discussion for several days among members of the General Committee for the World's Fair by which it is proposed to transfer the active management of preparations for the fair to a few officials, to be appointed under the system by which preparations were conducted for the exposition at Paris.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--There was a pulling out of plugs and a general letting down of prices on the Board of Trade to-day. Two weeks ago there was considerable comment over the fact that corn and oats on 'Change sold lower than for ten years before.
HELENA, Montana, Oct. 18.--A conference of leading Republicans of the Territory was held here to-day in the office of B. Platt Carpenter to arrange a programme of action in the election contest.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day:

Favored once more with delightful weather, the New-Jersey Jockey Club had a great crowd at the track to enjoy a fine day's racing. Some five thousand people were at the track, and as the fields were of very fair size, speculation was lively.
The crews of three vessels which were hopelessly wrecked at Laguna Bay during the September cyclone were brought to this port yesterday by the steamer City of Alexandria.

A correspondent asks what has become of the case of William McMahon of Rahway, N.J., against Maurice B. Flynn, William H. Kelly, the Consolidated Telegraph and Electric Subway Company, and the American Insulated Conduit Company. This was an action begun in November, 1886, in the United States Circuit Court.

The thirty-eighth annual anniversary exercises of St. Luke's Home for Indigent Christian Females was held yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Beloved Disciple, Madison-avenue and Eighty-ninth-street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--If there is to be any opposition to the election of Mr. Thomas B. Reed of Maine to the Speakership it ought to be provoked to appear as soon as it is learned that all the talk at present favors Mr. Reed's success.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 18.--Considerable indignation exists to-night among Democrats over an expression in Gov. Hill's speech this morning. He said, in substance: "I shall not attempt to describe the wonderful resources of your remarkable country.

The Republicans of Westchester County held their County Convention in Moran's Hall, White Plains, yesterday, for the purpose of nominating candidates for county officers. James Wood of Bedford presided.

The feature of yesterday's proceedings in the electric muddle, outside of the Feeks inquest, was a steady and powerful pressure brought to hear on Electrical Expert Wheeler to persuade him to formally allow the opening of certain circuits by the Brush and the United States Company.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 18.--The keepers of livery stables in this city and Newark are about to form a trust for the purpose of keeping up prices for weddings and funerals.

The Rev. Dr. John McDowell Leavitt, who for more than forty years has been a clergyman of the Protestant Episcopal Church, has recently decided to free himself from the burden of its doctrines and cast his lot with the Reformed Episcopalians.

The steady increase in the subscription list for the Washington Memorial Arch fund is creating much interest in this patriotic movement. Treasurer William R. Stewart of No. 54 Williamstreet acknowledges the receipt of the following additional subscriptions: Robert D. Benedict and F. de P. Foster, $25 each; John C. O'Connor, Jr., $20; Mandeville Mower, G.W. D., and Oliver Barrett, $10 each. Previously acknowledged, $54,336.56. The grand total is $54,436.56.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 18.--The crop of honey gathered in Ulster and adjoining counties this Fall has been small, and the quality of the product does not compare with that of former years.

This afternoon the New-York and Brooklyn teams will meet on the latter's diamond at Washington Park. "Lon" Knight will be engaged to umpire instead of "Bob" Ferguson. The Giants are determined to regain their lost laurels, and a good game may be expected. The teams will be composed as follows:

The fight at the primary election in the Thirteenth Assembly District between the CowieSprague forces and the Fred S. Gibbs faction yesterday was lively and interesting, and when the polls closed at 9 o'clock the leaders of the revolt against Gibbs and the district machine had made an excellent showing, although Gibbs mnanaged to squeeze through.

The meeting of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions came to an end yesterday afternoon. President Storrs appointed the Committee of Nine, which is expected to harmonize all the diverse opinions in the board, as follows: The Rev. Drs. G.L. Walker,...
CHICAGO, Oct. 18.--James M. Selover, a noted Wall-street operator, died at the Leland Hotel here to-day.

The Law Committee of the World's Fair met in the Mayor's office yesterday and discussed some of the legal problems that are liable to arise. All the members were present except Chauncey M. Depew. When the meeting broke up it was with the understanding that each would look up the law on certain subjects and furnish opinions.

The jealousy with which the members of the General Convention guard against any possible onslaught upon the integrity of the Book of Common Prayer is indicated by the fact that the whole of yesterday's business session of the House of Deputies, with the exception of a...

The steamship Portia of the Red Cross Line arrived here on Thursday after a remarkably quick passage. She left Halifax at 11:45 last Monday, passed Sambro Island, off Halifax Harbor, at 1:30 A.M., and on Tuesday arrived at City Island, where she took on her New-York pilot at 10 P.M. on Wednesday, making her actual time 44 hours.

Thomas Devin, aged nine, and John Devin, aged seven, both looking still younger, were brought before Justice White in the Harlem Police Court yesterday, charged with burglary, and after examination were handed over to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to children.

David A. Wells of Connecticut addressed about 150 members of the Reform Club, at the clubhouse, 12 East Thirty-third-street, last night, on "The Decay of Our Merchant Marine: Its Causes and Its Cure--Will subsidizing ships bring back our foreign commerce and afford markets for the surplus product of our manufacturing industries?"

Judge Cowing, in General Sessions, yesterday, sent John Mahon, a clerk, nineteen years old, to the reformatory, for having forged the names of James Hale and T.L. Ogden to a check on the St. Nicholas Bank for $43.20 on June 14 last. Mahon was in the employ of the law firm of Ogden, Beekman Ogden.

Some time ago Elizabeth and Daniel Kiernan were arrested in Jersey City, charged with having starved their child Elizabeth, a babe, to death. Yesterday they were tried in the Court of General Sessions, and the mother was convicted. The father, for some uuknown reason, was acquitted. Both are drunkards, and it was because of their indulgence in liquor that their child was starved to death.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18.--Information has been received from Honolulu by the steamer City of Peking, that the Hawaiian Cabinet, in answer to a committee representing a public meeting of Hawaiian citizens who made inquiry concerning the relation between the kingdom and the United States on Oct. 4, has issued a statement in which its position relative to the proposed treaty is explained.

A public meeting was held last evening in Chickering Hall for the purpose of interesting Christian people in the colored missionary work. About 400 persons were in attendance, about equally divided as regards color.

ALBANY, Oct. 18.--The Bentley-Oliver Republicans called a County Convention for to-day, but it was not held. The regular Republican Convention will be held at noon to-morrow, and name a ticket in which the Bentley faction will concur.

A story that would seem incredible were not its truth certified to by unimpeachable witnesses was hinted at by one of the speakers in the Republican County Convention in Hoboken on Thursday and was investigated by a TIMES reporter yesterday. It shows at once how completely justice is perverted in Jersey City and that Sheriff Davis is responsible for the perversion.

Twelve representative citizens were impaneled as a jury in Room 21, City Hall, yesterday, to investigate the death of John E.H. Feeks, the lineman who was killed by an electric current a week ago yesterday at Centre and Chambers streets. Ex-Commissioner of Charities Thomas S. Brennan was made foreman, and his fellow-jurymen were Gustav Pfingsten, 6 Whitehall-street, apothecary; Edward P. Steers...

Picking up "Jane Eyre" after a lapse of years sufficient to render all its outlines blurred, and even to cause one to forget the plot, the power of Charlotte Bronte comes over one again with a surprise.

The new cruisers Concord and Bennington will be ready for launching in a few days. The work has been pushed along so rapidly, and at the same time so quietly, that the news of the progress made will be a complete surprise to many in naval circles.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 18.--With regard to the reporter marriage of Maggie Mitchell to her leading man, Charles Abbott, the Herald announces to-day on authority that the ceremony took place at the residence of the actress, in Long Branch, on June 13 last. Mrs. Luther Holden and her son were the only witnesses.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 18.--State Labor Commissioner Meriwether has returned to Jefferson City from a tour of inspection among the coal mines in the northern counties of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--To-day's bond offers accepted were as follows: Coupon 4s, $2,000 at 127; registered 4s, $300,000, $22,050, $400,000, $200,000, $50,000, $800, $30,000, $2,000 at 127; registered 4 s, $12,500, $8,000, $8,000, and $2,700 at 105 .

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18.--The appeal in the Kemmler electrical execution case was argued in the General Term of the Supreme Court to-day. Bourke Cockran of New-York appeared for the defense, and Deputy Attorney General William A. Poste for the prosecution. The lawyers were given a week in which to prepare and submit their briefs, and the case was adjourned. A decision is expected about Jan. 1.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 18.--Another chapter in the trouble in St. Mary's Church at Waterloo was commenced last evening. When and where it will end nobody knows.

Political discussion went on very actively in Jersey City yesterday. The action of the Republicans and anti-ring Democrats in uniting on a single county ticket was canvassed in all its phases.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 18.--The Grand Jury today found six indictments, three against Major E.A. Burke and Maurice Hart jointly for publishing forged bonds as true, and two for forgery and one for embezzlement against exTreasurer Burke. Mr. Hart, who is a prominent capitalist and broker, was arrested and furnished bonds. Major Burke had previously been indicted for embezzling public money,...

The bond which was given for the free importation into this country of the paintings by Vassili Verestchagin having lapsed, duty was paid the other day on the entire collection. This means that the paintings will be dispersed here. They were shown in Chicago last Spring.

A little flurry in bass fishing has struck this town in the past two or three days, and the clear, cold weather following the storm has had its effect on the sport. Small bass were taken in quantities on Wednesday, and good fishing has been reported since. Every kind of sport with rod or gun seems to have come in cyclonic waves this year, and the anglers now hope for a regular bass blizzard.

BERLIN, Oct. 18.--Court reports appearing in the newspapers of this city credit the Czar with thanking Prince Bismarck for supporting the Russian protests to the Swiss Government against the harboring of Anarchists, and assuring the Chancellor that the statements regarding Gen. Obrutschef's recommendation of...
The County Democracy's County Convention will be called to order in Cooper Institute this afternoon at 2 o'clock.

According to the testimony produced yesterday in the Court of Chancery in Jersey City, Simon Baruch, charged with being an embezzler, will be able to prove that the property he brought to this country is legally in his keeping, although is claimed by the Austrian Government.
The races at Clifton yesterday were attended by some 2,000 people and resulted as follows:--

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 18.--The residence of Arthur Rodeman, a druggist, at 241 West Grand-street, was entered by burglars early this morning. The thieves carried off two diamond rings, a scarf pin and other jewelry, and clothing to the value of $250. They also tried to rob the residence of Joseph Ross, 140 West Grand-street, but were frightened away by a watchdog.

LONDON, Oct. 18.--Mr. Gladstone will issue a manifesto in the form of a speech at Southport Wednesday next. He will probably formulate an active programme of reforms and expound his home-rule proposals.

William Games yesterday murdered a fellowworkman named Eugene Sullivan on the farm of George Shields in the town of Bristol, Kenosha County, Wis., about two miles south of Bristol station. Games cut Sullivan's throat with a butcher's knife, and thrust the blade through his body seven times. He was arrested and confessed, saying he feared Sullivan would "beat him out of his job."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18.--The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Davies, rector of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church for the past twenty-one years, was to-day consecrated as Bishop of the diocese of Eastern Michigan, to which he was elected last June.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18.--At a meeting of the football association to-day Edgar Allen Poe, '91, of Baltimore, Md., was elected permanent Captain of the eleven for this year in the place of W.L. Ames of Illinois, resigned. Mr. Poe captained the second eleven last year, and did it well. He is a good player himself in his position as quarter-back, and never gets excited in a game, as Mr. Ames did.

Col. Albert H. Rogers, ex-Deputy Commissioner of the Street-Cleaning Department, was committed for examination as to his sanity by Justice O'Reilly in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning. On Thursday afternoon he had attracted a crowd on Broadway, opposite St. Paul's Church, by violently abusing a hansom...

Valentine Liebegg, a business man of Philadelphia, who had formerly been engaged in business in this city, was arraigned yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Martine, on a charge of larceny and of obtaining money under false pretenses from his partner, William Reitlinger of 103 Gold-street. Liebegg lives at 812 Tioga-street, Philadelphia.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 18.--Ex-Senator John W. Griggs of Paterson has written a reply to the open letter of Allan McDermott, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, who insinuated that Mr. Griggs did not introduce his Railroad Tax bill in the State Senate in 1883 in good faith, and that it was his own fault that it did not then pass.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music was crowded last evening at the first mass meeting of the Kings County Prohibitionists. Samuel Dickie of the Prohibition State Committee and Albert Griffin of the Anti-Saloon League argued for two hours on the question, "Shall Voters Support the Republican or the Prohibition Candidates?" Speeches were also made by Col. William C. Beecher and others.

William Repper, the Tax Collector of Newtown, L.I., who is charged with being a defaulter, was arrested yesterday on the complaint of Jacob Deboo, one of his bondsmen, from Glendale. Repper was taken before Justice Schumacher and held in $4,000 bonds for examination. Repper was over $3,000 short in his accounts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--Promptly at 10 o'clock this morning Admiral Franklin called the International Marine Conference to order and business was resumed.
Distressing tales circulating in this irreverent town insinuate that the excellent Vice President of these United States has been "done up" by his pious friend, "Col." Elliott F. Shepard.

The question of opening up Elm-street again came before the Board of Street Opening and Improvement yesterday. There was a large number of interested persons on hand, all of them ready to aid the board in coming to a conclusion.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 18.--The races at Latonia today were run with these results:

A new number of Goodwin's Official Turf Guide, containing the record of all races run up to the close of the meetings at Morris and Jerome Parks, is issued to-day, and makes a volume of about 700 pages of solid type. Its table of winning jockeys shows Barnes to lead with 153 victories in 581 races.

PARIS, Oct. 18.--The strike of coal miners at Lens, France, is spreadgin. M. Thevenot, Minister of Justice, has issued special instructions to the local authorities with a view to the prevention of disorder.
LONDON, Oct. 18.--The Cunard Line steamship Etruria, Capt. Hains, from New-York Oct. 12 for Liverpool, arr. at Queenstown at 10 P.M. to-day.
There is trouble in Weehawken over the Erie Railway Company's tracks. The tracks have been laid on land claimed by Fowler Brothers, coal storage dealers, and a lawsuit is in progress as a result.
AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 18.--The Common Council of this city passed a resolution to-night indorsing New-York City as the proper place for the World's Fair in 1892.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19.--The senior Presbyterian clergyman of Central New-York is the Rev. Julius S. Pattengill of Walton, who has just celebrated as a double jubilee the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination in the ministry and of his marriage.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19.--A suit was brought in the Superior Court Thursday by Fisher, Bruce Fisher, counsel for Richard H. Rudd and Martin Stansbury, copartners, against the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company of Baltimore for damages laid at $20,000.
To the Albany Evening Journal; In your issue of Friday, Oct. 11, there is published an account of the discovers at Ticonderoga of the remains of Lord Howe, who was killed near that place in 1758.

The ordering by the Navy Department of several hundred rapid-fire Hotchkiss guns looks as if the new navy is to be well supplied with these arms. The contract requires, however, that the guns shall be built in this country, so as to comply with recent requirements, whereby only American manufactured material can be supplied to the new fleet.

Oscar Mattox, John Bullock, Albert Norton, and James Monahan were arrested at Sullivan, Ind., Friday charged with the murder of George Farmer, aged seventy-five years, who kept a small restaurant at Shelburn. Farmer was found dead last Sunday morning in front of his place of business, and is believed to have been killed in a fight with a party of roughs.
The Protestant Episcopal Bishops from Southern dioceses now in convention here will be banqueted on Wednesday evening by the Southern Society of New-York.
The Republicans of the Second Assembly District of Westchester County met in convention at Port Chester yesterday for the purpose of nominating a candidate for member of Assembly.
A new grotto has been recently discovered and opened to the public at not quite twenty minutes' distance from the famous Cavern of Stalactites at Adelsberg, in Carniola.

The yachting interest is temporarily dormant, and there will not be much for yachtsmen to talk about until after the meeting of the NewYork Yacht Club, to be held in the clubhouse, 67 Madison-avenue, on Thursday night of this week.

Below will be found the reserve lists of the League, American, and Atlantic Associations. It will be noticed that Whitney's name does not appear among those of the Giants. The genial third baseman will probably be seen with the champion next season.
As many people were at the race track of the New-Jersey Jockey Club yesterday as were there when the gates were first thrown open to the public on Wednesday last.

E. Berry Wall, dressed very much like an ordinary mortal and looking slightly annoyed, was again before Referee Myers at 304 Broadway yesterday. He produced a very long and very black cigar and, cutting it in two, gave one-half to his lawyer, Orlando L. Stewart, observing that it was the best he could do. It made two very respectable smokes.

The first two days of the week saw some rally in the railway share list, but another break in the trust stocks and the continued close working of the money market operated to again depress prices. Furthermore, the advance was met by a good sprinkling of long stock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Coupon 4s, $2,300 and $100 at 127; registered 4s, $50,000 and $500, at 127; registered 4 s, $40,000 and $15,000, at 105 .

The large chapel of the New-York Juvenile Asylum was filled to overflowing yesterday on the occasion of the semi-annual reception given to the Board of Directors of the institute and their guests.
SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 19.--As the work of mining advances through the anthracite coal fields of Northeastern Pennsylvania, the fall of roof becomes more frequent, more extensive, and more fatal.

Superintendent Cleveland of the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane at Poughkeepsie telegraphed to Police Headquarters that Joseph T. Francis, an insane patient, had escaped from that institution on Friday and was still at large.
Seventy-five veterans of the Fifth New-York Heavy Artillery Regiment celebrated at the Chelsea, in West Twenty-third street, last evening the twenty-fifth anniversary of the battle of Cedar Creek.

PARIS, Oct. 19.--The Cabinet has expelled M. Laisant, the Boulangist Deputy, from his position as an officer in the territorial army. This action is due to a statement made in a speech by M. Laisant during the recent campaign that he would not take the field for France under the present Government.

A good deal of the esteem in which the banking house of Morton, Bliss Co. is held in financial circles, aside from the reputation its principals enjoy for conservatism and shrewdness, is due to its habit of fair dealing. It has not been given to putting screws to its customers.

SING SING, Oct. 19.--An exciting game of football was played here this afternoon. The Berkeley School eleven of New-York came to Sing Sing to try conclusions with their old rivals, the Olympics of St. John's School of this place. Four or five hundred persons assembled to witness the contest.

The late Gen. Rodney C. Ward, whose monument is that superb National Guard organization, "Ours"--the Twenty-third Regiment, Brooklyn--has left a record of his views upon what is unquestionably the most important of all regimental offices--the position of Captain.

New-ORLEANS, Oct. 19.--It looks very much, from several transactions to-day, as if the State authorities had forwarded to Washington the necessary papers to drink about the extradition of Major E.A. Burke, the ex-Treasurer of the State.

The Johns Hopkins Hospital is doing a large work for the city. The rooms are well filled every day and the physicians are kept busy. The new training school for nurses in connection with the hospital, of which it is a part, is progressing finely. The applications for admission come from all parts of the country.

A good deal of business was done in the real estate market during the last week. All of the sales at the Exchange drew a large attendance of bidders, and prices were excellent in almost every case.

Fullerton Rushmore, counsel for Sheriff Flack, have filed notice of appeal to the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas from the order of Judge Bookstaver, annulling the decree of divorce entered in favor of Mrs. Flack.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 19.--Ex-State Senator Thomas Green Chattle was stricken with paralysis here last night. The left side of his body is completly paralyzed, and he is unable to speak. Dr. William P. Brown, who is attending him, says that he cannot recover.

Knapp, '85, one of the old-time Yale rushers, has begun to assist in coaching the football eleven, and will frequently come from his home in Bridgeport for that purpose. Since the game with Cornell the Yale team's centre, which was a very weak point, has been strengthened by putting Ferris on the conter and Newell on right guard.

LONDON, Oct. 19.--The marriage of Prince Hatzfeldt and Miss Huntington will be solemnized Oct. 28 in the Brompton Oratory, Bishop Patterson will perform the ceremony. The wedding will be a quiet affair. Only particular friends of the two families have been invited.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore lectured at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday morning before the teachers of the City and State of New York. His subject was "Holland-- Amsterdam," and his treatment of it was followed with manifest interest by an audience that filled the lecture room.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 19.--Three routes for that portion of the Mexican Southern Railway lying within the State of Oaxaca are under personal examination by Contractors Read and Campbell of this city and London.

The orthography of our great-grandmothers was uncertain. The old Duchess of Gordon used to say to her cronies: "You know, my dear, when I don't know how to spell a word I always draw a line under it: and if it is spelled wrong it passes for a very good joke, and if it is spelled right it don't matter."--Notes and Queries.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19.--Yale defeated Amherst on the Yale field this afternoon at football by the score of 42 to 0. Yale played with a tentative team, Ferris at centre, Newell at right guard, and McClung at full back. The result was not satisfactory to Yale's supporters. There was much fumbling on the part of the half backs and the rush line was inefficient.

At the Produce Exchange yesterday and on the Street after regular trading hours very extensive speculative trading was reported in wheat options, the aggregate exceeding 10,600,000 bushels, the bulk of it for December and May.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 19.--The E. A.H. Batcheller Co. composition was completed today by the deposit with Elijah George, Register of the Court of Insolvency, of $936,944, the amount required to pay the 75 per cent. of the firm's indeptedness. The creditors will receive their checks Monday or Tuesday.

The Kentucky Club of the college has completed its organization and elected its officers for the year 1889-90 as follows: President--J.R. Todd. '90, of Louisvillie: Vice President--R.A. Watts. '91, Louisville; Secretary--W.H. Witt, '92. Henderson: Treasurer--L.A. Young, '92, Louisville.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--The unknown man who was arrested last night on suspicion of having had a hand in the murder of Dr. Cronin was released this morning. He was believed to have been the man who drove the doctor from his home the night of May 4, but Mrs. Conklin and Frank Scanlon failed to identify him and he was released. Capt. Schuettler refused to give the man's name.

"Exile" John J. McBride, who recently sent to the Right Hon. William E. Gladstone a testimonial containinig the names of 2,000 prominent Americans who sympathize with that statesman's efforts on behalf of home rule, is now preparing a second testimonial of the same kind. Yesterday he secured for it the signature of Vice President Morton.
Several months have passed since the chronicle informed the world of Prof. Willoughby's alleged mirage photograph, "The Silent City," said to have been taken at Glacier Bay, in Alaska.

Public Works Commissioner Thomas F. Gilroy in his report to the Mayor for the quarter ended Sept. 30 shows that the expenditures of the department were $1,086,123.16, of which $766,885.65 was on the appropriation account, $251,507.96 on the local improvement fund, $55,455.57 on the Croton water fund, and $12,273.99 on special funds.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct 19.--The annual report of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Road for the year ending June 30, 1889, has been received in the corrected form by the State Commissioners.

James Fagan, a carpenter residing with his three motherless children at 32 Adelphi-street, Brooklyn, fell from the coping of the New-York approach to the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday, striking on a pile of stones fifty feet below in an area, and was instantly killed.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19.--Drafts, sight, 15; telegraphic, 20.

CAPE CHARLES, Va., Oct. 19.--Ex-Congressman William L. Scott's horses, including Chaos, which won the great purse of $63,000, will winter on his big farm near here. Preparations are being made to receive them. This town is largely the creation of the Pennsylvania millionaire.
LISBON, Oct. 19.--The King of Portugal died at 11 o'clock this morning.

Those who really knew Wilkie Collins recall with sadness his singular kindness and charity of heart, and the singleness and simplicity of his character, his trustful nature, his old-world courtesy of manner, his entire freedom from anything like literary envy or jealousy, and his tenderness for all dumb creatures.

It is announced from Pittsburg that Miss Kate Drexel, a daughter of the late Francis A. Drexel of this city, who has been in retreat at the Mother House of the Sisters of Mercy in Pittsburg since June, has finally decided to embrace a religious life, and will take the veil next month, probably within three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--Archbishop Corrigan has informed the rector of the Catholic University of America that Mr. V. Loubat of New-York has ordered a colossal statue of Leo XIII., to be executed in Carrara marble by one of the leading sculptors of Italy, and will present it to the university next October.

This is the fiftieth year of ex-Gov. Alonzo Garcelon's practice of medicine in Lewiston. Now seventy-six years old, he is constantly at work, driving from fifteen to forty miles every day.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 19.--The twenty-five mile bicycle road race handicap came off this afternoon under favorable conditions of weather and road. The course was from Guthrie's Lane to Hare's Corner, said to be six and a quarter miles, the riders having to make two round trips. There were twenty-three starters, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Brooklyn, Newport, R.I., and Vineland, N.J., being represented, in addition to local riders.

A bare quorum of the World's Fair Finance Committee attended its meeting at the Chamber of Commerce at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. It remained in session nearly two hours, discussing with much animation the report of C. S. Brice, M.K. Jesup, and William Steinway, the sub-committee appointed to prepare World's Fair subscription lists.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 19.--The Mercer County Republican Convention to-day renominated John D. Rue for State Senator and John W. Cornell for Surrogate. Dr. Cornelius Shepherd having declined the Democratic Senatorial nomination, Charles Y. Bamford has been substituted for him.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19.--The Princeton football team played their third game of the season this afternoon on the Athletic's grounds. The opposing eleven was the Stevens Institute team, who returned to Hoboken carrying a score of 49 points against them, while they failed to tally a single point.

A sincere desire to expedite business was manifest in the deliberations of the General Convention yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Campbell Fair of West Michigan recited morning prayer, and then the House of Deputies entered upon the task of clearing the docket of reports of special and standing committees.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 19.--The trial of Frank Brenish, for the murder of his wife in July last, came to an end this afternoon, the jury finding the defendant guilty of murder. Sentence was deferred.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 19.--President Garfied of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, being asked to-day with reference to the prospects of the proposed new national association, stated that no one knew anything about it save a few disaffected Bostonians.

The last consignment of the Barnum show will sail for London to-day on the Anchor Line steamer Furnessia. It will have taken five ships to transport the show. A number of agents sailed on the City of Rome Sept. 20.

CHAMBERSBURG, Penn., Oct. 19.--An equity suit was begun here to-day between the two factions of the United Brethren Church, which has been prepared as a test case, and will, in all likelihood, decide the ownership of hundreds of valuable church properties in this and other States.

POCAHONTAS, Va., Oct. 19.--Capt. Philip W. McKinney, the Democratic nominee for Governor, to-day began his tour of the far-off counties of the southwestern border of this State. Two weeks ago it was reported to the Democratic State Committee that Mahone was making a bush whacking campaigh in the close counties of this section.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 19.--The chestnut crop in Connecticnt is practically a failure. The little nuts are scarce and costly, and those in most of the markets are from the West. It is one of the poorest seasons for chestnuts ever known in this State.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 19.--The fifty-fifth annual convention of the Delta Upsilon college fraternity will be held during the coming week with the chapter at Syracuse University.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., Oct. 19.--Mrs. Louisa Smith, wife of a hack driver, rushed from her house this morning with a bullet wound under her ear and said her husband had shot her. The husband, Joseph Smith, was found in the house dead.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y. Oct. 19.--A special election was held here to-day to determine whether the city would bond itself for a municipal electric-light plant. CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--At the afternoon session to-day the work of the Inter-Seminary Alliance Convention ended. The Committee on Resolutions reported in favor of supporting the "students' volunteer missionary movement" and recommending the Soudan as an important missionary field. It also recommended the ap- pointment of lay missions, and especially medical missionaries, by the Mission Boards.

CHERRY VALLEY, N.Y., Oct. 19.--Uriah Provough, a young man eighteen years of age, living in Salt Springville, a small hamlet four miles from here, white shooting squirrels from the porch of his residence accidentally dropped his gun, which was discharged and blew off the entire top of his head. The charge entered his head below the left ear, coming out above the opposite ear.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 19.--"Dan" Rice, the famous old showman, and his wife, have been is court this week as plaintiffs in an interesting suit. Edward H. Emmons, proprietor of the Merchants' Hotel at Long Branch, was the defendant. Rice and his wife boarded at the hotel and neglected to pay their board bill. Emmons thereupon seized two trunks belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Rice. They began suit to recover their goods.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 19.--The steamer Hudson from New-York reports that at 5:30 P.M. on the 15th inst. George Filoon, a steerage passenger, jumped overboard and was drowned. He was a bricklayer and had been in the employ of Provost Wightman at Schuyler's Falls.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--A morning paper has the following: "One of the most gigantic trusts ever organized in this country is about to be formed. The protection of men-of-war from the effects of lightning has reduced casualties from that cause in a remarkable degree. In fifty years before the introduction of lightning rods over two hundred English men-of-war were struck, while from 1810 to 1815 only forty-eight vessels were more or less damaged.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18.--"Grandma" Brown of Winsted was 100 years old Thursday, and her friends made up a purse for her of $1 for each year of her life. Last week Mrs. Brown fell and broke her collar bone.

The Junior Class and the Sophomore Class both held meetings this week for the election off officers. The Juniors elected the following named gentlemen: President--W.C. Sampson: Vice President-- A.W. Hopper; Secretary--Philip Betts; Treasurer--T.M. Hopper; Historian--C.W. Hulst. The Sophomores selected the following officers: President--E.C. Hazard; Vice President--Drury W. Cooper: Secretary--H. ALLENTOWN, Penn., Oct. 19.--The Committee on Missions of the Reformed Synod, in session here, reported that the income of the last year aggregated $19,576, being slightly in excess of the previous year, while the number of missions was about the same.

Some good prices were brought at a sale of modern paintings at Palen's auction room, 290 Fifth-avenue, last Friday night. There were 61 pictures in the collection and they sold for a total of $11,387.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 20, via Galveston.--At a late hour last night Minister of Finance Dublan, speaking of the bond robbery, stated that everything would be cleared up on Monday. The Minister of Justice insisted that the bonds had not been found.

There was a large crowd at Ridgewood Park yesterday to see the Brooklyn and Baltimore Cubs play an exhibition game. Although the Brooklyns had some raw material in their ranks, they won the game.

The appointment of Commodore Francis M. Ramsay, commandant of the New-York Navy Yard, to succeed Acting Rear Admiral Walker as head of the Bureau of Navigation in the Navy Department, by President Harrison Saturday, gives very general satisfaction.

A man went to the house of Caleb Dunn, at 198 East One Hundred and Twenty-sixthstreet, on Thursday night and told him that his niece, who lives a few blocks away, was very sick. Mr. and Mrs. Dunn hurried away and found the niece all right.

BERLIN, Oct. 20.--While Prince William of Wurtemberg was driving to church at Ludwigsburg to-day he was fired at by a man named Klaiber, who, upon being arrasted, exclaimed, "It is high time Wurtemberg had a Catholic King." The Prince was not hurt. The wouldbe assassin is supposed to be deranged.

An interesting exhibition of lantern-slide views was given by the members of the Brooklyn Academy of Photography in the Hoagland Laboratory last week, the members of the academy contributing views taken on their Summer trips and vacations.
AILSA CRAIG, Ontario, Oct. 20.--The outbuildings of Robert Norton, near here, were burned to-day. His seven-year-old boy perished in the flames.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 20.--Mr. R. R. Dobell of Quebec is here to interview the Dominion Government in regard to his scheme for constructing a cable from Ireland to Canada, via the Straits of Belle Isle. He has succeeded in organizing a syndicate of English capitatists, under the title of the Canada Atlantic Telegraph Company. Mr. Dobell says the cable will be laid next Spring.
There was such a rush for the "Giants'" benefit at the Broadway Theatre last night that the management was forced to stop selling tickets of admission almost as soon as the performance began.

Mrs. Agnes Hochstetter, one of the victims of the Mount Auburn incline plane accident last Tuesday, died at the Cincinnati Hospital yesterday of injuries caused by the crash of the car at the bottom of the incline. Miss Lillie Oskamp and Mr. Joseph McFadden, who were also injured, are doing well, with a fair and much improved prospect of recovery.

An electrician and contractor who has put in several alternating current plants in this and other cities talked freely with a TIMES reporter yesterday of the tripartite contest now going on here in which the light companies, the Board of Eleatrical Control, and the Subway Construction Company represent the three interests at stake.

LONDON, Oct. 20.--Discount was quiet during the past week at 3 to 2 . Business on the Stock Exchange was dull. The enormous settlement just concluded left dealers listless toward fresh business, and realizations by weak operators added to the depression.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--The Washington Post has interviewed at some length several members of the Fifty-first Congress, in order to ascertain their views about what will be accomplished by the Congress.

W.J. Scanlan, the young Irish comedian and vocalist, will follow the Jefferson-Florence company at the Star Theatre, Nov. 11, for an engagement of four weeks. He will open with a special production of "Myles Aroon," which will be given with new scenery and new costumes. This will be Mr. Scanlan's first appearance in this city since his recent starring tour of England, Ireland, and Scotland.

The Rev. W.H.P. Faunce, who has been chosen to succeed the Rev. Dr. Armitage as the pastor of the Fifth-Avenue Baptist Church, yesterday delivered his inaugural sermon and was received into the church with the usual ceremony.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 20.--The Brotherhood of Baseball Players is, in reality, backed by the magnates of the National League, and Spalding, Conant, Billings, and Soden are prepared to advance the money necessary to float the young association for the season of 1890.

Wilhelm Pfeffer, a German pocketbook maker, was found dead, and Morris Redding, a Norwegian fresco painter, was found unconscious yeaterday morning in a room occupied by them on the third floor of the flat house 206 East Thirty-fourth-street. The cause was inhalation of illuminating gas from an open burner in the room.
NASSAU, N.P., Oct. 14.--General trade is dull. The sponge market, however, is brisk, but only small quantities are being offered. Good prices are obtained.

Dr. Talmage was seen at his home yesterday afternoon by a TIMES reporter and was enthusiastic about the site selected for his Tabernacle. It is in just exactly the right plane, he said, just in the centre of the district to which the increasing tide of population is tending, and could not possibly be improved upon.

A number of small burglaries has taken place recently in Sing Sing, within sight of the prison walls. Early yesterday morning Leonard A. Ganoung, whose residence is at the corner of Ellis-place and Churchill-street, went to the dining room on the first floor, and there found things in confusion. Samuel Titlar lives in the same house.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20.--The Sabbath was indeed a day of much-needed rest to the delegates to the International American Congress. Eighteen days ago they started from the city of Washington.

The subject of Prof. Cromwell's lecture at the Bijou Theatre last night was "London," and the list of stereopticon illustrations extended from Westminster to Whitechapel, and depicted all phases of high and low life. The auditorium was filled by an appreciative audience, which frequently interrupted the lecturer with applause.
Incoming vessels yesterday brought further news of the ravages of the recent storms. The steam schooner Louis Bucki, from Jacksonville, was caught in a heavy northeasterly gale on Oct. 15.

Blauvelt of Easton, Penn., will be installed as pastor of the church at Franklin Park, to which he was recently called.

Mary Power, an immigrant girl, arrived on the Teutonic on Oct. 10. She had a ticket for San Francisco, but went to visit some friends in this city. Yesterday a young man, giving his name as James Walsh, presented a check for the girl's trunk at Castle Garden.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 20.--The discussions of the last week prove that Senator Griggs of Passaic reckoned somewhat without his host when he threw himself into the arena of the railroad tax discussion a few days ago.

John J. Clancey, head clerk of the Western Union Telegraph office at 8 West Twenty-thirdstreet, was charged in Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday by the manager, Patrick J. Casey with stealing various sums of money aggregating $1,500. The accused was remanded until further examination of the books is made.

Among the passengers of the French steamship La Gascogne, which arrived yesterday from Havre, were Benjamin Constant, the Count and Countesss d'Aramon, R.L. Cutting and family, Dr. A. Derivaux, Dr. J.M. Gomez, Gen. de Trobriand, Pascal Derrive, and James H. Clarke.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20.--A novel feature of the agricultural fair held last week at Windsor, Broome County, was an offer of premiums for a contest in speed, open to farmers' daughters only, in harnessing as well as driving horses.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 20.--The preliminary arrangements for the taking of the United States census for 1890 are already being made in Connecticut. The State has been divided into two districts, the line running west of Hartford and Middlesex Counties. In 1880 the population of the State was 622,709. The estimated increase for the decade is about 30 per cent.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 20.--Another Yale student died at the New-Haven Hospital to-day of typhoid fever--Thomas Joseph Roberts of Scranton, Penn.

Bishop Randolph of Virginia occupied the pulpit at Grace Church last night. He preached a sermon to the Evangelical Educational Society, which is now in annual session here. Many of the delegates were in the church. He spoke of the difficulties and dangers that beset the young theological student, and also of his encouragements.

What may prove a fatal shooting case happaned in the Fifth Police Precinct on the wast side before daylight yesterday morning. It is peculiar because it demonstrated a new danger for New-Yorkers while the streets are left in darkness by the suspension of electric highting. In this case an innocent man was shot by a policeman who was pursuing a fugitive.

Like a mighty army the churchless congregation of Dr. Talmage's Brooklyn Tabernacle rallied about their pastor yesterday, and in numbers and enthusiasm gave evidence of their cordial sympathy for him and their hearty desire to aid him in the work of replacing the edifice destroyed the Sunday before.
Bethany Presbyterian Church, on Halseystreet, near Howard-avenue, Brooklyn, had every reason to congratulate itself yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 20.--A special to the Times from Wichita, Kan., says: "An attempt was made at 10 o'clock this morning to wreck a passenger train on the Rock Island Railroad, fifteen miles east of McFarland, Kan. A strong piece of timber was placed in an upright position in a culvert, the end portruding five feet above the tracks.

ROME, Oct. 20.--The Pope to-day gave audience to a party of French pilgrims and delivered an address to them. He appeared feeble and his voice was almost inaudible. In his address he urged the necessity of religion for the masses, and said that the Papacy was a protector of the working classes. He also reiterated his protests against the attitude of the Italian Government toward the Papacy.
