PITTSBURG, Oct. 20.--The scarcity of railroad cars is causing an advance in coke. Furnace men through the Ohio Valley are offering $2 per ton for it, and cannot get a full supply at that price. Three months ago it was $1.

BELGRADE, Oct. 20.--The Skuptschina was formally opened to-day. M. Ristics read a message from the Regents which declared that Servia's relations with all foreign powers were friendly and that the Regents desire to cultivate harmony and guard the independent development of the Balkans.

A woman chasing a man and a six-year-old boy down Carmine-street crying lustily "Stop thief!" at every step called together a crowd and a policeman on Saturday. The trio stood up before Justice Gorman, in Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday and told their stories.

When the three-masted schooner L.Q.C. Wishart of Bridgeton, N.J., which left here at 2:30 o'clock Saturday afternoon for Virginia, was about ten miles off Barnegat, N.J., a quarrel occurred between Curtis Maddix and George A. Phillips, colored hands on the schooner, during which Maddix drew a pistol and shot Phillips in the neck.

LIMA, Oct. 20, via Galveston.--The Grace bondholders' contract, with all modifications, was finally approved yesterday at a joint session of Senators and Deputies. The two houses also approved an extensive irrigation scheme for Piura and a water service for Paita.

LISBON, Oct. 20.--The funeral of the late King will take place in the Royal Pantheon probably Saturday next. Monday next the body, accompanied by the royal family, will be taken to Belem, where it will lie in state in the monastery of the Church of St. Jerome.

The Central Labor Union did not succeed yesterday in effecting a fusion with the Central Labor Federation. Delegate Barr reported that there were still some obstacles in the way of consolidation, as the Central Labor Federation had admitted to membership several organizations that had been suspended from the Central Labor Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--The report of the board which investigated the Pension Office, at Secretary Noble's order, has been made public. Its examination covered the months of December, 1888, and January to July, inclusive, 1889.

The Executive Committee of the Legislative Reform Party held a meeting yesterday and indorsed the nominations of John J. Murphy for Assemblyman in the Fifteenth Assembly District, and of John Keegan for Assemblyman in the Seventeenth District.

One of the finest exhibits of Fall importations is that made by W. J. Sloane Co., at Broadway and Nineteenth-street. Ladies who visit the store go into ecstasies over the magnificent carpets, tapestries, portieres, and furnishings.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20.--The week at the Chicago playhouses has been a prosperous one, cool weather and a good class of attractions contributing to that end; indeed, the attractions thus far this season have been above the average.

COLUMBUS, Ohioi, Oct. 20.--Gov. Foraker caught a severe cold at Sandusky last Thursday night and was compelled to leave his office here on Friday noon for his residence. Yesterday morning he was a very sick man, and peritonitis was threatened. Last night he was much better, and has continued to improve during the day. Other speakers will fill his appointments until he has fully recovered.

Miss Adelaide Phelps Thompson, a sister of Joseph H. Thompson, a wholesale tobacco merchant of 83 Front-street, committed suicide yesterday morning by jumping from the thirdstory window of her brother's house at 77 Hancock-street, Brooklyn.
The Rev. R. Heber Newton appeared in the pulpit of All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday for the first time after the long Summer vacation.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 20.--It is now believed that Charles A. King, the United States Express agent who disappeared from here on Monday last, is a defaulter. Newark detectives went to New-York to-day with Cashier Sanford and had an interview with President Platt at the FifthAvenue Hotel. King has been seen in NewYork by some of the company's officers. They refuse, however, to say anything on the subject, and deny that any money has been stolen.

Mrs. Agnes Elliott, the wife of ex-Patrolman James Elliott, formerly of the Thirty-first Precinct, amused herself last night by smashing a large pane of plate glass in the door of a small restaurant in West Third-street, near Broadway, which she claims is kept by her husband. This is the third time that she has indulged in the same performance.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 20.--As the Rev. A. Judson Barrett, D.D., pastor of the LakeAvenue Baptist Church, was walking to that place of worship about 7 o'clock to-night, he was seen to fall to the ground, and before any examination of his condition could be made he was dead. His death was probably due to apoplexy.

The Young Men's Democratic Clubs of NewYork State will hold a convention in Parlor A of the Hoffman House at noon to-day. President John Boyd Thacher of Albany will preside.

The Olympics have declared another war with the amateur branch of the california Athletic Club, and will not allow its athletes to compete in games given under the Olympic Athletic Club's management.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Oct. 21.--The prevailing great distress among the farmers in the Northwest has roused them almost to a fury, and at the meeting of the Legislature they will demand a strict usury law.

stock market bears had a jubilee yesterday Every raid they made was successful, and they made many. The club they wielded most forcibly, and most effectively was the continuing threat of a tight money market.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 21.--John A. Thomas of Moravia, the Democratic nominee for member of Assembly in the Second Gayuga District, has discovered that because he is Postmaster of Moravia he is ineligible to the office of Assemblyman, and has withdrawn.

After a long period of wandering in provincial theatres Mr. Antonio Pastor, gay, rotund, and debonair, returned to his own place of amusement last night and was accorded a most florid welcome both as regards the bouquets and the applause.

Mrs. Wilhelmina Standinger has brought suit in the Superior Court against her mother-in-law, Mrs. Mary Ann Staudinger, for $50,000 for alienating the affections of her husband, Rudolph A. Standinger. According to the complaint the elder Mrs. Standinger will not allow her son to live with his wife.

There was very heavy speculative trading in wheat on the Produce Exchange yesterday, over 17,750,000 bushels changing hands. Of this amount 8,700,000 bushels were for December and over 8,350,000 bushels for May.

VAN WERT, Ohio, Oct. 21.--The residences of George Kessler, six miles south of this town, was burned Sunday evening. His daughter, aged six, perished in the flames and his sisterin-law, a young woman who was doing housework, was so severely burned that she died today. The fire was caused by the explosion of a lamp. Kessler and his wife were absent at the time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Coupon fours, $60, $330, $650, $4,000, at 127; registered fours, $32,000, $2,800, $10,000, $500, $7,500, $83,000, $5,000 at 127; coupon four and a halfs, $3,000, $200, at 105 ; registered four and a halfs, $30,000, $10,000, $45,000, $37,000 at 105 .

Probably very few of the audience at Palmer's last night who remembered Forrest in his muscular and boisterous prime failed to be reminded of him upon the first appearance of Salvini as the Gladiator, and, indeed, at intervals throughout the play.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 21.--The kirmess dances were opened to-night at the Lyceum Theatre. The society leaders of this city have been busily engaged preparing this entertainment all the Fall, and its successful opening was assured.

RHINELANDER, Wis., Oct. 21.--Edward Hicks, a conductor on the Soo Road, was killed yesterday morning at Bradley. His train was standing on the track, when he was run into by another train. He jumped from his caboose, but the collision lifted the cabbose oft the track and threw it directly upon Hicks, crushing him. Both freight trains were badly wrecked.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct.21.--The Senior Class of Rutgers College to-day made its appointments for Class Day. Arthur F. Mahon of New-Brunswick was made Class President; Alexander Van Wagoner of Paterson, Orator; Harry J. Scudder of Saugerties, Historian, and Warren A. Mahon of New-Brunswick, Poet.

LONDON, Oct. 21.--A company has been formed here for the purpose of erecting a tower in London on the Eiffel plan. The tower is to be 1,250 feet high. Five hundred pounds is offered as a prize for the best design for the proposed tower, and 250 for the second best design. The competition is open to the world.

A dispatch from Albany announced the fact yeaterday that Gov. Hill had again granted a respite to the eondemned murderer Charles Giblin, now awaiting execution at the Tombs. The time fixed for the hanging of Giblin was Oct. 24. The action of the Governor puts it thirty days further off-Nov. 23.
Judge Andrews called together yesterday the counsel in the proceedings to enjoin the city from interfering with the electric light wires, and pointed out some discrepancies in the paper submitted.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 21.--There were some developments to-day in the case of Frank A. Daiger of the firm of Daiger Jackson of Baltimore, who is accused by his partner of closing the firm's business and shipping the goods to this city without his knowledge. The goods were shipped to Cosack Co., lithographers, of this city.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 21.--American boodlers resident in Canada were rejoicing a few days ago over the announcement that the imperial authorities had refused to assent to the Weldon Extradition bill passed last session by the Dominion Parliament.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--The Grand Jury to-day considered the case of James J. West and Charles E. Graham, held by Justice Brayton on a charge of fraudulently over-issuing stock of the Chicago Times Company, and found an indictment against them.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 21.--Mahone has recently had a conference with some of his leaders with the allegod object of devising means for having the vote of his men counted on the day of election.
Every now and then some member of the Cotton Exchange carries off the Chronicle, the leading trade paper and reliance of men in the cotton business.

The members of the Presbyterian Union and guests to the number of about four hundred held the first of their series of sociables in the Assembly Rooms at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening.

Col. William L. Brown was nominated for State Senator in the Fifth District by the Tammany Senatorial Convention held at 8 Beachstreet yesterday afternoon. Congressman Frank T. Fitzgerald, nominee on the Tammany ticket for Register, called the convention to order, and George W. Ellis of Richmond County was made Chairman.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21.--Dr. Daniel Ayres, Emeritus Professor of Clinical Surgery in the Long Island College Hospital, last April added to his many endowments $25,000 to Wesleyan University, at Middletown, toward the establishment of a chair in biology.

At its final session as a Board of Missions, held last evening in St. George's Church, the General Convention referred to the Board of Managers, with kindly and encouraging approbation, resolutions presented by the Rev. Paulus Moort, recommending that presbyters and deacons ...

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Oct. 21.--The citizens of Johnstown have raised $5,000 to continue the search for the dead. James McMillen of the Cambria Iron Company and A.J. Moxham of the Johnson Company subscribed $1,000 each.

Last night's performance of "The Drum Major" at the Casino signalized the seventh anniversary of the opening of that popular place of amusement. The audience was a large one, as usual, and the principals in tha cast received some beautiful floral tributes.
The rainfall yesterday morning was sufficiently heavy to convert the Elizabeth track of the New-Jersey Jockey Club into a very undesirable spot for racing.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 21.--The political situation in Dutehess County is badly "jarred," so far as the Democratic Party is concerned, and it looks as if the Republicans are going to make a clean sweep in November, not only in this, but also in Putnam and Columbia Counties.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21.--At a meeting of the Freshman Class to-day R.H. Warren of New-York was elected President, E.Y. Thorp of New-Jersey vice President, R.V. Buckley of Pennsylvania Secretary, C.A. Newton of NewYork Treasurer, and G. Chapin of New-Jersey historian.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 21.--Gov. Hill returned from the South yesterday afternoon. He was too tired to talk much, but said he had a pleasant time. He speaks in glowing terms of the South and its resources.
Two Philadelphia journals have curiously similar comments to make on the appointment to TANNER's place of Gen. RAUM.

Beethoven Lodge of Masons began its fair at the German Masonic Temple, 220 East Fifteenth-street, last night. The proceeds of the entertainment, which is to be oven every night this week, as well as this afteernoon and on Thursday and Saturday afternoons, will go toward aiding the widows' and orphans' fund of the lodge.

ALBANY, Oct. 21.--Prof. Melvil Dewey, Director of the State Library, made a discovery while in Paris. He has arrived at home after an extended tour of the famous libraries of Europe, which he made with the view of gathering ideas as to the best mode of conducting New-York's big and valuable library. He comes back well paid for his trouble, he says.

Leonard W. Jerome, who has served as President of the New-York Jockey Club since its organization, yesterday resigned his position, and H. De Courcy Forbes was elected as his successor by the Directors of the club:

The Central Railroad of New-Jersey is erecting a fine new ten-story office building on Weststreet, opposite the company's ferry slip. According to the plans the new building will be a great improvement on the old style which prevails in that part of the city.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 21.--Another sensation has been spoiled. A statement was widely telegraphed from here to the effect that Mr. Chisholm of Chicago, Ill., proposed to apply to the Dominion Senate for a divorce from Mrs. ...
BOSTON, Oct. 21.--Richard Mansfield presented at the Globe Theatre in this city to-night the play of "Richard III," as it was produced by him early in this year at the Globe Theatre in London.

The following members of the World's Fair Finance Committee attended its meeting at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon: Samuel D. Babcock, August Belmont, Calvin S. Brice, John H. Inman, Morris K. Jesup, Eugene ...
BRUSSELS, Oct. 21.--The miners of Borinage, Mons, and Pets demand a 20 per cent. increase of wages. If this is not granted the men will strike.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 21.--A horse car with seven passengers had a narrow escape last night at the East Jersey-street crossing of the Long Branch Railroad. The car was in charge of Driver Packenham, one of the most careful men on the road, and to his presence of mind is chiefly due the prevention of a frightful accident.

The address delivered by the Pope to a party of French pilgrims on Sunday, as it is the latest, is the most authoritative of the expressions that show the disposition of the Roman Catholic Church to take sides rather with "labor" than with "capital" in any conflict of the two that may arise between employers and employed.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Oct. 21.--With solemn ceremony the body of the late Gen. John F. Hartranft was consigned to the grave in Montgomary Cemetery this afternoon. In the morning private services, according to the ritual of the Protestant Episcopal Church, were held at ...

EASTON, Penn., Oct. 21.--The trial of William H. Bartholomew for the murder of Washington Dillard was stopped suddenly about noon today by Mrs. Dillard (who is charged with complicity in the murder) coming into court with Sheriff Miller, determined to go on the stand ...

Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court yesterday issued an attachment in a suit for $200,000 damages brought by James C. Fagan against Hector D. Mackay, Rafael G. Martinez, and Charles K. Ruiz, composing, the firm of Mackay Co. Fagan alleges that in November, 1888, he made an agreement with Mackay Co. in regard to surveying lands in Michoacan and Sinaloa, Mexico.

LONDON, Oct. 22.--The correspondent of the Daily News at Constantinople, speaking of the trial of Moussa Bey, says that the United States Legation complained to the Minister of Justice that the court officials and the presiding magistrate fawned upon Moussa Bey and browbeat the witnesses against him.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21.--The British steamer Laro, Capt. Chisholm, which sailed for Rotterdam on Saturday, ran ashore this morning in the cut-off channel above Bodkin Island, caused by the steering gear breaking. She will have to be lightered.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 21.--The following letter was received to-day by Mr. Preston Belvin, President of the Powhatan Democratic Club, this city, from ex-President Groves Cleveland:
ALBANY, Oct. 21.--The following business was transacted in the Firat Division of the Court of Appeals to-day:

Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday issued a writ of habeas corpus for the production of Amos Cross, who, according to the petition for the writ, is confined in the Butler Asylum at Providence, R.I.

Miss Ida F. Newcombe, daughter of Mr. Richard S. Newcombe of the law firm of Donchue, Newcombe Cardoza, at 96 Broadway, was on Saturday married to George Washington Lederer, business manager of Herrmann's Transatlantique Vaudevilles, the company now ...

Members of the Cotton Exchange were yesterday greatly incensed over the appointment of Oscar F. Williams as Consul at Havre. None of them knew the gentleman, and that was the reason why they were feeling annoved.
ATHENS, Oct. 21.--Ex-Empress Frederick and her daughters, including Princess Sophia, the fiancee of the Crown Prince of Greece, will arrive at Corinth on the steamer Imperatrix Thursday evening.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21.--The status of colored veterans with the Grand Army in Con necticut has been disclosed with special emphasis during the past week in this city by the course of Nathaniel Lyon Post toward the application of an upright colored soldier for membership.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21.--The Emma Juch Grand English Opera Company made its first appearance as an organization at the academy of Music to-night, presenting "Faust," with the following cast: Faust, Charles Hedmondt; ...

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 21.--The dry goods and clothing house of B.F. Kahler Co. was closed to-day by the Sheriff on the foreclosure of a mortgage for about $13,000 held by the National Exchange Bank of Augusta.

A committee of conference was requested yesterday by the House of Bishops on the question of the adjournment of the General Convention on Thursday, as voted by the House of Deputies, it being the belief of the former that the important subjects remaining to be considered could not be disposed of in the three days remaining of the session.

Judge Wallace of the United States Circuit Court for the Northern District of New-York has rendered a decision in the petition of Morris and the American Live Stock Transportation Company for a mandamus against the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 21.--At Tappan this afternoon John Tailman and wire of Rochland County celebrated the seventieth anniversary of their wedding with a large company of friends. Mr. and Mrs. Tallman's daughter is the wife of Charles W. Bradley, Superintendent of the West Shore Railroad. All the parties live at Tappan.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 21.--The Republicans of this city held a big mass meeting the Opera House to-night, at which Gen. Grubb, their Gubernatorial candidate, made an address. Speeches were made by ex-Senetor Griggs of Peterson, John S. Gibson of Dover, John H Conger, the Republican candidate for County Clerk, and others.

Candidates and orators were present in force at last night's meeting of the Republican Club, and this fact, in connection with the expected report on the proposed new clubhouse, brought out a good attendance.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21.--The seven survivors of the ill-fated steamer Earnmoor of the Earn line, which foundered at sea on Sept. 5 in a cyclone, when 300 miles off Turk's Island, bound from Baltimore to Rio Janeiro, arrived in this city to-day from New-York, to which port they were brought this morning by the steamer Santiago from Nassau. They tell a story of terrible suffering.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 21.--On Saturday the unconscious body of William A. Carter, a cadet of the Third Class, United States Military Academy, was found in the woods at West Point. He was conveyed to the hospital, and had not up to this afternoon recovered consciousness.

The Rev. Dr. Maynard will begin his eleventh year at Chickering Hall on Wednesday afternoon of next week, and will during the Winter deliver ten illustrated lectures on foreign lands. Dr. Maynard has been for many years instructing the ear and the eye, developing in the minds of his hearers an interest in the places and historical events of the older countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21.--Serafino Aposto today pleased guilty to murder in the second degree in causing the death of vincenzo Perroni by stabbing during a quarrel in June last. Aposto was sentenced to six years' imprisonment. George Hall, colored, also pleaded guilty to murder in the second degree in causing the death of his wife last May by stabbing her while he was intoxicated. He was sentenced to ten years' imprisonment.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 21.--Warren Shipman, confined in the county jail at Herkimer on a charge of highway robbery, made a desperate attempt to break jail early this morning. Sheriff Morey heard a noise in the jail, and called on an Under Sheriff to go with him and find out the cause.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21.--Baltimore is in the midst of her biennial fight for the control of the City Government. The contest is clearly defined. The regular Democrats, masquerading under the title of the Business Men's Association, have put forth Robert C. Davidson, a successful financial manager of a big dry goods ...

The people of this city are evidently sincere in their efforts to help complete the Washington Memorial Arch fund, as each day brings forth now and substantial encouragenent, which tends to strengthen the confidence in the working committee.

Assemblyman "Silver Dollar" Smith was placed on trial in the Court of General Sessions before Judge Martine yesterday, charged with bribing voters in the Eighth Assembly District on election day last year.

The report of the President of the Iron Steamboat Company, which has just been issued to the stockholders, shows how a careful management can achieve a success in the face of many difficulties, and the declaration of a cash dividend of $2 per share payable on and after Nov. 1 is good news to those interested in the welfare of the company.
Lieut. William H. Schuetze, United States Navy, is at the St. James Hotel. Speaker Fremont Cole of Watkins, N.Y., is at the Grand Union Hotel.

The Republicans of the Twelfth Senatorial District, comprising Westchester and Rockland Counties, met in convention yesterday at the Orawaupum Hotel, White Plains, for the purpose of nominating a candidate for Senator. Capt. James Milward of Yonkers was elected Chairman.

Yesterday fire at Larabee, Penn., destroyed J.J. Newman's saw mill and 3,000,000 feet of lumber; loss, $24,000. J.C. French's store; loss, $6,500; two barns and ten tons of hay belonging to D.C. Young; loss, $2,000, and Mrs. D.C. Smith's boarding house; loss, $800. The fire caught in a heap of sawdust near the mill furnace. The loss on mill and lumber is covered by insurance.

A gas jet left burning all night in Nelson E. Campbell's dry goods store, 1,025 Third-avenue, Brooklyn, at 1:45 yesterday morning set fire to some ribbons hanging near, and in a few moments the rear of the store was in a blaze. Campbell lived over the store.
WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 21.--An Associated Press reporter who visited the scene of the oil excitement in the new field near Mannington, Marion County, returned to-night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--Five different times to-day the Cronin jury was complete unless the talesman on the stand at the moment was subjected to a peremptory challenge. Three times the prosecution interposed and twice the defense.

BOSTON, Oct. 21.--While workmen were engaged rearranging the old records in the Probate Court House at Salem this afternoon a lot of old papers, supposed to have been left by the late Hon. James Kimball, were discovered in a vault utilized for the storage of county documents by the Commissioners. Among the records found were several witchcraft documents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--When Admiral Franklin called the International Marine Conference to order this morning at the beginning of the second week's proceedings there were but few vacant chairs around the conference table.

The Grand Duke Nicholas for many months past has remained in the strictest seclusion, refusing to see eyes the members of his family and permitting only his doctors and confidential attendants to have access to the darkened apartments in which he is spending the sad eventide of his life.

The County Convention met at 3 o'clock at the Athenaeum and was called to order by John P. Adams. He quickly gave way to Patrick Keady, who was elected Chairman. John A. Clary and Jacob New were made Secretaries and a committee on resolutions was appointed.

It was cabled from London yesterday that the announcement had been made there of the organization of the Metropolitan Trading Association, which proposes to run a line of freight steamers between London and Galveston and other Southern ports.

The above city and county tickets were nominated by the Democrats of Brooklyn and Kings County yesterday. Alfred C. Chapin developed last night into a leader of the Brooklyn Democracy. He not only forced his own renomination as Mayor on the managers who accepted him with great hesitation two years ago, but ...

Sixteen new members to the Corinthian Mosquito Fleet were elected at a meeting held last evening in the Sturtevant House. They are Thomas M. Cahill, Jr., J.C. Summers, W.G. Newman, J. Seymour, J. Neilson, Paul Butler, Dr. F.B. Bronson, Dr. Sidney Bishop, Dr. F.S. Grant, C.M. Bird G.G. Murray, F.B. Lewis, G.A. Stow, and G.G. Stow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--A bigger house even than that which saw the first representation of "Erminie," in this city, greeted Mr. Rudolph Aroneon's capital company at McVicker's this evening, when "The Brigands" was introduced to the Chicago public.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of this city, which, excepting the seminary in Cincinnati, is the only institution in the United States devoted solely to the preparation of students for the Jewish ministry, opened the first term of its new year yesterday.

The privilege of viewing a very large and beautiful collection of specimens of Oriental art is afforded any person who chooses to enter the show rooms of A.A. Vantine Co., at Broadway and Eighteenth-street. Here the visitor will encounter a display which, while entirely ...

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 21.--The various wire goods companies of Worcester, it is reported, have entered into a combination with the leading Eastern manufacturers of wire goods to raise the price of their manufactures, especially of those relating to household utensils. Mr. Hamblin of Hamblin Russell this afternoon did not deny the report to a Gazette reporter, but was reticent regarding details.

Heyman Shapiro, the boy who was recently committed to the New-York Juvenile Asylum, was last night returned to his father by the asylum's Committee of Indentures and Discharges. Theron G. Strong, Chairman of this committee, thus explained the whole affair to a TIMES reporter:

There was a penetrating quality in the atmosphere yesterday morning which forcibly reminded everybody that an overcoat would be comfortable. In fact, there were those who hinted of frost as the day wore on.

The steamship St. Ronans, Capt. Campbell, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool brought news of the racing steamships City of New-York of the Inman Line and the Teutonic of the White Star Line, which left this port for Liverpool last Wednesday morning.
Steamship Alvena, (Br.,) McKay, Aspinwall, Port Limon, and Fortune Island 12 ds., with mdse, to Pim, Forwood Co. Arrived at the Bar at 6:20 A.M.

Tammany's Committee of Twenty-four had a long meeting yesterday afternoon, and the resolution relative to union on legislative candidates, passed by the County Democracy's convention on Saturday, was before ...

M.A. Green caught the largest German trout Friday that has ever been taken from a stream in this country. The fish weighed six and onehalf pounds, measured twenty-five inches, and contained over five thousand eggs, which are now in water at the Caledonia fish hatchery.

The Athletic Club defeated the Philadelphia team 9 to 0 yesterday. Base hit--Athletic, 11; Philadelphia, 2. Errors--Athletic, 3; Phildelphia, 3. Batteries--Sandere and Decker, Seward and Robinson. Umpires--Messrs. Curry and Connell.

The fifth annual ball of the Edward J. Rapp Association brought together a large and merry gathering last night in Concordia Assembly Rooms. The programme embraced the usual selection of waltzes, polkas, lancers, quadrilles, , with an hour's intermission at midnight for supper.
Every day that the ring that rules Jersey City and Hudson County continues in power gives new proof of its corrupt practices and in satiable greed.
BLACK RIVER FALLS, Wis., Oct. 21.--Forest fires are doing a large amount of damage just west of here. Many acres of young timber are being destroyed.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21.--Drafts, sight, 15; telegraphic, 20.

Two gentlemen, both from New-York State, have to-night been announced as being chosen to places in the Consular Service, but no one out of the State Department appears to be able to give any information concerning them.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 21.--Judge Gibson this afternoon granted the petition of William Grant Everhart for a change of name to William Grant Hart. The petitioner alleged that his father had disgraced his name by permitting his infant child to die from neglect, so that he might not be hampered with it in his marriage to a woman in Buffalo, whom he married immediately upon the death of his first wife.
There was a double funeral yesterday after noon in the little Church of St. James the Less at Scarsdale.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct, 21.--Over three hundred members of the Synod of New-Jersey met in Educational Hall this afternoon at the opening session of the Synod's sixty-sixth annual meeting.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 21.--L.B. Rea of Miles City, Montana, a member of the Montana Legislature, who is in the city, says in Western Montana the grass is literally withered away for want of rain.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 21.--The opposition to the candidacy of L.W. Emerson of Warrensburg, for the nomination of Senator in this (the Nineteenth) district at the Republican Convention at Port Henry to-morrow has assumed form here.

Annie Green, the thirteen-year-old daughter of Carpenter Green of Kearny, N.J., who was found unconscious in the rear of her parents' house, after a day's absence, a few evenings ago, and who afterward claimed to have been beaten and robbed of $60, has at last told the truth.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 21.--The condition of Gov. Foraker is substantially the same as yesterday, although he appears somewhat stronger to-night. His physicians forbid him seeing any sellers or to discuss political work.

The new British war ship Royal Sovereign work upon which has begun at Portsmouth Dock Yard, will, it is said, be the largest war-ship in the world. The vessel is to be completed for sea, with all guns and stores on board, by 1893.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 22.--At the First Assembly district Republican Convention of Union County this afternoon Assemblyman Voorhees positively refused a renomination and was followed by County Collector Wood, James McMaster, and J.E. Hedges, each of whom declined to stand.

The Democratic Convention in the Third Assembly District, Brooklyn, consisting of delegates from the Third and Tenth Wards, met last night and nominated John Cooney to succeed Peter K. McCann who has represented the district for five years. The convention had been in a deadlock since Thursday night, McCann and Cooney each having three delegates.
The new play at Daly's is successful beyond all doubt. It will easily hold the stage until the revival of "As You Like It," which, it is now announced, will probably be early in December.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 22.--In two cases in which decisions were handed down by the Supreme Court to-day, the opinion having been prepared by Judge Given, several old features and some new ones of the prohibitory law are passed upon.

LIMA, Oct. 22, via Galveston.--In order to complete the plan for Peru's economic restoration and the re-establishment of the national credit initiated by the Grace bondholders' contract, as well as to profit by the consequent extension of railways and augmentation of industry, ...

A representative assemblage filled the parlors of Mr. Hugh R. Garden's residence, 14 West Fifty-third-street, last evening at the reception tendered by him to Bishop Thomas U. Dudley of Kentucky. Bishop George W. Peterkin of West Virginia, and Bishop Alfred W. Randolph ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22.--The twenty-second annual convention of Railroad Conductors' Life Insurance Association of the United States and Canada met here to-day, 100 delegates being present, President C.C. Whitaker and B.A. French delivered addresses. Chattanooga was selected as the place for holding the next annual convention.

The meeting of the World's Fair Committee on Site and Buildings in THE TIMES Building yesterday afternoon was devoted chiefly to the consideration in executive session of letters received from property owners within the boundaries of the site.

When the woolen manufacturers at their recent annual meeting gave up the tariff contest with the wool barons of Ohio, into which they had entered with such extraordinary show of courage--for them--it was generally supposed that the surrender was abject and complete.

In the Superior Court at Boston yesterday the jury returned a verdict of $9,000 in favor of the plaintiff in the case of Willis against the Merchants and Miners' Transportation Company, an action brought by the heirs of Mr. Willis three years ago to recover damages for his death, caused by the steamer Chatham coming into collision with the yacht Ethel in Boston Harbor.

A difference which arose about a year ago between two factions of the Lafayette German Sunday School Association of Jersey City has ripened into a legal contest according to the latest reports. A number of members of the association, representing, it is said, 130 out of the 250 shares of stock in the association, had virtually seceded from it and formed a church of their own.

Physicians, clergymen, sanitarians, hygiene experts, and others of kindred pursuits to the number of nearly two hundred composed the gathering at the Brooklyn Institute on Washington-street yesterday, at the opening of the seventeenth annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

Brooklyn voters had their last opportunity to register yesterday, and 51,432 availed themselves of it. The total registration for the year was thereby increased to 133,352, an increase of about 4,000 over the registration of the last Mayoralty year, 1887. It was, of course, a falling off from the registration of last year, when a Presidential canvass was in progress.

Lewis C. Tufts made an individual assignment yesterday to M.B. Richardson. He was the senior partner of the firm of L.C. Tufts Co., manufacturers of moldings, at 119 and 121 Elm-street, and operated on his own account in Harlem real estate, claiming to be worth, a few years ago, $75,000.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22.--William E. Wheeler, a Stratford coal dealer, fell from a tugboat in the harbor at Stratford to-day and was drowned. The tug had a coal barge in tow and Mr. Wheeler was attempting to untie the rope, when he lost his balance and fell into the water. The body has not yet been recovered. Mr. Wheeler was about fifty years of age.

The Republican County Convention will be held in Essex County, N.J., this afternoon. The primaries held Monday night favored the nomination of ex-Speaker Schuyler B. Jackson for Surrogate. J.W. Von Giessen of Montclair is the only one mentioned for Director at Large of the Board of Freeholders.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22.--A special to the Post-Dispatch says the residence of ex-Mayor Ballard at Lexington, Mo., was burned last night, and Mrs. Ballard, who was of unsound mind, perished in the flames. She was alone in the house, and it is supposed that she set fire to it and then went back to bed, as her charred remains were found in the debris of her room this morning.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 22.--A special to the Union from Johnstown says: "Extensive operations with paper bearing forged indorsements of prominent Fulton and Montgomery County people, including Congressman Sanford and Assemblyman Brownell, became known to-day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 22.--The sixteenth annual convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Connecticut was begun in the Pearl-Street Congregational Church in this city this afternoon, and will last until Thursday noon.
A considerable stir was made in theological circles yesterday by the announcement that the Presbyterian Review would suspend publication with the October number.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 22.--The Synod of New-Jersey met in Educational Hall here this morning. Devotional services were conducted by the Moderator, the Rev. Henry M. Storrs, D.D., of Orange.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 22.--The students of Rutgers College have been on the warpath to-day. Last night the Sophomores and Freshmen had two cane rushes on Georgestreet, in which neither side came out victor, and early this morning, before the rest of the ...

The citizens' mass-meeting for the purpose of nominating a ticket in opposition to Tammany will be held to-night in the Grand Opera House Hall. This is the small, hall back of the Opera House proper sometimes used for small political gatherings.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Oct. 22.--The veterans of the Seventeenth Connecticut Regiment this morning dedicated their twenty-foot granite shaft on the southeast side of Cemetery Hill. The Rev. Beverly E. Warner of Bridgeport, Conn., offered the prayer, Sergt. Patrick Wade, Jr., of Bridgeport presented the monument, Miss Henrietta Huss of Mount Vernon, N.Y., ...
The League of Young Men's Democratic Clubs of New-York State met at the Hoffman House yesterday.

At the meeting of the Duluth (Minn.) Chamber of Commerce yesterday a communication was presented from L.T. Hunt, a capitalist of Springfield, Mo., asking the co-operation of the Chamber in the formation of the Saline Pass and Duluth Railway, in which he has heavy money backing.
The New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor has elected the following officers for the current year:
William F. Ladd has on exhibition at his store, 104 Broadway, two antique porcelain china vases that possess considerable historic interest. They are 18 inches in height and over 100 years old.

EASTON, Penn., Oct, 22.--The jury in the case of William H. Bartholomew, charged with the murder of Aaron W. Dillard, came in this evening after being out an hour and a half and handed up a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree.
An important change was announced as being under consideration and about to be put in practice yesterday by the Oregon Improvement Company.

Gen. James W. Husted of Westchester County met a member of the Washington Memorial Arch Fund Committee recently and said: "I want to subscribe to that patriotic work, I wish I could give a thousand dollars, but I can't, so I give in accordance with my means.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 22.--The man who claims that he is Lord Hinton, a real live English peer, with a pedigree as long as a rope and family record that almost equals it, passed through this city yesterday on his way to New-Orleans.

The testimony in defense of Assemblyman Charles Smith, who is on trial in the Court of General Sessions, charged with bribing voters last election day, was introduced for the purpose of proving an alibi.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22.--A complete jury was secured in the Cronin case late this afternoon. When this work had been finished the State's Attorney asked for an adjournment for two days in order to give the prosecution time to make out a plan for the presentation of its case. The defense objected, and Judge McConnell compromised by adjourning the hearing until Thursday morning.

The Edison Electric Light Company held its annual meeting yesterday, and added two important names to its Board of Directors. Henry Villard was elected in place of A.J. Thomas, and Samuel Insull in place of F.R. Upton. The board is now composod as follows: Thomas C. Buck, C.H. Coster, Noah Davis, John W. Doano, Thomas A. Edison, J.H. Herrick, E.H. Johnson, M.H. Smith, F.S. Smithers, Henry Villard, Spencer Trask, Samuel Insull, and J. Hood Wright.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 22.--The Republicans of the Third Assembly District of Middlesex County, at their convention at Old Bridge to-day, nominated D.M. Kane by acclamation for the Assembly. Mr. Kane is the Assemblyman who introduced the Ballot Reform bill in the last Legislature.
A meeting will be held on next Monday evening at Kirchoff's Hall, 529 Ninth-avenue, for the purpose of organizing a co-operative stock company to run a steamboat to the fishing banks next season.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 22.--The Seventh Day Adventist Conference in session here is attended by delegates from twenty-eight States and Territories and Canada, Mrs. Ellen G. White, "The Prophetess," is present, and is still the spiritual and intellectual leader of this sect.

Master Otto Hegner, the musical prodigy imported by Messrs. Abbey, Schoefiel Grau for the entertainment of the American public, received a warm welcome down the bay when the steamship Fulda arrived yesterday, bringing the boy and his father.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 22.--It has been a very lively day at Cornell. The Senior election was the most closely contested in years. The principal officer, the President, having only six majority out of 194 votes cast, this being the largest Senior Class Cornell has ever had.

DUBLIN, Oct. 22.--Father Matthew, Prior of the Order of Capuchins at Cork, accompanied by Father Marsio, sailed for New-York on the steamer Alaska, which left Queenstown Oct. 20.

The appointment of Commodore Ramsay as chief of the Bureau of Navigation is considered a very good one by many navy people. Commodore Ramsay has enjoyed a good deal of shore duty, and in one way or another has always managed to obtain most desirable stations.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Oct. 22.--The work of removing the unknown dead and their reinterment in a plot especially for that purpose is progressing. It is the intention to erect neat headstones at each grave, and a full description of each body, with a memorandum of every article likely to lead to identification, will be kept in a permanent record.

Residents along Twenty-eighth and Twentyninth streets have been somewhat surprised by a beginning at track laying made by the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth-street Railroad Company during the past few days.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 22.--Judge Thurman was found at his home to-night by THE TIMES correspondent, suffering severely from rheumatic pains.
Riley Allen Brick, a well-known iron manu facturer, was seized with apoplexy yesterday morning in a Third-avenue street car near Eighteenth-street.

The West Point cadets has an opportunity to show Gen. Sherman how they can drill Monday. Accompanied by Walker Blaine and Miss Margaret Blaine, the General went on board the Government steamer Chester A. Arthur at the foot of West Fortieth-street and steamed up to the Academy.

William Daniels, a married man of forty-eight years, fired six shots at his sister Mary yesterday in an attempt upon her life. One of the balls passed through her shoulder and another struck her in the head just above the right temple.
Messrs. Le Boutillier Brothers of Broadway and Fourteenth-street are creating a great stir among shoppers by the extraordinary bargains they are now offering.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 22.--Firebugs are again at work here. On Sunday evening they burned the nearly completed residence of David Warren. Since the fire Mr. Warren has not been seen or heard of, and his friends believe that he was burned in the building.

O'Connor of the Third District, Brooklyn, and Assemblyman Aspinall of the Eleventh, both of whom were denied a renomination by the Republicans because of their opposition to Platt, made formal announcements yesterday of their intention to run in their respective districts as independent candidates.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 22.--The extensive negro element of this place is again deeply agitated over the color line question, and it is thought that the present excitement may have a great effect on the colored vote in the approaching election. An indignation meeting was held in Morrow's Hall, West Park, last night.

Capt. H.B. Trout of the tugboat Bruce reported to the Steamboat Inspectors yesterday that on Monday night an outward-bound ocean steamship had run down the scow which he was to wing and sunk her. Capt. Trout says the accident happened about 6:30 o'clock in the evening, near the Scotland Lightship.

The trial of Charles McElvaine for the murder of Grocer Luca, which has occupied the attention of the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, since Monday of last week, ended yesterday morning, when Judge Moore charged the jury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22.--One of the sensible reforms effected by Mr. E.O. Graves when he was Chief of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing was to stop the indiscriminate rush of visitors to the Bureau of Engraving and Printing.

The nomination by the Republicans of James M. Varnum for Attorney General, satisfactory as it is to all classes and professions, is particularly gratifying to the real estate interests of this city. Mr. Varnum was one of the original members of the Real Estate Exchange and was prominent throughout in its organization.

The three members of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, Mayor Grant, President Arnold of the Board of Aldermen, and President Coleman of the Tax Department, met yesterday in the Mayor's office and spent almost the entire day considering the estimates for the expenses of the city departments for the year 1890.
BERLIN, Oct. 22.--A German protectorate has been proclaimed over the east coast of Africa, from Vitu to Kismaya, with the consent of the native chiefs. The rights of foreigners are preserved.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22.--The friends of Congressman Abner Taylor of the First District may be surprised somewhat at the intelligence now made public for the first time that the statesman has taken unto himself a wife, and furthermore that there is an interesting story in connection with it.

There was filed at the office of the Register of Deeds yesterday a mortgage signed by Florence E. Maybrick, the central figure in London's recent poisoning case. The mortgage is given to Richard S. Cleaver of the firm of Cleaver, Holden Co., solicitors of Liverpool.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22.--Dr. J.L. Posey of the Marine Hospital Service, on duty at Jacksonville, Fla., telegraphs to the bureau that Dr. Porter reports another sporadic case of yellow fever at Key West, Fla., and in consequence quarantine restrictions have been resumed.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 22.--A Princeton team, composed of Sophomores, were defeated in a game of football with Lawrenceville to-day by a score of 26 to 0. George, last year's centre rush on the Princeton team, played the same position on the Lawrenceville eleven to-day. He is in good training and will play his usual excellent game for the orange and black in the championship games this Fall.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 22.--The Mercer Gun Club opened their second annual tournament on the club's grounds, about two miles from the city, to-day.

The Philadelphia Club defeated the Athletics, 3 to 1, yesterday in six innings. Base hits--Philadelphia, 4; Athletic, 6. Errors--Philadelphia, 1; Athletic, 6. Batteries--Day and Decker, McMahon and Cross. Umpires--Messrs. Curry and Connell.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22.--The trades display begun here to-day celebrating the completion of the Knoxville, Cumberland Gap and Louisville Railroad was more of a success than was anticipated.

Coroner Levy was summoned to ChambersStreet Hospital at 8:30 last evening to take an ante-mortem statement of William F. Campbell, the young man who was shot by Policeman Patrick T. Morris in the saloon of John Campbell, at West and Morris streets, late Monday night.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 22.--The New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company is the first coal mining corporation to introduce electric motors in place of mules for traction purposes in its mines. An electric motor was set at work last week in the Erie Company's Hillsdale coal mine, near Forest City, Penn.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 22.--The annual meeting of the Grand Division of the Sons of Temperance of Western New-York was held here today. Many members of the order from different parts of the State were present. The session closed this evening.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich, Oct. 22.--Fireman John Hadden and Engineer Thomas Callahan of the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railway, whose homes are in this city, were blown from the cab at 5 o'clock this morning near Hascall's, Ind., by a bursting boiler head. Fireman Hadden was blown ten rods and instantly killed. Callahan is fatally inured.

The Daniel McEntee Association, a political and social organization of the Eleventh Assembly District, is getting ready for its annual ball which will occur next Monday evening at Lyric Hall.
OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 22.--As a result of the Union Pacific board meeting in Boston last week an almost entire reorganization is announced of the official staff at headquarters.

The venerable Isaac Wildrick, known throughout the State of New-Jersey as the "Patriarch of the New-Jersey House of Assembly," died at his home near Blairstown, N.J., on Monday. He had been declining for several months. Mr. Wildrick was born on March 3, 1803, in Hardwick Township, then Sussex County.
The setting apart of the western portion of the Diocese of Nebraska as a missionary jurisdiction was yesterday agreed to by the House of Bishops.

LONDON, Oct. 22.--Mr. Gladstone left Hawarden to-day for Southport, where he will speak to-morrow. When the train upon which he traveled reached Chester a large crown that had leathered about the station cheered him. Mr. Gladstone made a short speech in which he said he hoped that in the political contest in Great Britain the right side would soon be uppermost.

A small audience listened in the hall of the New-York College for the Training of Teachers, 9 University-place, yesterday afternoon, to an interesting lecture by the Rev. Charles E. Lord, D.D., of Newburyport, Mass., under the auspices of the New-York Academy of Anthropology.

A tenant of 143 West Twenty-sixth-street, a four-story tenement house which is occupied by five colored families, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning found that the house was on fire and aroused the inmates, who succeeded in putting out the fire without calling on the firemen.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct 22.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad was held here to-day.

A fine day brought several thousand people to the race track of the New-Jersey Jockey Club yesterday afternoon to see the six races that wound up the inaugural meeting of the NewJersey Jockey Club decided.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22.--Considerable progress was made at the morning session of the International Marine Conference to-day in consideration of the "Rules of the Road."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22.--The second biennial conference of the Young Women's Christian Associations of the United States and Canada began this afternoon at the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association. Mrs. C.E. Beebe presided. Delegates were reported from fifty associations, an increase of twelve during the past two years.

Wall-street was surcharged with blueness yesterday morning. There was a widespread apprehension that something of a most disastrous nature was about to happen. The bear sucessess of Monday, when the whole list weakened and ran off, had the effect of spreading demoralization all around.
Officers of the Navy Department are chagrined at another delay in the completion of Torpedo Boat No. 1.

LONDON, Oct. 22.--Mr. Charles Bradlaugh, the well known political and social reformer, and member of the House of Commons for Northampton, is very ill, and it is feared that he is dying. He is suffering from congestion of the lungs, and has a high fever.

At 9:20 o'clock last night Park Policeman Thomas J. O'Connor found a young girl lying in the bushes near Seventy-seventh-street on the East Drive. Thinking she was intoxicated he began shaking her when a two-ounce bottle having a strong odor of chloroform fell from the folds of her dress.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 22.--A big Democratic meeting was held at Hirtzel's Hall, Elizabethport, to-night. Ex-Assemblyman Mathews presided, and all the prominent party leaders in the city were on the platform.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 22.--Horace Phillips, formerly manager of the Pittsburg Baseball Club, who has been confined in the insane asylum at Merchantville, N.J., for the past three months, has entirely recovered his reason and will be released from the asylum on Thursday. Dr. Foster, his physician, says his malady was not paresis, but acute mania.

The Brooklyn Democrats began their campaign work in earnest yesterday and arranged for public meetings on every night, except Sundays, from now until election day. Mayor Chapin and District Attorney Ridgway will appear in every ward in the city, and the former expects to make over half a dozen formal addresses.

Dr. Benjamin Franklin of New-Jersey, the majority of which went over for the consideration of the next session of the convention in 1892.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 22.--At their annual reunion in 1888, the Sullivan County soldiers and sailors who served in the rebellion took measures to raise a fund for the erection of a suitable monument at some central point in the county in honor of their comrades who gave their lives to preserve the Union.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23.--William S. Wallace of New-York, the "October pork man," has at last decided to succumb to the inevitable and abide by the decisions of the courts.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 23.--When the Harrisburg Terminal Railroad Company was chartered a few weeks ago only those who were interested knew for what purpose the corporation was created. Now, however, it is known that the company will build a bridge across the Susquehanna River at this place to link the Philadelphia and Reading with the Harrisburg and Potomac.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 23.--The Times-Democrat's Yazoo City (Miss.) special says: "The steamboat Gamma, Capt. D. C. White commanding, sunk this morning at French Bend, Yazoo River, below Greenwood. This was her second season. She was run in the interest of the Yazoo Oil Mill, and valued at $10,000 and was, partially insured. She can probably be raised."

An unknown man shot himself last night in Eighty-seventh-street, near Ninth-avenue. The report of the pistol attracted a policeman, who found the man lying dead upon the sidewalk with a bullet hole through his head.

Francis B. McMahon, who declares that he is a private detective, was held for examination yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court on a charge of swindling made by Charles Bulkley, President of the Whiting Manufacturing Company. Mr. Bulkley said in court that some time ago he engaged McMahon to ferret out the thief who had stolen some $600 worth of metal from his company.

The question of who can be given the title of Colonel with propriety in Kentucky has at last been settled by a competent authority. By the latest rule every man who conducts a large distillery is ipso facto a Colonel. Every prominent railroad official is also a Colonel.
Mr. Henry E. Abbey and Marcus Mayer, with the boy pianist, Otto Hegner, called upon Mayor Grant yesterday afternoon to get a permit allowing the boy to perform in public.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 23.--McDowell did not resume to-day in the bicycle contest. The scores at the close were: Dingley, 434 miles 10 laps; Rhodes, 424 miles 9 laps; Desmond, 388 miles 7 laps. At present Rhodes seems to be running easiest. The five-mile amateur race was won by D. Nasmith of the Toronto Wanderers.
It is rarely that the good people of the quiet little hamlet of Jamaica, L. I., are so effectually aroused from their semi-lethargic condition as was the case yesterday.

PORT AU PRINCE, Hayti, Oct. 8.--There is still no Government in Hayti, except, of course, the provisional affair created and sprung ready made on the country by the recent revolution. The Constitutional Assembly has been in session at Gonaives since the 24th of September.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 23.--Mrs. Walter Burke of Delaware-street, Elizabethport, had a fight for life with half a dozen savage dogs last night. She was walking past John Socta's place, when his dog, a ferocious mastiff, leaped upon her, knocking the woman down and biting her savagely.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 23.--F. M. Hoyt, a fine-looking, middle-aged stranger, was arrested this afternoon charged with obtaining money by false pretenses. The warrant was sworn out by Mrs. Julia Hunt, a widow from Defuniak, Fla. He went there two months ago, representing himself to be a detective, and by promising to marry her be got possession of her entire estate, which he sold and came to Louisville. He also secured $815 in cash from her.

UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 23.--Lyman Davis, aged 114, the oldest man in this valley died in the town of Salisbury yesterday. He was a farmer and had lived in Salisbury for nearly a century. He remembered well events of 100 years ago. One daughter, Mrs. George Carlisle of Little Falls, survives him.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23.--Henry S. Todd, a commuter who did business in New-York, met a terrible death at the Brick Church Station of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad this evening. He attempted to alight from a moving train and lost his footing. His head struck against the side of the car as he fell and he was hurled beneath the wheels. His body was terribly mangled. Mr. Todd was a salesman for Brokaw Brothers.

A collision occurred just outside of City Island harbor yesterday afternoon between the schooners Charles H. Sprague and Annie R. Lewis. The Sprague was bound from Hoboken for Boston with a load of coal, and she carried away her flying jibboom and all her headgear. The Lewis was also laden with coal bound for Bucksport, Me. Her injuries were very slight. Both vessels will undergo repairs at City Island.

LYNN, Mass., Oct. 25.--This forenoon there was a praise meeting of the Universalists from 8 to 9 o'clock, when the business of the General Convention was resumed. A committee to send greeting to the Unitarian Convention at Philadelphia was appointed.

SING SING, N. Y., Oct. 25.--Francis Mulhern was sentenced Oct. 25, 1886, to four years in Sing Sing Prison for assaulting his wife. His term of imprisonment expired to-day.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 25.--A three-year-old son of John Syers of 1,146 East Grand-street, was terribly burned last night, and it is feared, cannot recover. Mrs. Syers rushed to his assistance ana tried to tear the flaming garments from his body. She finally succeeded, but was severely burned on the hands and arms.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Oct. 26.--At this point on the Southwestern plains, 2,600 feet above sea level, the Santa Fe and Hays City trails crossed each other in days gone by. The Hays City trail had its beginning in Texas, and over it thousands of cattle were driven annually by semi-barbaric cowboys. The Kansas Pacific was the only overland railroad then, and Hays City enjoyed the distinotion of being the principal shipping point for Texas-grown cattle.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 26.--An alarming rumor is current in this city to-night that the training ship Portsmouth has met with a serious mishap and is now being towed, in a helpless condition, into the harbor of New-York.

MONTICELLO, Ill., Oct. 26--Diphtheria has made its appearance in Cisco, in this county, and throughout Central Illinois. At Illiopolis the public schools have been closed on account of the disease and several deaths are reported. There were two deaths reported to-day at Decatur, two at Greenville, and several at other places. It is said to be caused by the decaying vegetation.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 26.--The fire which broke out in the steamship Harrogate at midnight Thursday was in the forward compartment, in which 1,400 bales of cotton were stored. The fire was got under control yesterday morning. The ship was not damaged. The damage to cotton by fire and water is estimated at $20,000. It belonged mainly to Rail Brothers and Strauss Co., and is fully covered by insurance.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 27.--Politics here is as lively just now as it ever is in an off year. All the nominations have been made by both parties and issues are fairly joined.

NEWARA, N.J., Oct. 27.--Ernest Kimpka was arrested this morning on board a steamship at Hoboken, Kimpka was the proprietor of a hidedressing establishment in Hamburg-place. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27.--James Wood McLane, Jr., the son of the New-York physician, who died at his home in New-York Saturday night, was a member of the Yale Freshman Class. He was taken ill with typhoid fever last week and went home on the advice of his father.

The United States steamer Kearsarge arrived yesterday. She left Port au Prince on Oct. 8 and reached the Delaware Breakwater several days ago. Upon her arrival here she proceeded to the navy yard in Brooklyn. The Kearsarge is under the charge of Commander Whiting. She carries 195 officers and men, and mounts seven guns.

SELMA, Ala., Oct. 27--A fire broke out in Liepold Brothers' dry goods establishment on Broad-street, in the centre of the business portion of the city, about 2 o'clock this morning. The people were all asleep and the fire had gained great headway before it was discovered.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union James P. Archibald was elected Chairman for the day. About nine months ago the Central Labor Union declared that it would not have him as a delegate because he had persisted in taking an active part in politics in the support of President Cleveland.

LONDON, Oct. 27.--Discount was easy during the past week at 3 to 2 . Business on the Stock Exchange was inactive. The flood of new enterprises weakens established stocks, causing realizations and diverting capital into fresh channels.

The stage at Dockstader's Theatre was occupied yesterday afternoon by an assemblage of a somewhat different character from that which is usually seen there. It was composed of representatives of the New-York Temperance Union and their guests, who intend to reopen their campaign against intoxicating beverages by meeting at this place every week.

A loyal New-Yorker, just returned from the West, sends me this squib: "The other day in Chicago I was asked if I would like to see the site of the great World's Fair. Being a Gothamite, I, of course, replied: 'You will have to come to New-York to see that.'

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27.--City Attorney Dailey to-day stopped a Southern England Telephone construction gang from working on the telephone lines, because they were violating an old Connecticut Sabbath law. They were allowed to proceed with the work at sundown.

A number of vessels which reached this port yesterday brought news of the ravages of the recent gales. Capt. Ingram of the steamship Benefactor, from Wilmington, says that at 3 P.M. last Friday, when southeast by east of Body's Island, he sighted a vessel which was flying signals of distress.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27.--According to advices received from Honolulu to-day, there are four American men-of-war vessels stationed at that port--the Iroquois, Mohican, Nipsic, and Alert--the Iroquois having recently arrived from San Francisco and the Mohican from Callao.
Capt. Newman of the bark Kelvin, which arrived from Rio Janeiro yesterday, says that on Oct. 5, in latitude 13 6' and longitude 55 58', the Kelvin ran into a whale about eighty feet long.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., Oct. 27.--Information was brought by courier to-day from Hamlin, Lincoln County, that about midnight Friday a mob surrounded the Lincoln County Jail, forced an entrance after a short resistance by the authorities, took two of the prisoners, Green McCoy and Milton Haley, and hung them to a ...

BANGOR, Me., Oct. 27.--The most important capture of a smuggler, desperado, and all-round villain which has been effected in this region since the arrests of Bartley, the Moose River terror, and Morrison, the Megantic murderer, took place Thursday on the beach of the St. John River, and on the Amarican side, when one ...
Judge Barnard has filed his decision in the case of Goring against Kennedy to recover damages for injuries received from an accident occasioned by a dog in the possession of the defendant.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 27.--A feud of twenty years' standing was settled yesterday near New-Hampton, the county seat of Chickasaw County, by a general battle, in which two men were killed and several others wounded.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 27.--There was completed yesterday the tallest smoke shaft in America on the grounds of the Fall River Iron Works. The chimney is 340 feet high above the granite base, and is 30 feet square at the bottom. Previous to its completion the tallest smokestack in the country was that recently ...

A family in which five generations were represented was at a christening at Roscoff, in the Department of Finistere, a few days ago. It is true that the youngest member on whose account the gathering in the church had occurred ...

HOTEL AMPERSAND, Oct. 27.--Two weeks of the finest weather ever known in the mountains has been greatly enjoyed by those spending the Fall here. A small amount of snow fell on Tuesday night, which made the country look somewhat like Winter. The mercury has registered as low as 12 during the week, but one would not believe it with the dry, fine air here had they not a thermometer to look at.
Dr. K.A. Claugh, a prominent physician of Denver, Col., was taken to Bellevue Hospital last night suffering from a severe scalp wound. Dr. Claugh has been a sufferer from vertigo and ...
NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 27.--Mr. Thomas W. Palmer of Stonington, who for the past few years has been a commission merchant in New-York, died of apoplexy there while gunning last Friday.

--Houghton, Mifflin Co. will publish next week the eighth and last volume of "The Narrative and Critical History of America," edited by Justin Winson, covering the later history of British, Spanish, and Portuguese America. A full general index is issued with this volume.

It was a little before noon yesterday when the officers of the revenue cutter Manhattan observed a signal of distress, an ensign, union down, flying at half mast from an American ship anchored near Red Hook. As the cutter ranged up alongside of the ship one of her officers sprang over the rail and jumped upon the big vessel's deck.

No apprehension was felt at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday because of the report from Newport that the training ship Portsmouth, which was bound for Newport from the Madeira Islands, had been disabled and was being towed to New-York.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27.--Political circles are much excited over a fight Thursday night between a burly Police Captain and a stalwart Common Councilman, in which the Police Captain got decidedly the worst of it. The Common Councilman is James Park of the Second Ward.

WASHINGTON, Oct 27.--From one canvass of the House of Representatives it is reported that Mr. Reed of Maine leads in the race for the Speakership with fifty-nine votes, while McKinley has fifty-four votes in sight, Cannon of Illinois being third, with thirty-one votes; Burrows fourth, with thirteen, and Henderson of Iowa fifth, with twelve.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 27.--Kentucky, noted for the lawlessness of her county clans, has never had a factional feud that was more bitterly fought, and in which there was less in the way of extenuating circumstances, than the present Howard-Turner war in Harlan.

M. Weyl in Le Yacht has an article on the position of officers in the French Navy with regard to promotion, based on a recent announcement that a certain proportion of midshipmen, instead of becoming Sub-Lieutenants after a fixed period of service, as in the English Navy, must wait for vacancies in the SubLieutenants' list before receiving promotion.
The following yachts have gone into winter quarters at Northport, L.I.: Steam yachts Isolene and Normaid, schooners Columbia and Glimpse, sloops Gracie and Olga.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 27.--The All-Americas party has had a day without a tiresome feature. At 11 o'clock the entire party mounted Concord stages, seating nine people on top. There were six horses before each stage, and a ride in clear sunshine was enjoyed. The greatest smelting works in the world were visited.

Archbishop Ryan said yesterday that Miss Mary Drexel, daughter of the late Francis A. Drexel of this city, would take the white veil in the Convent of Mercy, Pittsburg, on the 6th of next month. Miss Drexel has been trying her vocation as a postulant since the 6th of last May, ...
CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--A dispatch from Washington says that President Harrison has in view the appointment of S.W. Allerton, the wellknown packer, as Collector of the Port of Chicago.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 27.--In a little wooden church, heavily hung with black, and relieved only by the colors of the United States and Portugal, a curious ceremonial was performed today in a foreign tongue over an empty coffin. It was a service in memory of King Luis of Portugal, ...
The Woman Suffrage Party's new State Committee organized Saturday night by re-electing Mrs. M. Louise Thomas, Chairman; Dr. Ida L. Dildine ...
About forty members of the Second Battery, N.G.S.N.Y., under command of Capt. David Wilson, attended service, in uniform, at St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church last evening.

The funeral of Capt. Michael O'Boyle, a veteran or the war, was largely attended yesterday afternoon. Owing to the storm the services were held in the chapel at Calvary Cemetery instead of at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
During his lifetime the late ex-Gov. Nelson Dewey refused information regarding his early life. But two years ago he sketched an outline of his career, which, in his own handwriting, ...

The Rev. Father Mathew and Brother Massio of the Capuchin Order in Cork arrived in this city yesterday on the steamship Alaska. The object of their visit to this country is to solicit funds for the completion of a church which is ...

Sarah Dean of 548 Hudson-street, wife of a furrier who has a place opposite the Charlesstreet station house, was a somnambulist. At 6 o'clock yesterday morning a woman passing out of the alley at 544 Hudson-street stumbled over her body. It was found that Mrs. Dean had walked over the roofs of 548 and 546 Hudson-street and had fallen over the parapet into the alley. Mrs. Dean died at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 27.--The registration in Cincinnati for the November election closed last night. It is estimated that 60,000 have registered, against something over 66,000 last year. The falling off seems uniform throughout the city. In the country precincts, where the registration law was enforced for the first time, it proved very satisfactory, although the number of those registered is not quite so large as the vote last year.

BERLIN, Oct. 27.--The National Zeitung declares that Turkey occupies a solid position in the European concert, and that she enjoys the protection afforded by the Berlin treaty. Regarding Emperor William's coming visit to Constantinople, the paper says that the omission of such an act of courtesy would admit of the worst interpretation.

The concert given at the Broadway Theatre last night by Mr. Nahan Franko in connection with the Musin Concert Company was largely attended, the audience espressing its gratification in earnest and repeated applause.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 27.--The advertising columns of the local press yesterday morning were the most interesting parts of the papers. They were full of warmth and argument. Politics sizzled all over them. It is a feature of local contests that a large part of the campaign funds is spent in advertising.

Mrs. Annie Price, the 525-pound fat woman, who died on Friday night as 19 Bayard-street, where she lived with her husband, the whitehaired albino, was buried in Evergreens Cemetery yesterday. It was decided not to have any funeral service, as it would have collected a big crowd in the street.
CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 28, via Galveston.--A British consular report from Vera Cruz says that one cigar manufacturer alone shipped 50,000 worth of cigars in one year to England.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Oct. 27.--The prospects of Johnstown being again under water are very good. Rain has been falling almost continuously for the past thirty-six hours, and a great many of the street are already almost impassable to pedestrians.

Permit me, Mr. Editor, in reply to questions that frequently come to me, to say in your columns a few words about the two great parties, which ever since the formation of the Government have been contending for supremacy, and something more (trite as it may be regarded) upon the subject which more than anything else now divides them.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 27.--The Democratic Convention for the First Assembly District of Union County, contrary to expectation, passed off in an orderly manner on Saturday night. The party leaders, dismayed at the prospect of a saloon ...

BARNESVILLE, Ga., Oct. 27.--News has just reached here of an attempt to rob and murder the Assistant Tax Collector of Pike, Ed Matthews, Tax Collector Oliver is old and infirm and employs Matthews to assist him, usually leaving the money collected during the day in Matthews's possession.

The Montefiore Home for Incurables held its annual meeting yesterday. Considering the extremely bad weather, the attendance of patrons and members uses very large, doubtless due to the fact that in this meeting, the first held since the Home moved into its new building at One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street and the Boulevard, there was a special interest. The board of officers of last year was unanimously re-elected, as follows:

"THE NEW-YORK TIMES deserves the thanks of all true sportsmen and lovers of nature for its efforts for the preservation of the Adirondack Wilderness," said Mr. Wakeman Holber ton, the well-known artist angler, yesterday.

The New-York Maennerchor opened its Winter festivities last evening with what, according to the programme, was an Abend-Unterhaltung. Perhaps it was, but among those who were fortunate enough to be present there was a prevalent opinion that it should have been called a most delightful evening's entertainment.

In point of fact, California wines are more frequently adulterated at the East than here. Pure wine is so cheap in this State that the temptation to make wine out of lees or dried grapes is small. Some of our wine merchants do doctor their wines by adding water and ...

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 27.--The closing week of the Virginia campaign promises to be unusually exciting. The situation as it presents itself now is merely a question as to the size of the Democratic majority.

The movement to overthrow the corrupt ring that rules and fattens on Jersey City has taken a deeper hold than is apparent on the surface. A TIMES reporter has, within the last week, talked with many substantial citizens of ...
G.M.L. Sacks said last evening that he intends to offer a challenge cup for a team race at crosscountry running. He hopes to arrange a race for this Autumn.

Prof. Jameson's introductory notice is excellent, giving us in concise form a sketch of M. Victor Duruy. Born in 1811 in Paris, Victor Duruy may be said to have been an eye witness of all the events occurring in France from the accession of Louis Philippe up to to-day.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 27.--The Rev. Father Bruns of the Catholic parish of St. John Baptist has incurred the dislike of some of the young men of his congregation for his outspoken condemnation of a ball announced to ...

Gov. Hill and Edward Murphy, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, spent yesterday at the Hoffman House. Chairman Griffin of the State Executive Committee also spent Sunday in town. Roswell P. Flower was a visitor at the hotel and spent some time with the managers of the campaign. They spent most of the time in their rooms and conferred upon the situation.

Harry Liebrecht, a young German who manufactures cigars for a livelihood at 5 Delanceystreet, was held in $1,000 bail by Judge Duffy in Essex Market Police Court yesterday morning. Liebrecht was charged with abducting Rachel Lazarus.

Mahone's name has been hauled down from the masthead of the Spirit of the Valley, at Harrisonburg, a paper edited by Mr. D. Sheffey Lewis, son of ex-Senator Lewis. It is a strong Republican paper, and up to last week had been supporting Mahone, the editor having participated in the convention which nominated him. It gives very emphatic reasons, in vigorous language, why it will no longer aid in his election.

George W. Lederer gave himself up at Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to answer the charge of Clara Binns, or Clara Chester, for abandoning her. He was held in $300 bail for examination on Thursday. Herman Oppenheimer of 426 West Fifty-second-street became his bondsman. His trial for bigamy in the Court of General Sessions will be moved soon.

Unusual attention has been attracted recently to the system in vogue in the civil courts in this county and State of sending cases to referees for trial and report of their findings back to the court by which they were appointed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--It is understood that Secretary Tracy will award the contracts for the three 2,000-ton cruisers to-morrow. Two of them will go to the Columbian Iron Works of Baltimore, and the other to either Harrison Loring of Boston or N.F. Palmer, Jr., Co. of New-York, whose bids were the same.
The Committee of Marshals and Aides of the Centennial Civic and Industrial Parade have completed their arrangements for tendering ...
Ellen Crawford, a septuagenarian widow, who lived with her daughter, Mrs. Mary Brown, who keeps a boarding house at 402 West Fifty-sixthstreet, suffered from asthma.

It is well known to physicians that there are certain diseases that may be said to be self-curing. The trouble caused by them begins and gradually increases until in one form or another the system relieves itself.
