HARTFORD, Oct. 27.--The masculine interest in the curious order of the Connecticut Shakers near Scitico has ebbed to such an extent that outside labor has to be hired to perform the work on the Shaker farms. The Shakers own 3,000 acres of land, divided into three families --the North, South, and Church family.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27.--Mrs. Charles Crocker, the widow of the railroad millionaire, died of apoplexy at her home in California-street, San Francisco, this afternoon. She was about sixty years old and highly esteemed by all. She was very charitable. Her share of her husband's estate has been estimated at nearly $10,000,000. The house in which she died, which was awarded her in Mr. Crocker's will, is one of the finest residences in California.
Samuel Gompers, the nominee of the County Democracy and Republicans for Senator in the Seventh Senatorial District, hes declined the nomination tendered him by both organizations.

About two weeks ago one Berrier killed his mother-in-law at Lexington, N.C., and, on being captured, he was lynched. Gov. Fowle urged Solicitor Long to discover the lynchers, and Long made an affidavit before Judge Phillips on which twenty of the lynchers have been arrested and confined under strong guard. Some of the ringleaders have fled. Much excitement prevails at Lexington.

No nominations were made last night at the Aldermanic Convention of the County Democracy in the Twentieth Assembly District. The convention, after being called to order, adjourned until to-night at 8 o'clock. This was done in order to see what the Republicans in that district intended to do.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--At the opening of the Cronin trial this morning an employe of Patrick Dinan, the liveryman, testified as to the facts of the hiring of the white horse on the evening of the 4th of May, when Dr. Cronin was killed. His evidence did not differ materially from that given by Dinan himself on Saturday, either as to the taking out of the horse or his description of the man.

When the Quarantine officials on Swinburne Island examined the effects of Joseph Fennell, stoutly built, middle aged, a passenger by the steamship Hondo who arrived there Sept. 15 suffering from yellow fever, from which he soon died, they were surprised to find neatly stowed away in his trunk a portable faro outfit consisting of a green barze folding lay-out, ...

LONDON, Oct. 28.--It was learned tonight that word was sent around to the London dailies yesterday asking them not to print any reports their correspondents at Athens might wire about the Prince of Wales's health. The papers here all obeyed the suggestion.

"The Merchant of Venice" was presented at the Broadway Theatre last night with Edwin Booth as Shylock and Helena Modjeska as Portia. Mr. Booth's Shylock is a well-known performance of the character, and the best that this generation has seen or is likely to see. Shylock, to be sure, is not a difficult part nor is its meaning obscure.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 28.--The Republicans of the Fourteenth Senatorial Dstrict, comprising the Counties of Ulster, Greene, and Schoharie, met in convention at Catskill Oct. 25 and made no nomination. The matter was left to a committee. Charles C. Kromer of Schoharie County was tendered the nomination later on. To-day he telegraphed the committee that he had accepted the nomination. Mr. Kromor is editor of the Schoharie Union.

Pim, Forwood Co., the agents of the Atlas Steamship Line, state that their steamer, the Adirondack, which left New-York for Port au Prince on Oct. 10, arrived at her destination four days and sixteen hours later. This is the quickest passage on record between New-York and Port au Prince.

Frank Stevenson, the Bleecker-street sporting man, had his attention called yesterday to a dispatch from Baltimore, stating that he had been engaged in the unlawful business of colonizing voters in that city. The statement, he said, was without foundation, and William E. Harrig, the author of the attack, should be called to account.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 28.--On assembling at 9 o'clock this morning the convention of Locomotive Engineers decided to put in nomination candidates for Grand Chief. The Ohio delegation put in nomination P.M. Arthur. This was followed by the nomination of Mr. Vroman of North Platte, Neb.; Vedder of Sedalia, Mo., and Bellows of Mississippi.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 28.--At a late hour Saturday night William Marks, a brakeman on a New-England freight train, slipped and fell between two cars near Glenham. Both legs were cut off and he died this morning. At 7 o'clock last night an unknown man was struck by a train near Fishkill Landing. He was ground up so fine that the remains were gathered up with a shovel.

Emil Van Gelder, the fugitive diamond dealer, is indirectly responsible for the death of Henry Horwitz, a diamond broker at 17 Maidenlane, who committted suicide in his office yesterday afternoon. Van Gelder cheated Horwitz out of $4,000 worth of diamonds, and Horwitz, ...

There was a particularly lively meeting of telephone subscribers yesterday at the Board of Trade rooms in Liberty-street, at which, in spite of an effort made by the Metropolitan Telephone Company to have action postponed, ...

The trial of Andrew Becker, a Tompkinsville saloon keeper, for the murder of James Conway was begun yesterday in the Richmond County Oyer and Terminer Court before Judge Cullen. The murder was committed in Becker's saloon at Bay and Hannah streets, Tompkinsville, on Sunday morning, Sept. 22. Becker's wife had furnished him with money to run a saloon ...

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 28.--A fast freight on the Pennsylvania Railroad jumped the track at the Main-street crossing to-night. Several persons who were waiting for the train to pass were injured by flying debris, some of them fatally.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28.--Since Malcolm A. McDonald, the son of ex-Senator McDonald, was brought here from Indiana some months ago by the Drexel-Morgan interests and made General Manager of the Pittsburg and Western Railroad Company, he has effected a complete reorganization of that concern.

Coroner Messemer was summoned to Roosevelt Hospital yesterday to take the ante-mortem deposition of Peter Geraghty, a laborer, of 531 West Thirty-sixth-street, who was suffering from a fracture of the base of the skull, the result of violence. The man was unconscious, and his statement could not be obtained.

Mrs. August Schmid writes to THE TIMES that the statement that the father of S.L. Kapff, the despondment japanned goods dealer of 122 Fourth-avenue, who disappeared two or three months ago, was once proprietor of the Lion Brewery is a mistake. Mr. Kapff was for a time the lessee of Lion Park.

Prof. N.L. Britton read a paper last evening before the New-York Academy of Science at Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, on "Ferns and Their Allies, Present and Past." The paper was accompanied with illustrative views of the plants thrown upon a screen: Many handsome groups were exhibited, notably of the tree ferns and maidenhair ferns. Specimens of "club" mosses and "horsetails" were also shown.
ALBANY, Oct. 28.--The election calculators here are at sea. The state of political affairs puzzles the best of them, and predictions as to next week's results are not based on anything tangible.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 28.--It is stated tonight by an officer of the Fort Wayne, Cincinnati and Louisville Railroad that that line has been consolidated with the White Water Valley Road, and that from Harrison, the southern terminus of the White Water, a new road is to be built to Cincinnati. The papers were drawn in this city to-day. The consolidated company has entered into a traffic arrangement with the Mackey system.

A new Tammany club was opened in Harlem last night. The faithful followers have shown their Indian blood by naming their organization the "Massasoit." Its charter members are largely a part of the Tammany contingent which kicked and bolted from the Harlem Democratic Club on account of the County Democracy coloring that organization assumed.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28.--Russell Munro and Walter A. Clench of London, William D. Guthrie of New-York, and Angus Cameron of Cumberland are in this city. They are said to represent a syndicate for the purchase of a wellknown Baltimore brewery, and that negotiations are now under consideration.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 28.--The Journal's Helena (Montana) special says: "The application of the Democrats to the Supreme Court for a writ of mandamus compelling the canvassing board of Silver Bow County to receive and count the rejected returns in the Tunnel district has been denied on technical defects in the application.

The Campaign Committee of the Republican Club has issued a circular urging the members to active work at the pells on election day. They are instructed to report to the Republican Captains of the district and assist them. The Campaign Committee, in another circular, asks the members ...
Two announcements recently made in the London press tend to show why so much English capital has been invested in American industries during the last twelve months.

The Forum for November has an excellent variety of timely and thoughtful papers. Its subjects are of importance to the public, and its contributors are men whose words have weight. President Angell of Ann Arbor discusses with knowledge the rights of this country in Behring Sea; he considers the matter historically and explains its international aspects.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 28.--The circus train of King Franklin was badly wrecked on the Mobile and Girard Branch of the Central system of Georgia early yesterday morning. The wrecked cars were brought to the city last night and repaired. The circus men have decided to sue the road for heavy damages.

PARIS, Oct, 28.--The funeral of Emile Augier took place to-day. The service was held in the Church of the Trinity. Among those present were Premier Tirard, Minister Spuller, and many members of the Academy. An incident that attracted attention was a meeting between the Duc d'Aumale and M. Tirard. The two gentlemen shook hands cordially and conversed together for some time.

BOSTON, Oct. 28.--The police of Station No. 2 still continue their war upon the pool rooms and lottery ticket sellers. To-day officers went to 18 Faneuil Hall square and arrested Charles Haley on the charge of selling lottery tickets, and at the same place arrested William Hayes on the charge of registering bets on races, and also for the alleged selling of pools.

The Health Board milk chemist employs the Wauklin-Waller method for analyzing milk, with a view to obtaining the amount of fat contained in it. Milk inspectors used this method in testing some of the milk of Henry W. Houston, a dealer on Sixth-avenue. The law says that milk must contain not less than 3 per cent of fat, but in Houston's milk, ...

The Berkeley Athletic Club is training a lightweight tug-of-war team. Efforts are being made to have the team pull against a team from the Lorillard Debating and Athletic Association of Jersey City Saturday evening. The Berkeley Gymnasium is being used by a good many members of the club every afternoon and evening, and all who enter it are pleased with Prof. A.E.W. Barker, the club's new gymnastic instructor.

The American Oriental Society will meet tomorrow afternoon in the Greek lecture room (Hamilton Hall, No. 15) of Columbia College. A number of papers will be read. In the evening the members of the society will attend a reception given by Dr. Henry Drisler. Acting President of Columbia, at his residence, 48 West Forty-sixth-street.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 28.--The funeral of the Hon. Jeremiah McGuire, ex-Speaker of the Assembly, was held here to-day. It was attended by a large number of prominent lawyers and representative men from Southern New-York. The Rev. Dr. McKnight and the Rev. Dr. Jennings conducted the services.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 28.--The brutal butch ery of a peaceable German named Jacob Sontag late last night in his own parlor, in the presence of his wife and children, by three desperate Hungarians, who broke into his house, has produced a bitter state of feeling against the filthy Huns.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 28.--Gov. Foraker was not feeling quits as well to-day, and his physician would not permit him to leave the house. All his appointments except that at Cincinnati on Saturday next will be canceled.

From the present outlook the Brotherhood of professional Baseball Players intends to ignore the League officials. At first it was proposed to hold a conference with them, but from a reliable source it was learned yesterday that that idea was dropped, and the players will go it alone. Contrary to rumors, there have been no conferences in this city with capitalists.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 28.--Nothing has been heard from Blount County to-day except that Rube Burrows is still at large and the pursuers need more dogs. An effort is being made to secure dogs here, and if they are obtained a special train will leave with them to-night. The Sheriff of Blount County asked the Governor for help last night, and this morning he sent a train up with twenty picked men.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 28.--To-day, upon receipt of information that Mercie could not furnish the bronze horse and rider for the Lee Monument until the latter part of January, the Lee Monument Board postponed the unveiling until May, 1890.

There was a meeting of those stockholders in the Fifth-Avenue Transportation Company who object to the permanence of the control which is now exercised by the pious Col. Elliott F. Shepard held in the office of Barnes Brothers at 18 New-street yesterday afternoon.

With a purpose as indefinite as a mass of conflicting testimony could make it, the twelve worthy jurors who for a week past have been listening to evidence in the so-called Feeks investigation straggled one by one into Room 21 City Hall yesterday. At 11:30 o'clock, all having arrived, court was called to order and the jurors took proper and necessary precautions ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--The President to-day made the following appointment:

Archbishop Corrigan ordained two young ecclesiastical students at 7 o'clock yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral, James Fitz simmons and William Kelly, both born in this city. Fathers Fitzsimmons and Kelly would have been participants in the Christmas ordinations in the Catholic seminary at Troy, but this ...

Inspector Williams made a preliminary examination yesterday into the case of Roundsman Thomas Cassidy of the Twenty-first Precinct, who was complained of by Terence McMahon, the proprietor of an oyster saloon and restaurant at 499 Third-avenue, for having arrested an employe for an alleged violation of the excise law.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 28.--With reference to a dispatch from Washington stating that on and after Nov. 1 packages containing mailable liquids, fatty substances, confections, and pastes shall be admitted to the mails exchanged between Canada and the United States, provided they are put up in the manner prescribed ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 28.--As THE TIMES stated this morning, there is great dissatisfaction in this district, the Second Monroe, over the renomination by the Republicans of the Hon. Joseph Bauer for the Assembly. The city of Rochester, It is believed, should have a more worthy representative, without reference to ...

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28.--The handsome twohundred-and-fifty-dollar can offered by the graduates as a prize for kicking the football has been won by Denison, '90. Johnson and Trafford tied for second place.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28.--A special to the Post-Dispatch from Abilene. Kan., says: "The Abilene Bank, owned by Mayor C.H. Lebold and Col. J.M. Fisher, suspended this morning, creating great excitement, as it has been considered the strongest financial institution in Centrel Kansas. Deposits amount to $200,000, principally local.

The will of Mrs. Jane Antoinette Gibson has been filed for probate in the Surrogate's Court. It was executed on Jan. 28, 1887, and some of its provisions were changed by a codicil executed last May. The executors and trustees are the testator's nephew, the Rev. Dr. Cornelius R. Duffie; her son-in-law, william Jaffray, and her grandson, Issac Gibson Jaffray.
Steamship Hermann, (Belg.,) Meyer, Antwerp 22 ds., via Boston, with mdse. to Funch, Edye Co. Arrived at the Bar at 7:45 P.M.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct 28.--The Courier-Journal correspondent telegraphs from Pineville to-night as follows:

Dr. Matthew Wolf, whose office is at 608 Broadway, Brooklyn, was a prisoner in the Fourteenth Precinct Station House last night, charged with assault with intent to kill, and standing a very fair chance of being tried at an early date for murder. He is a young man, about thirty-five, and has a wife and family.

Edward Garner, an old leather merchant of eighty, who lived at 117 Sands-street, Brooklyn, became ill in a bridge train while on his way to Brooklyn at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon and died before a physician could reach him. Heart disease was the immediate cause of death.

Miss Annie Russell, a native of the Transvaal Republic, in South Africa, delivered a lecture before the American Geographical Society at Chickering Hall last evening, on South African republics, their races, and progress. This is Miss Russell's second appearance before a NewYork audience, she having lectured in this city ...

Dockstader gave an unusually entertaining programme at his theatre last night. The first part was made up of excellent songs, sentimental and comic, and many jokes and stories, old and new. Dockstader himself had a fresh topical song, in which he told how Baby McKee might be intrusted with an office, but that such a thing could not occur in New-York without the consent of Commodore Gerry.

The reports of the freight car famine received in this city indicate that it is much more serious than any similar one for many years, but though there is great difficulty in transporting the great volume of heavy freights the delays bring solace to the railways, for they mean an enormous increase of business. However, rates are exceedingly low.

The Executive Committee of the Coney Island Jockey Club, at a meeting yesterday afternoon, decided to begin its race meeting for 1890 on Tuesday, June 17, on which day the Suburban Handicap will be run. The meeting will be continued to Wednesday, July 2, on which day ...

John Murray, twenty-four years old, who on Oct. 19 snatched a pocketbook from the hand of Miss Lizzie Daly of 187 East Seventy-firststreet while she was walking on Madison-avenue, pleaded guilty before Judge Martine, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, and was sentenced to nine years in State prison.

LIMA, Oct. 28, via Galveston.--The President of Peru recently requested Congress to grant him extraordinary powers in order that the Government might be enabled to cope more effectually in the future with revolutionary movements.

John Markham, who died Sunday at his late residence, 109 Bedford-street, was an old resident of this city. He was born in 1815 in County Clare, Ireland, and came to this country in 1832, when he went into the business of furnishing outfits to sailors and longshoremen. He soon established a business of his own at 201 West-street, and as he became successful ...

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 28, via Galveston.--Affairs in Guatemala are in a bad state. A revolution on a large scale, said to be backed by New-York parties, is imminent. The revolutionists make a pretense of counting on Mexican aid, but Government officials hare say that Mexico will not back any revolution.

CLAREMONT, N.H., Oct. 28.--Caleb Dinsmore, aged seventy-five years, committed suicide today by placing the muzzle of a gun to one of his eyes and firing the gun with a cane. He left a note, saying that he must soon die from cancer and preferred not to suffer. He had made arrangements for his funeral, even to laying out a suit of clothes in which he wanted to be buried.

If the voters of this State wish to please the Standard Oil Company they can readily do so by electing Judge ALBERT HAIGHT of Buffalo to the Court of Appeals bench. Standard Oil influence was active in securing the nomination of Judge HAIGHT at the Republican Convention in Saratoga.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 28.--The recent report that the C.C. Washburn mills have been sold is followed to-night by the announcement that the sale of the Pillsbury Mills and also of the washburn Mills is about to be consummated. For the first time in connection with these deals a price is given--as regards the Pillsbury interests. It is that the option on the Pillsbury system of mills and elevators calls for $5,200,000.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 28.--One of the most important meetings of a labor organization held in this country for some time convened in this city yesterday. Nearly 130 delegates of the International Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, representing every section of the United States, met in secret session to consider the question of a proposed federation of labor, now ...

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28.--An attempt was made early Saturday night by some unknown person, supposed to be a crank, to cause an explosion in St. Peter's Catholic Church for the purpose, it is supposed, of wrecking the church. John Doyle, the sexton, on entering the church between 6 and 7 o'clock, was nearly overcome by gas.

PORT HURON, Mich., Oct. 28.--Not less than 75,000 Michigan farmers have joined the Patrons of Husbandry since last May, and the number is increasing every week. They threaten to become the controlling power in the politics of the State, and then to spread over the entire country.

Two names were offered in nomination for Assembly from the Twenty-first Assembly District at the Republican Convention held in Morton Hall last night. W.D. Murphy proposed Richard J. Lewis, and ex-Judge Noah Davis offered William N. Grinnell. Mr. Lewis was selected by a vote of 27 to 13. The nomination was then made unanimous.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Oct. 28.--Beyond the washing away of the piers of the Cambria Iron Company's railroad bridge, no damage has yet been done by the flood. The only public bridge across the Conemaugh is in very bad condition, and it is feared it will go if the river continues to rise. A force of men are at work clearing the bridge of floating logs, , which have lodged against the piers.

The New-York County Medical Society at its annual meeting last night elected the following officers: President--Alexander S. Hunter; Vice President--J. Leonard Corning; Secretary-- Charles H. Avery; Assistant Secretary--William E. Bullard, and Treasurer--John B. Warren. The usual Board of Censors was chosen and twenty-eight delegates selected to attend the next convention of the State Medical Association.

While the Board of Estimate and Apportionment was discussing the estimates put in by the Board of Education for next year's expenses yesterday, Mayor Grant refused to allow $3,000 for the salary of Rufus G. Beardsley, who has been acting as legal adviser of the board.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 28.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day Judges Butler and McKennan set aside the verdict in favor of the city for $14,438.32, which was recently rendered against the Western Union Telegraph Company as a license fee for the use of the streets for poles and wires from 1885 to 1888 inclusive. In filing the opinion Judge Butler said:

The abuses in the conduct of affairs in Jersey City and Hudson County, which have received attention from THE TIMES during the last month, are perfectly known and appreciated by the well-informed people of that community. The entire truthfulness of the exposition is testified to by numbers of men who know whereof they speak and who are trustworthy witnesses.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 28.--Mayor Davenport slapped Congressman Tarsney full in the face this afternoon and in return very nearly received a shot from the Congressman's revolver. It was all on account of the entertainment of the Pan-American tourists, who will arrive here next Wednesday morning.

The subscriptions for the World's Fair flowed in steadily yesterday, although reports from some quarters indicated a lukewarm patriotism such as only an appeal to the pocket can disclose. The sums received at the Mayor's office, the Exchanges, and newepaper offices and reported to Secretary Wilson at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday made a total of $210,070 for the day.

The Central Liquor Dealers' Association of New-York City is making an effort to raise the price of beer to 10 cents a pint. The prevailing price for some years has been 8 cents per pint, but the retailers asserted that they were making no money by selling it at such a figure.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 28.--The first section of the new Church of St. Peter was dedicated yesterday. Bishop Starkey of Newark conducted the service, assisted by the clergymen of the parish, the Rev. Robert N. Merritt and the Rev. Wynant Vanderpool.

The substantial subscriptions made yesterday to the Washington Memorial Arch fund attest the beneficial results of the publication of the gratifying statement of the Treasurer. The fund is now in a flourishing condition. Nearly twothirds of the sum requires is now secured, and earnest and continued interest will soon crown the committee's efforts with complete success.

The ferryboats of the Pennsylvania Railroad Line running from the foot of Cortlandt-street to Jersey City were somewhat unlucky in picking their way through the passing fleets of tows and tugboats yesterday. In two instances collisions occurred.

Mr. HUGH MCCOLLOCH stands easily at the head of the men in this country who have shown ability and wisdom in dealing with financial and fiscal questions. His experience far surpasses that of any other.

Robert Burns, who lived at West New Brighton, S.I., mysteriously disappeared from his home on Sunday night, leaving his wife and a young child. Burns, accompanied by his wife, went to church on Sunday evening. Soon after the service began Burns left the church.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--The Portsmouth which was reported to have suffered from the heavy weather in the past few days, arrived at Newport. R. I., this morning. Her officers reported all well on board.

Ground on the site for Dr. Talmage's new Brooklyn Tabernacle was formally broken yesterday afternoon. A large crowd had gathered to witness the ceremonies and listen to the incidental addresses. The property is the old Marshall homestead at Greene and Clinton avenues, and both the thoroughfares named were packed with people as was the space within the fences.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 28.--George C. Coffin, representing Charles M. How, a stockholder in the Bentley-Knight Electric Railway Company of New-York City, appeared before Attorney General Tabor to-day and asked him to commence action to annul the charter of that company.

Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday handed down a decision overruling the preliminary objections of property owners to the application of the Metropolitan Elevated Railway Company for the appointment of Commissioners to condemn the easements of 400 pieces of property along the lines of the elevated roads.

New rooms of the young Men's Christian Association in the station of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, at Hoboken, N. J., will be opened this evening. Owing to the limited capacity of the quarters the rooms will be open for inspection all day, but only men will be admitted this evening.

A runaway couple who arrived Sunday on the Cunard steamship Servia were detained yesterday at Castle Garden. The case is a somewhat peculiar one, as the woman induced the man to run away with her. The man is John Dolan. He is but nineteen years of age and is very youthful in appearance.

The enrolled Republicans of the Twentythird Assembly District met at their headquarters, at Third-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty third-street, last evening some four hundred strong, and threw their arms around the County Democracy's neck to the extent of indorsing James Owens for Alderman.

The Mayoralty contest in Long Island City, now that it has narrowed down to Mayor Gleason and City Treasurer Bleckwynn, is being carried on vigorously. Bleckwynn now has all the interests opposed to Mayor Gleason united in his support, and is looked on as a sure winner. Wagers of six to one in his favor were freely offered yesterday, with few takers.

It would be difficult to recall a political canvass in this State in which so little concern was displayed for the fate of the candidates for State offices as there has been thus far in the present canvass.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--Senator Farwell's attention was called to-day to a story from Washington that President Harrison had asked Congressman Taylor of Chicago why he and his colleagues of the Senate and House did not submit a list of five or six names for each of the Chicago offices so that there would be room for the exercise of Executive choice in filling the place.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28.--Oliver Garrison, one of the oldest and most prominent citizens of St. Louis, committed suicide late this afternoon in Forest Park by shooting himself through the head. For some time past he had been suffering from kidney trouble, and during the past four years had not attempted to attend to any business. Despondency at his incurable ailment was undoubtedly the cause of his self-destruction.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct 28.--Several daring burglaries have been committed in this city within the last thirty-six hours, and the thieves at one place made a rich haul.

Ladies' day at the Lotos Club drew a brightfaced company to the club parlors yesterday afternoon. There were two attractions--a loan exhibition of paintings from American artists, left over from Saturday night, and Mr. and Mrs. Kendal.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 28.--The reports received by the Agricultural Department at Washington indicate that Connecticut crops for 1889 have exceeded the average for the entire Union except in the isolated instance of Irish potatoes. The latter are fully twenty-five points be low the average.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 28.--Dispatches received here report the arrival at San Francisco of the Whaling bark Charles W. Morgan, Capt. Layton, of this port, from the Japan Sea, with six whales, making 600 barrels of oil and 6,000 pounds of bone.
DUBLIN, Oct. 28.--The term of imprisonment imposed on Dr. Tauner, member of the House of Commons for Cork, who was convicted of offenses under the Crimes act, expired to-day and he was released.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28.--Eighteen hours were consumed in the journey of the international excursionists from Omaha to St. Louis, the train arriving here at 7:30 P.M. The 471 miles had been covered by the Pennsylvania engine that has pulled the train thus far, and it is said that it constitutes the longest run ever made in the United States by one locomotive.

There seemed every prospect of a substantial rise in the stock market when business began yesterday morning. Many stocks scored substantial advances. But there was a quick dissipation of bull hopes, and throughout the greater part of the day quotations showed a downward tendency, closing prices being generally lower than were the opening figures.

Elijah R. Kennedy of Brooklyn, a Republican of the Blaine stripe, who in the last Mayoralty campaign pronouced Col. Andrew D. Baird illiterate and ignorant, and who accepted the office of Park Commissioner under Mayor Chapin, is out for Col. Baird.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--The International Marine Conference resumed its sessions at the Wallach Building, this morning, being called to order by Rear Admiral Franklin, President of the Conference. Nearly all the delegates were in attendance.

We are taught in school to read and to write but how many of us are ever taught how to talk? And if we wished to learn, where should we seek a suitable teacher? And yet, among all the accomplishments which men and women possess, there is not one that can give so much pleasure as an ability to talk pleasantly and entertainingly.

Prof. John Mason Child, proprietor of the Beverly School, at 28 West Twentieth-street, has been missing since the 12th inst. From the circumstances of his disappearance his friends fear that he became suddenly demented and that he committed suicide.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 28.--The forces of the striking switchmen were augmented to-day by the men on the Chesapeake and Ohio and the Louisville and Nashville, who have hitherto remained at work. The Louisville and Nashville, however, anticipating trouble, brought a number of men here from Louisville several days ago.

It was announced in Boston yesterday that the Fitchburg and the Boston and Albany Road had agreed to end their rate war on Western passenger business. This agreement was laid to the good offices of Mr. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who has been in Boston.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--Among the cases heard by the United State Supreme Court to-day were the following:

In the easiest possible manner the New-York, team won a game from the Brooklyns yesterday, and now lead the latter by two for the world's championship. The Giants were in a batting mood and they hit the ball hard and often, Terry, who had won the game in which he pitched against New-York, was in the box and his presence inspired the Brooklyn enthusiasts with confidence.

Many facts of interest were last evening presented at the fifteenth anuual meeting of the United Hebrew Charities held in the lecture room of Temple Emanu-El. President Henry Rice presided and read the Executive Committee's report.

SELMA, Ala., Oct. 28.--In removing the walls of the buildings burned in the late disastrous fire this morning at 10:30 o'clock an accident occurred. Ben Taylor, a contractor, with a lot of hands was standing on a veranda attempting to push the walls of one of the buildings inward when the veranda gave way with a crash, precipitating Taylor and the laborers to the ground and covering them with debris.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 28.--Stephen Smith of Goshen is ninety-three years of age. He has lived on the farm he now occupies since he was ten years of age. For over seventy years he has voted at the same polling place, and has never missed a general election or one of any local importance. He is an inveterate smoker. His ballot from the outset has been cast for Democratic candidates.

President Cable of the Rock Island Railroad arrived in New-York last night from the West. Other Western Directors of the company are also here. Representatives of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, Chicago, Burlington and Northern, Chicago and Alton, and of the St. Paul Companies are scheduled to appear here within the next few days.

The Old Dominion steamship Wyanoke, which arrived yesterday morning from Norfolk, sighted a schooner flying signals of distress off Fenwick Island at noon on Sunday. The distressed vessel was under short sail and was bound in the same direction as the Wyanoke.

The mysterious disappearance of George W. Sillcox, a wealthy young man who lived with his family at 13 Seventh-avenue, Brooklyn, until June 6 last, way partially explained yesterday, when his wife began suit in the Supreme Court to prevent him and J.F. Tapscott, or Maximo Mora, from selling the Seventh-avenue property.

The nomination of Mrs. Emma Beckwith as equal rights candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn has been ratified. The ratification took place last evening at the corner of Bridge and Willoughby streets, in a hall which was not large enough to hold all those who were eager to see the ceremonies. It was a very small hall.

The Thirteenth Assembly District Republican Convention opened up in the small hall of the Grand Opera House last night to a good house, with the ever wicked Frederick S. Gibbs as star performer. Mr. Gibbs was supported by pretty much the same gifted company that has helped him in the past, and, as was to be expected under the circumstances, the performance moved with the ease and measured dignity of French clock-work.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 28.--The first race, it is said, that ever occurred between oyster steamers took place on the Sound this afternoon between the J. Howard Loundes, owned by Stanley H. Loundes of Five Mile River and William H. Hoyt and Sons' trim little vessel, the Albert J. Hoyt of South Norwalk.

Miss Lydia Thompson arrived yesterday on the Anchor steamship Circassia from Glasgow. On the same vessel were the Balmoral Choir, which has sung before the Queen and will give concerts in this country. Mr. Patrick is the manager and Mr. Bruce the conductor of the choir. Among the other passangers of the Circassia were the Hon. A.R. Haines, Dr. J.G. Thomas, Dr. R. Gale, the Rev. T. O' Rielly, and George St. J. Bremner.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct 28.--A remarkable trial began here to-day in the Middlesex County Court when John C. Raymond, once a New-York architect and builder, was placed on trial for arson.

BRIDGEPORT, Oct. 28.--Frederick Merrill, while under the influence of liquor on Saturday night, beat and choked his wife in a brutal manner. She was rendered unconscious, in which condition she remained until last night, when she was found and the facts made known. She was taken to the hospital, where she died this morning.

The following circular has been issued by Secretary Tracy: "In order that prompt payment of labor rolls at navy yards and stations may be secured it is essential that the monthly money requisitions be submitted to the Paymaster General as early as practicable. An estimate of funds required for the payment of the rolls of each department, showing the amounts to be required under the different appropriations for the ensuing month, ...

BOSTON, Oct. 28.--The announcement in Chicago, and reproduced elsewhere, that the International Hotel property here, owned by Lotta, had passed into the hands of Mr. J.H. Beekman, recently of Parker's, is denied. It was said that Mr. Beekman was to have a silent ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Registered 4s, $15,000, $8,000. $1,050, and $1,200 at 127. Registered 4 s, $55,000, $3,000, and $4,000 at 105 .

LONDON, Oct. 28.--The marriage of Prince Ratzfeldt to Miss Clara Huntington, daughter of Mr. Collis P. Huntington of New-York, took place to-day in the Catholic oratory at Brompton. The ceremony was performed by Bishop Emmons. The wedding was private, only relatives and a few friends of the bride and groom being present. A wedding breakfast was served at the German Embassy, after which Prince Hatzfeldt, and his bride started for Italy on their wedding tour.

The track at Linden dried out so well yesterday that the interrupted meeting of the Linden Park Blood-Horse Association will be resumed this afternoon. The card is a very good one, and, with anything like favorable weather, should attract a good crowd to enjoy the sport. The entries to the several races and the weights assigned the horses are as follows:

One of the liveliest meetings in the history of the Young Men's Democratic Club was held last night in their quarters in the Hoffman House. Oscar Yenni's resolution indorsing the Tammany ticket came up for action and was the bone of contention over which the club argued long and energetically.

Mrs. D.P. Bowers has been engaged by Manager A.M. Palmer to support Salvini during his coming tour. She will make her first appearance with the great Italian actor in Philadelphia next Monday evening, playing "Emilia" to Salvini's "Othello."

Herman O. Pollanz, a cigar packer, has been given a judgment in the City Court for $526 against George Barnstoff, a policeman. Pollauz was standing in front of the cigar factory on Second avenue where he worked, during the last car drivers' strike, and was ordered to move on by Barnstoff.

The course of free lectures for working men and women, under the direction of the Board of Education, will begin on Thursday evening at Grammar Schools 83, 216 East One Hundred and-Tenth-street 82, First-avenue and Seventieth-street: 51, 523 West Forty-fourth-street; 67, 225 West Forty-first-street; 34, IOS Broome-street; ...

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 28.--The picked life-saving crew from stations Nos. 4, 5, and 6 succeded this morning in rescuing the only surviving member of the crew of the schooner George T. Simmons of Camden, N.J., wrecked last Wednesday night near False Cape. Of the five members of the crew who lashed themselves in the rigging ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--Charles Clark, better known as "Old Charlie," once a millionaire in New-York and latterly a bartender in this city, committed suicide this morning at 173 West Lake-street. Despondency is thought to have been the cause of the deed. Clark was an American, born in New-York State.

A woman with a bad record was arraigned before Justice Hogan, in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, charged with assault. Her name is Bridget King. She is a virago of forty-six or thereabouts. Her husband, Michael King, has lived for some time at 5 Minettalane with William Ryan, who works for him.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 28.--Charles Smith, his wife, and Thomas Robinson, all of Newark, came here last week to work for John La Rue Groves, a tailor of this city. The three stopped at Mr. Groves's house. Mrs. Smith last evening wanted to send out for a pint of beer, but Mrs. Groves, being a temperence advocate, said she would not permit it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--"Boss" Mahone has abandoned his Virginia puppets long enough to pay a flying visit to the capital.
Judge Patterson, in Part I., Special Term of the Supreme Court, yesterday said:

A. Jaeckel, furrier, 11 East Nineteenth-street, near Broadway, is exhibiting to customers a very attractive assortment of fur goods, including jackets, sacques, ulsters, dolmans, cloaks, men's fur-lined cloth coats, rugs, and every other variety of goods, Mr. Jaeckel has received from the Paris Exhibition the silver ...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 28.--The Rev. J. Ward Gamble of Milltown comes out to-day as an advocate of the election of D.M. Kane, the ballot reform candidate for the Assembly, who is contesting the Third Assembly District against the Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--Mr. Edward Blunt, a well-known young lawyer, a gentleman steeplechase rider, and owner of Seymour, St. Swithin, and other race horses, was shot and seriously wounded about 4 o'clock this afternoon in the Shoomaker wine rooms by George Mantz, formerly proprietor of a notorious saloon in this city, but now a political worker in Maryland.

ATHENS, Oct. 28.--After the ceremony of kissing the bride's hand at the palace this morning, the Duke of Sparta and his wife drove through the still decorated streets, which were thronged with people. Upon returning to the bridal residence, they were received by the King, who ducted them to a balcony to acknowledge the cheers of the crowd. To-night the city is again brilliantly illuminated.

William Nicholas Hoag was nominated by acclamation in the Eleventh District Republican Assembly Convention last night to succeed Robert Ray Hamilton. Mr. Hoag is twenty-six years old and the Secretary of the Lawrenceville Cement Company, whose offices are at 115 Broadway.
Assistant District Attorney Edward Grosse sent the following letter to Henry G. Autenrieth, First Vice President of the Central Committee of the United German Democracy, yesterday:

The Initial steps were taken last right toward the formation of a State naval reserve. Circulars signed by the well-known yacht rigger, Philip B. Low, were sent to a number of gentlemen last week requesting their presence at the Second Battery Armory, Seventh-avenue, near Fifty-third-street, for the purpose of organization.

The subject of ballot reform was discussed by the Reform Club last night. The meeting was called in pursuance of a resolution adopted Oct. 28 to consider this resolution, which should become the platform, so to speak, of the organization during the present political campaign.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 28.--In the Vice Admiralty Court this afternoon Chief Justice McDonald delivered judgment in the case of the American schooner David J. Adams, seized for fishing and preparing to fish and for buying bait within the three-mile limit three years ago.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 28.--A frightful exhibition of the power of the electric current of the street railway circuit was given to-day, along the line of the Mount Auburn-street Railroad. The guard wire, which hangs above the conducting wire to protect other wires from coming in contact with the electric current, broke, and as it formed a circuit when resting on the charged ...
Judge Alfred C. Coxe of Utica is at the Albemarle Hotel. Emilio C. Varas, Chilian Minister at Washington, is at the Clarendon Hotel.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 28.--Next month New-Jersey will see a religious movement of a somewhat novel character. The Presbyterian Synod proposes to hold a series of mission meetings for the week--Nov. 3-9--with several new features. The plan is in the hands of a large central committee and a co-operative ...

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 28.--A board consisting of Naval Constructor Varney, Lieut. Commander Longnecker, and Carpenter Smith, United States Navy, are surveying the training ship NewHampshire as to the cost of fitting her for future use as a home for naval apprentices. This is the first move of the Consolidation Board, which consists of Capt. Pythian, President; Commander Bridgman.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 28.--The last Jersep Water Company, which has the six-milliondollar contract for supplying Newark with water, hae begun operations in the construction of an immense storage reservoir on the upper waters of the Pequannock River, near Oak Ridge station of the Susquehanna and Western Railroad. Here a huge dam, more than 1,000 ...

Frederick W. Diehl was nominated by the County Democracy's reconvened Senatorial Convention in the Seventh District last night in place of Samuel Gompers. Mr. Diehl was spoken of as a candidate before Gompers was selected.

What may be a case of murder was reported to Coroner Everitt at Jamaica, L.I., yesterday morning. Richmond Hill is a western suburb of the township of Jamaica, and the only hotel in the place is one over which Mrs. Armbruster presides. The place is frequented mainly by farm laborers and men employed in the factory of Lalance Grosjean, at Woodhaven, about a mile distant.
The annual meeting of the Westchester County Historical Society was held at White Plains yesterday, and after the usual routine business the following officers were elected:

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 28.--The New-Orleans Cotton Exchange statement issued to-day makes the net rail cotton movement across the Ohio, Mississippi, and Potomac Rivers to Northern American and Canadian mills for week ending Oct. 25 29,215 bales, against 50,822 last year, and the total since Sept. 1 95,858, against 148,791.

Ex-Senator Thomas C. Dunham yesterday declined the posthumous candidacy for Senator from the Eighth District confided to him by Tammany Hall. Following is the text of the letter which he personally handed to Arthur Dickinson Williams, Chairman of the Tammany Convention.

SAN JUAN DEL SUR, Oct. 29, via Galveston.-- The Nicaraguan Government is disposed to found a city, to be called America, at the Atlantic terminus of the Nicaraguan Canal. A commission of engineers has done to San Juan del Norte to survey the locality of the proposed city and set off building lots.

Judge Gildersleeve's workers are worrying over the attitude of the liquor dealers toward his candidacy. For a few days past circulars emanating, it is claimed, from County Democracy sources, have been sent to the liquor sellers calling their attention to certain utterances against their business made by the Judge while on the bench.

ALBANY, Oct. 29.--A flier for votes was sent out to-day by a sub-committee of the Republican Campaign Committee, Eugene Burlingame, William H. Haskell, and Henry E. Abell. It is in the nature of a letter to the Chairman of the Democratic County ...

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 29.--The Yale corporation at a meeting to-day established a professorship of biblical literature in the academical department. The foundation for the professorship is $50,000, given by a few men who desire their names to remain unknown. The object of the new chair of instruction is, as expressed by the donors, to impart an intelligent apprehension ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 29.--The Hon. James E. Neal, Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee, talked to-night in an encouraging manner and exultingly claimed the election of his favorite candidate for Governor. Chairman Neal says:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 29.--Passenger train No. 4 on the Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad collided last night near Glendale with a westbound freight train. The accident occurred within five miles of Council Bluffs at 10:15 o'clock. The engine and the express, baggage, and smoker were burned.

Some of the names in the City Directory grouped together present to the eye of the imagination a picturesque landscape, as, for example, the following: Field, Mead, Heath, Fenn, Boggs, Marsh, Glenn, Hill, Vale, Mount, Lake, Rivers, Brooks, Pond, Ford, Forrest. Rhoads, Lane, Bridges, Hedge, Wall, Stone. Rock, Cliff, Wood, Rush, and Brush.

Coroner Everitt of Jamaica, L.I., began last evening the inquest in the case of Leo Bolinger, who was found dead at Armbruster's Hotel, Richmond Hill, Monday morning. The evidence showed that Bolinger, who boarded at the hotel, was one of a crowd who remained late in its barroom Sunday night.
BOSTON, Oct. 29.--The following is the Union Pacific view of the Union Pacific-Northwestern alliance in answer to the question, "How does this contract differ from the old tripartite alliance?"

Reports of dangerous wrecks and pieces of wreckage drifting about in the path of vessels bound to and from this port are coming in with great frequency. Capt. Smith of the steamship City of Birmingham, which arrived yesterday from Savannah, states that on Monday, in latitute 37 5' and longitude 74 59', he passed a ...

The funeral of William Henderson, the wellknown theatrical manager, will take place tomorrow at 1 P.M. at his old home at Long Branch. The services will be conducted by the Rev. Elliot D. Tompkins, rector of St. James's Episcopal Church, and the interment will be in the family plot in the cemetery of the West Long Branch Methodist Episcopal Church. Friends should leave the train at the West Eng station.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 29, via Galveston.-- Gen. Barrundia, who, as stated in a dispatch from Guatemala received yesterday, was said to be at the head of a revolutionary party in the mountainous district bordering on the State of Chiapas, has been a resident of this city for the last two years.

The application of Charles M. How, a stockholder of the Bentley-Knight Electric Railway Company, for the annulment of that corporation's charter, which was presented before the Attorney General at Albany yesterday, is likely to bring out the facts with reference to another step in the direction of consolidating all the electric interests which are opposed to Mr. Edison.

A little thread hung on the shoulder of Broker Dan Dixon's coat when he went on the floor of the Produce Exchange after lunch yesterday. Prince Claggett, during one of the lulls, called his attention to it.

The jury in the Feeks investigation was locked up from noon until 4 o'clock yesterday in Room 21, City Hall, preparing their verdict. Their finding was as expected--weak, so far as a verdict is concerned, and necessarily so, but with such recommendations as would naturally be looked for from so solid a body of men.
The sale of race horses and thoroughbred yearlings, the property of A.J. Cassatt, Chesterbrook Farm, occurred yesterday morning at the American Horse Exchange, Broadway and Fiftieth-street.

Mr. Samuel M. Pettingill, one of the Trustees of the Metropolitan Transit Company, the corporation which some years ago was going to build an elevated railroad in Broadway, got a judgment for $25,954.29 against the corporation about two weeks ago for money advanced.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 29.--About 2 o'clock this morning the house of Thomas McCausland, at McCausland Station, on the line of the Milwaukee Road in Scott County, was entered by two burglars. Mr. McCausland heard them moving about in the room below, and came down stairs, interrupting them in their work.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 29.--Thirteen steamers cleared to-day with 47,481 bales of cotton, all foreign except 6,515 bales for New-York. There were also 109,205 bushels of corn and a million feet of lumber, with much other products, oilcake, staves, Thirty-seven vessels are still in port loading. This is the best showing in many years.

GLASGOW, Oct. 29.--The prices of iron ring warrants jumped to-day from 58s. 3d. to 60s. During the afternoon heavy realizations in behalf of Southern speculators caused Scotch warrants to fall 1s, 1 d, per ton. Boiler plates advanced 10s, and ship plates 5s. per ton. There is much excitement in Middlesborough and prices are rising there.

James T. Van Rensselaer was yesterday appointed by Attorney General Millar Assistant United States District Attorney, to succeed MacGrane Coxe, resigned. Mr. Van Rensselaer is a man of middle age, and has been for many years a lawyer of good standing in this city. He was graduated from the Columbia College Law School.

Mrs. Edna J. Dougherty, whose husband, Joseph, died a few months ago, and who was buried in Holy Cross Cemetery, Flatbush, began suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday against Bishop Loughlin and Joseph and Jane Dougherty, her husband's relatives, to gain possession of the body.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 29.--There was much testimony to-day in the case of John C. Raymond, who is accused of a long series of arsons and is now answering the last charge, the burning of the Adrian Institute at Iselin. Raymond is defended by Courtlandt Parker of Newark and Judge Woodbridge Strong and Alan Strong of this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--From time to time the old soldiers of the country are likely to hear from the men who fell with Tanner, and who have incurred the displeasure of the Administration of Mr. Harrison because they permitted themselves to be rerated and gladdened with arrears.

ALBANY, Oct. 29.--The candidates for the class in practical librarianship, which the Regents of the University, by arrangement with the Trustees, transferred from the library of Columbia College, New-York City, to the State Library last April, were to-day examined for admission.

The State Fencibles Battalion, National Guard of Pennsylvania, arrived here yesterday on a visit, and were welcomed by a battalion from the Seventh Regiment. They left Philadelphia 200 strong by special train, and arrived at the foot of Cortlandt-street at 4 o'clock, where, ...

"It is my great privilege and honor," said Mr. George B. Herzig, "to present to you a gentleman whose fame and ability are not only well known to this large and brilliant audience, but to the people of the whole country, Col. Elliott F. Shepard." [Loud applause.]

The subscriptions sent in during the past few days for the Washington Memorial Arch fund have been so substantial that the grand total is very near the fifty-seven-thousand-dollar mark, and as the popular subscriptions are again pouring in the committee are more than ...

LONDON, Oct. 29.--Mr. John Morley, speaking at Bristol to-night, referred to Mr. Chamberlain's career as a lamentable illustration of the "rake's progress" from ultra-Radicalism to ultra-Toryism. He warned the Liberals not to be drawn by Unionist catechising into framing a Constitution for Ireland, as they were under the fire of a set of men who were only pretending to be acting in good faith.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--A rumor current this afternoon that the firm of Heston Erben, wool dealers, 110 Chestnut-street, had failed for a large amount was confirmed late in the day. The firm has made an assignment for the benefit of its creditors to George W. Fiss and Samuel Lea.

One of the most remarkable judicial decisions ever made in this State was that by Judge Gil dersleeve in what is known as the "pool-selling case," entitled "The People against William Spencer." The facts taken from the records ...

Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court yesterday issued a writ of habeas corpus requiring Cornelius Oberwater to produce in court Barbara Weber, whom he is accused of having abducted. John R. Planten, the Consul General of the Netherlands, makes the complaint against Oberwater on the strength of information received from The Hague to the effect that on ...

When it was first pointed out that TANNER was unfit to retain the office of Commissioner of Pensions, because of his violations of law and his notorious and scandalous contempt for sound and careful methods of administration, there was a great outcry from the claim agents, the "rerated" favorites of the Commissioner, and many thickand-thin partisans.

In order to demonstrate the superiority of the material used in the underclothes made by the Dr. Jaeger's Sanitary Woolen System Company over certain imitations of the goods which have been put on the market, some interesting experiments were yesterday made by Dr. R.C. Rutherford, the chemist of the company, at the ...

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 29.--Travel over the through lines of the Erie Railroad was interrupted for several hours last night by a smashup between Otisville and Middletown. N.Y. A long freight train going west broke in two while on a steep down grade. The signal was given and the engineer slackened the speed of the engine.

Complaint was filed in the United States Circuit Court yesterday in a suit brought by the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad Company against the United States Trust Company to compel the trust company to countersign $136,000 of the railroad company's bonds.

An exciting game of football was played between the Sophomore and Freshman Classes of Stevens Institute, at the St. George Cricket Club's grounds, Hoboken, yesterday afternoon, and resulted in a victory for the "Sophs" by a score of 18 to 0. The game was called at 3:30 P.M., and was witnessed by about three hundred people.

William T. Morgan, a prominent citizen and Republican of Crawford County, Ark., was shot and killed Monday night by one D. Gibbs. Morgan recently served a term as Circuit Judge. He was violent and overbearing and greatly feared. Monday he met Gibbs at Alam, began abusing him, and threatened his life.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 29.--United States Senator M.S. Quay of this State, who is Chairman of the Republican National Committee, has been blackballed by the Young Men's Republican Tariff Club of this city.

PARIS, Oct. 29.--The Journal des Debats denies that Prince Bismarck suggested that a French protectorate should be established over Tunis. It says that M. Waddington, Lord Salisbury, and the late Earl of Beaconsfield considered the Tunisian question at the Berlin congress in 1878.

One more great railroad property comes into the Vanderbilt control. The Chicago and Alton --no line in all the West is more important or proportionately more valuable--is about to pass from its long-time Western ownership as the result of a deal bigger than any ...

Gilbert C.H. Stiles made an individual assignment yesterday as the liquidating partner of the late firm of Stiles Co., composed of Mr. Stiles and Leopold Gottlieb of Chicago, jobbers in woolens and tailors' trimmings, formerly at 123 and 125 West Broadway, to David E. Williams, giving two preferences to John B. Brenneiser Co. and Stiles Co., Limited, Henry H. Browne of 132 Nassaustreet being the attorney in the matter.

While the effect of Judge ANDREWS'S decision in the matter of the wires of the electric light companies is to continue the injunction which prevents interference with the wires under the resolution of the Board of Electrical Control and the order of the Mayor until the trial of the action, it cannot ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--The fact that there is a division of interest in the defense in the Cronin case, and that Senior Guardian Beggs of Camp 20 is having his case conducted independently of the others, was shown to-day.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29.--The first of the series of mass meetings in this city in favor of the secret ballot at the polls was held to-night in the Newark Academy of Music and was a successful one. There were nearly two thousand people in the audience and they cheered themselves hoarse.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the New-York State Cleveland League was held last evening at its rooms, 254 West Twentysixth-street. Representatives were present from different sections of the State. Letters and advices were received from members at Albany, Buffalo, Troy, Syracuse, Rochester, Jamaica, ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--The bond offerings accepted to-day were as follows: Four per cents. registered, $40,000, $10,000, $22,500, $11,000, $10,000, $50,000, $500, $500, and $20,000 at 127. Four and a halfs coupon, $5,200 and $1,000 at 195 .

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29.--The Directors of the Theological Seminary held their annual Fall meeting to-day in the Seminary Library. Besides the transaction of the regular business the committee on building a new dormitory was reappointed, and definite action will soon be taken.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 29.--William Wilkinson, senior member of the Birmingham firm which is manufacturing the Government postal cards for Contractor Albert Daggett, says that there is no ground for the published insinuations that Mr. Daggett may not fulfill his contract because he finds no money in it.

LONDON, Oct. 29.--Mr. Michael Davitt resumed his address before the Parnell Commission to-day. He referred to the action of the Chicago convention as disproving the assertion that the Clan-na-Gael was actively allied with the League. The authors of the articles on "Parnellism and Crime," which were printed in the London Times, he said, willfully invented and garbled quotations from American papers.

NEW-HAMPTON, Iowa, Oct. 29.--Tom Doud, who shot and killed Peter McKenna near here on Saturday, made his ante-mortem statement last night, and it was read before the Coroner's jury this morning. He said he knew from threats that had been made that the McKenna party would attempt to force a passage across his land and kill him if necessary to accomplish ...

Ensign R.P. Schwerin has been detached from the Naval War College and ordered to the training ship Jamestown as Watch and Division Officer; Ensigns Edwin M. Tillman and James C. Drake from the Coast Survey Office and ordered to the Petrel as Watch and Division Officers: Ensign Franklin from the New-Hampshire and ordered to the Petrel as Watch and Division Officer: Ensign P.W. Hourigan from the Jamestown and placed on waiting orders.

Assistant District Attorney Dawson and Arthur J. Delaney appeared in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday before Judge Andrews in relation to the alleged stealing of the papers in the divorce suit brought against Benjamin F. Olmstead by his wife. Mr. Dawson had a motion to make for the removal of the receiver of Mr. Olmstead's property, who was appointed ...

The estimates of the Police Department were taken up yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. Commissioners Voorhis, McClave, Martin, and MacLean were present. They asked for $4,824,265, the amount allowed for 1889 having been $4,484,250.94.

After a scrutiny of the political horizon in the Eighth Senatorial District last evening Mr. MAURICE J. POWER calmly announced that he saw nothing to indicate that NELSON J. WATERBURY, Jr., the candidate of COSTIGAN and the County Democracy, would withdraw.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 29.--In the Assizes Court today Gillete, who swindled a number of Winnipeg merchants with forged paper, withdrew his plea of not guilty and pleaded guilty to three charges. The Judge, in delivering sentence, said commercial men and society must be protected from American swindlers who came here to operate their ...

FISHKILL, Oct. 29.--The Health Board of this village has had a tussle with two faith curists and came out victorious. A child of William Winans was attacked with diphtheria and a physician was summoned. Under his treatment the child began to improve. Friday Dr. Watson visited the house and found a Mrs. Lockwood and her daughter of Yonkers, who claim to be ...
LONDON, Oct. 29.--The court has ordered Dion Boucicault to pay 30 monthly as alimony to his divorced wife, (Miss Agnes Robertson.)

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The brig Clara Pickens, from New-York for Savannah, was abandoned on the 25th inst. in latitude 35 40', longitude 72 25'. The Captain and crew were rescued by the schooner Anna L. Mulford, which arrived at Mantua Creek, N.J., to-day, from Charleston.

The notion that every man, and every woman too, for that matter, in the public service should give money to the party in power is a logical inference from the spoils system; it is also a complete violation of the principles of sound administration.

Much comment has been caused in Peterson, N.J., on account of the action of the Grand Jury in adjourning on Monday after noon until after the election. At the beginning of the term Judge Dixon charged the Grand Jury strongly on the subject of reported official corruption in certain departments of the City Government.

George B. Prescott, Jr., read a paper last evening at 127 East Twenty-third-street, before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, on "Some Methods of Regulating Accumulators in Electric Lighting." The production was largely technical, but had some features of general interest.

A dinner party was given at the Windsor Hotel last night by the Hon. Roswell P. Flower to Mr. Evan P. Howell of the Atlanta Constitution. The guests, besides Mr. Howell, were Thomas Rutter, J.D. Probst, Andrew Carnegie.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 29.--The Territorial Legislature of the Canadian Northwest has adopted a resolution in favor of the abolition of French as one of the official languages. This is an offset to French aggression in Eastern Canada. The resolution will be transmitted to the Dominion Parliament.

When the notification from the Board of street Opening and Improvement that the proceedings relative to the acquisition of property for sewerage purposes from One Hundred and Sixty-seventh-street to the Harlem River were discontinued was read at yesterday's meeting of the Aldermen, Mr. Carlin got up and ...

Frederick Fischer of 212 Bowery, whose arrest in Brooklyn recently led to the discovery of over $1,000 worth of stolen property in his room, was arraigned before Justice Tighe yesterday. He said his real name was Henry Lester, and that his ambition was to be an artist, but that he had to steal in order to live while pursuing his studies.

The railroad branch of the Young Men's Christian Association threw open its new reading rooms at the round house of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, at Seventysecond-street and North River, yesterday. The rooms are neat and comfortable.

Shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning Gerster's Hotel, Rockaway Beach, was discovered to be on fire, and the prompt action of the volunteer firemen alone saved it from total destruction. The fire was confined to the lower floor and the damage will not exceed $2,000.

Herman Stiefel has sent a letter to John R. Voorhis resigning as a member of the Count Democracy of the Twelfth Assembly District, and saying that he has determined to support the "Democratic ticket nominated by Tammany Hall." Thomas Gilmartin, Secretary of the County Democracy organization of the Second ...
At the polls on Tuesday next the people of this State will decide by ballot whether Judge Albert Haight of Buffalo or the Hon. Denis O'Brien of Watertown is to be Judge of the Court of Appeals.

Yesterday afternoon there was a private funeral service over the body of Judge Hooper C. Van Vorst at the house, 811 Madison-av., conducted by the Rev Henry J. Vandyke, Jr., pastor of the Brick Church, and subsequently the body was transferred to the Fifth-Avenue Presbyterian Church, where a public funeral service was held.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The National Conference of Unitarian and other Christian Churches commenced their sessions this morning in the Academy of Music. Dr. Francis H. Brown of Boston presided. The Hon. Samuel F. Miller of the United States Supreme Court, the President of the Conference, in addressing the delegates, stated that he felt it had been an ...

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 29.--A fire which threatened to destroy the mammoth packing houses of Armour Co. in Kansas City, Kan., was discovered in the fertilizer at 3 o'clock this morning. The fertilizer was the last of the buildings to the north, and was separated from the refinery works by only a narrow alley.

Suit has been begun by United States District Attorney Mitchell, on behalf of the Government, against the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company to recover $1,500 in ponalties. The complaint alleges that the West Shore Railroad, operated by the New-York Central and Hudson River, has a bridge near ...

The complication between Tammany and the Counties over the candidate for Senator in the Eighth Senatorial District was left unchanged by the Tammany Convention, which reconvened last night. On motion of Deputy Commissioner or Public Works Martin another adjournment of ...

The unfortunate Hindu Colah, who came to this country to have a good time and died here, left considerable money, which was placed, by order of the Court of Common Pleas, in the keeping of Nathaniel Jarvis, Jr., ex-Clerk of that court.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 29.--Woolsey R. Hopkins, a young lawyer of this city, was nominated for Representative in Congress from this district by the Democratic Congressional Committee, which met at Weedsport to-day. Mr. Hopkins is a son of the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Hopkins of the Faculty of the theological seminary of this city.

A letter signed by Charles Miehling was yesterday sent to Mr. Henry G. Autenrieth, First Vice President of the United German Democracy of the city of New-York, announcing the withdrawal from that organization of the United German Democracy of the Tenth Assembly District, of which Mr. Miehling is President.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The rumors that have for some time been current of an attempt on the part of an English syndicate to buy up the principal cheese factories of the great cheese-producing region of Central and Northern New-York seem to have a substantial foundation in fact.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 29.--The Board of Trustees of Rutgers College to-day conferred the degree of LL. D. on William Walter Phelps. Other degrees conferred were upon the Rev. Emillo Comba of Italy, LL. D.; W.W. Swainson of London and Christian Vanderveen of Michigan, D.D.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 29.--Dominick Fitzpatrick's saloon, at 605 Elizabeth-avenue, was gutted by fire early this morning. The flames originated in a closet and it is supposed that rate or mice gnawed and ignited a large quantity of matches stored there. Fitzpatrick, his wife, and two children were nearly suffocated in their beds and were rescued with difficulty by the firemen.
Running for office in this city nowadays is rather expensive work. The candidates on the Tammany ticket, for instance, have to stake pretty round sums on their chances of getting elected.

It appears upon more thorough investigation of the laws relating to the location and building of the proposed new Custom House and Appraiser's Stores that Secretary Windom, in selecting the Bowling Green site, has not only exceeded the authority conferred upon him by ...

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 29.--It has just leaked out that Mahone's reliance in carrying this election was to buy up weak Democratic judges of election. This sort of work was to be confined chiefly to the doubtful centres of the southwest and the great black belt districts.
Ex-Gov. James E. English of Connecticut is at the Windsor Hotel. Solomon Hirsch, United States Minister to Turkey, is at the Victoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--Notice is given by Lieut. Cottman, Secretary of the International Marine Conference, that all documents, plans, systems, and devices, or other matter coming within the consideration of the conference intended to be submitted to the Committees on Lights and Sound Signals must reach him by to-morrow (Wednesday) at 6 P.M.

CAIRO, Ill., Oct. 29.--The great steel bridge of the Illinois Central Railroad crossing the Ohio River at this point was formally tested at 9:30 this morning by sending nine large mogul locomotives coupled together across, their aggregate weight being about seven hundred tons.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--A great deal of surprise was created in political circles to-day by the announcement that the commission of John Field as Postmaster had arrived, because it was generally supposed that Postmaster Harrity, having been allowed to stay in so long, would be left undisturbed until the expiration of his four years, which would be early in December.

The Eastern creditors of Solomon Bennett, a big clothier and jobber of Peoria, Ill., who failed on Sept. 24 for $365,000, met yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Hotel. The meeting was naturally a stormy one, but, on the whole, rather more satisfactory than such events usually are.

Ransom Parker, who conducts an ice business at 380 West Eleventh-street, has icehouses on the Hudson at Castleton and Rondout, and is credited with an income of $100,000 a year, was arrested yesterday charged by Edward J. Adams, cashier of the White Star Line, with delivering the company only twenty-six tons of ...

For the benefit of those desiring to attend the Catholic Congress the Baltimore and Ohio and Jersey Central Roads will sell excursion tickets to Baltimore and return at the rate of $5.30. Tickets will be good going Nov. 7 to 12, and good returning until Nov. 16, inclusive.

MATTEAWAN, N.J., Oct. 29.--The Rev. Henry C. Bedinger, rector of St. Luke's Church of this village, at a meeting of the vestry last evening, tendered his resignation. He will remove to New-York, where he will become an assistant to the Rev. Mr. Satterlee. There has been trouble in the church for some time past, owing to the dissatisfaction expressed by some of the ...

BOSTON, Oct. 29.--Postmaster Corse, who is a Democratic hold-over, said to-day of Postmaster General Wanamaker's proposition to establish Post Offices on the various lines of steamships which ply between the ports of the United States and foreign countries:

A Custom House sale of unclaimed, abandoned, and seized goods was begun yesterday at the Barge Office. John H. Draper was the auctioneer. The articles were of a miscellaneous character. Two hundred dozen pints of champagne brought $700.

Except in Sugar Trusts there was not much chance for speculative profits in Wall-street yesterday. Rumors were abundant relative to various important interests, but nothing akin to facts of consequence was anywhere within reach. It is a waiting time in Wall-street, just as it has been for months and months past.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 29.--Five thousand miners employed in the collieries in Borinage have gone out on strike. The strike has caused much excitement in the district.
Gov Hill, who was at the Hoffman House all day yesterday, concentrated his energies and influence toward patching up the differences in the Democratic Party in this city.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29.--For some time past Truant Officer Haynes has been puzzled to know what to do with Frank, the sevenyear-old son oP Peter Lynch of 114 Broomestreet, The Rev. Father White of St. Bridget's Church notified the authorities several days ago that the boy was a truant who spends all of his days roaming the streets and all of his evenings around the theatre doors.

ALBANY, Oct. 29.--With a capital of $600,000 the firm of George Ringler Co. of New-York is incorporated. The objects are to deal in malt, ale, porter, beer, and all other fermented liquors. The Trustees are John C. Boettner, Christian Hachsmeister, William G. Ringler, Frederick Orth, and Frederick A. Ringler.

The three new Deputy Surveyors appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury on Monday will assume office on Nov. 1. They are all the stanchest of Stalwart Republicans. John W. Corning of Palmyra gives up the position of Sergeant at Arms of the State Senate to accept the new place.

BUTLER, N.J., Oct. 29.--The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company is having considerable difficulty in securing water privileges along the Pequannock River at this place. The rubber mills and paper factories demand over a million of dollars damages for the reduction of the stream that will ensue upon ...
The County Democracy are in somewhat of a muddle in the Twentieth Assembly District. In fact, yesterday seemed to be an off day for them all around.

The recent publications of the death by yellow fever of William Bruns and Joseph Fennell, passengers to this city on the steamer Hondo from Greytown, Nicaragua, have given rise to the impression that yellow fever prevails at that place, where many Americans are now engaged at work on the Nicaragua Canal.

The trial of Andrew Becker, charged with the killing of James Conway in his saloon at Tompkinsville, was continued before Judge Cullen in the Richmond County Oyer and Terminer yesterday. Becker's wife and children occupied seats within the bar, but entirely ignored the prisoner.
The Richmond County Democrats held their convention yesterday afternoon in the German Club Rooms, Richmond road, Stapleton, S.I., and nominated county officers.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Oct. 29.--The schooners Mary A. Hall, from Fernandina for New-York, and Isaac H. Tillyer, from Kennebec for Philadelphia, were in collision this morning. The Hall is sunk off here and the Tillyer is beached six miles north of Barnegat, full of water.

The Republican Club rooms at 1 Abingdonsquare last evening fairly blazed with bright lights and red, white, and blue bunting, the walls echoed campaign oratory, punctuated with enthusiasm, and waves of music, vocal and instrumental, rolled out into space all on account of, and incident to, a reception to Lispenard Stewart, candidate for Senator in the Eighth District.

Owing to the declination of Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, to stand for the Republicans in the Seventh Senatorial District, because, as he puts it, he can be of more service to his labor constituents by remaining away from Albany, the convention met again last evening in Concordia Hall, Avenue A, and indorsed by acclamation ...

Renewal contracts were signed yesterday by the terms of which Bronson Howard's "Shenandoah" will remain at Proctor's Twenty-thirdStreet Theatre until Jan. 1. A special production of the play is to be given at McVicker's Theatre, Chicago, beginning next month and continuing six weeks, by a company composed of the following artists:

Residents of One Hundred and Fifteenthstreet have been complaining that boys have of late been breaking their windows with birdshot fired from spring guns, and lately a child was badly cut in the neck by pieces of glass broken from a pane through which it was looking.

A great sale of silks is being conducted at Ehrich Brothers' new store, Sixth-avenue, Twenty-third and Twenty-second streets. Seldom since the days of A.T. Stewart has a dry goods nouse in this city made a more attractive offer than the one announced by this firm on Sunday.
