ALBANY, Oct. 29.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted: Decisions Handed Down.--Susan Provost, re- spondent, vs. The Mayor, , of New-York, appellant; Samuel D. Coykendall, respondent, vs. Abram Constable et al., impleaded, , appellants: ...

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 29.--Cornelius Keefe, one of the convicts at work on the State dam across the Owasco outlet, near the State-street bridge, succeeded in eluding the guards and escaped about 3 o'clock this afternoon. Keefe was a transfer from Sing Sing to Auburn Prison. He is a New-York man, and had twenty-nine months of a four years' sentence to serve.
Walkill Boy, a valuable trotter, with a record of 2.22 and valued at $5,000 the property of Roscoe Brothers of Syracuse, was burned to death on Monday night.

The guarantee fund for the World's Fair enjoyed a boom yesterday. Subscriptions for the day amounted to $454,478, bringing the total amount of actual subscriptions to $1,398,350. It was by far the best day since the fund started.

It was a gala night at the Amberg Theatre when Ernst Possart made his reappearance as the weak young King of France in "Die Bluthochzeit" of Albert Lindner. What with the presence of ex-President and Mrs. Cleveland, laurel garlands from Edwin Booth, Mme. Zimmerman, and other admirers of Possart, and the appearance of the many new friends this able actor ...

The first joint mass meeting of the Republicans and anti-ring Democrats in Jersey City was held in the Seventh District last evening. St. Michael's Hall was filled to the doors with as attentive an audience as is seldom seen at a political meeting. Men of both parties composed it. On the platform were the speakers of the evening and others.

ST. LOUIS, Oct 29.--The levee was visited by the Pan Americans to-day, and the guests from the South were interested. They saw the steamers and plane and method of shipment of many United States products that go Southward to the other Americas.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 29.--George Westinghouse of this city has just concluded the purchase of some valuable copper mines in Washington Camp, Arizona, the production of which will be used at the works of the Westinghouse Electric Company. An application for the charter of the Duquesne Mining and Reduction Company ...

There was a notable gathering of representative Hebrews around the big round table in Delmonico's large dining hall last night, the occasion being a complimentary dinner to Sir Julian Goldsmid, Bart., M.P., who has been a sojourner in the city for a short time.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The body of Walroth, the aeronaut, who was lost in Otsego Lake Sept. 24, was found this afternoon 20 feet from where the parachute was found and 600 from shore. The body is badly decomposed.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Oct. 29.--Three thousand citizens attended a Statehood rally at the Rhodes Grand Opera House to-night. Gov. Warren, Delegate Carey, Gen. Thomson, and the Hon. A.C. Campbell were the orators. The people are enthusiastic for the Constitution and Statehood.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 29.--The Engineers' Convention this morning elected F.B. Deitrick of Altoona, Penn., Second Grand Assistant Engineer, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Cavener of Chicago, and A.H. Butler of Pittsburg, Penn., Third Grand Assistant Engineer.

The Republican Senatorial Convention of the Ninth Senatorial District met last evening at 215 East Thirty-fourth-street and unanimously indorsed the nomination of William J. Boyhan, the County Democracy candidate for Senator.

The shade trees and telegraph poles and fences in sections of Jersey City are just now extensively decorated with election notices and the various colored hand bills and posters of the candidates for Assemblyman and Freeholder.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 29.--A lawsuit was instituted here to-day by five veteran soldiers against the old borough of Hyde Park, now in corporated as a portion of Scranton, for the recovery of $300 bounty, which each was guaranteed by the borough as an inducement to reenlist and be credited to the quota of that place during the war.

A surveying party was organized at Danville, Va., yesterday to survey the route of the Danville and East Tennessee Road from Danville to the coal fields of Southwest Virginia. Danville recently subscribed $150,000 to the road, and the work will be pushed vigorously.

PLATTSBURG. N.Y., Oct. 29.--The Clinton County Republican Convention to-day nominated Alfred Guibord of Plattsburg for member of Assembly. Mr. Guibord is President of the Merchants' National Bank. The Democratic nominee is Alexander Bertrand of Beekmantown, late United States Consul at St Johns. A hot fight is anticipated.

Tammany's Committee on Organization met yesterday afternoon, and Richard Croker had some things to say to the members. There was an attendance of three hundred or more, and Mr. Croker was cheered when he got up to make his address. He told the leaders that the "deal" between the Republicans and Counties extended to the inspectors of election and to the poll clerks.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 29.--Mr. Robert Denham died at West End this morning. With his death there is connected a story of a dog's devotion. Mr. Denham left his house yesterday morning with his dog and gun to engage in a squirrel hunt. He had not proceeded a quarter of a mile in the woods when he was stricken ...
There is at present pending in the United States Circuit Court a suit against ex-Sheriff Peter Bowe, the last action to date in a course of litigation of great interest.

BERLIN, Oct. 29.--The Reichstag to-day discussed the budget. Herr von Maltzaher, Secretary of State for the Imperial Treasury, said that the customs duties promised an increase of 40,000,000 marks. It was expected that expenditures in addition to those already announced would be required for the army.

Capt. Jordan of the Schooner Edward Stewart, which arrived yesterday from Fernandina, reports that his vessel was run into by an unknown schooner at 7 P.M. on Monday. The collision took place off Barnegat. The Stewart was displaying her side lights and observing the caution usual when approaching port.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 29.--Social and naval circles are in a state of pleasurable excitement this evening over the union in marriage of Ensign George Randolph Clark and Miss Mary A. Brown, a prominent young society lady of this city. The bans were proclaimed in the Park Presbyterian Church. The groom and the ushers, officers from the United States ship Michigan, were in full dress uniform.
New-Yorkers ought to feel proud of their baseball nine. The Giants have once more proved their supremacy in diamond field matters and again claim the distinction of being the world's champions.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday voted to abolish the hand organs and itinerant street bands. This action has been hanging fire for some time. The Musical Mutual Protective Association, District Assembly 49, the Balfe Association, and others had petitioned the Mayor for the extinction of the street bands and other itinerant musicians, and the Mayor sent the petitions to the Aldermen for their action.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29.--Democratic Assembly Nominating Conventions were held in this city to-night with the following results:

Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday rendered his decision in the electric light cases, continuing the temporary injunction restraining the city from interfering with the wires of the United States Illuminating Company pending the trial of the action for a permanent injunction.

The news that Secretary of the Navy Tracy has awarded the contract for the construction of the two new 2,000-ton cruisers to the Columbia Iron Works of Baltimore is not generally well received in naval circles. The botch made by the Columbia Iron Works people in the construction of the Petrel is still fresh in mind, and it is this impression that leads navy oficers to fear that the two 2,000-ton cruisers will be failures.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 29.--R.B.F Pierce, Trustee of the Indianapolis, Decatur and Western Road, says that his road is to go into Russell Sage's big consolidation and be made the connecting link between the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton and the Iowa Central. He says:

BOSTON, Oct. 29.--The crippling effect of the present tariff upon New-England industries is well illustrated by the recent sale of the great Norway Iron Works of South Boston to a syndicate, who purpose moving them immediately to the West. It is a sad but telling fact that these great iron works, the pride of Boston, the ...

ROCKAWAY, N.J., Oct 29.--The great dam near Rockaway, Morris County, has been declared unsafe by engineers. Considerable apprehension exists among the residents of the Rockaway Valley. The owners are endeavoring to strengthen the dam, but the residents in the vicinity demand that the water be drawn off ...
PARIS, Oct. 29.--The Gaulois says that the marriage of Prince Murat to Miss Caldwell has been postponed.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 29.--The Republicans of Union County are going to make a determined effort to wrest control of the First and Second Assembly Districts from the Democrats, and to this end have nominated their very strongest candidates, Messrs. Voorhees and Benjamin.

The inaugural meeting of the Linden Park Blood Horse Association ended yesterday with a very small attendance and six uninteresting races. The Executive Committee made a serious mistake in not postponing the races, as the track was in anything but a safe condition, ...

The military parade incident to the laying of the cornerstone of the Brooklyn Memorial Arch this afternoon promises to be very imposing. Grand Marshal Henry W. Knight will head the column, preceded by an escort of mounted police. Major B.R. Corwin will be Adjutant General and Chief of Staff and Past Department Commander Ira M. Hedges will be Assistant Adjutant General. The staff will consist of the following:

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--Mr. L.B. French, who has recently returned from Alaska, saw the wonderful and much-written-about mirage which has been named the "Silent City." It is occasionally visible in the Summer season from certain points in Glacier Bay. He describes it as follows:

BOSTON, Oct. 30.--A Joint circular has been issued by the Boston and Albany, the Fitchburg, the Boston and Maine, the New-York and New-England, and the Central Vermont Roads to the effect that on Sunday, Nov. 11, the rates of passenger fare from Boston to Western points via these lines will be restored to the tariff rates published by the Boston Passenger ...

Arnheim, the tailor, caught the World's Fair fever yesterday and subscribed $1,000 to the guarantee fund. This may be taken as a sign of prosperity. There is nothing very wonderful in Arnheim's succeses however. Any New-York merchant who conducts business on the same basis as Aruheim ought to feel in the mood to put his name to one of the World's Fair subscription blanks.

Adjt. Gen. Kelton has had prepared a table giving the results of the rifle, carbine, and revolver competition among the army teams this year. At the cavalry competition held at Bellevue, Neb., for the cavalry troops of the Departments of Dakota, the Platte, and the Columbia, J.M. O'Conner, Corporal, Company A. Eighth Cavalry, won the gold medal, with both the carbine and revolver, scoring 478 out ...

BALTIMORE, Och 30.--Mr. John K. Cowen has replied to Senator Arthur P. Gorman. It is in the shape of a letter, nearly four columns long. It is rather more dignified than the lovers of Sensation expected, but that fact is looked upon as adding to its effectiveness as a campaign document.

DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 30.--The people of Danville, Pittsylvania, Halifax, and Charlotte are justly indignant at the recent actions of Deputy United States Marshals, who are evidently acting under Mahone's orders. Several days ago three gentlemen who were judges of election in Charlotte County last Fall were arrested on a trumped-up charge that they had intimidated a United States Supervisor.

A suit for $150,000 has been brought in the Supreme Court by Edmund Green against William Henry McWood. The plaintiff claims that amount as damages under a Mexican railroad contract. The complaint asserts that the Mexican Government some years ago granted to Sebastian Comacho the right to build several railroads and agreed to pay him $7,000 for ...

Wall-street in many a day has heard no news worthy to be compared with that which, announced in THE TIMES yesterday, made plain the aggressive and progressive spirit of the Vanderbilts in their practical, absorption of the Chicago and Alton system.

The commission merchants in dairy products in this city do not seem to be alarmed over the reports published that an English syndicate has been buying up the cheese factories in the western part of the State, for they do not believe that any syndicate can possibly control the cheese trade in this country.

A fashionable out-of-town wedding was that of Miss Sarah Lavinia Barney, daughter of Gen. C.H. Barney, Treasurer of the Sawyer-Mann Electric Company, and Charles H. Carter of the firm of St. John, Kirkham Co., at Christ Church, Hackensack, N. J., last evening.
CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 30. via Galveston,-- The e is a great scarcity of meat in Yucatan, owing to the exportation of beef cattle from the State.

ALBANY, Oct. 30.--There has been received in the State Library a yellow-stained map which was engraved by Dufosse in 1605. The lettering on it is entirely in Spanish. The territory embraced is what is now part of New-England, New-York, and south to land including Virginia.

ATHENS, Oct. 30.--A State ball was given at the palace last night, which was attended by 3,000 guests. The royal and imperial personages present marched in procession through the ballrooms. Emperor William, escorting the Queen of Greece, led the march. They were followed by the King of Greece and the Empress of Germany, the Czarwitch, and the ...

The tangled condition of affairs in the Eighth Senatorial District was not improved yesterday by the latest developments. Gov. Hill remained over, as THE TIMES said yesterday, to straighten the matter out, but met with no success at all.

The Police Captains in the various precincts have been engaged since the close of the registry in making a canvass of the names of registered voters to ascertain where colonization has been attempted and whether there are fraudulent names entered on the lists.

Finding that it was impossible to get their track in condition by next week, the Linden Park Blood Horse Association at a meeting of its Executive Committee last night, very sensibly decided to postpone racing on its ...

A citizens' meeting, having for its object the indorsement of Mayor Chapin and the rest of the Brooklyn Democratic candidates, was held last night in the Art Association Rooms in Montague-street. A large number of people attended it, and prominent in the crowd were ...

Detective Sergeant Hickey returned last night from Chicago, having in custody Newton Percy Randolph Hatch, the defaulting cashier of the Baltimore and Ohio Express Company, who absconded in December, 1887, with $7,000 belonging to the company. Hatch fled to Canada, where he opened a billiard saloon. He was found in Canada and unsuccessful attempts were made to extradite him.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 30.--One of the large boilers of the Belle Aire blast furnace at Belle Aire, Ohio, exploded this morning with terrible force, cracking two other boilers in the main battery and wrecking the boiler rooms. The south end of the nail factory was entirely demolished. The damage to the mill and adjoining property is $200,000. No one was injured.

Commissioner Raum went to the Interior Department this afternoon and had a long conference with Secretary Noble relative to the cases of the rerated Pension Office employes. At the close of the conference Gen. Raum said that the subject of the rerated employes' cases was discussed.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30.--Ensign W. Hannum Grubb Bullard, United States Navy, was married here to-day to Miss Ellen Beirne Saunders, daughter of John Selden Saunders. The ushers were Lieut. W.B. Caperton, Assistant Engineer H.P. Norton, Ensigns George F. Cooper and George Breed, and Naval Cadet Turner Saunders, all of the Naval Academy Annapolis.

The British steamship Biela, Capt. Hammond, from Rio Janeiro, towed into port Tuesday the abandoned schooner Mary A. Hall, 362 tons, which had been in a collision off Point Pleasant with the schooner Isaac H. Tillyer, 568 tons. The latter vessel had drifted ashore after the collision and her crew had been rescued by the crew of the Barnegat Life-Saving ...

LONDON, Oct. 30.--Mr. Michael Davitt continued his speech before the Parnell Commission to-day. He argued that the Government is now adopting some of the leading proposals originally made by the Land League. For instance, the League proposed to buy out the landlords in Ireland on a twenty years' valuation of their property.

Prof. John Mason Child, who disappeared from his home, 28 West Twentieth-street, on Oct. 12, is still missing, the police having failed to discover any trustworthy clue to his whereabouts. His brother, Thomas A. Child, went to Police Headquarters yesterday with a gentleman who said that he had seen Prof. Child last Friday.

There was held last night at the Athenaeum, in Atlantic-avenue, in Brooklyn, what was called a "Lecture Symposium of Ballot Reform." The meeting was under the auspices of the Brooklyn Single-Tax Club. The announcement of the topic to be discussed drew a large audience. It was stated that the speakers would be from all the parties.

George Koch, a young married man, who with his wife kept a small cake bakery at 160 Riverstreet, Paterson, N.J., has been in the habit of buying bread for his store from Jacob Miller, who has a bakery at River and Straight streets. For some time Miller has missed goods from his shop, and a few days ago began to suspect Koch.

Mrs. Nora Hogan of 3 Bethune-street is the worthy mother of Peter R. Hogan, a boy of fifteen years. Yesterday Mrs. Hogan went to the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street police station and asked that the youthful Peter be arrested, as he had run away from home and taken refuge with a family named Tiernan, living in the neighborhood.

The defection from the ranks of the United German Democracy, owing to its indorsement of the Tammany ticket, is increasing. Two meetings of seceders were held last night in the Fourth and Fourteenth Assembly Districts. The one in the Fourteenth was held at 266 East Tenth-street and was presided over by Leo Sonnenberg, and that in the Fourth was held at 68 Henry-street and ...

The accounts of the Conemaugh Valley Relief Fund Committee of this city have been closed. Subscriptions through the committee amounted to $516,937 69. This represents scarcely more than half of the contributions for the flood sufferers by the people of this city. It takes no account of clothing and other supplies, or of money sent otherwise than through the committee.

The funeral of William Farrant, at St. Peter's Church, Jresey City, yesterday morning, was disturbed disgracefully by an attempt on the part of union back drivers to enforce a boycott. When the mourners arrived at the house they were notified by a union driver named Downer that, inasmuch as the undertaker had engaged a number of coaches from Clarence Edwards, a ...

The fund to build the Washington Memorial Arch in Washington-square is steadily swelling. Treasurer William R. Stewart acknowledges the following additional subscriptiond received yesterday: Paul Dana and F.O. French, $100 each; Alfred Young, $20; through the Commercial advertiser, 18 subscribers, $1 each; total, $239. Previously acknowledged, $56,771 70. Grand total, $57,009 70.

The actors of the Madison-Square Theatre began their winter term last evening, presenting very successfully two new plays that are likely to hold the stage for a long time. The principal comedians were welcomed warmly by a large ...

In the Third Assembly--commonly called the Hourglass--District the Republicans held Assembly and Aldermanic conventions last night. Notwithstanding the district is overwhelmingly Democratic there was a strong minority of ardent partisans who wanted to make straightout party nominations. This had been done before many a time, only to demonstrate the inability of the party to do anything but suffer.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30.--The second day's session of the national conference of Unitarian and other Christian churches was this morning opened with devotional exercises, conducted by the Rev. William Garrett of Rochester, N.Y.

PARIS, Oct. 30.--The Figaro says that the marriage which had been arranged between Prince Murat and Miss Gwendoline Caldwell has been abandoned. Prinoe Murat, the paper says, left Paris yesterday and Miss Caldwell will embark for New-York Saturday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 30.--Gen. J.W. Keifer to-day, in conversation with Judge Smith, at the Court House, over the situation said that "the result promises to be close," but in a tone which plainly said "Foraker's name is Dennis."
In addition to the nominations for State Senators, Assemblymen, and Aldermen, reported in yesterday's TIMES, the following have been made to date:

Manager McGunnigle of the Brooklyns will sport a handsome gold watch and chain and a diamond-studded locket. It is the gift of the players of his team. When the manager made his appearance at the clubhouse yesterday...

The appropriation of $10,000 for the salary of Judge William F. Pitshke of the City Court was stricken out of the list at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on motion of Mayor Grant.

MONTREAL, Oct. 30.--Molson's bank stock dropped three points this afternoon, owing to a report that the firm was in difficulties. The head of the house was seen this evening, and emphatically contradicted the report that his firm was in trouble. The liabilities were said to amount to half a million.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 30.--The famous Frazee Lee contested will case, which has dragged along for two weeks in the Union County Court, before Judge Van Syckel and a struck jury, terminated at noon to-day. At 4:30 o'clock the jury, after being out five hours, came into court with a verdict for the plaintiffs for the miser's real estate, estimated, to be worth $100,000.

There was humor galore and plenty of silk hats and buttonhole bouquets at the ex-Wicked Gibbs's Aldermanic Convention in the Thirteenth District, which was held in the Grand Opera House Hall last night. The general effect was that of a first night, although it was in fact a second performance.
Yesterday the staid business circles of Philadelphia were agitated by the announcement that the firm of HESTON ERBEN, dealers in wool, had become insolvent and made an assignment for the ...

The Mercantile Exchange has issued a statement giving the receipts and exports of butter for five years and showing the yearly, weekly, and daily consumption in this city. The amount exported during the past year has been larger than that of any of the five years. The receipts for the year ending May 1, 1885, were 1,616,534 packages, and the exports amounted ...

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 30.--Charles S. Hill, a New-York business man, and Miss Minnie F. Borden, daughter of Freeholder Richard Borden of Little Silver, were married at 2 o'clock this afternoon at the bride's home. It was the bride's wish that the wedding be private, and therefore only the immediate relatives of the couple were present.

The steamship Colorado of the Mallory Line, which left for Galveston on Saturday, returned yesterday with her ruddar gone. She was assisted into port by the City of San Antonio of the same line. The officers of the Colorado say that on Sunday, when off Cape Lookout, the vessel was caught in a severe storm from southsoutheast to east, in which she labored violently.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 30.--Miss Mamie Hughes, the seventeen-year-old daughter of Superintendent R.W. Hughes of the First Baptist Sunday School, fled from her home last night, and her parents have been anxiously searching for her all day.

C.H. Risk, a Bridgeport (Conn.) physician, was found by the police of the Church-street station in an unconscious condition and suffering from an overdose of morphine. He was removed to the Chambers-Street Hospital, where the usual antidotes were administered, and at a late hour last night Dr. Proctor of the hospital said be would recover. Dr. Risk refuses to say why he took the deadly drug.

Marie Halton, who has heretofore sung the role of Claudine in "The Drum Major," will no longer be seen and heard at the Casino. Yesterday morning she sailed for Europe on the City of Paris, without giving her manager any ...

Big milk dealers in this city, commenting on the action of the Executive Committee of the Milk Producers' Union taken recently at Middletown, say that producers make little money, for two reasons. In the first place, freights are high. Sometimes it costs as much to send a can of milk a given distance as the fare of a passenger would be.

The New-Jersey Jockey Club is nothing if it is not progressive. Yesterday its track near Elizabeth, which a week ago was decidedly incomplete, was as perfect for racing as could be expected under weather conditions. It was deep to be sure, but it was a race track; to people who had been following the horses over the bogs at Linden, it was comparatively, a perfect ...

The third number of the North American Review issued by Lloyd Bryce, the new editor, has for its leading feature a discussion of divorce by Cardinal Gibbons, Bishop Potter, and Col. Ingersoll, with a general introduction containing statistics of interest by the Rev. S.W. Dike, who has made a special study of the subject.
TROY, N.Y., Oct 30.--The Democrats of the Second Assembly District of Rensselaer County this afternoon at Lansin-burg nominated J.T. Dennin.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 30.--The laying of the last rail of the Orange County Railroad, the new piece of road which connects the northern terminus of the Lehigh and Hudson River Railroad at Greycourt with the Poushkeepsie Bridge Railroad system at Campbell Hall is an event of more than ordinary importance in railroad construction.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 30.--Word was received here to-day that a large number of foreign laborers employed in the construction of the Raritan River Railroad were rioting near South River, and Sheriff Fick with a party of deputies left for the scene of the riot. For some time the men have had trouble with A.B. ...

The Railroad Department of the Young Men's Christian Association at Hoboken, N.J., threw open their new rooms in the recently-finished station of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad on Tuesday evening last. The rooms are on the second floor, and are lighted by the incandescent light and heated by steam.

The ordination of the Rev. John Brittan Clark occurred last night at the Church of the Pilgrims, on Henry-street, Brooklyn. The pastor of the church, the Rev. R.S. Storrs, D.D., officiated at the ceremony, offering the ordination prayer.

William A. Boyd. who has been nominated by the County Democracy and indorsed by Tammany Hall as member of Assembly for the Twenty-first Assembly District, was born in this city, graduated from Columbia College in the Class of '61, studied law in the office of Judge George Shea, late of ...

Yesterday's subscriptions to the guarantee fund for the World's Fair amounted to less than half the amount pledged Monday, but the grand total climbed to $1,600,152. The impression seems to have got abroad that the books were open for cash instead of promises. Several enthusiasts, acting on this idea, had their money returned to them.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 30.--Edward R. Adams, President of the Central Railroad Company, owns a handsome country seat at Rumson known as "Rohallion." A few days ago Mr. Adams's gardener transferred the tropical plants about the grounds to the greenhouses.

Interest continues in the troubles of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad Company, although little was done by any of the factions yesterday. What is known as the Olcott committee held a meeting and elected Joel F. Freeman, Treasurer of the Standard Oil Company, to take the place on the committee of President Richard King of the Bank of Commerce, resigned.

GUAYAQUIL, Oct. 30. via Galveston.--A new Cabinet has been formed as follows: Carlos R. Tobar, Minister of the Interior and of Foreign Affairs; Francisco Campo, Minister of Finance; Elias Lazo, Minister of Public Instruction and of Justice; Gen. Julio Saenz, Minister of War.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--"Not dead, but sleeping," is the motto of the great Salt Trust, which went up on the tail of a kite not long ago. Wellington R. Bunt, the prime mover of the defunct trust is at the Tremont, and is going to New-York to see about a reorganization of the bid combination.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--There was a little speculative squall on the Board of Trade to-day. At noon, when the traders were slipping in twos or thees for luncheon, all was calm. An hour later there was not a man on 'Change but had business enough to tax both nerves and wits to save himself from losses.

Twenty women, clad in garments of various degrees of fashionable finery, sat in Recorder Smyth's court room yesterday and chewed gum vigorously as they watched the trial of David Harfeld, the Richmond pawnbroker, for bigamy.

The American Oriental Society held its semiannual meeting in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, yesterday. There were present at the afternoon meeting and at the reception, which was held in Prof. Drisler's home, 48 West Forty-sixth-street, in the evening, Prof. Haupt...

The reports that Mr. John Kelly of the Eighth Ward, who is universally known as "Smiling John Kelly," is prostrated by pneumonia are exaggerated. Mr. Kelly is only troubled with an attack of neuralgi, and will be about both in political and racing circles as usual in a day or two.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 30.--The Pioneer Press to-night celebrated its fortieth anniversary by moving into its new building, which has been nearly a year and a half in construction. It is in the style of the modern French Renaissance, treated with all the simplicity consistent with good taste. The foundations rest upon pilings which have been driven through the blue clay to a substratum of rock boulders.

The first music ride of the season at Durland's Riding Academy was given last evening. The seating capacity of the galleries was sorely taxed by the numbers of patrons of the institution and their friends, and many were obliged to turn away from the doors.

ALBANY, Oct. 30.--Ithaca has been selected as a home for Psi Chapter, the Psi Chapter House Association having been incorporated to purchase and maintain a house and lot for such society in that place, to be used by the members thereof who may from time to time be students at Cornell University or others who may hereafter visit Ithaca.

The Young Men's Christian Associations within the First District of New-York State, comprising the countries of New-York, Westchester, Rockland, Kings, Queens, Suffolk, and Richmond, twenty-eight associations in all, will hold their annual convention at Peekskill, beginning Friday evening, Nov. 1, at 7:30 o'clock, and continuing through Saturday and Sunday. All the sessions are open to the public.

Yale and Stevens Institute will begin a football game at the Berkeley Oval this afternoon at 3 o'clock. A train will leave the Grand Central Station over the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad at 2:10 P.M., and another at 2:55, both of which will stop at Morris Dock, only a few hundred yards from the Oval.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 30.--Considerable interest was expressed to-day in certain circles at Yale College over the report of an important find of a prehistoric workshop on Marblehead Rock, on the northeast coast of Massachusetts. The rock is of volcanic formation, precipitous, and about four acres in extent.

While Willy Loeb, a young oil broker, was busy trying to fill some orders in the oil ring of the Consolidated Exchange shortly after noon yesterday, Maurice Mendham, another broker, was devoting a few moments to pleasure. It took the form of playfully thumping those close to him in the ribs, and in other general skylarking.
David A. Wells of Norwich, Conn., is at the Park-Avenue Hotel. Congressman Robert R. Hitt of Illinois is at the Hotel Brunswick.

DETROIT, Oct. 30.--Mention has been already made in THE TIMES of the purchase of three entire blocks of land in the heart of the city to be devoted to the purposes of a union station by the Canadian Pacific, Wabash. Flint and Pere Marquette, and, perhaps, other railroads.
The County Democrats have not had the good sense to correct the blunders made in the Eighth Senatorial District, nor the courage to punish the men who perpetrated them.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30.--Yale downed the University of Pennsylvania at football to-day, after a rough battle, by a score of 20 to 10, or by 5 touchdowns to 1 goal and a touchdown. The score was much closer than was expected, and the home team gave the New-Haven eleven a plucky fight.

In the selection of candidates for Register, the work of the Citizens' Convention seems to have been performed with a due conformity to the proprieties that, notwithstanding the respectability and intelligence of Tammany's candidate, were given no consideration in his ...

ST. PAUL, Oct. 30.--President Hill of the Manitoba to-day returned from a trip over that road. When asked about the rumored consolidation of the Burlington and Northern with the Manitoba. Mr. Hill said: "The Manitoba will not consolidate with the Burlington and ...

ALBANY, Oct. 30.--A delegation from the Holland Society and many friends received the body of Judge Van Vorst, President of the society in New-York, when it arrived at the Union Station from that city this afternoon. The Rev E.A. H. Rudd conducted the interment service at the Rural Cemetery.

The electric light companies are at work steadily putting up new wires in the place of old. President Jackson of the United States Company, in conversation with a TIMES reporter yesterday, reiterated and emphasized his statement of the day before that no currents ...

The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, with his wife and daughter, started upon his pilgrimage to the Holy Land yesterday morning on the Inman steamship City of Paris. The noted preacher appeared to be in the best of spirits when he boarded the steamer shortly before 9 o'clock. Upon the cabin table he found an immense floral design built to represent a church, and ...

WASHINGTON, Oct 30.--To-day's bond offerings accepted were as follows: Registered 4s, $15,000 and $4,500, at 127. Registered 4 s, $4,600, $45,000, $5,000, and $90,000, at 105 . Four and a halfs coupon, $2,000, at 105 .

A collision occurred on Tuesday morning about eight miles off the Delaware Lightship between the Old Dominion steamship Cleopatra and the excursion steamer Crystal Wave. Both vessels were lost, but the crews were rescued by the Old Dominion steamship Kanawha, which landed them at this port yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 30--The following nominations for Assembly were made to-night in Essex County:

Daniel J. Moore, a member of Tammany's Committee on Organization from the Fourteenth Assembly District, wrote a letter to Commissioner Gilroy yesterday resigning as a member of the committee, and giving as his reason that he intends to vote the Citizens' ticket. Mr. Moore is an ex-Assistant Appraiser, and was at one time Chairman of the Tammany organization in his district.

Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday reserved his decision on a motion made on behalf of Mrs. Maurice B. Flynn for the appointment of a receiver of the electric railroad property in Richmond, Va., which, she claims, belongs to her as the executor of her husband.

ALBANY, Oct. 30.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following causes were argued: Minerva J. Beaver, as executrix, , respondent, vs. Charles C. Beaver and another, administrators, , appellants--Argued by A.T. Clearwater for appellants, F.L. Westbrook for respondent. Ella M. Haynes, appellant, vs. Catharine M. Sherman et al., respondents.--Argued by Abel E. Blackmar for appellant, S.P. Nash for respondents.

The suit of Margaret S. McGuirck, a dressmaker, against Joseph S. Britton, proprietor of the Vendome Turkish Baths, for $2,000 damages, was tried yesterday in Part II, of the Court of Common Pleas before Judge Bookstaver and a jury. The plaintiff claimed that while bathing in the establishment a year ago a ...

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 30.--The board which is surveying the New-Hampshire has found the keelson quite rotten. This runs from the stem to away aft of the mainmast. The bilge stringers, amidships, are also quite rotten. Though the survey is not yet finished, it will undoubtedly result in the ship being condemned.

HAVERHILL, Mass., Oct. 30.--Miss Harriet Jeannette Day of this city and John Kinley Tener, the well-known pitcher of the Chicago baseball team, were marries this evening at the Summer-Street Universalist Church by the Rev. J.C. Snow. A reception followed at the residence of the bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Tener left for Boston on their wedding tour, and will make their future home in Pittsburg.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--J. Alexander Harris, the head of the Harris Fruit-Canning Company at Milford, Del., arrived in this city yesterday morning, accompanied by a young lady, and registered at a hotel.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct 30.--The regular Fall meeting of the Trustees of Cornell University was held this afternoon, and there was a very full attendance on account of the ceremony of laying the cornerstone of the new library this morning.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30.--The Catholic hierarchy centenary celebration, for which preparations have been making for several months, under the general direction of Cardinal Gibbons, will be one of the most brilliant and interesting ...

Charles L. Sicardi, Assistant Manager in the Eastern District of Brooklyn of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, in accepting the Democratic nomination to the Assembly from the Ninth Assembly District, pledges himself to support ballot reform, reduction of State taxes by retrenchment in public expenditure, and the building of a tunnel or another bridge from New York to Brooklyn.

The business of "Roger La Honte" at Niblo's has improved so steadily this week that Manager Gilmore has decided to continue the play until next Wednesday, postponing the appearance of Mr. Terriss and Miss Millward in ...

A strange and pitiful scene was witnessed by a score of visitors at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth-avenue yesterday at noon. An elderly woman, wearing widow's weeds, advanced down the centre aisle carrying in one hand a large oil portrait and in the other a porcelain miniature.

The New-York Scottish Society gave a reception last night in St. Andrew's Hall, in the Grand Opera House, to the Balmoral Choir, which arrived on Monday in the Circassia from Glasgow. The hall was prettily decorated with flags and about two hundred gentlemen and ladies were present.

BERGEN POINT, Oct. 30.--A few minutes after last midnight a pale-faced man rushed into Police Headquarters and reported that he had just seen a ghost flitting about the meadow adjoining Constable Hook. He was quite frightened, and talked somewhat incoherently, but was so earnest in his protestations that when one of ...

Tammany Hall is said to have assessed its candidates for Register, Judge of the Court of Common Pleas, and Judge of the Court of General Sessions $15,000 each; its candidates for Judge of the City Court...

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 30.--The only society wedding of the present season came late and found a large number of the cottagers with their Summer homes closed and themselves in their Winter houses. This wedding took place to-day and was a great social event despite the ...

MATTHEW TOWN, Island of Inagua, Oct. 15.-- The American steamship Caroline Miller, Capt. T.C. Ryder, is lying at anchor off this port in a badly disabled condition. She left New-York on Sept. 24 last, bound for St. Marc and other Haytian ports, but on Sept. 29, when about two hundred miles north of the island of San Salvador, she broke her crank shaft.

In the matter of the application of the Metropolitan Elevated Railway Company for the appointment of a commission to condemn the easements of sundry pieces of property along the line of the road, testimony was taken yesterday before Stenographer Adams in Part II.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--A burglar secured an entrance to the residence of George M. High, 66 Bellevue-place, Monday night, and seeing his image in a large plate-glass mirror became so badly frightened that he drew his revolver. The man in the mirror did likewise, and in a moment the pair were blazing away at each other with a precision that was hard on the mirror.

The building trades unions of this city are carrying on a war against Morton Chesley, contractors, of Boston, who are also doing business in this city, and who have contracts for work at Columbia College, the Museum of Natural History, the Wilkes Building in Wall-street, and on houses in Manhattan-square and other places.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 30.--Five thousand Delawareans assembled at Dover to-day to do honor to the memory of Caesar Rodney, patroon, soldier, Governor, and member of the Continental Congress, whose bones reposed in an ...

The Rev. Dr. Maynard, Fellow of the Royal Historical Society of Great Britain, gave the first of a course of ten Wednesday afternoon lectures on "Sacred Art and Mediaeval Architecture" at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. A very large and fashionable audience attended and wandered with the lecturer for two hours among the northern and midland cathedrals of England without losing their appreciation or interest.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct 30.--Shortly after ex-President Cleveland took unto himself a wife there was a little settlement in Delaware County. It had no Post Office, and James P. Mornen and many other Democrats, having been caught in the tide of admiration for the President's wife, asked the Postmaster General to christen the town Folsom in honor of the first lady of the land.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 30.--The strikers in the Mons district now number 8,000. Delegates sent here by the strikers waited upon M. de Bruyn, Minister of Industry, to-day, and urged him to support the men's demands. The colliers in the central and Charleroi coal fields are joining the strikers.

ALBANY, Oct 30.--Edward Murphy, who caused the Garside men of Cohoes to kick out of the harness over the nomination of Norton Chase for Senator, has succeeded in settling everything satisfactorily with those men and smoothing the matter over so that the Garside men will support Mr. Chase solidly.

To-day is the second and last day for registration in Jersey City preparatory to voting next Tuesday. The election boards in the various voting precincts are required to sit as Boards of Registry from 7 o'clock this morning until 8 o'clock this evening.

Brooklyn yesterday honored the memory of her soldiers and sailors with an imposing public display, both civic and military. On Prospect Park Plaza, overlooking New-York, the bay and harbor, and the confines of Jersey beyond, there is to be erected what is known as the memorial arch, a structure which, when completed, will rank second only to the famous Arc de Triomphe in Paris.

A large number of people assembled in St. Mark's Church, at Stuyvesant-street and Second-avenue, yesterday morning to pay their last token of respect to the memory of Hamilton Cole. The University Club was largely represented, as were the other clubs of which the dead lawyer was a member. The solemn service of the Episcopal Church was conducted by the Rev. Richard Cobden.

The complications of this high-tension-wire, overhead-insulation, subway-construction, and Board-of-Electrical-Control muddle which was temporarily covered over, not cleared up, by Judge Andrews's decision announced on Tuesday, are calculated to make the head of a lay-man dizzy.

The Board of Medical Officers convened by the Secretary of the Navy last August is still in session. It has been unable to obtain a single than from the examinations given at the Naval Hospital in Brooklyn.

Simon Baruch, the alleged Austrian embezzler, who reached this country on the 8th of last August, and who has been in hot water ever since, had a hearing before Master in Chancery Cassidy yesterday afternoon in Lawyer Loewy's office in the Evening Post Building.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--The leading feature in the Board of Trade markets to-day was a sharp break in prices just at the close for Provisions. The gross earnings of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company for the month of September were $2,495,224, an increase over those for the corresponding month last year of $20,080, and the net earnings $1,152,578, an increase of $164,130. BERLIN, Oct. 30.--In response to a letter from Mayor Grant of New-York, requesting his assistance to further the interests of the proposed World's Fair in New-York in 1892, Mr. William Walter Phelps, the American Minister, has written a reply, in which he states that he will gladly do all he can to interest the Government and people of Germany in the project.

The matinee audience which assembled at Daly's yesterday afternoon to witness the performance of "The Great Unknown" was one of the old-time Wednesday gatherings at this house and emphasized the fact that Mr. Daly had again scored a success in a new production.

Mrs. Sarah S. Deey applied yesterday to Judge Andrews for an order of reference to inquire into the existence of an alleged agreement between her father, Samuel R. Percy, and her mother, Mrs. Jane M. Percy, who died in 1881. Mrs. Percy bequeathed all of her property to Mrs. Deey, and before her death conveyed some real estate to the latter.

The jury in the case of Andrew Becker, on trial at Richmond, S.I., for the murder of James Conway, came into court yesterday morning, after having been locked up all night, with a verdict of murder in the second degree. Becker was overcome when he heard the foreman's words, and came very near fainting.

HARTFORD, Oct. 30.--The total amount of bonds outstanding against the city of Hartford, which will mature within the next eight years, is $2,175,000. Included in this amount is the issue of half a million bonds, maturing Jan. 1, ...

The candidates on the Citizens' ticket were formally notified of their nomination at the Westminister Hotel yesterday afternoon. They were waited on at 5 o'clock by sub-committees from the Notification Committees appointed at the County Democracy, Republican, and Citizens' Conventions.

Ex-Mayor W.R. Grace cabled at the NewAmsterdam Club last night, and ex-Mayor Edward Cooper arrived a few minutes later. CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--At the opening of the court in the Cronin trial this morning State's Attorney Longenecker asked for an attachment for Edward Spellman of Peoria, Ill., the district officer of the Clan-na-Gael.

Patrolmen Edward Walsh of the Fifth Precinct, who on the morning of Oct. 20 while in pursuit of two suspicious characters fired his revolver and shot a young longshoreman named John Coleman, was on trial before Commissioner McClave yesterday. Coleman is still in the Chambers-Street Hospital, and is not yet out of danger.

In the Insolvency Court at Auburn, Me., yesterday a petition of heavy creditors of the insolvent Denison Paper Manufacturing Company of Mechanic Falls has filed, asking that the claim of Morey Co. against the insolvent corporation for $134,815 be disallowed. The petitioners allege that the firm is not entitled to prove its debts and that there had been no investigation or hearing in the case. The hearing is fixed for Dec. 5.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--The American Missionary Society resumed its sessions this morning. Secretary A.F. Beard of New York read a paper entitled "The Missionary View of the Southern Situation."

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--The Inter-State Commerce Railway Association is practically dead. The Rock Island, the Burlington, and the St. Paul Roads take the ground that the agreement has been violated by the traffic arrangement of the Union Pacific and the Northwestern, and that they will consider the agreement annulled.

It has been learned from a very reliable source that the Yale football team will be strengthened by Terry, the famous half-back, and Bull, the full-back, both of whom are playing with the Crescent team of Brooklyn, and also by Corbin, who will take the position of centre ruslier, now held by Ferris.

The Aldermen have passed an ordinance which, curiously enough, appears to come within their competence and jurisdiction. If it is signed by the Mayor, it will banish the street band and eke the hand organ.

ALBANY, Oct. 30.--Narrow-minded Gov. Hill is getting somewhat frightened over the turn political affairs have taken. He has become aware that he cannot turn the independent Democratic voters of this State with the icicle hand.

A meeting of the Baseball Committee of the Amateur Athletic Union, made up of A.G. Mills, New-York Athletic Club; A.C. Stevens, New-Jersey Athletic Club, and F.W. Janssen, Staten Island Athletic Club, was held at Mr. Mills's office in the Potter Building on Monday afternoon.

The Gleason Democratic candidate for Assembly in the Second District of Queens County, S. O. Jennings of Hempstead, has withdrawn. All the candidates nominated for county offices by the Gleason wing of the Democracy have now decline.

The Legislative Reform Party has issued a circular to its own candidates for the Legislature and those of other parties in districts where it has made no nominations. When John Brougham died, so long ago that he is fondly remembered by only the veterans of the theatrical profession, he left what property he possessed to his friend Annie Deland. This property was composed of plays. Brougham's stepdaughter, Phyllis Hodges, disputed his will.

ALBANY, Oct. 31.--It does not took as if the Democrats of the Second District will nominate my candidate for Assembly. The convention adjourned for the second time to-day, to meet at the call of the Chairman.

NEW-BRUNAWICK, N.J., Oct. 31.--The State to-day occupied nearly all the session in the trial of John C. Raymond, charged with arson, in offering testimony to corroborate that of John Leeper, the informer. William Jeffries, a Rahway hackman, testified that on the afternoon before the night of the fire he had driven Raymond from Rahway to the house at Iselin, arriving there at 4 o'clock, as Leeper had testi fied.

Yale's football eleven slipped into town yesterday, after having fought its hard battle against the University of Pennsylvania the day before, winning a victory of only 20 points to 10 for Pennsylvania, while the latter had been defeated by princeton by a score of 4 to 72.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31.--To-day's bond offerings were as follows: Registered fours, $5,000, $10,000, $75,000, and $25,000, at 127. Registered four and a halfs, $2,500, at 105 . Four per cents registered, $100,000, $5,000 and $2,000, at 127; four per cents coupon, $1,000, at 127; four and a halfs registered, $15,000 and $1,000, at l05 . All the offers were accepted.
LONDON, Oct. 31.--The action for libel brought by Mrs. John W. Mackay against the Manchester Examiner came up for a hearing in the Court of Queen's Bench to-day.

Ballot reform was advocated strenuously last night by several prominent speakers before a fine audience in the Tabernacle, at York and Henderson streets, Jersey City. The meeting was called by the Hudson County Ballot Reform Association, which has been actively agitating the matter for some months.
There was a very interesting and significant meeting held in Brooklyn on Wednesday to advance the cause of ballot reform.

Messrs. John Ortlieb and Thomas McArdie of the New-Jersey Yacht Club have bought from George C. Everett the cabin catboat Henry Gray and will have her taken from the Brooklyn Yacht Club's anchorage to that of the New-Jersey's. The boat is 26 feet long on the water line, 11 feet beam, and 3 feet draught. She was built in 1884.

The United States steam sloop Galena grounded on the Romer Shoal while proceeding up the lower bay at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, but floated off an hour and a half before high tide and came up to the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The Galena left Baltimore on Wednesday morning.

The County Democracy had its ratification meeting in the large hall of Cooper Union last night, and the Democratic State and Citizens' local ticket got a warm and hearty indorsement. The hall was crowded soon after 8 o' clock.

Tammany Hall had a ratification meeting last night at the Wigwam, in Fourteenth-street, but it was not of the rousing kind. Not more than two thousand persons were present, and they failed to display the amount of enthusiasm generally aroused in that place on similar occasions.

LONDON, Oct. 31.--The Right Rev. John Virtue, Roman Catholic Bishop of Portsmouth, England, is a passenger on the steamship Saale, which sailed from Southampton for New-York this evening.

The Republicans and anti-ring Democrats of Hoboken held a well-attended meeting in odd Fellows' Hall last evening, to ratify the fusion county and district nominations. Previous to the meeting there was distributed through the hall a reprint of a TIMES article, indorsed as follows:
By order of the court the estate of the late Benjamin C. Whitmore, the wealthy real estate dealer, was yesterday disposed of at auction on the Real Estate Exchange. Peter Meyer was the auctioneer.

BOSTON, Oct. 31.--Judge Devens of the Supreme Court made a decree this forenoon in a case which involves taking of property valued at about $600,000 out of this Common wealth and into the State of New-Jersey.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Oct. 31.--If the two great Democratic meetings which were held in this city this afternoon and to-night are indications of the spirit of the party throughout the State, then indeed has the Hon. James E. Campbell, the Democratic candidate for Governor, much reason for saying: "My prospects grow brighter each hour.

The approaching consolidation of the old First Presbyterian Church people of Jersey City with the Bergen Presbyterian Church has been a fruitful topic of discussion in Presbyterian circles in that city.

Charles A. Stadler, the Tammany nominee for Senator in the Ninth District, was a member of the Committee on Commerce and Navigation of the Senate of 1888-9. As a member of such committee he vigorously and successfully op posed a bill for the construction of a bridge ...

BOSTON, Oct. 31.--A horse-car blockade, due to a very unusual cause, had a very unusual ending to-day. A truck bearing a load of granite for the new Ames Building stood on Courtstreet between the inclosure and the car track.

The Brooklyn Mayoralty fight is becoming hotter as it draws to a close, but the work is being done by only one side. Mayor Chapin is as busy as a bee, and during the last week has addressed meetings in every ward in the city.

Two hundred gentlemen, chief among whom were the Marshals and Aides of the industrial parade of May 1 last, assembled in the gallery dining hall of the Cafe Savarin yesterday afternoon for the purpose of extending a reception to Major Gen. Daniel Butterfield, the Grand Marshal of that parade. The speechmaking was brief and to the point.

Public attention has again been called to the so-called New-York Juvenile Guardian Society by a printed advertisement from the Rev. David F. Robertson, the "Pooh-Bah" of the society, warning the public against giving money to G.P. Edwards, an alleged collector.
It is to be regretted that the experiment of appointing women to be members of the Board of Education has not been beyond dispute successful.

NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 31.--The board considering the subject of the consolidation of three naval stations here, of which Capt. Pythian was the President, left last night to assemble at Washington at an early date.
Several thousand Brooklyn laboring men, under the auspices of the Central Labor Union, held a mass meeting at the Clermont-avenue Rink last night to indorse the local and State Democratic tickets.

It was mid-week in the country. There were half a dozen girls whose brothers and sweethearts were all toiling in the city and could not get to the watering place till Saturday. There was not a male human in sight, and hadn't been for two days. They were all sitting gloomily on the veranda of the hotel.

Brooklyn Republicans filled the Academy of Music in Montague-street last night to celebrate the glories of their party and of Senator Frank Hiscock. The band was in the midst of a familiar selection from "The Mascot" as the Syracuse statesman walked down the stage arm in arm with ex-District Attorney A.W. Tenney.

Many spectators were attracted to the Eden Musee last night by the Viennese girl fencers and the Hungarian dancing girls from BudaPesth. A prize of a gold watch was awarded to Miss Mathilde Jagemann, a handsome braceset to Miss R. Neruda for their excellence in fencing. The dancing girls' part of the programme was very attractive, too, and was greatly enjoyed by the spectators.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31.--The official statement of the receipts of live stock for the month ending to-day will show a handsome increase for the totals over October of last year. There is a gain of 365,000 head. There was but slight change to-day in any feature of the Cattle market.

Charles McElvaine, the convicted murderer of Christian W. Luca, was received at Sing Sing Prison very quietly on Wednesday night, being taken there by Sheriff Rhinehart and Warden Brymer of the Raymond-street Jail in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31.--Major Gen. George Crook, commanding the Division of the Missouri, has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of War. The subject of desertions is given prominent attention. He says:

There is bitter opposition to the reappointment of Commissioners Grace H. Dodge and Mary Nash Agnew as members of the Board of Education among many of the women Principals and teachers in the schools.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 31.--"Unless miracles should suddenly become the fashion the jig is up with J. Benson Foraker," is the rather unexpectedly frank admission which comes from a very prominent Ohio Republican, a man who has contributed liberally to the Republican campaign fund and has the very best of opportunities for inside information concerning the political situation here.

The list of candidates for Senate and Assembly in the city districts is now made up, with little probability of change. The County Democrats and Republicans are virtually united against Tammany in the Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, and Ninth Senate Districts, but the candidates are all Democrats.
Long Island City is in the throes of a political canvass which has never been equaled in general interest and intensity even in that town of factional fights and scrimmages.
The Rev. William D. Perry resigned the pastorate of the North Reformed Church, on Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, after having occupied the pulpit for four years.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 31.--"Butch" Miller, the New-York thief, and his confederates, John Jennings and Frank Miller, alias Schmidt, today confessed that they had robbed the houses of Susan Mulford and Mrs. Mary J. Ross of this city. They were remanded for sentence, which will be pronounced by Judge McCormick on Saturday.

William C. Tenner, who claims to be the Count de Vermont of France, one of the most expert forgers in the business, will spend five years in State prison. Recently he has been in hard luck and compelled to stoop to vulgar, petty forgeries and swindles upon small tradesmen.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 31.--Adjt. Gen. Roberts received a telegram to-day notifying him of a riot at Axiell, Marshall County. The telegram was from the Mayor of the city and asked that a detachment of militia be sent at once to quell the disturbance.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 31.--To-day Assistant State's Attorney Baker and Lawyer Howell went out to Stony Mountain to have another interview with Convict Gillette. It is learned that Gillette's statements were of the greatest importance.

Concerning the proposed reorganization of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company the Olcott committee continues to print its card instructing holders of securities to deposit securities with the Central Trust Company.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31.--Judge McConnell's court, in which the Cronin trial is in progress, was called to order nearly half an hour later than usual this morning. Patrick McGarry, who occupied the chair at the time of the adjournment last night, was still a witness.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 31.--There seems to be no end to litigation in the matter of the wills of the two Vassars, John Guy and Matthew junior.
